texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to page four, I will just give you a brief update on Japan, and the impact of the natural  catastrophe in Japan on the Continental business. We have six locations in Japan, five of them in  the South, one Monbetsu in the very north, none of them directly in the area where the tsunami and  the earthquake was hitting worst. Total sales of Continental is approximately €680 million, we have  950 employees. Overall, our exposure directly in Japan is very limited. We have, though, effects  from our supply side. Most critical parts are electronic and electromechanic components. And you  know we are as an automotive supplier, the biggest one who is using those components in its  products and systems. 146 of our suppliers were impacted by the earthquake; 26 of those suppliers  are severely impacted. And their products make – are in about 1,400 of our products and systems  going to our customers. So this is an impact.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So it’s not coming up so much, it’s not so volatile. And then on the other hand side, this is our  division, with the lowest sales share in NAFTA and in Asia, and of course, this is one factor to get  somewhat lower gross margins. And of course again, all divisions’ profits from being part of these  megatrend in the auto business concentration of Conti safety, digitalization, information, and the  emission reduction together with affordable cars. We are strong in those segments and that has to  grow [ph] average (16:52) 20%, which we have shown again.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Page 15, is giving some more details on the cost burden out of the raw material price increases.  And if you go on the left chart, you can see the price increase, which started basically in the end of  2009, beginning of 2010. We saw the peak in March, and then with the earthquake hitting Japan,  we had a brief relief, prices were going down, but now we are up to a high level again, which seems  to be sustainable. So on average first four months year-to-date in 2011 we see $5.31 per kilogram  in one of our major qualities, which we are buying and this is comparing to only $3.45 on the  average of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The average rubber price here of $5.50 per kilogram, might be at the upper end, but on the other  hand, we have saved more than €700 million so, more than €700 million will probably be a little bit  less more than we have stated or have thought about, when we talked about this first time.

So, we really don't have a problem with that  number being negative. So, overall, the reduction in Industrial Chemicals' overall impact on the group number,  1.1% on a constant currency basis.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: What I want to bring to life with you today is sustainability. And you shine a sustainability lens on the group, and  it's very powerful. A lot of our growth is coming from that sustainability megatrend, and we mustn't lose sight of  that.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So, the megatrends, I won't spend too much time, but you've heard it – you've heard me talk about Beauty &  Ageing, and Health & Wellbeing. People want to look good, feel good. They want to take medication where they  feel they need to, and they'll do that on a regular basis. That's increasing. But added to that is living a balanced  life with the planet that we've got. It chimes really well with our crop business, food consumption doubling, the  land isn't. Everybody wants more bang for their buck with the chemicals and the ingredients that they use, big  powerful trend for the group.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And if I look at the Performance Technologies business, and this energy revolution in this circular economy using  waste streams in the business, and for your own factories, but also for your customer's factories, really important.  And this unprecedented technology change is creating a lot of opportunity, particularly in Performance  Technologies with lots of niches coming. And Croda's philosophy is, we're here to create markets, not destroying  markets. So we see a number of these trends as a source of new innovation opportunities for the group, really  important.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And if you look at how it's driving the group, the top left, we've had 10 years of sustainability reporting. And for  investors and analysts alike, start – have a look at the reports and really interesting projects in there that's driving  some significant growth for Croda. And in the appendix in the pack, there is a slide that describes a strong  financial performance for the group over the last 10 years, but also the strong sustainability performance as well.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So we're decoupling our financial performance from doing the right things, energy down, landfill down, water  usage down, significantly big numbers, but our profit up significantly, 5.5 time increase in profit over that period.  So, we're doing the right things and we think that's important.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And the stats don't lie. Consumer trends are accelerating. So this is a stat for Beauty Care. You just look in 2007,  those products on the market with what I'd call a sustainability claim, hardly any, 2017, a ten-fold increase in that.  And the more important stat is over about 11,000 products are on the market now. These are finished products  that have got a sustainability claim. That's 11,000 opportunities for the group to launch products into those  formulations. That's big opportunities.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And for a number of you the United Nations sustainable development goals are probably well-known. For others,  maybe not, but again we see this as a great source of new market opportunity for the group. So this is a  framework from the Paris Accord, 200 countries together government's businesses, opinion farmers, effectively is  to try and reduce climate change. Behind that is about 167 objectives. If you really want to look at them, you can.  But the important point for Croda is, it's not a theoretical exercise. We've mapped some of these objectives on to  our business, and we can see with government change in policy that we're starting to open up new markets for  the group.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And through that last 10 years of reporting, we've taken a leadership position in sustainability. Now, we are an  industry leader, and we're very recognized for that. We're proud of that. We're really delighted with that.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And that strong track record is starting to come through in the numbers as well. So, we see it as a powerful  growth driver. But I think with the appendix, that's classic CSR, is we would say, Customer Sustainability  Reporting. That takes you to one step and we should be proud of that, we are. But really the exciting bit is the  new markets that are coming, and how do we take advantage of that. I don't want to try and bring that to life in the  sectors for you.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So, in Personal Care, there's lots of stats around this, but that's a big number, 65% and effectively just over one  and two products now have got a sustainability tagged to them in marketing, environmental or social positioning.  And for Croda, that's excellent, because a lot of our ingredients chime with them. The sustainability development  goals that really sort of look strong against our business are 12 and 9.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So, the responsible consumption and production, that's all about every day now, our customers want safer  ingredients, ingredients free from pollutants, preservatives, phosphates, sulfates, and, and, and. And if you look at  the innovation, people want sustainable innovation. How can we reduce our carbon burden, but how can we also  reduce our customers' carbon burden, and we can have a much bigger impact on our customers carbon burden  or carbon reduction than we can on our own. And we think that's some great opportunities.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: But just – I won't go through all the examples, ethical sourcing is a big area for all of our customers at the  moment. So, we led the industry through responsible palm oil, and as you know, we've moved the industry to  sourcing palm oil in a responsible way. Sales growth in the last two years is 60% for the group in responsible  palm oil derivatives. We've led that. We've captured the growth.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And you might be surprised, but we now have skin creams on the market with antipollution actives. So when  you're walking around big cities, you're putting cream on your face to protect you from the pollution exhaust fumes  and the like and Sederma they've got antipollution actives. So, if you're walking around London you know where  we are.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: But these are markets that weren't there two years ago. These are markets that are starting to be created as a  consequence of the government policy, consumer interest and customer innovations and that's really important.  And you'll never get anywhere in sustainability without good solid innovation and Croda's got a great track record.  So you combine innovation and sustainability and you capture growth and we think we're just on the cusp of  significant growth because this powerful megatrend is unstoppable and it's creating opportunities all the time. And  it's not just in Personal Care. I look in Life Sciences and 60% increase in agricultural productivity needed in the  next 30 years about – to the point around food production and the lack of land around that.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: We shouldn't be surprised that the fastest growing business in Croda in the last 10 years has been our Crop Care  business. And the reason we bought Incotec is because of that trend. This is an unstoppable trend and every day,  people want better delivery systems, more intelligent delivery systems, so it's chiming to that. The life on land and  the good health and well-being, they probably speak for themselves. But big pressure now to reduce – to improve  the quality of land, restore the land, stop the land being eroded any further and how do you get better soil fertility  and the like. And one of our examples are drift reduction. We're world leaders in the drift reduction market. It  wasn't there three years ago. Legislation in America forced it, imposed it. So, it's the penal reforms for farmers  spraying outside their boundaries, big fines. So, drift reduction is helping the environment.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: And I think on the other point, the point around the sustainability development goal number 3, health and well- being, high purity excipients is the fastest-growing technology in the group and has been for probably five years.  Why? Why do people want it? Well, it takes out trace impurities; it takes out heavy metals like no other material  can. So in topical creams or in cancer drugs, they want the purest of the pure. They need that. Customers want  that and they formulate with that. So that market is developing on the back of, we would say, powerful  sustainability trends.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So we're encouraged with the Life Sciences performance around that. I think in Performance Technologies too,  it's all about greenhouse gas reduction – greenhouse gas emissions, the whole sustainable development goal,  philosophy is driven by greenhouse gas emissions, really, but big numbers, greater than 80% needed. What's that  doing? It's driving clean energy, green energy, box number 7 for sustainable development goal and purity of  water, less water pollution. And how do we stop the plastic getting into the water. Great opportunity. So examples  there are reduced emissions. We've got lubricity additives that improve biodegradability of the formulation, reduce  the carbon dioxide emissions, new markets and water purity. We got dispersants that improve the quality of the  water.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: These are growing markets for Croda and it's all on the back of legislation and investment by companies and by  government too. So sustainability is not just about personal care for the group. It's about all three businesses, and  that's why we see – we're encouraged again with the results starting to come through. A lot of the growth is  coming from these trends. We don't expect these trends to reduce. We expect them to accelerate over the next  few years [indiscernible] (00:31:33). And again, it's all about innovation, delivering innovation against this and  making sure that we can meet the unmet needs as they come along rather than a year or two afterwards.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So we're in a very strong position to capitalize on that going forward. And back to the high-purity excipients, we're  doubling capacity in North America because of this big trend for reducing trace impurities in your products. So  we're in a good position, and we're investing heavily around this sustainability trend which is important. And we  shouldn't forget our technology-led acquisitions. This is the central focus in the group. It's driving a lot of passion  and interest and excitement from our commercial teams, and this is where we want to go, and we want a lot more  of these. But I don't need to spend any time on them because you know them all. But a lot of them are based on  sustainability: plant stem cells, marine biotechnology in Nautilus; the next-generation sustainable surfactants,  disruptive surfactants for Enza and crop and so on.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Croda International Plc
texts.text: So, we are investing heavily around sustainability. And we – a lot of companies talk about sustainability as a  parallel universe because I think sometimes they think they have to. We're embedding that in the organization  because it is driving a lot of the growth. And that's really important. So, in conclusion then, priorities remain  unchanged. It might come across boring for you, but the three priorities remain the most important priorities for  the group. We apologize for being boring, but we deliver around the boringness. Delivered consistent top and  bottom-line growth have started to come through now. We screen well for mid-single digit sales growth now. We  expect that to continue. The innovation continues to increase and, yeah, we're going to accelerate and capture of  new sustainable technologies. I'm just giving you some examples of how we're starting to do that in the pack.

texts.speaker: Stephen Edwards Foots
texts.profession: Group CEO, Director & President-Croda Europe, Croda International Plc

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And fuel card business continued its – over many years, since we've acquired that, it has moved forward in every  year since we bought it. And it again strengthened its market share and had a good performance. It's a smaller  part of the business but we're very pleases with that.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then the other feature of the energy business in the first half was, there had been a lot of focus on this off-grid  market study that was being carried out by the OFT and particularly in the back of lots of publicity around the  heating businesses generally in the early part of this calendar year. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking at the outlook, and I mean we're saying – we're entering our seasonally much more significant second  half. And there is an important assumption here that we need to remember, that we said – clearly, we had a very  cold winter overall. Despite the fact that February and March were mild, overall that sort of end of November,  December period was exceptionally cold as everybody remembers. And we said last year when we announced the  results in May that we believed that we had been the beneficiaries of that very cold weather over a normal winter  to the extent of about €17 million.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, we have to make some assumption clearly about the weather, and we've assumed that we're going to have a  normal winter, a winter more like we would have had three years ago. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Environmental; I suppose story of environmental in the first half has been the integration of two acquisitions,  both in the Midlands in the UK, there was an excellent performance in Oakwood Fuels, which is a waste oil and  other hazardous waste and management business which – business is quite synergistic to – our existing business  in the Midlands in the UK is really – has historically been a non-hazardous business, and this acquisition has been  complementary. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The market remains challenging and no particular change – our results in the year were almost exactly in line with  the prior year. And we anticipate a very strong increase in constant currency operating profit for the full year in  environmental and are pleased that we've got a little bit more scale into that business, which is something that  we've been trying to do for a while.  Our food and beverage business, as I've said earlier, performed well, driven primarily by what we call our  Indulgence Foods business. Our Robert Roberts coffee brand are – the Goodall's and YR brands that were  acquired last year and integrated into the business and we have wine distribution business there. And in a tough  market, those businesses all performed very well.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Just talking then about the outlook for the year to 31 March – and, again, you probably had a chance to read this  morning, we're clearly operating in an environment where the economic background is challenging and perhaps  has become increasingly uncertain over the last number of months, particularly for all that's been going on in  Europe and the implications that that has for markets generally. The outlook to 31 March 2012 is based against  that background and it's also based on the assumption that I referred to earlier that the overall weather pattern for  the second half will be that of a normal winter.

texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc

texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc

texts.speaker: Donal Murphy
texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc
texts.text: Moving on to Technology, again, a very strong performance in the first half of the year, principally driven by  acquisitions. Operating profit up 24.9% on a constant currency basis. texts.speaker: Donal Murphy
texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc
texts.text: Touching on development, again, as I said earlier, it's been a really active period for development for us over the  last six months. texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc

texts.speaker: Donal Murphy
texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc
texts.text: And again, one of the things, if you go back to how DCC has built its oil business here in Britain, we bought a  business back in 2001. texts.profession: Executive Director and Managing Director, DCC Energy, DCC Plc

texts.text: Moving on to Retail & Oil, again a very strong performance in the year. Operating profit of 17.6%. Pleasingly, as  heard, that growth was organic growth within the Retail & Oil business. texts.speaker: Fergal O’Dwyer
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Financial Officer, DCC Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Donal. First thing you'll notice about our results is that we're not calling out any constant currency  numbers. And the main impact sort of impact on translation of our numbers comes from the euro-sterling  exchange rates. And it was broadly unchanged at [ph] 113 (00:15:36) for both years, so we can save ourselves  the trouble of having to call it as a constant currency number along with a reported number. texts.speaker: Fergal O’Dwyer
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Financial Officer, DCC Plc
texts.text: In the year just ended, we're really, really pleased with the overall free cash flow development of the group, up  nearly a third on the previous year and a free cash flow conversion of around 94%. We have cash inflow of nearly  £38 million on the working capital line, driven in the main by a reduction in the working capital of some of the  businesses that we bought last year and in the current year, particularly within the Technology space. Our CapEx  is roughly £60-something million ahead of our depreciation. As we continue to invest in the organic growth of our  businesses, particularly within the LPG division. We have the initial development of our Avonmouth storage  facility. We've got oil-to-gas conversions that require CapEx.

texts.speaker: Donal Murphy
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Executive, DCC Plc
texts.text: So maybe taking you through a couple of the highlights and going back to the strategies that we outlined for each  of our division in Marseille back in September. I think we've clear kind of demonstration of that strategy in action.  So in the LPG division, we bought the Retail West business. We took it over on the 1st of April just gone. Buying  that business was [indiscernible] (00:23:19) 0.6% share of the highly fragmented U.S. LPG market. It was by a  platform that we could start to consolidate further on. We've been busy building relationships, working those  relationships as we typically do to find acquisition opportunities. So we're very pleased to be announcing Pacific  Coast Energy today. That's a business operating in the northwest of the U.S.; it's in Washington and Oregon. It  has six facilities. It's supplying product into both residential customers and into commercial customers and it is  very synergistic with our existing business. We have three states where we have very strong positions: In Indiana,  in Illinois and in Kansas, and we have a modest or more modest presence in seven other states before we  announced this acquisition. So, part of the strategy within the U.S. is to build out into new markets, into new  regions, and then obviously infill acquisitions in the markets that we're already in or within the states that we're  already in. So it's a £30 million acquisition, so it's material enough in terms of a first-step within building and  consolidating that U.S. market and just to remind people like there's 4,000 players within the market. It's very  fragmented. There's a small number of larger players and there's lots and lots and lots of smaller players, so this  plays very much into DCC's sweet spot of acquiring, integrating, extracting synergies out of energy businesses,  so very pleased with that acquisition.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: So, I will as usual start by taking you through the income statement for the quarter. We recorded operating  revenues of NOK 248 million in the quarter on production of 59,800 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Petroleum  revenues account for NOK 247 million. That's down about 9% from the previous quarter on lower production and  lower realized oil prices. We realized an oil price of $47 per barrel in the quarter and we had other revenues  amounting to $1 million mainly related to our commodity hedges.

texts.speaker: Alexander Lorentzen Krane
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Production costs amount to $32 million. This equals $5.8 per barrel of oil equivalent. In this figure, we have  included shipping and handling costs of $6 million and we have production costs for the legacy assets of around  $3 million. This leads Alvheim production costs at $23 million or just over $4 per barrel. This includes costs  associated with the 13-day turnaround that we had in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Alexander Lorentzen Krane
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Exploration expenses amounted to $31 million this quarter. This reflects dry haul costs of $9 million mainly  Rovarkula, acquisition of seismic data of $5 million, area fees of $4 million, and other exploration expenses of $13  million, which includes evaluation costs and costs associated with the latest APA round.

texts.speaker: Alexander Lorentzen Krane
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Total production was 117,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day during the first nine months. We expect to see a  higher production in the fourth quarter as first oil from both Ivar Aasen and Viper-Kobra is scheduled to  commence. Full year guidance is thus 118,000 to 120,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: In the third quarter, we produced about 113,000 barrels of oil equivalents per day. The production was impacted  by plant shutdown off at Alvheim with 13 days, and Askja with 27 days. And has been, previously communicated,  the production booked in the P&L representing the Norske assets only, was just below 60,000 barrels of oil  equivalents per day.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The [ph] oil (22:39) was sold at an average of $47 per barrel in the quarter, and the combination of production  from AkerBP and legacy Det norske into Aker BP for the first nine months, averaged 117,000 barrels of oil  equivalents per day.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The Viper-Kobra wells were completed in [ph] June (23:27). And the subsea campaign tying the wells back to the  Alvheim FPSO is about to be completed. The start-up crew will be mobilized this week, and we expect first oil  from these wells in November.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The Transocean Arctic drilling rig, which was contracted earlier this year is expected to commence drilling at the  Alvheim area in December this year. The drilling campaign will start with two wells at the Volund field, one single  lateral and one trilateral are planned. In addition, there are plans for two Boa wells at the Alvheim field, and we  expect these to be approved and licensed by year-end.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Then moving on to Ivar Aasen, the third quarter has been extremely busy, also for the Ivar Aasen team. And most  importantly, the project remains on plan and on budget for first oil in December 2016. The drilling campaign was  concluded in early July, with five producers and three waters injectors currently in the ground. The Ivar Aasen  team has thus completed twice the number of wells originally planned in the pre-drilling campaign. And when  Maersk Interceptor is back in the field later this year, the rig will be utilized as an accommodation unit until the  drilling campaign continues expected in the first half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The Ivar Aasen team has worked together with the contractor, Aibel, as one team and has done a tremendous job  to finalize the hook-up and commissioning scope to secure first oil in December. The exact date of production  commencement will be decided shortly and depend on a number of factors, amongst others, the weather, during  November and December this year.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Then, moving on to Johan Sverdrup, the project is moving forward according to schedule. Platform construction is  ongoing and progressing well, and the pre-drilling campaign is currently ahead of schedule.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Further, as earlier communicated, debottlenecking studies have concluded with an increased production capacity  at Phase 1 of about 440,000 barrels of oil equivalents per day and 660,000 barrels of oil equivalents per day in  the full-field development.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: At the same time, Statoil, as the operator on Johan Sverdrup has recently released new CapEx estimates  amounting to some NOK 99 billion for Phase 1, bringing the breakeven price to below $25 per barrel. The  operator has also released updated CapEx estimates for full-field development in the range of NOK 140 billion to  NOK 170 billion. This will contribute to the full-field breakeven price below $30 per barrel. And Aker BP still  believes that there is potential for further cost reductions in the various supply markets going forward.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The topside of the [ph] 2/4 G rise platform (29:55) located at the Ekofisk area was successfully removed at the  end of July. And this platform was a part of the original export route from Valhall and was closed down in 1998.  Work is currently ongoing to cold-stack, the Valhall Quarter Platform, the living quarter, the original living quarter  of Valhall. And this is expected to be completed in November.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Now, looking forward, the Valhall drilling campaign, well we commenced in the first quarter next year after a  drilling break at the field. The program, initial program is a 7-well program, which will include implementation of a  new well design at Valhall, and new technology including managed pressure drilling, and is expected to  significantly reduce the well costs vis-à-vis previous performance and drilling campaigns. The teams are also  working to mature new possible project in the Valhall area, and Aker BP is continuing to believe in significant  upside in this area.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Moving on to Ula. The primary focus on Ula for the time being is to sustain operational efficiency, which was 75%  in the quarter negatively impacted by delayed restoration of WAG, water alternating gas injector. At Tambar,  which is to the south of Ula, south part of Ula complex, team is working now to conclude on drilling decisions for  infill targets in the first half of next year. And this decision in the first half of next year. And also to conclude on  whether or not the Tambar artificial lift program will be decided on into early 2017.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The Ula project, previously named Butch will be tied back to Ula and have a positive impact on Ula. And the  partners of Ula is working towards PDO delivery later this year. When Ula comes on stream, Ula will supplied with  an increased gas volume to be used for water alternating gas injection which will result in increased oil recovery  and increased oil rate.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: The Snadd field has had test production during 2016. And we are currently in dialog with the authorities with the  aim to extend the Snadd test production permit to 2017. The extension is being linked to production of the Snadd  field development project, and assurance of no harm to the reservoir. The teams are working with the Snadd  project with the aim to achieve a concept selection early in 2017, and possibly deliver our PDO as earlier as  second half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: When it comes to exploration, we've had an extremely active year in AkerBP this year and an ambitious drilling  program for 2016 is coming towards an end. The Askja/Krafla drilling campaign was concluded in July with  discoveries at Slemmestadand Haraldsplass amongst others, and have concluded with proven resources in the  area of a gross volume of 60 million barrels of oil equivalents.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: In August, Aker BP announced an oil discovery at Langfjellet, more into details on Langfjellet at the next slide.  The last exploration well this year will be Filicudi in the Barents Sea, where the well would test a prospective trend  analog to Johan Castberg trend, and if successful open up for more opportunities in this area.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: An important addition to this work, and this project is the discovery at Langfjellet. The Langfjellet well accounted a  gross oil column of 109 meters in the [ph] West Flank (35:55) group and preliminary volume estimates of the  discovery are in the range of 24 million to 74 million barrels of oil equivalents.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Maersk Interceptor is currently drilling a third sidetrack at Langfjellet to get more data for better appraisal and  knowledge of the area. The Langfjellet discovery adds additional resources to the roughly 116 million to 117  million barrels of oil equivalents currently in place in the Norway area prior to the Langfjellet discover. And  following the completion of this sidetrack, Maersk Interceptor will return to Ivar Aasen as previously  communicated.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: We expect this field to hold by a gross volume of about 43 million of barrels of oil equivalent. The partners are  targeting an investment decision before the end of the year and as mentioned the gas volumes for order will  contribute positively to increase production and increased recovery at Ula. The transaction is still subject to  normal regulatory approval.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Det norske oljeselskap ASA
texts.text: Now, in addition to this very important work that are taking a lot of management attention. A quick summary and  outlook will be as follows: Ivar Aasen is continuing the track on towards first oil in December. Viper-Kobra will  commence production in November, and we expect to start drilling in the Alvheim area in December, again.

texts.speaker: Alexander Lorentzen Krane
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Karl. Good morning. In the fourth quarter income statement, we reported operating income of $255  million. texts.speaker: Alexander Lorentzen Krane

texts.speaker: Alexander Lorentzen Krane

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer

However, if we  adjust for the motor incident, the production efficiency – the background production efficiency was about 96% in  the quarter. texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As we now talked about a bit, the production was negatively impacted in the quarter by the fact that the high - voltage drive motor for one of the gas compressors failed in the quarter. That meant that we changed out t hat  motor and it's not a small exercise, the motor – driving the housing itself is actually 25 tonnes, so it's the small  motor. The  reason for that is despairing philosophy that we have, where we're continually keeping one spare motor on  standby to be able to change out rapidly, and we've also been able to accelerate the layout of cranes and lifting  equipments to do this in a much more quick way now going forward.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Production so far in 2016 has been good. We averaged around 62,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in January,  and we are quite confident in our guiding of production in 2016 between 55,000 barrels a day and 60,000 barrels  a day.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The other ones just for recuperation is Bøyla and into Bøyla wells and the infill well at the Kameleon reserve. So  far in 2015, we've been able to fight the natural decline in the Alvheim area. This has been an overarching  ambition for us ever since the acquisition of Marathon back in 2014. And we will continue to invest in this area to  fight decline going forward.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In 2016, we planned to put another three wells on stream. Firstly, we are going to put BoaKamNorth well, which  I'll come back to in a second. And then secondly, the first oil of Viper and Kobra are scheduled towards the end of  2016, and drilling is currently ongoing on those two wells.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In November, we awarded a rig contract to Transocean for the lease of Transocean Arctic as a semi-submersible  rig. The rate, in our mind, is favorable at $179,000 a day. And the rig contract is scheduled to commence in  December this year, and we have a fairly flexible contract with auction periods also extending all the way to 2019,  while the firm scope now committed consists of four wells in the Alvheim area, including two infill wells at the  Volund reservoir, a well in a shallow formation that we call Alvheim Arctic and exploration well at West Volund.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I'm very happy to see that the work is already ongoing between Det norske, Transocean and the vendor of drilling  equipment on the rig to make sure that this rig is in good shape when it comes to the Alvheim field. We have high  ambitions for the performance of Transocean Arctic under our operatorship.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Including in the well was three pilots. First, landing pilot just below the first branch to control the depth and the  oil water contact. And second, two geo-pilots that tested positives we had about seismic anomalies in the field.  And I'm happy to say that the tests were positive and that we have now an even more positive outlook on this area  than we did prior to drilling these geo-pilots.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We subsequently then drilled the three producers extending East and North, and if you can see them up, it's the  blue lines on the map. The map is seismic map, where the bright colors are oil and more pinky colors are  background.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I'm also happy to see that the drilling performance on Transocean Winner, a rig that was built in 1983, is stepping  up. And the performance of this well was 17 0 liters a day, which is only three wells of multilaterals on the  Norwegian Continental Shelf with more rapid progression than that.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of results, the BoaKamNorth came in much better than expected. We had a gross pre -drill assumption of  9 million barrels. And after a bit of tweaking on the geological models after the drilling, we are now assessing this  to be roughly 40 million barrels, or roughly 50% better than pre-drill.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The A3 is the last out of three IOR wells that we drilled on Transocean Winner. And all in all, the 2015 IOR  campaign are expected to give an excess of 20 million barrels gross of added reserves to the Alvheim area,  basically reflecting a reserve replacement rate close to one as our production in that area is on average roughly 20  million barrels. I'm quite happy about that.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now moving on to Ivar Aasen. This project also progressed well in the quarter. And project is still unscheduled to  develop first oil in 2016. The pre-drilling campaign that we talked about during the Capital Market Day started in  July, and is continuing with world-class drilling performance.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Det norske's drilling team would long our service providers and rig contract, the Maersk, have consistently driven  top quartile and even P10 performance, both in drilling and completion since we commenced on the pre -drilling  program.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: By year-end 2015, we had three producers and one water injector in the ground. And we have thus completed the  number of wells that was initially planned to be completed during the pre -drilling phase. We will continue to drill  until the summer of 2016, where the Maersk Interceptor rig will drill the Rovarkula exploration well, while the  topside of Ivar Aasen is being installed.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We expect that the topside and the living quarter will be mechanically complete during the first quarter this year,  and sail away is planned now for May. During the fourth quarter last year, we decided along the other operators  that are going to lift in the summer of 2016 for lifting window in July 2016, which gives us a mple time for hook-up  and commissioning in order to achieve first oil in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The work is likely to continue throughout this quarter, as we will try to  test as much sub-systems as we possibly  can in the quarter. The offshore commissioning, the onshore commissioning for the topside will continue all the  way until load outs on the heavy transport vessel. We expect that to happen sometime in May, when we wi ll load  out a different modules and then sail away in late May, depending on weather window.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The subsea scope is also continuing. And the first activity in this campaign will be the power cable that will be  installed between Alvheim and Ivar Aasen. We will also carry out testing activities, trenching activities and other  subsea activities prior to installation on the topsides. The topsides will then be installed in July, using the Saipem  7 000 heavy lift vessels. Including the living quarter, we are planning for five lifts in total.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then finally, when the topside of living quarter are in place, the 450 bed Floatel safe surface will be mobilized,  accommodate the workforce in the offshore commissioning phase to ensure that first oil will be completed in  December 2016.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, moving onto Johan Sverdrup. This project is also progressing well. During the fourth quarter, contract was  awarded to amongst other, the jack-up accommodation unit, Haven, and fabrication of pipelines, so called spool  fabrication. Pre-drilling of the first production wells are expected to commence this quarter. And the operator  expects to pre-drill six wells to eight wells with a semi-sub unit for each year during the period of 2016 to 2019.  We are really pleased to see that the cost estimates continue to come down.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And Statoil, as the operator, has announced a phase 1 CapEx reduction from NOK 123 billion to NOK 108.5 billion  in nominal terms. They have also announced that based on the cost reductions to -date, the phase 1 breakeven oil  price is now estimated at below $30 a barrel. The partnership have also decided on debottlenecking measures to  increase the phase 1 production capacity to above the initial 315 million to 380 million barrels a day estimate.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The operated Rovarkula represent the potential tying candidate, Ivar Aasen, and will be drilled with Maersk  Interceptor this summer. And the Filicudi well in the Barents Sea will test a prospective trend in the Loppa South  area.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now moving out onto outlook. 2015 has been a challenging year. We don't expect 2016 to be any less challenging  for the oil and gas industry. However, we hav e chosen to take really proactive approach to the challenging  marketing conditions.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Besides our execution on the activity program for 2016 that I've talked about in some detail, both during the  Capital Markets Day and also today, we have initiated an extensive and deep improvement program to improve  the way we operate as an oil and gas company in a low oil price environment. We do not see that sufficient to  execute on the same level as we have done historically even though the performance on average is quite good.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Actually, we are taking all measures we can to reduce our cost base in the years to come. And we are working to  exploit the market situation and reduce supplier spend by postponing and canceling activities that are not critical  to our business and not driving performance. However, the question for me is, how we, as an oil and gas company,  in a decade highly influenced by high margins and high cost can turn this downturn into a sustainable and  recurring savings and productivity increase in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I'm of the opinion that the company needs to embed the true improvement culture across the company and across  its vendor base. And that we empower that with executing projects in a flawless manner, need to train the  organization and the vendor base and continuous improvement in the same manner that onshore industries have  been doing for years. They have succeeded in surviving with significantly lower margins than the oil and gas  company has been blessed with for time to come.

texts.speaker: Karl Johnny Hersvik
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have about 90%, but I don't think we differ from other oil and gas company. About 90% of our spend  externally. That means that working with the external supplier and improving the way we collaborate, improving  productivity in the value chain is crucial to a permanent and recurring cost saving and increase in productivity  across the value chain.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: In June, we announced further cost savings initiatives and we're now targeting total ongoing costs of £1 billion in  2014, which is about £130 million lower than our prev ious target.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: The overall first half results show we're making good progress towards our financial target. In fact, on two  measures, we're actually ahead of our targets at the headline level. However, as I've already said, this was flatted  by a particularly benign weather in the first half.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Stripping out the weather, we believe on an on-going basis – or stripping out the weather, the RoTE is  approximately 15%. So a good progress, but given the competitive market backdrop, there's still much to do.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Paul, and good morning, everybody. Starting with GWP then, that was down 4% versus the prior year due  to reductions in Motor and Home, partially offset by growth in Commercial and International.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: As I mentioned just now, GWP overall in the first half was down 4% versus last year. But as we show on the left,  it's still around the £1 billion per quarter level it's been over the last few quarters. Within this, there are few key  trends to bring out.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: First, when looking at the divisional figures, you need to adjust for the van business, which was transferred from  Motor to Commercial as of the 1st January this year. The chart on the bottom-right shows the quarterly GWP  movements adjusting for that.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: In Motor in the second quarter, we've seen an improvement in the trend from the first quarter. So you'll recall in  the first quarter, our GWP was down 14%. texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: International GWP is up 12% in the first half [indiscernible] (04:28) performance in Germany. There's also a  slight wrinkle in Home to point out. texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: There were no claims of major weather events in the first half of this year against the normal expected level of £40  million. In the first half of last year, we incurred approximately £90 million of such events due to major freeze and  flood.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Our reserve release of £239 million in the first half are broadly in line with last year and represented the green bit  of this waterfall. We can split there by division over the next page.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: The £32 million release in Home includes a reduction in last year's weather event costs and improved frequency  on [indiscernible] (06:02). Some of these positive experience are shared with our partners through profit shares.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: So let's us now look at the divisions, starting with Motor. Motor saw an improved operating result and a COR  below 100% as management actions taken since 2009 continue to flow through to the results. As I've already  mentioned, IFPs were down in the first half but broadly stable in the second quarter. The underlying reduction in  GWP is 11%, 14% first quarter, 8% second quarter and reflects both the change in IFPs and the low risk mix versus  last year.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to Home, the result is dominated by weather, improvements in weather claims. But starting at the top, in - force policies, down due to removal of Home risk response policies, as mentioned, with the underlying fall of  about 2% since the start of the year.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: GWP was down 5% following a trend in IFPs and lower average premium, Paul will comment on that later.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: The improvement in current year loss ratio of 51.7% is mainly due to the absence of weather claims in the first half  2013 versus £90 million in the first half of last year. And Homes also benefited in prior-year reserve releases, as  mentioned.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Combined ratio improved to 86.3%, almost entirely due to the weather. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to Rescue and Other Personal Lines, which is the only division that seen a reduction in operating profit  versus last year, IFPs were lower due to reduced volumes in packaged bank accounts which affects rescue and  travel. texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: The GWP reduction is mainly due to run-off of the creditor book, with a fall in IFPs from packaged accounts  having little impact on GWP. Rescue GWP is up 8% to £7 4 million for the first half.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Whilst the main reason for the fall in operating profit relates to the one-offs last year, Rescue was also impacted in  the first half of this year by the cost of that Green Flag marketing campaign. So good results from that campaign,  but at a cost.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: On to Commercial and, first, I'll demonstrate the progress towards the 100% COR target for next year. texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, International, and for the first time, International reported a sub -100% COR at the half year, just 99.9%  COR. texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: We improved customer propositions, for example, through the launch of Together for Direct Line and Green  Flag's one-hour response campaign and through telematics and legal services launches, which, again, I'll cover in  a second.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: The app, which you can get, customers will receive 10% discount after clocking of 200 miles of monitored driving,  which will then give them a score which they'll be able to continually monitor and, hopefully, improve their  driving behavior.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: International overall was again growing GWP and profit is managing the different trends being experienced across  the two countries we operate in. texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Okay. Then will go with their packs. On page 32, people on the phone. John's already given you the figures for the  slowdown and reduction in Motor GWP in the second quarter and I'll now give you a little bit more color.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: So to summarize, another period of good progress. Adjusting for the benign weather, we're on-track to meet our  98% combined operating ratio target this year.
