texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Good morning. So good morning to everyone on the room and on the phones, to our Second Full -Y ear Results  Presentation, here in [indiscernible] Goldman Sachs. Good to see the sun shining after the recent weather.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: I'm Paul Geddes, CEO, and I'm joined by John Reizenstein, CFO. We're going to follow the usual format today,  which is I'm going to start off with some key messages, John is going to come with the numbers, and I'm going t o  come back with an update on our transformation agenda and then some topics I'm sure high on your list of things  to talk about, the UK motor market, flooding and weather, and then we're going to take some questions.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Now, this guidance assumes a normal level of claims this year from major weather events. And clearly, the start of  this year has been anything but normal. Severe flooding and storms is a timely reminder that insurance isn't just  about price and our staff did a great job in helping customers get back on their feet.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Paul, and good morning, everybody. Let's start with financial highlights on slide seven (sic) [six], and I'll  talk to performance against the full year 2012 to begin with. GWP was down 4%, re flecting the impact of a  competitive marketplace, particularly in UK Motor, together with the group's continued focus on managing for  value.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: A couple of observations on Q4, GWP was down 3.6% in the fourth quarter with Motor down 9%. Operating profit  of £108.7 million was 4% lower than prior year, due to higher weather costs in 2013, partially offset by higher  reserve releases. Other income was lower due to the banning of solicitors' referral fees. Investment return was  higher due to the effects of changes in the investment portfolio and there were very few gains in Q4.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to underwriting performance on the next slide, in a year which saw material market price deflation,  holding our current year ratio flat was, we think, a pretty good result. The ongoing business, our current year  attritional loss ratio remains stable despite competitive market conditions and higher weather losses in  Commercial and International, which are not adjusted for in the attritional ratio on this slide.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: We've seen prior-year releases up substantially, which I'll come back to. Interestingly, despite the floods and  storms, Home weather event costs of £69 million in 2013 were actually a bit lower than our budget and lower than  2012 and we think we've made a prudent assessment of those claims and how they will develop .

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Both International and Commercial were impacted by weather in 2013. Commercial suffered higher than normal  claims from the very recent bad weather in Germany from hail events in the summer. We don't adjust this table  for those. But if we did, the attritional loss ratio would be around 0.5 percentage point better in 2013.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to Home on slide 11, we saw a reduction in Home IFPs and much of that is due to the removal of low   premium home response products from packaged accounts. The underlying reduction is 2%. And within that,  volumes on own brands were flat. As we said previously, we continue to reinvest transformation benefits in the  Home business to maintain performance in a competitive marketplace. As you know, we've experienced a number  of weather events in Q4. We had the St. Jude Storm in October and coastal flooding in early December, followed  by flooding and storms over Christmas. In total, these weather events cost £64 million on top of the £5 million in  Q3.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to Rescue and other personal lines on slide 12, the reduction in policy account, mainly due to reduced  volumes in packaged bank accounts, this is partially offset by growth in Green Flag direct sales following key  marketing campaign, which we showed you. There was a small reduction in o verall GWP but Rescue GWP was up  4.4% over that campaign.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Turning over to Commercial. Good performance in Commercial, with results demonstrating progress towards the  target COR of below 100% this year. IFPs were up 25%, GWP up 9%. On an underlying basis, excluding the  transfer of the Van business from Motor, GWP growth was 2%, largely due to growth in Direct Line for Business,  thus the policy count was up a lot.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: The current year loss ratio shows a 2.9 percentage point improvement despite higher weather claims. The prior - year releases are similar to what we've seen in the past and we expect this to be an ongoing feature of Commercial  business. Overall, the financial loss ratio was 62.3%, a bit lower than last year – than 2012.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: There were small improvements in commission and expense ratios as a result of management actions taken on   cost and efficiency. COR of 106.8% was 1.4 percentage point better than 2012. If you exclude the higher claims  costs from weather, the underlying COR would have been around 104%, a bit lower than 104%, which we think is  a good sign as we go towards 100%. Overall operating profit increased by £7 .3 million to £9.5 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Profit from Germany was obviously down due to the weather I mentioned, but on a normalized basis, showed  progress. Profit initially was flat with performance maintained despite very challenging markets and economic  conditions. We've seen competition in Italy intensify during 2013 and this will impact growth in 2014.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Let's start with distribution. We continue to invest in building customer capability and propositions. Last year, we  set out a number of priorities as shown here on the left. So, let me update you on our progress in 2013, which  further differentiates our propositions, with offerings such as Direct Line Together and Green Flag's one -hour  proposition. Our more targeted marketing campaign was achieved with a 9.4% reduction in our marketing spend.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: So, I'm now going to turn to three topics close to your hearts: Motor pricing, Home weather, and regulation.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Next on to weather where I'm sure you'll be interested in our take on the level of claims coming through from  recent events. In the fourth quarter, the Home weather cost was £64 million and that was made up of three quite  different events. Firstly, St. Jude in October, where some of the countries suffered severe gales. The costs  associated with this event were fairly low but the volume of claims was pretty high.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: In early December, parts of the UK suffered storms that led to tidal surges across the East Coast. We received over  200 flood claims and with most of the damage caused by saltwater, has increased the average claims cost. We also  received claims from storm damage at a much lower average claim costs. Overall, the mix of incurred costs was  skewed towards flood claims.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, for those of you in the country at Christmas, you will remember the bad weather  and again, a mixture of  floods and storms. However, this time the floods were inland which means lower severity. The mix of flood and  storm claims of the event was roughly equal. The adverse weather obviously continued into Q1 with further storm  damage and further flooding.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Our initial view as of 22nd of February is that the cost will be in the region of £7 0 million to £90 million for  Home, with a further £20 million in Commercial. However, all the usual caveats apply. This is still very early days.  We'll only start to get a more accurate assessment when the floodwaters fully recede.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Compared to 2007 floods, we're not seeing claims from the same scale. And to date, flood claims volumes are less  than a tenth of what we saw back in 2007. The chart on the right shows the development of claims volumes both  for Q4 and Q1 events, including both storm and flood. As you can see on the chart, notifications for St. Jude and  the tidal surge developed quite quickly, whereas the events in 2014, we're seeing a slower pa ttern, which makes it  difficult to be totally accurate on the estimate cost at this point in time.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Over the course of the next few months, we'll be back-testing our flood models to understand whether the flood  defense system that were put in place post-2007  operated as we expected and to assess the impact of strategic  decisions taken to tactically flood certain areas. We're going to use insights gained from these events to further  enhance our flood models and to inform our reinsurance buy. And on reinsurance, our current claims estimates  are well below the retention of reinsurance of £150 million. And to remind people, that is a deductible on a seven  days [indiscernible] basis for flooding.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: So before I wrap up, an update on the targets and guidance for the year ahead. Starting with COR, the market  today remains highly competitive. But with our self-help agenda and assuming normal weather claims of £80  million, we would expect to achieve a COR of between 95% and 97 % in 2014. And within this, we reiterate our  commercial COR target of better than 100%, again, assuming normalized weather and large loss claims.

file: DLGL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 3March2015 545 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Look at top line. In the lower half of the slide you can see our improving quarterly GWP trend. In the fourth  quarter overall GWP was flat versus the prior year. This improving trend was driven by performance across Motor  and Home own brands. You can see from the bars on the top right that we saw a small increase in Motor own  brand IFPs in Q4 whilst Home own brands were stable.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Motor we saw improvement in quarterly GWP versus the prior year with 2.5% year-on-year growth in GWP in  the fourth quarter. Home GWP was down 4.7% for the full year, but sharper pricing helped to hold our own brand  policy count flat in the final quarter. We saw good growth in Rescue and Other Personal Lines, including Life,  which ended the year up 6.8% and 3%, respectively. And Commercial continues to grow GWP and IFPs, GWP was  up 2.6% with growth across all channels.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The red bars show we experienced lower claims from major weather events in Home. The number was £63 million  in 2014 all from the first quarter. It was also another year of significant prior year reserve releases with £398  million in 2014. This is equivalent to 13.3% of NEP and is a function of our prudent approach to reserving, which  I'll talk about in a moment.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Marketing costs were down 22.2% (sic) [22.1%] (5:55) despite having rolled out new marketing campaigns for  Direct Line and Green Flag. In my job it goes with the territory to be a bit skeptical about marketing costs. But  when you think about our new campaign and the better sales picture for the group, I mean no doubt we're getting  more efficient in our marketing spend.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So having held our pricing relatively flat during the year, our prices in Q4 were about 2% higher than a year  before. The combination of a better trading environment and our actions meant we were able to hold policy count  pretty flat in Q4, And so GWP was up versus the prior year despite a slightly lower risk mix.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Let's get into the Motor claims trends. Improving economic conditions and lower fuel prices contributed to the  first increase in road traffic since 2011. We haven't seen any impact on claims frequency from that, at least not yet.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving down to current year attritional loss ratio, this improved by 2 percentage points to 49.3%, reflecting  improved risk selection and good underlying claims trends. As mentioned weather-related costs were slightly  lower in 2014. Prior year releases totaled £50 million, reflecting underlying favorable claims development. This  gave a reported loss ratio of 50.8%, 3.1 percentage points better than 2013.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: GWP was up 2.6% with growth across all channels, particularly eTrade and DL4B [Direct Line for Business] other  than the Van. The current-year loss ratio improved by 4.9 percentage points with reductions across all products. It  was a normal year in terms of weather and large losses.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Behind our new mission to make insurance much easier and better value for our customers are three strategic  pillars. Our famous own brands, DirectLine, Churchill, Privilege, and Green Flag, together with our rich customer  data give us a head start as a great retailer, the first of our pillars.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Also in the future we may choose to retail more product that we don't manufacture ourselves as we do today with  white-labeled life.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Taking all of this together, we've updated our COR guidance for 2015 aiming to achieve a COR in the range of 94%  to 96%. This of course assumes no more weather claims, with the spread reflecting the uncertainty surrounding  claims inflation versus market pricing in Motor. Finally of course our 15% RoTE target remains ongoing.

file: DLGL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 1March2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We're also moving back to becoming a disruptor again. Telematics policies more than doubled. Green Flag  continued to challenge the AA and the RAC, and Direct Line for Business broke through 400,000 policies.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And our clear strategy has also enabled us to meet or exceed our targets in 2015. We delivered a combined ratio of  94%, which adjusted for normal weather was 93% and better than the guidance we set out at the start of the year.  RoTE increased again to 18.5%, well ahead of our 15% target.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Combined ratio was 94%, and within that, the total cost base down again to £885 million, a reduction of 4.6%. At  a segmental level, all segments were profitable, with Motor and Rescue and other personal lines improving their  profit, Home broadly stable, while Commercial was impacted by higher major weather event costs from the  December floods.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The headline ongoing combined ratio improved by 1 percentage point to 94%, one point better than 2014. Y ou  recall that we gave guidance on COR of 94% to 96% at the start of 2015, which we upgraded to 92% to 94% at the  mid-year. All these numbers being normalized for major weather cost. Our actual COR on this basis was 93%,  which puts us in the middle of the upgraded range.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The loss and expense ratios were stable, with an improvement in the commission ratio. Below this there were  some positive trends, which we've highlighted in the waterfalls on the right. The total loss ratio was stable at  59.5%. Within this we saw a 1.4% improvement in the current year attritional loss ratio. This was partially – partly  offset by a small reduction in the level of prior year releases and higher weather-related claims.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: With GWP growth coming through in 2015, the pressure on NEP should abate going forward. We're saying today  that in 2016, we expect total cost to be lower, although with a smaller reduction in 2015. That's in part due to the  cost of the Flood Re levy.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, Commercial reported a headline combined ratio of 104.5%, which is 5.7 percentage po ints higher than  prior-year. Commercial result was impacted by approximately £40 million of claims from December storms and  floods, about £20 million more than normal. Normalizing for this and other large claims gives a COR of  approximately 99%, similar to the previous year. At 12.9 percentage points, Commercial continued to experience  large prior year reserve releases as in previous years. You can find more commentary in the appendix where we've  included the usual segmental P&L.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We maintained our competitiveness across our strong own brand portfolio, growing policy count by 1.5% during  the year. Our underlying claims picture in Home, discarding the major weather, has been good, with overall  inflation running below the long-term average. This together with our initiatives in pricing, meant we were able to  reduce our own brand risk adjusted prices by around 3% in the fourth quarter year -on-year. This brought the  overall reduction for the year to around 2.4%.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our focus has also been on improving our trading capabilities, in particular optimizing our pricing across different  brands and channels. In addition to this, we continued to invest in digital initiatives and rolled out new quote  and  buy journeys for Home and Green Flag in 2015, building on the work we did in Motor in 2014.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, turning to Green Flag, we've implemented a number of digital initiatives, which drove 8% policy growth in  2015. We rolled out our new cleaner web journey, with web chat functionality and this delivered an immediate  uplift in revenue compared with the previous site. Behind the scenes, we've been busy working on a big pipeline of  future initiatives with a focus on digital. These initiatives are designed to improve the service we offer to our  customers, whilst retaining the value for money that Green Flag offers versus its peers.

texts.speaker: Mike Holliday-Williams
texts.profession: Managing Director Personal Lines, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: We've also been looking beyond telematics to the development of in-car technology. For example, today, we've  launched Green Flag Alert Me, which offers battery health and vehicle fault alerts via an onboard diagnostic device  and a smartphone app. Safety technology is also an area of focus for us. And we've recently introduced discounts  for vehicles with autonomous emergency braking fitted as standard.

texts.speaker: Mike Holliday-Williams
texts.profession: Managing Director Personal Lines, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, just a few words about the floods. Steve and his team have really focused this year on making it much  easier for our customers every time they make a claim. We were really able to demonstrate our customer focus  during the floods caused by the storms Desmond, Eva and Frank in December. These three events generated just a  short of 5,000 claims.

texts.speaker: Mike Holliday-Williams
texts.profession: Managing Director Personal Lines, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: So, how did we help our customers? Well, first, we were proactive and took a number of actions before the storms  hit. We deployed our field teams in various locations, carrying tablets with customer details. They were proactively  knocking on doors, providing advice and assistance to our customers, such as helping them to move items  upstairs. We also sourced a considerable amount of alternative accommodation in advance, such as hotels, flats  and holiday homes.

texts.speaker: Mike Holliday-Williams
texts.profession: Managing Director Personal Lines, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Once the storms had hit, we were there to ready and ready to help our customers. Our mobile response center,  which we called CHARLIE, was set up in Carlisle and later on in Y ork to enable customers to get advice, Internet  access or indeed just a cup of tea. We also deployed our off-road vehicles in Cumbria, which meant we could get to  areas that were inaccessible to many others. More than 80% of our flooded customers were visited within seven  days of reporting their claims to us, 51% of properties had work commencing within a week of notifying their  claim, and about 20% of content-only claims were settled on the spot.

texts.speaker: Mike Holliday-Williams
texts.profession: Managing Director Personal Lines, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Y ou've heard how we're using video and photo evidence to enable us to assess, plan and start work sooner and  settle claims faster, but this is a really huge benefit in bad weather, when claims volumes are high, bec ause these  images help us to prioritize face-to-face visits and minimize inconvenience and distress for our customers.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Furthermore, we expect total costs to be lower in 2016, although with a smaller reduction than in 2015, in part due  to the cost of the Flood Re levy. We'll continue to invest in building future capability, as I've just taken you  through.

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Taking all this together, our COR guidance for 2016 is to aim for COR in the range of 93% to 95%, which, of  course, assumes normal annual major weather claims for Home and Commercial. Finally, of course, our 15%  RoTE target remains ongoing.

file: DLGL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 7March2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Paul Robert Geddes
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: All this enabled us to improve our underlying COR to 91.8%, which after adjusting for weather was 93.5% towards  the bottom of the 93% to 95% range we set at the start of 2016. Post-Ogden, the combined ratio is still  comfortably below 100%. Return on tangible equity was 20.2% before adjusting for Ogden and 14.2% after.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: There, of course, are a number of moving parts which I'll come on to later, but in summary, the biggest movement  was a £70 million increase in underwriting profit which reflects lower weather-related claims cost and a higher  prior year releases. This was offset by higher cost in commissions. Secondly, installment and other income  increased to £168 million due to higher written volumes while investment return was £27 million lower than prior  year on lower assets under management and fewer unrealized property gains.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Ongoing COR of 91.8% was a couple of points better than 2015. Adjusted for weather, that would have been  93.5% in line with our guidance. Total costs were £924 million in 2016, that's £39 million higher than prior year.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: It includes an additional £24 million Flood Re levy and £39 of million non-cash impairments. We believe the  underlying position is reasonably good, particularly in the context of our strong new business growth. At a  segmental level, better weather in 2016 led to a significant increase in Home and Commercial profit and that was  partially offset by Motor and Rescue and other personal lines.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: But the Direct growth story continued in Green Flag and Commercial as well. Green Flag policies we're up 7.4%  and in Commercial, our Direct Line of business brand, reported a 6.4% increase in policy. This growth in our own  brands in a high-shopping environment demonstrated that we're doing the right thing for customers.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: In 2016, we levied another 0.7 percentage point reduction as the results improved underwriting. The contribution  from prior years was higher yet again, continuing the trends since the IPO – sorry, [ph] continuing the (11:05)  higher than we expected in 2016 and £51 million more than in 2015. This was mainly due to positive development  from the storms at the end of 2015. Finally, the majority of the loss ratio improvement, i.e., 2.5 points was due to  better weather in 2016.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Absent these items, the expense ratio would've improved by about 0.4 of a percent. The commission ratio  increased a bit to 11.5% as a result of sharing better weather and prior-year development with our partners.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Moving to Home performance on slide 14. Home combined ratio improved significantly in 2016 to 85.0%, driven  by lower weather losses and higher prior year releases. The current year loss ratio deteriorated by two points, but  at 47.8% is still a good number. The year-on-year increase is partly driven by claims inflation and partly due to  changes in tenure and channel mix away from partners to PCWs which I'll come onto.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Prior year releases were higher in 2016 as Home recognized favorable development on the 2015 storms. The  expense ratio increased by 1.9 points due to the additional Flood Re levy in 2016 although we were able to  partially offset the cost of that in other efficiency measures. The higher commission ratio in 2016 reflects profit  shares associated with stable weather and prior year development.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Last but certainly not least, Commercial. It's a great set of results in Commercial in 2016, the best results since  the IPO. Headline combined ratio was 93.2% and underwriting profit was £30.6 million, really with some very  favorable tailwinds namely low weather and large losses, but – and some favorable development on the 2015  accident year.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Normalizing for weather and large losses, Commercial COR would have been three points better than 2015 due  to higher prior year, but also some current year improvement. So, moving left to right, starting with the current  year loss ratio, this improved by 9.5 points. As I've said, some of these improvements was due to better weather  and fewer large losses, but Commercial did deliver over a point of underlying attritional current year improvement  due to better pricing and risk selection.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: In ratio terms in 2016, our expense ratio was 25.3% and 24% ex the impairment. Looking ahead, we see further  opportunity to improve efficiency, so we can continue investing in the business and improving our  competitiveness. We, therefore, aim to reduce the expense ratio in 2017 along with a commission ratio,  normalized for weather and we aim to reduce further – both ratios over time.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Before I move to the outlook, let me just summarize some of the financial highlights. 2016 marks another year of  progress. We grew premiums and improved the current year loss ratio again. Our underlying cost base was flat,  having offset the Flood Re levy and costs associated with new business growth through improving our underlying  efficiency.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: Now, while I'm on the subject of partners let me just mention the Prudential, had long-term relationship. That deal  came to an end this year. We have a new deal, where we will be paying them a brand license, but commissions  we will not be paying anymore. So we'll keep that a net-net that's favorable. It's one of the reasons why we see  commission ratios going down in the future as we said. Finally, in Home the weather load for 2017 has reduced to  around £65 million, reflecting lower volumes. In Rescue and other personal lines, we'll continue to enhance the  Green Flag customer experience building on the growth we achieved in 2016.

texts.speaker: Anthony Jonathan Reizenstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Direct Line Insurance Group Plc
texts.text: In the rest of personal lines, we plan to roll out new initiatives in Pet and Travel, help drive profitable GWP growth  there. texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of Regeneration, Derwent London Plc
texts.text: The company's largest ever project to-date will be 80 Charlotte Street in Fitzrovia, which is due to commence at  the end of this year. texts.speaker: Simon P. Silver
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of Regeneration, Derwent London Plc
texts.text: The new facades will comprise a variety of new brick elevations together with fair-faced concrete. The complex will  also include a new pocket park which when all combined will help break down the massing of the site and prove  more in keeping with Fitzrovia than the current building.

texts.speaker: Simon P. Silver
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of Regeneration, Derwent London Plc
texts.text: So, what is so different about this development? Well, to explain it more fully is to set out its main principles  which are, number one, smart servicing. This entails concrete core cooling which replaces the normal over- specified air conditioning systems and simply entails chilled water pipes through an exposed concrete slab which  allows it to cool through absorbing heat.  However, in order to achieve requisite temperature levels, it is paramount to have the second principle, which is  tall ceilings of 3.5 meters which allows increased natural daylight as well as flexibility for retrofitting due to its  generous volumes. And thirdly, simple passive facade. This minimizes unwanted solar gain but permits opening  windows and allows natural ventilation.

texts.speaker: Simon P. Silver
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of Regeneration, Derwent London Plc
texts.text: We believe when completed, the new brick building will tick a lot of boxes with established TMT companies in  respect of sustainability and green issues. It should provide exactly the type of space they require with a strong  emphasis on major savings in carbon output, thereby – therefore, sorry, minimizing tenant's energy costs by as  much as 20%.

texts.speaker: Simon P. Silver
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of Regeneration, Derwent London Plc
texts.text: The tall ceilings are particularly important feature as we place more importance on volume and natural cooling  techniques than perhaps others who instead would prefer to squeeze in an extra floor within a fully-sealed air  conditioned environment which, by the way, is also less healthy.

texts.speaker: Simon P. Silver
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of Regeneration, Derwent London Plc
texts.text: I should emphasize concrete core cooling is not rocket science. It has been used in Germany and Scandinavia  before now. When completed, the 15-storey building will provide a total of 220,000 feet with fantastic 360-degree  views from the eight-floor upwards. There will also be outdoor roof space to include a small running track for  those keen enough to go jogging at lunchtime.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: The interesting area, I think, of the announcement is this wide-ranging review that is going to be  published in, or put out for consultation this autumn, which is really about the whole market  structure, and covers all aspects of the markets, renewables, as well as the power market. We think  this is very much due. We see Drax as a very strategic outfit in the UK. We have no question that  we’re critical to security of supply and system support services, but we do not feel fairly  remunerated for the effective support we give to the system. And we believe this is a real  opportunity to rebalance some of what we see as an inequality, or inappropriateness in the market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: Moving on to biomass itself, I’d like to provide a little bit of context before we talk a bit more about  what we’re doing in biomass. We actually have been burning biomass at Drax for seven years, and  this has been a progression. I mean, we’ve been learning as we go along, and we’ve been using  increasingly more sophisticated equipment for both how we burn and how we handle biomass.  We’ve become increasingly sophisticated in how we procure the biomass and how we handle the  logistics, and we’ve become increasingly knowledgeable about the global biomass market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: 10 As we’ve built this knowledge, we believe we’ve built true expertise in biomass. And I think we’ve  demonstrated it in this first six months by the smooth commissioning of our co-firing facility, which is  indeed the largest in the world, and also our ability to buy the biomass to put through that facility.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: As we’ve worked on co-firing and dedicated biomass, what we’ve found is that the engineering  work has been invaluable for putting forward more options for Drax. And the option we think is quite  interesting is converting units at Drax. And we really see this as three options, all to develop a  bigger renewable burn through biomass for the UK. And I must emphasize, biomass is a relatively  cheap renewable source of energy for the UK; it’s reliable, and it is flexible.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: So we see it as a suite. Co-firing we’ve already talked about. We see co-firing leading into  conversion of units, which I’d like to go on to, and then the dedicated biomass plants being  complementary to that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: So in terms of conversion, we now do have the technical confidence on how we – that we can burn  100% biomass in Drax’s units. And as I said, it’s a combination of the engineering work we’ve been  doing on both co-firing and dedicated. We’ve done an awful lot of test burns and test facilities for  dedicated.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: What we haven’t decided yet is what is the optimal way to do that and what should be the capital  investment, what’s the optimal capital investment, and what should be the fuel diet. And what we  think is the right way forward is we’ve created demonstrator unit, really working actually in tandem  with government, and used that to establish what would actually be the optimum configuration for  converting units from coal to 100% biomass. And we see that as really designing an investment  and a program for converting further units at Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: There is no provision under the renewables obligation for actually support for a converted unit. You  can go to the full legislation, but it isn’t really good enough protection for converting a unit, and so  we have been in active dialog with government for this. We were very encouraged by the call for  evidence, but we do believe that, for the very first unit which we would propose as a Drax unit, we  do believe there needs to be a special treatment as a demonstrator status.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: And one thing I’d like to make really clear, we do not propose to go down this path unless we are  absolutely confident that the support and the remuneration we get for taking that demonstrator risk  is appropriately remunerated through the structure of the renewables support we would get. And it  is a challenge. This is something which has not been done on this scale anywhere in the world. But  it is a challenge that we think we’re well placed for, because we’ve got this depth of experience, this  seven years of experience, and the expertise that we’ve brought through our co-firing.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: In terms of the dedicated biomass development, we do not now believe it’s credible we can make  the investment case by the end of this year. What effectively the hiatus on knowing what the band  is going to be, as it does stall key commercial parts of the development. We are trying to get  ourselves in the position that, as soon as we do have clarity, we can move with real speed. We  remain very confident about this. We think it’s a really attractive proposition for ourselves and  Siemens Project Ventures, as well as, of course, our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: 11 We are ongoing with our fuel procurement. We remain in the position that we’re being offered more  biomass than we have sources for, which is good. But the key to this, we think, is strong long-term  relationships, so we’ve been working very hard on that. We have made progress on our concept for  how we hedge the bark spread, and we have appointed a financial adviser. But we are frustrated  and we would like to move with greater speed on this.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we begin? So good morning, welcome to our 2010 Interim Results. I’m going to briefly
texts.text: And with that, I’d like to draw the results to a close. And as I opened with, the main themes I think  are improved profits in 2010, underpinned by the strong hedge; really good operational  performance, and it has enhanced our profitability. There has been some improvement in the  spreads, but they still are very meager, and we remain cautious about the commodity markets, and  relieved that we have good hedges in place for ‘11 and ‘12. And we are progressing our options for  creating value for Drax from our biomass core competency.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So open with the main themes of today, increased profits this half just passed compared to last year, underpinned  very much by the strong hedge that we had as we came into the year, which is stronger for the first half than the  second half of the year, and continued good operations. We are seeing an improvement in near term markets for  coal generators, but there is limited visibility beyond 2013. And we have seen or had announced the introduction  of the Carbon Four, which will erode the competitiveness of coal plants in the longer term.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We're very pleased with two developments on our balance sheet, a favorable outcome to the Eurobond tax  discussions and the completion of our refinancing. And last but not least, our work on biomass research and  development is progressing very well and we stand ready if there is the right regulatory support to convert Drax  into a predominantly biomass generator.  So, firstly recovering operational performance, as always, our management ethos is dominated by safety. We think  safety is actually central to good operations and we're very pleased again this half to have delivered world-class  performance in safety, as you can see from the top graph.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our load factor was 80%. That actually is a 93% utilization rate when we were able to generate, much higher load  factor than the average coal plant – the other coal plants in the system, which on average have a load factor of 34%  and also a higher load factor than the average for gas plant at 47%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We have a higher load factor really because we have very good efficiency. Drax is much the most efficient coal  plant on the system now and getting better with each turbine upgrade. We do continue to provide active support  to the grid, and we are making very good progress on our advantaged fuels, all of which encourage dispatch. But I  should say that a lot of the additional hours are at very low margin. It is about cost avoidance as well as making  profits.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of further operational performance, actually, the production team and generally across the business,  we've had a very busy six months. A lot of project work. We've completed the fifth turbine upgrade. We've only got  one more left to go. It was again on budget to schedule and to performance, which we're very pleased with. The  last one will be done next year. And at that point we will have all the units operating at 40% efficiency compared  to the U.K. coal plants standard of 36% efficiency, which gives us a very clear competitive advantage.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We worked hard on fuel flexibility. Last six months, we've been in 12% of advantage fuel and we consider an  advantage fuel any coal that has a big cost advantage over our standard coal and normally that means because it's  got some difficult feature in how you handle it or burn it, or a fuel that's a very low carbon. And that's, of course,  our biomass, but it may not necessarily be at an enhanced margin.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our co-firing facility is working beautifully. We've now been running this facility for one year, and we're very  pleased with the plant, we're very pleased with its design and its operations. Our only regret is we're not running it  at a full capacity because there is not enough ROC support to make all biomass that we could buy economic. We  did – nevertheless, despite the fact we weren't running at full capacity – we did produce 6% of the U.K.'s  renewable power, almost twice as much as any other facility in the U.K. over the first six months.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The two other areas of activity on the project side of biomass are Research and Development, of which I will talk  about more later on in the presentation, and Industrial Emissions Directive compliance work is ongoing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Haven has had a good six months. I'd just like to remind you of our strategy for Haven. Haven is about a credit- efficient route to market for our power sales, and of course, as we get – have that credit-efficient route to market,  we have to be very careful on our assessment and our treatment of the credit quality of our customers at Haven.  Our aim is to build Haven into our major route to market for generation contracts. Our target is that somewhere  between 40% and 60% of our sales will be with Haven in three to five years' time.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Trading update. As you'll see, we have moved on our 2011 and 2012 hedge position. Limited change in 2013. There  are many reasons for this, but probably the most important is we are very hopeful that 2013 is going to be a  transition year for Drax. We're hopeful we're going to be able to dramatically increase our biomass sales. Biomass  have a different balance to coal sales in that you have the benefit of the index-linked rock income. We actually  right now are working out what we think should be the optimum trading strategy for Drax, if and when we become  a predominantly biomass business.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On to the power market. The power market pricewise continues to be dominated by gas. But whether or not a  plant runs really is about its efficiency and the margin it can gain from its efficiency. And that's really well  illustrated though by the fact that we had an 80% load factor compared to the U.K. coal plant average of 34%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: What this graph shows you is what are the different spreads for different efficiencies. And if I just walk you  through it, if we go to the far right, what you see is the range of installed plant in the U.K. Dark blue is coal plant.  Most efficient, our upgraded Drax units, 40%. Least efficient, 31%. The light blue is the gas plant, most efficient,  58%, and that's the newly commissioned gas plant. Least efficient 42%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And what the chart does is it paints the picture of the spreads that those different ranges of efficiencies from fuel  plants can earn across the forwards. So if we look at the far-left, the two bars show the day-ahead spreads or the  prompt spreads for coal and gas plant. And what you see is the spread that a high-efficiency gas plant can earn is  just above the spread that we earn for our efficient units. And what that shows you is that the high-efficiency gas  plant is dispatching just ahead of us, but actually if you look at it, we're both running and we're running hard.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If you go down those two  bars, what you see is that it isn't economic for either the least efficient coal plant or for  the least efficient gas plant to run base load because they've got negative spreads. If we go across the forwards, if  you go right to the – almost the far-right of the chart, you get to winter 2013, what you see is there is actually quite  a dramatic improvement in the competitiveness of coal plant compared to gas plant. So we are dispatching well  ahead of those most efficient gas plant.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: But what's also I think quite interesting is the mid-merit coal plant is dispatching ahead of the least efficient – of  the most efficient gas plant. What this I think does illustrate very, very clearly is why a lot of the low-efficiency gas  plants have been mothballed, because the economic prospects for those plants are very, very slim as you look  across the forward and they have been poor and when you go back over the last six months, 12 months.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On to the gas price – part, the gas market, well, we're very pleased that gas prices have been pleasantly resilient.  What the – you can really see the movement in the last six months in the two charts at the top, so I'll just quickly  the top, is the European benchmark price. The gray is the U.K. gas price and the blue is the coal switching price.  And I think the way we think about this is the U.K. gas price is actually becoming a sort of an indicator of what's  happening in the global market. So when the global market is tight, what we've seen, experienced in the U.K. is  that the U.K. gas price oscillates around the U.K., European benchmark price. When the global market was in  surplus, what we saw was a lot of these surplus LNG try to find a home and one of the places it found a home was  in the U.K. And what that did is depress the U.K. gas prices – gas price. We saw it moving towards the then low  price in the global market, which was Henry Hub.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: What you'd expect to see if the U.K. market was in – if the global market was in balance, is you'd expect the coal  switching price to have more of an influence on the U.K. gas price. And what we've actually seen I think over the  last six months is a movement away from the low coal switching prices, certainly in the forwards, to the European  benchmark price, which really illustrates what I think we are all very familiar with, that all the factors that are  proving type – proving or causing the global gas market to get a bit tighter over the last six months.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The other graph I like just because I do think it paints a picture which is rather classic is the bottom graph because  where the top line is it's U.K. domestic production. You can see the gradual reduction in U.K. production. What  the gray line is Norwegian imports. And what's interesting about that is the seasonality of the Norwegian imports.  And then the blue – the turquoise-y blue line is the progressive or growth of LNG. All trends we're used – we're all  familiar with but it does illustrate, I think, it quite well.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now looking at revenue in more detail, the total of £866 million includes £115 million of sales through Haven  compared to £49 million last year. Total net power generated of 13.1 terawatt hours is a little up on last year's level  of 12.7 terawatt hours, which as Dorothy said earlier reflects our strong availability and plant dispatch economics  throughout the period. The average achieved price of our electricity sold in the wholesale market is £55.30 per  megawatt hour, up from £50.60 last year, reflecting the higher price is locked in for 2011, through the hedge we  entered the year with, together with additional sales volumes captured at higher prices on trades placed  throughout the period. An upward trend in power prices which can be seen in the charts, driven by gas prices.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to other income, and firstly, ROCs and LECs, and you do need to look at the balance sheet as well as  the income statement really to see the full picture. So within income, we recorded ROC and LEC sales of £6  million, against £2 million at the same stage last year, but we hold on the balance sheet to £61 million ROC  inventory compared to £33 million at the end of last year. The income on these will be recognized when they are  sold later in 2011 at a price likely to be close to the balance sheet value. The overall ROC increase, as you would  expect, is driven by the increased biomass burn at Drax.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So for 2011, whilst we have no contracts in place with the grid, we have continued to play a key role in the  balancing of the system, and earning appropriate margins from these activities, which are included in the gross  margin figure. Finally, other revenue is at £4 million, are predominantly from the sale of ash and gypsum to the  building industry.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to cost of sales which is at £585 million and up 14% year-on-year and this includes power buybacks to  Drax, power purchases at Haven and grid charges in both businesses. And within cost of sales, £445 million  related to fuel and carbon cost compared to £382 million at this stage last year. It's an increase of 16% with higher  generation and commodity prices. Grid charges and other cost of sales of £62 million, up £22 million year-on- year. This increase is in retail cost of sales where grid charges have risen as we grow sales through this business.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Outage fuel cost excluding carbon is £29.80 per megawatt-hour, up from £24.70 last year, primarily as a result of  higher international coal prices. Prices began to trend upwards at the end of last year when severe weather in a  number of regions across the world resulted in supply constraints. And you can see that move in the top chart.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Including carbon, average fuel costs are £34.10 per megawatt-hour, up from £30 last year, with the average cost of  our purchase carbon requirements up 60 pence per ton on last year. And this is mainly a result of the higher  in the lower chart the prices have fallen in recent weeks. So when all of these factors are taken in aggregate, we  delivered a gross margin which was 6% ahead of last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Operating cost and capital investment, our total operating cost were £91 million, up £10 million and on track to  meet the guidance we gave at the beginning of the year of £185 million. And we continue to control our cost base  carefully. Most of the increase to date, £8 million, reflects investment in growth, growing the Haven business and  very importantly, research, development and planning on increasing the level of biomass burn at Drax to be in the  best possible position to deliver a step change as quickly and efficiently as possible in the volumes of biomass we  co-fire at Drax, if support is confirmed at the appropriate level.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: This business is characterized by high annual electricity volumes but requiring more complex contracts and  products than for SME. So to give you a bit more color, this program is designed to deliver the complex contracts  and products necessary for the INC sector, improve operational efficiency with increased automation and provide  high quality management information to support decision-making and, importantly, manage credit and cash  efficiently.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: To meet these objectives in aggregate over the life of the program, we will be investing some £15 million in IT  systems. And within this, we are implementing two integrated customer management platforms, an energy retail  suite, which performs customer registration, contract management and billing, and a contract entry system, which  acts as a single point of capture for customer and contract information fully integrated with the new and existing  systems within Haven. The project is well on track. All new I&C customers are now live on the new platform,  supported half hour billing, along with fixed price and flexible contracts. And looking forward, SME capability is  being phased in over the next year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So on to cash flow, and firstly, working capital. We increased coal stocks by 400,000 tons in the first half to stand  at 1.6 million tons at the end of the period, which together with the impact of higher coal prices has resulted in an  outflow of cash and working capital of £38 million. And for ROC, as I said earlier, our ROC inventory increased to  £61 million at the end of June driven by this – driven by the increased biomass burn. So this adds a further £28  million outflow. Tax cash of £42 million reflects payments on account in respect to their liabilities for 2010. So  after other cash movements of capital expenditure, debt service, and items of equity, the closing cash balance was  £300 million, with the previously ring-fenced cash tax saved from utilizing the Eurobond unwind losses, now

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: That said, it's also worth noting here that if and when we get the green light to make a step change in our biomass  burn, we will need an appropriate trading strategy and capital structure to support what will be a different  business model at Drax where we also have a growing hedge from our retail business.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our work on the options for trading and financing is well-advanced but we can only conclude when a clearer  picture of the regulatory support leverage for biomass coal firing emerges and when we have completed the  current trial design work and costings for enhanced coal firing at Drax. And Dorothy will cover these areas shortly.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In regulation, Electricity Market Reform was published in July. Still a lot of work required in this area by  government. There are two aspects of it that we think of as being positive. We've always believed that the Feed-in  Tariff with Contracts for Difference was the right support mechanism for renewables going forward. We think it's  the most cost-effective solution for the consumer. And we think for the investor what it provides is income  stability and contract security. So we were pleased that the government has confirmed that that is indeed the  instrument they expect to use.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We also were very pleased that the government is giving considerations to a wider capacity mechanism. We  strongly believe that as the U.K. increases its mix of renewables within the generation mix, you do need a wider  capacity mechanism to provide security of supply. The government is also still considering the targeted capacity  mechanism and we think that would be insufficient and distortionary on the market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The two negatives also remain there. So the Carbon Four is still in place and we continue to be of the view that it is  inefficient and ineffective. The emissions performance standard is also there, doesn't effect existing coal plants but  we do consider it unnecessary legislation in light of all the other environmental legislation that covers these areas.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: What we find very interesting is what's happening with the government on renewables. There are three areas of  work on renewable that are important to us. Firstly, the Renewables Roadmap that came out in July, the second is  the Banding Review that is under way. And the third is the bio-energy review, which is under way. We think these  three together should provide the clarity on the support for biomass going forward and actually the role of  biomass in the U.K.'s energy mix going forward.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So the Roadmap first. There are two things I'd like to point out in the Roadmap. Firstly, it's the first time I think  government has ever gone on print saying that co-firing is a cost effective biomass. So we're very pleased to see  that recognition in a government document. The other thing which I think is really interesting about the Roadmap  is it lays a picture for what government thinks is going to be a likely range for renewable electricity sourcing in  2020. And if you look at that picture, what you see is under most scenarios biomass will provide a third of the  renewable electricity in 2020. And indeed has the potential to provide more. So we found both those points very  encouraging.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the Banding Review, we were very pleased when the government committed last year to accelerate the  program for the Banding Review by one year. And we think that's very important because renewable investment  investors in advance what are going to be the levels of support. So having a Banding Review that provided under  the proposed timetable clarity at the end of 2011 for the bands that would be in effect in 2013 we thought was very  sensible and very good timetable.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The third area, the bioenergy, is really about providing – bioenergy review is really providing clarity on the scope  the government sees for biomass, but I think we really have a very good indication from that, from the Renewables  Roadmap. So, what have we been doing? Lots of research and development work. I think probably the most  interesting for us is the trials we have been doing. We have been trialing  biomass through Unit 1, or one unit and  it happens to be Unit 1.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And we started this summer, and what we are effectively doing is we are trialing different types of biomass,  different levels of biomass, different types and different levels of biomass with different coals, and we're doing all  that at a different load factor, so you can imagine the permutations are enormous.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Where we've gotten through so far is that everything, all the results so far confirmed what we already believed and  knew from our own analysis is that Drax can be predominantly biomass fueled, no issue with that. But we've still  got an awful lot of work from all those permutations to come out with the results of this trial. And the results of  the trial, we don't really expect to conclude until the end of the year. And what it's really about is its understanding  optionally. We know we can burn the biomass, what we want to maximize is our optionally in burning the  biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The other area where we've been doing a lot of work is what will we need to do in terms of changing the facilities at  Drax to transform ourselves into a co-firing at 50% or more. And there are two segments of this. One is the storage  we will need for the biomass and the other is the modifications to the plant itself. We believe that the longest lead  items actually will be the storage, and so we've done a lot of work on design and tendering.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: One thing which is really positive about this is we were very concerned when we first looked at this that it would  be very challenging to get a very cost effective solution to the storage on the Drax side, and that's because Drax  was designed to burn coal and to store coal. What we've actually done is we've managed to modify our approach to  storing coal and we now know that we're going to be able to put the biomass storage with the coal storage. And  what that actually means is we can keep it all with the rail loop and it's a very good cost efficient, cost effective and  efficient solution. And that's actually what you see on the top picture. That sort of loop is the rail loop and what  you see is possible biomass shed. It's just a mock up alongside our coal stock, which is a good development.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We're not convinced we're going to have sheds yet. We might have silos and we might have domes and that's what  the bottom pictures are about. The rest of the work on plant modification is ongoing but we haven't needed for  that work to go to outside tender yet whereas with the shed – with the storage we have.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, essentially, the message is that so far so good. So far everything we've done confirms that we can not only  dramatically increase the biomass burn at Drax but also we can do it on a timely basis if the Banding Review is  done on time.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On biomass sourcing itself, very good progress. I apologize but this does remain a highly commercially sensitive  area. So, as normal, we're not willing to communicate anything about where we're buying, who we're buying it  a number of years now, have had a very robust sustainability policy and within that sustainability policy, we  carbon footprint our biomass. We're now in our third year of carbon footprinting our biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And what the top chart illustrates it's the carbon footprint of some biomass we imported from Western Canada  compared with the carbon footprint of some biomass we brought down from Scotland. So the imported biomass  from Western Canada, the dark bars, and the Scottish biomass are the light bars. And I think what's interesting is  it shows that they actually, when you get to the final delivered point, they have a very similar carbon footprint.  And that really reflects the carbon efficiency of shipping very large quantities over long distances.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The bottom graph shows the carbon footprint of that same Canadian biomass compared with the carbon footprint  of typical gas and coal plant in the U.K. And we put this in because we thought you might like to see the clear case  that biomass delivers significant carbon savings compared to fossil fuel generation. And I think you can see that  clearly from the graph.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The U.K. is going to have mandatory sustainability standards from 2013. The government now is drawing up the  rules and details of how those are going to be controlled and we've been engaging with government on that and  specifically or particularly, on the standard carbon footprint model that the government intends to use. And we  have a high confidence that we'll begin compliance with those standards, actually, in many respects, it follows a  similar line to our current policy. So we're very comfortable with those standards.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So to bring it to a conclusion, good half year, underpinned by a strong hedge at the beginning of the year and  continued good operations. We are seeing a welcome improvement in near term markets, but little visibility  beyond 2013. We're pleased with the resolution of the Eurobond tax position and with the refinancing and we've  made good progress on biomass. And we're confident that with the right support, Drax is well positioned to  become a predominantly biomass station. And I would remind you that biomass is low cost and is a very good  renewable.
