texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As many of you know, for many years, we have been pressing government, trying to convince government to give  us the mandate to band biomass profitability. We have always believe and still believe there is a compelling case  for this cost effective renewable.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We believe that last week's announcement gives us that mandate. And I hope that during the course of this  morning, we will help you to understand why converting units to biomass is good for Drax is good for the  shareholders and is the right strategy going forward.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: First, I'd like to talk about early 2010 because it was in early 2010 that we developed a unit conversion strategy.  And we went to talk about that strategy with government. Government or DECC at the time were very interested.  And their interested for two reasons, firstly they wanted to sport biomass and coal stations, but they wanted to be  confident that there was a truly committed renewable. And their concern was that co-firing could be opportunistic  or gaming whereas they saw conversions of units as really a long-term solution.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The second reason for their interest was actually there was nowhere in the world where really high levels of  biomass were being used effectively in coal generating units. So they wanted to demonstrate. They wanted to  demonstrate whether that truly was feasible or not. At the time, those discussions came to nothing. And the  reason they came to nothing is under the current legislation. There was no provision for accreditation of a single  unit. You have to accredit a whole plant. So there was no way to give us the financial support we needed to  demonstrate unit conversion. You needed to amend the renewable obligation legislation, the sort of amendment  one might put in place for a banding change.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And they clearly stated that the reason they did that was because they recognized that actually large coal-fired  plants could not convert quickly to biomass. The reason being that it takes time to build up the biomass supply  chain. And if you don't have – if you only have low levels of co-firing support as you build that supply chain up,  then [ph] effectively (03:45) you can't afford to convert to biomass.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So they explicitly put co-firing enhanced conversion and enhanced co-firing at the same level to give large power  stations the opportunity to progressively convert to biomass. What we then did was we refocused our biomass  strategy on to co-firing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In the subsequent months, as we went through our responses to the consultation, there are number of notable  developments. We going to have increasing confidence that we would indeed be part of the solution and a  profitable part of the solution for renewables in 2020.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: This was because government constantly reaffirmed their interest in biomass and coal stations as part of the 2020  solution for renewable electricity. We knew we have the technology. We knew we had the biomass sourcing ability.  We knew we had the competitive advantage, both our efficiency and our technical know-how, which I would  suggest is second to none and possibly better than all.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then thirdly, we knew there was a real benefit of Drax remaining on the system, providing that strategic asset,  providing this strategic asset with key security supply and there are many scenarios, where the UK is facing  something of a capacity crunch somewhere in the second half of this decade. So with this confidence, we did more  and more work on what we would do with biomass.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The second development over this period was Tilbury. Tilbury demonstrated that you can successfully generate  electricity from coal stations using very high percentages of biomass. That was a real change in what was available  in terms of technical knowledge.  The third development was over this period from the publication of the consultation to actually probably today or  last week is every single one of our competitors developed or communicated to government a really strong interest  in either co-firing or converting their coal units to biomass.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: This was a change. 12 months ago, a number of our competitors had little or no interest in biomass. When we tried  to get support for removing the co-firing cap, not one of our competitors would lobby with us for removal of that  cap. For government, this created possibly a dilemma, or we thought it maybe created a dilemma, because what  they wanted to support through the renewables policy was committed long-term renewables. What they were  worried about was supporting opportunistic co-firing or gaming, and it was very hard for them to determine  which was the right way forward.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Then, a number of months ago DECC issued a confidential request for further information under the banding  consultation. That confidential request went to every single coal generator. There was a list of information  required, but one specific request was for our views on converting units, specifically converting units.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We took this as an indication that they could well be considering a change in policy, and that change in policy  would be from coal plant conversion to unit conversion. So we decided to refine our unit conversion strategy. We  looked at our technical designs. We accommodated both enhanced co-firing and unit conversion in those designs,  and most importantly we embarked in a large series of trials to demonstrate to ourselves whether we could indeed  run tracks units on a commercially attractive basis on a converted basis. And it also gave us the information – the  technical information to engage with DECC on this request for information on what was needed to define  successfully a converted unit.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The simplest reason is there's no cost subsidization. One of the challenges with co-firing is there are times if you  look through the scenarios, where you have coal effectively being subsidized by biomass. The second reason is that  actually it's a very simple commercial optimization and in any business, simple is good.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The reason it's simple is effectively we will be running a biomass plant business and a coal plant business on the  same side. And we will be optimizing for the biomass business and we will be optimizing for the coal business. We  do this by running a bark spread book and a dark green spread book. And we optimize them separately because  they are effectively separate commercial operations. So we think that's a real strength.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The third advantage of a unit conversion strategy or in this case actually, I mean, policy, is it should lead to a more  stable biomass market. And that is important because the biomass market isn't in its infancy. And they not do well  with disruptions. But an opportunistic co-firing, surge and sudden decrease actually could lead to a disturb at  stabilization in the market. So we think because we have a committed long-term strategy to biomass is our interest  at that biomass market isn't subject to shocks.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The next advantage is clearly addressed advantage. We believe under a unit conversion, we get better advantage  than actual and we still got the work we're doing, it may lead to reduce cost on compliance with the Industrial  Emissions Directive. So when will the government publication came out? We were pleased we thought it worked. I  just wish we've been able to announce that at 7 o'clock rather than 9 or 9:30 when we did.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Biomass is about long-term contracting, if you really want to secure a supply and this grandfathering gives us the  abilities contract. I should explain it's subject to no EU tightening. At the moment the UK actually has more  rigorous sustainability criteria than the EU. And obviously, the UK government cannot command what the EU is  going to do. But there have to be a really a substantial change in the EU for it become tighter than the current UK  provision. So we feel comfortable with this.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And the second, also I hope you understand is that they are considering putting in tools to manage volumes in  2014. This is because there is a scenario in government's mind that there will be a dash to biomass. That there will  be an enormous surge in electricity generation, biomass. We have never believe this is credible and the reason we  don't believe this is credible is it really takes time and expertise but time particularly to build out large biomass  supply chain, it's just not going to happen overnight. And so we don't see this as a particular area of concern, but  government has no way – they're not in the market buying biomass every week, every month, every year, it's very  hard for them to them discern what this risk might be.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So maybe I thought we'd go on to our combustion trials. So we started the trials number of months ago and  essentially they build on the trials – extensive trials we did last year, we trialed 90% biomass – 90% plus biomass  through the units. And what we were looking to do was optimize over four key success criteria and those key  success criteria are availability, and that's about filing slugging, corrosion, outputs levels, efficiency and the range  of biomass fuels.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I must say and actually unusually somehow I would say for us, we actually took a really bold approach to these  trials. A really innovative approach and we used a lot of the work we've been doing with expert universities. We  used standard and non-standard mitigants and we did some quite innovative things on boiler design and also – or  boiler modification, but also fuel delivery.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We were very, very pleased. The results despite – the trials were very encouraging and indeed quite surprising in  some areas. They make us absolutely confident that we can work these units on a converted basis. There were  optimization work is ongoing. We still got some further areas to cover. Most important is what we consider as that  fifth key indicator, which is the NOx performance of a converted unit.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: What we're not in a position to do is announced what are the details of these trials results. So we're not going to  tell you what the availability is. We're not going to tell you what the efficiency is. We're not going to tell you what  the output is and we're not going to tell you the fuel range.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now onto biomass sourcing. I suppose the way to describe our progress in this area over the last six months is  careful. We were waiting for banding clarity, but we didn't want to move standstill. We have secured rights for the  first 2 million tonnes that we need, is actually we secured rights for 2 million tonnes in the ROC year 2013.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Biomass purchasing is not just about buying the pellets, it's about the logistics. It's about getting the pellets from  the point of production through normally rail, port, rail and into Drax. This logistics provisions is an area where  we have made very good progress over the last six months, in all the areas, in rail negotiations, in port  negotiations and in shipping arrangements.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: What particularly pleases me is actually we've made progress on wagon design, might not seem important, but it is  very important. So, we've now got to design of wagons that we're going to start now building the wagons that  actually will enable us to carry much more biomass on the same rail cost. So same length of train, same number of  biomass, a lot more biomass in book, sorry, same number of wagons, but a lot more biomass. And the biomass  actually all about this is that it's finding the economy at every point you can. So that's been very good.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The other area where we've made good progress is on our North American pellet plant development. So we've  secured sites for the first few pellet plants. We have submitted the permit applications. We're well advanced with  the engineering design and we started the tendering for equipment.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We believe that we're going to be in a position to make our first decisions on investments towards the end of this  year. Timing these investments and timing commissioning has become even more important as we go through  unit conversion strategy because unit conversion is all about having the right amount of fuel available when you  convert the unit. And we think one of the strengths of our strategy is that we will be building our end plants. So we  to a certain extent can control that timing which is very important. And that was all I was going to cover on

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So we're very pleased with the 4.4%, any period we'd expect to be above or below or around – also later on that  5%. Very high load factor. 82% load factor. And the way I think of it is high is that's actually 95% utilization when  we're available. This is going to be a high generation year for Drax probably as much as 27 terawatt hours. So I  would say the additional generation, it's a very small margins.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our load factor remains high relative to our competitors. 55% average for other coal plant and close to 30% for the  gas plant, very difficult market for gas generators at the moment. There are three main factors where we have a  high load factor. Efficiency is the obvious one, but also we are a competitive asset for great support and we do get  advantage or financial advantage from burning advantage fuels. And during the period, 13% of the fuel burnt was  non-standard coal.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The largest component of this was biomass for R&D, which I'm not sure as advantage is quite the right term for it.  It certainly progressed our research and development, but it was a little bit costly. The other large component was  pond fines, which is very attractive and will be even more attractive going forward as it does not attract the carbon  flow.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We also concluded our turbine upgrade, and I know we're always going on about this. But this has been a very  good program. It's hard putting new technology in old machine, not so old – in existing machinery, I think it's  probably the way to put it. But this has been a fantastic success on time to budget and delivering the performance  and that advantage is going to come even more valuable as we build our biomass generation, because biomass is  substantially more expensive than coal.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And onto our hedge, here you can see the numbers and you can see that we have indeed more than doubled 2013.  substantially bigger biomass generation. We are working hard on developing our trading strategy alongside our  biomass conversion strategy. Yet the core of this is going to be what I said earlier that we will be running biomass  plant. And we will be running coal plant. So we will have a strategy for our bark spread book. And we will have a  strategy for our dark green spread book.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of the markets, well, the power market is still dominated by the gas market, but efficiency is – relative  efficiencies of plants remain very important. I know this is familiar to most, but I think probably I should go  through the top graph because it is very important. What that illustrates – what the top graph illustrates is what  are the margins different coal and gas plants can expect in the context of the current forwards?

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So if you go to the far right what you have is the range of installed plant in the UK. The dark blue is the coal plant,  at the top you have the Drax units, at the bottom you have the least efficient coal plant in the UK that runs at  about 31% efficiency, we run at about 40%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On the – at the light blue you have the same for the gas plant, 58% efficiency for those newly commissioned gas  plant. The last one is just going through commissioning as we speak, and then 42% for the less efficient gas plant.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And if we take the Day Ahead, the first two columns on the left first. What you see is that coal plant are  commanding much more attractive margins than the gas plant. All of the coal plant are running ahead of the gas  plant and some of the gas plant are hardly running if running at all. And you have that shown by the load factors.  If the average coal plant load factor – our load factor is 82%, average coal 55%, gas only 28%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As you go across the forwards and the carbon flow particularly begins to take effect. What you see is an erosion of  some of the benefit of the coal plant relative to the gas plant, but I would note that the high efficiency coal plant  like Drax – or Drax is the only one at the top efficiency will continue to dispatch well ahead of the gas plant.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Apparently, sorry, no actually, our wind capacity now varies from 0 to 6 gigawatts. That is very, very large when  you think the summer overnight demand is only 20 gigawatts. So the system is beginning to have to deal with  quite a material amount of intermittency.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then lastly, we put on a chart for the bark spread for the first time. We've used forecast ROC prices. We've  used the AEA prices, that was the government published report for biomass and we've used the forward biomass  prices – forward power prices. And what you can see is there is a strong correlation between the bark spread and  the power price, which is what you'd expect because biomass prices have been generally stable over the last few  years.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of the gas market, well, Europe is still affected by the impact of Fukushima. Japan still only has two  nuclear plants in operation, a way short of their total capacity. And that has led to continued high price in Asia and  what that means is spot cargos are attracted to Asia, which reduces the flows into Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: UK gas prices remain strong, but I think as always it's interesting to compare the markets. So the bottom two  graphs compare the European benchmark price, which is the dark blue with Henry Hub, which is the red, with the  UK gas price, which is the gray with the coal switching price. And what you can see is actually it's quite interesting  the forwards, there's beginning to be a movement away meeting from the European benchmark price if you

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: It's been an attractive coal market for us recently. The biggest single factor in the coal market probably is U.S.  shale gas because there has been an incredibly large increase in U.S. gas generation and a decrease in U.S. coal  generation. And this has led to U.S. coal production needing to find a home, and so that has led to more exports  from the U.S. and that happens to have coincided with increased exports from Colombia and increased exports  from Australia. So what that has led to is a softening of the market. We're seeing prices in our market, the API2  market fall by 20%, and that market still is relatively soft, very high coal stocks in Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The area which is a little bit more difficult is coal production in the UK. There are number of coal producers in the  UK that are under pressure. This normally for us is a very competitive source of coal. We buy about half of our  coal in the UK. So it is a matter of concern that some of them are facing difficulties.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And finally, earlier this month, we took the first step towards funding our biomass plants when we secured the  commitment to a new £100 million term loan facility. This facility will form an important component of the  funding solution for our plants to transform Drax into a predominantly biomass fuel generator. And I'll go  through this in more detail shortly.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The average achieved price for our electricity sold in the wholesale market is £52 per megawatt hour, down from  £55.30 last year. With 2011 benefiting from earlier forward sales captured at enhanced prices together with higher  power prices on trade placed in the first half of last year, with prices driven up by the gas markets in the  immediate aftermath of the Fukushima disaster. You can see this trend in power prices in the chart.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: But to remind you, we have changed our accounting policy for ROCs to better match the value generated to the  period in which the biomass was [ph] bunched (32:03). But as we barely breakeven at the half of ROC, the new  policy has negligible impact this year, but will have impact going forward into 2013.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Ancillary services, payments to Drax by the grid to support the balancing of the system are £6 million, down from  £8 million last year. And this decrease is a consequence of our high output and load factor. Although running  hardly, there was less opportunity to provide ancillary services to the grid. I should remind you that we do  continue to operate in the balancing mechanism, where we add value to the plant's reliability and flexibility. And  finally, other revenues of £5 million are predominately from the sale of ash and gypsum into the building industry.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, on to cost of sales, which are £613 million, about 5% year-on-year, which includes power buybacks at Drax,  power purchases at Haven, and grid charges in both businesses. And within cost of sales, £455 million related to  fuel and carbon costs. So an increase of 2% year-on-year with higher generation, but lower average fuel costs when  including the cost of carbon.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Average fuel cost excluding carbon is £30.70 per megawatt hour, slightly up from last year, primarily as a result of  fuel mix. However, including carbon, average fuel costs are £33.50 per megawatt hour, down from £34.10 last  year. With the average cost of our purchase carbon requirement down at only £5.90 per tonne compared to £13  per tonne last year. This is a result of the collapsing carbon prices in the second half of 2011, driven by an  anticipated oversupply in Phase II of the EU ETS. And you can see that in the lower chart.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So when all of these factors are taken in aggregate, we delivered a gross margin which was 9% down on last year.  And to reiterate a point made last week, within gross margin, we have taken a loss of £15 million, relative to the  expected profits with coal on additional trials to support an understanding of unit conversion technical data. This  has been invaluable R&D. We have also provided an additional £5 million on the same basis for further trials in  the second half of the year.  On to operating costs. Total operating costs were at £101 million, up £10 million and on track to meet our full year  guidance we gave at the beginning of the year of £205 million. As a result, full year costs will include a year-on- year increase of £20 million as a direct result of the planned double outage in 2012, together with the structure  uplift in business rates charges.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Further full year increases result from R&D investment in biomass. That is construction related to trials which is  not capital in nature. In addition to building our Haven business and after three successive years of holding  underlying cost level, taking some inflation into the underlying cost base.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Capital investment. Asset additions were £90 million in the first six months. So as well as the final installment on  our turbine upgrade project, this includes £70 million for biomass infrastructure. To remind you, we have  commenced construction of biomass fuel delivery, storage and distribution systems by the Drax site. These are  required to support our plans to handle over 50% biomass. That is 7 million to 8 million tonnes a year of this fuel.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: From that, the biomass is transferred into a screening building. And the purpose of that is to remove any debris,  any [indiscernible] (36:43), anything from the fuel that we don't want. So you have clean fuel at that point then  moving into the transportation system. Fuel can go two ways. It can either go bypass the domes, straight into the  transfer tower, or it can drop into the domes themselves.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The fuel that drops into the domes is reclaimed out of the domes into an underground conveyor system by a  system of vibrating floors within the domes. So that shakes the biomass down into the underground conveyor  system. That is then transferred through the conveyor system and up into that transfer tower you see on the  diagram. The transfer tower then moves the biomass into a sampling building which does what it says really. We  take samples of the biomass from that point for technical and regulatory purposes.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The biomass is then transferred into the day silos, those two things near the far right-hand side, for ongoing  transfer then into a pneumatic distribution system. That's effectively a very, very large pipe with compressed air  that blows the biomass then on to the boilers. The real value in that is it manages dust incredibly efficiently.  Because those of you who probably know about biomass would know that dust is your problem with biomass. It's  explosive. It's difficult. It's a fire hazard. And therefore, these sealed units are hugely efficient in moving the  material.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: But then moves on to the boilers through modify mills that pulverizes the biomass and then into the boilers  themselves. We're making modifications to the boilers partly to capture as much heat as we can out of the  biomass. It does burn differently to coal and the heat transfers in slightly different places in the boilers. So  modifications captures the heat efficiently out of the fuel and also to minimize slagging and fouling and other  modifications.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The other thing that we don't show on here is another distribution system that will add further mitigants into the  boiler, again to manage the slagging and fouling issue. And finally, I think just to give a sense of scale, if you look  at those domes with the heads on top, they're around 180 feet in height each. And that compares to something like  I think about 130 feet if you look at the Royal Albert Hall. So that just gives you a sense of the scale of what we're

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And in due course, I'm sure we'll invite you up there to have a look of what we've been doing. So a very significant  physical scale. And including the investment made in the first half, we expect to invest in the region of £170  million progressing this biomass construction project by the end of this year. So, that's within an overall group  capital expenditure of around £200 million for the full year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, although our central plants are now progressively converting full units to Drax not enhanced coal-firing,  we remain confident in the overall scale of the total £650 million to £700 million investment we set out at the  prelims in February. Around half of that is the investment in this downstream infrastructure which is largely on- site that I've just described. The balance being the development of upstream supply chain infrastructure, which is  predominantly overseas pelleting facilities plus any necessary work to ensure the plant is complying for the  Industrial Emissions Directive which comes into play from 2016.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On now to cash and firstly working capital. We did increase coal stocks by 600,000 tonnes in the first half of the  year to stand at 2 million tonnes at the end of June. This coal stock build is linked again to our biomass plants as  we prepare for a rail outage to facilitate plant modifications. However, other positive movements including the  seasonal reduction in receivables have resulted in a small net inflow to cash from working capital and other minor  items of £4 million for the period.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our working capital outflow is probable for the second half of the year as we build biomass stocks ahead of the  first unit conversion in quarter two 2013. Tax cash of £30 million reflects the settlement of our 2011 liability. And  so after other cash movements of capital expenditure and items of equity, the closing cash balance was £241  million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We've also taken the first steps towards funding our biomass plants. And earlier this month, we secured the  commitment to the new £100 million term loan facility with the M&G UK Companies Financing Fund. The facility  is competitively priced with a six to eight-year maturity. In terms of our remaining funding requirements, we  continue to assess a number of options available to us, but with our strong balance sheet and the facility we  secured earlier this month providing us with good foundations.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So in summary then, we delivered solid financial and operating performance in the first half of 2012. And we have  taken advantage of the improvement in trading conditions to strengthen our hedge for 2013 at good margins.  Although of course you know, next year's profits will be impacted by the removal of the free allocation of carbon  we have had in recent years.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: As just covered, we have secured the first commitments of funding our biomass plants with our strong balance  sheet providing a good foundation for the remainder of our funding requirements. And finally as a result of our  solid financial performance in the first half, the interim dividend will be £0.144 per share compared to £0.16 last  year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So I'll now pass you back to Dorothy to conclude.  Dorothy C. Thompson  Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc  So in conclusion, I think you probably now appreciate that there is real depth to our confidence in conversion  strategy. A large part of that depth is the technical work we've done. But it also about the sourcing work we've  done. It's about our confidence now in the grandfathering of the sustainability standards. And it's about what we  see as a well designed policy for a stable biomass market. We also are pleased with our 2012 first half performance  where we had solid profit and good operating performance, and have managed to increase our 2013 hedge of good  spreads.

texts.speaker: Operator

texts.text: I'd just like to point out if you haven't noticed it we've got a new logo. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Onto the main order of the day, so the main themes of our results. Profits, we've delivered in line with  expectations, but as all expected significantly lower. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We've had a very good market conditions and because of those very good market conditions, we've extended our  hedge a little bit for 2013, but we're already very well hedged in 2013. We've made a substantial increase in the  hedge for 2014. We're very pleased with our progress on biomass transformation. Our first converted unit is  operating very well, and our construction on site, major construction on site is on time and to budget.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, we now operate a coal generation business and the biomass generation business. And because of that we're  now going to separate how we report technical performance and showing each of the operations separately.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let's start with the coal business. We had 82% availability that was combination of 7 .6% forced outage rate and a  11.1% planned outage rate. Now, our target, our long-term target for the forced outrage rate is 5%, and I think  most of you know that we arrive at that 5% by extensive benchmarking, get the right balance between good  availability and cost competitiveness. We are above that 5%, and actually we would have been below that 5%, if it  wasn't for the fact that we've had some ash bridges.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The ash bridges are exactly what the name describes, it's going to have a bridge of ash in the boiler and it's large  enough you have to take the boiler off. The reason we had the ash bridges is we've really been pushing the  envelope on low cost, but more technically challenging coals. We now – we push those limits, we now understand  those limits, these ash bridges were a consequence of that, but I think a necessary consequence as we won't be able  to minimize our coal costs. We've now adjusted our buying procedures and actually some of our operational  procedures to get exactly the right balance.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of planned outage, we had our first planned outage during this period. It came in on schedule and  actually, just marginally below budget with very good safety performance. We're now right in our second planned   outage for the year. Our load factor was 7 8%, high load factor shows the good economics of our generation. We  only dispatch when it's economic to do so.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now on to biomass generation, so we took the coal unit off on March 5, 2013. We brought it back on as  a biomass- fuelled unit on April 5, 2013, and I would remind you that this unit is initially fuelled with temporary systems.  These are the mainly the modified co-firing systems. In terms of performance, the output range has been from 250  MW to 585 MW though actually operating on these temporary systems were often constrained to 500 MW or  lower. The efficiency and flexibility is very much what we expected, we're very pleased with both, and what is  particularly pleasing is we had the boiler off, we done extensive inspections and we're confident no slagging, no  fouling, and no corrosion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of availability, we achieved 76% availability, 13% forced outage rate and a 13% planned outrage rate, and  a key part of that planned outage rate was taking the boiler off for these inspections. Our load factor was 57 %, as  you will see from our announcement, this was in line with plan, but if I'm honest we had hoped to beat plan.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: It's always economic to generate from biomass if you have the fuel. We had fuel constraint s during this period.  We'd expected that the reason is we've got very, very limited storage on site, until we get the permanent systems.  And as a result, we're dealing with just in time delivery that is challenging, when we haven't got the final rail  wagons, when we haven't got all our port facilities. This picture will change, it will change as we bring the facilities  on site, once we have the domes available for permanent storage, and once we have our new rail wagons, and once  we have more options for the port. But we're still pleased with the 57%. What I'd like to point you to is the graph.  And what the graph shows you is our dispatch so far this month. And what you can see is we've had a significantly  higher load factor and what you can see also is we're really using that flexibility to maximize value. So, where we  do have constraints, we'll pull down generation in the night to get the higher margins that we would get during the  day.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On to hedging, trading, or hedging. I'd like to start just by reminding you of our trading strategy. We talked about  this at the prelims. We now run two traded books, one is for our coal business and one is for biomass busin ess. In  terms of the biomass business, in terms of the coal business, it's a relatively short-term hedge, and when we hedge  what we do is we sell the power and we match that with the coal and carbon position, so we fix the margin. And we  typically will trade two to three seasons forward. They actually timing of the hedge would depend on the  attractiveness of the spreads in the market, market liquidity and credit availability. So, it's a relatively short -term  hedge.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of biomass, completely different philosophy. It's all about starting with a long-term position and because  it's all about security of biomass supply. So we start with a long-term contract for biomass fuel and what we try  and do is fix as much of the cost as we can around that contract and some of that is about hedging currency  exposures and that notably can also be about hedging freight exposures. Tony is going to talk to you a bit about  the currency exposure hedging. What that does is that pretty well locks in our biomass cost. Some of t hat is  covered by our ROC and LEC income or renewable income. We've only finally fixed the margin when we sell the  power.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And going forward, we're going to give you the power data and we're going to give you for the current year and the  year ahead and that reflects our trading strategy. We're no longer going to provide  the carbon of fuel data. And  there is a very good reason for this. As our biomass generation grows, actually what is our biomass position  becomes more and more sensitive. So, we don't think it's commercially sensitive to put that information in the  public domain. So, we'll provide full power information, but minimal.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc

texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc

texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc

texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now moving onto funding and debt, the chart shows the refinancing work will be completed last year. We secured  the funding we need for the biomass transformation. texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second development in December, we executed a new commodity trading facility. As a reminder, this is an  innovative structure.
