It works by offering  trading counterparties uncut access to the security package available to our senior lenders. Interesting, this facility  has been very strong this year and I'm pleased to say we now have the necessary consensus with our senior lenders  to extend capacity under the line from 600 to 900 megawatts for winter 2014. This again strengthens our business  model by further reducing collateral exposure. And on that point, the steps taken over the last three years to  restructure our business and trading arrangements now enabled Drax to trade very successfully as a sub - investment grade entity.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So summing up, we delivered slowly financial performance in the first half, our balance sheet is strong providing a  robust platform on which to execute our plans. Biomass investments are on track, market forecast recognized the  profits in 2013 will be below recent levels impacted by the increasing cost of carbon, but the significant investment  required over the next two years to raise secure the biomass transformation has the potential on the many  reasonable scenarios to deliver substantial profit and cash growth beyond the investment phase.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Tony. So we'd like to start with sustainability, because it is so important to  actually our biomass strategy.  And as I think most of you know, we have a very well established sustainability policy. And there are two key  components to sustainable biomass. One is that you buy your biomass from a truly sustainable source and what  we mean by that is there is no depletion in the carbon stock. One of the easiest ways to illustrate that is through a  forest.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So we take our biomass from forest whether rate of extraction of fiber from that forest is less than or equal to ratio  of growth of the forest. So what that means is effectively, the forest itself is stable in the amount of fiber or  growing, and that's what we mean by stable source, that's the first key criteria. The second key criteria is that with  the biomass does not have such high bio – carbon cost and in fact we're not delivering savings. And what – to  understand that, you need to measure the carbon cost of the biomass, the full lifecycle analysis from the field of  forest all the way to this furnace. We do that, we're actually in our fifth year of carbon foot-printing of all our  biomass and the biomass we burn delivers at least 80% carbon savings relative to coal. There are other elements  to our sustainability policy but those are the two key components that really make us confident t hat we're  delivering a true renewable to the UK.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We're very pleased that the UK is going to introduce robust sustainability standards and mandatory sustainability  standards. We have been strong supporters of that from the outset. The UK has set the high -line policy for this.  It's now consult – or has been consulting on the detail behind that and we expect publication of their conclusions  imminently.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In parallel, we are actually working with the six other large biomass users in Europe to establish a sustai nability  procurement standard for biomass purchases for use in large electricity generation, and I think that's a very  positive cross-industry initiative.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of wider regulation, very, very busy time, very busy time. The Energy Bill is making its pa ssage through  Parliament and that will be the enabling legislation for electricity market reform. I think the two key areas of  activity on electricity market reform now are the support for new investments and renewables, that's the contract  differences or CFDs and the capacity markets. I thought I'd talk a bit about both.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So effectively the CFDs for converted units will be coterminous and support to the ROC support, that actually is  very important in the context of EU state aid approval because it should make state aid approval more straight  forward. And then third in terms of process, the timetable is that we – that is expecting to publish the final prices  because they've published are only draft in December. They expect the first, the early CDDs to be available in  March, we'll see awards in March, but their effectiveness will be dependent on the necessary approvals stayin g in  place. So the energy bill has to go through its passage in Parliament and be approved and in addition the UK has  to secure EU state aid approval.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So that's the position on the CFDs. As you probably read in the press, a lot of interest in this, there will be 57   applications to apply, you have to get qualified to apply. So 57  applications covering 18 gigawatts, this is not an  automatic ride. I'd really like to impress on you. This is the process and it's not an automatic ride for us or any  other renewable generator. In terms of the capacity market, Drax has been working very closely with industry,  they are now very clear that they were and non-catchy what has been their plan for quite a well, the first auctions  will be in 2014 and that will be for capacity support from 2018 onwards. In the interim, what we have is a  consultation by national grid on capacity support, and that's about demand and supply by response.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the main capacity market development, what we now have clarity is units that rec eive renewable  support will not be eligible for the capacity market. We are hopeful though that we will be able to participated in  it, in an attractive way for our co-units.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: I wanted to talk a bit more about the supply chain. We make – continue to make steady progress in the first six  months. As we said before, we've contracted the biomass we need for the first unit which is now operational. We  now have more than 3 million tonnes contracted for 2014 and 2015 which is the next critical year for us. We hav e  only made one new contract public in this period and that's a contract with the company called Rantec, a U.S.  company, but the contract actually is the Wood Pellets supplies out of Canada. We gave before other key suppliers  and they have a green circle pinnacle and Plum Creek of course Plum Creek is fiber rather than pellets.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Very, very important to success of biomass strategy is the whole supply chain and key part of that is logistics in the  U.K. We are making good progress on the ports, the time 2 million tonne facility is operating well were under  construction of a rail loading facility at Port of Hull, and we will rather ABP well into construction of the new  bespoke 3 million tonne facility that are boarding for us at Port of Immingham. We also are -- pleasing progress  on our biomass wagons, these are being fabricated by WH Davis in Nottingham, quite an important event, there  are the first new wagons on the British railway systems since the early 1990s. So very popular transporters. The  first wagons have been fabricated and actually they are going through accept – or one of them is going through  acceptance testing. At the same time, we've released one that we don't need for that acceptance testing to Y ork  Railway Museum. It's been on display there since the 25th of July. Y ou can see a picture of it there and I suggest  you all go and have a look at this fascinating new wagon in the UK.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, we go onto the U.S. We've concluded our construction contracts for the U.S. Each of the contracts there are  three, one for each facility, fixed price, date certain with performance guarantees. We started construction on the  first pellet plant, which is the Amite facility in Mississippi. We expect to start construction on the second plant in  the autumn and we're staggering this so the disciplines move across and we've just let or started let – how do you  call it, release for activity I suppose the way to put it, construction on the Baton Rouge facility. It did take us  longer than we expected to negotiate these contracts, but we really believe that the importance is to get this right  rather than to rush. That has created a bit of a gap in our biomass supplies. But, we're doing a very good job of  filling those and we're very confident we will do as it is far more important to get this right. So, these set of teams  will now come online in the first half of 2015.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And now let's move onto actually what's happening in the Drax site. We're going to have a very busy and actually  to be honest a very exciting autumn. So, what happens is during – starting from September, we start to  commission the permanent facilities and initially how we fuel the first unit. And what it starts with is the rail  unloading then once the rail unloading is commissioned then we'll start commissioning the b iomass delivery  systems and that's direct delivery of biomass to the boilers. What that will need is further modifications to the  boilers and that's mainly mill conversions. And then finally at the end of the year we commission our first, so we  have a first large permanent storage and when we commission that, we will in one task with more than quadruple  of storage on site for biomass, which release some of those constraints, I was talking about earlier.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So when we get to the end of the year, we expect to start 2015 with this first unit fully supported by the permanent  bespoke facilities. And at that point we'd expect normal output range to be up to 585 megawatt, we'd expect when  we operate at 585 megawatt to have an efficiency drop at 1.3%, all in line with previous guidance. What would take  a little longer to level will be the availability. We'll need to work through this proper operation. So we do expect in  time to deliver an availability in line with our core units. But that will take time. But the activity continues. So we  end 2014 with work ongoing on the direct site with completion of the wagons – the wagon fabrication as well. So  we expect first 50 wagons come into operation by the end of the first quarter, in parallel we would expect the  second dome to come into operation also in the first quarter and then the two subsequent domes in the third  quarter of the year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In the background, what is going to continue is our optimization work and this is about efficiency optimization,  this is about NOx reduction and this is about most importantly almost widening the fuel envelope, so we can burn  some of the lower cost biomass. So, we have to burn over time.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And as we now are well track for the first three units, we're doing initial engineering and the sourcing to see  whether it actually is an attractive opportunity to then convert the  fourth unit. That's the first low cost option.  Second, I think you all are quite familiar with is carbon capture and storage. This is a demonstration CCS plant  430 megawatts that were developing in partnership with our two partners, British Oxygen and Als tom. We will  only go forward with this project with a substantial support from government that's both direct financial support  as well as indirect support with strong contractual support. The actual capsule exposure of the partners is limited  for this project and the next stage of this project is a two-year feasibility study, which for the most part is funded  by government.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of biomass supply, if you remember, our strategy to build pellet plants in port facility in the U.S. was all  about security of biomass supply. It was not about asset ownership and it's always been our intention at an  appropriate time to actually raise third party capital against those facilities to release capital, which we would then  expect to deploy and further strengthening improving our biomass supply and sourcing. So, what we're looking at  is what our options for improving our biomass sourcing in this way relatively low cost, land options for possibly  further pellet notes and looking at port options. This is all very complex  because what we need to do is really  interlink it with our third party supply and what we're aiming at is to have as much biomass as we can through a  selection of pool. So, we can use large ships rather than the smaller ships. So, we're looking at options  on that and  the way we would do it is by releasing capital already invested in the first facilities.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And then finally, possibly most complex, the whole time they have been at Drax, we have not believed the gas  generation presents an attractive opportunity. We've actually looked over the years, a quite number of  opportunities and each time we felt it's not the right opportunity. There is a possibility that this could change and  that is because of the introduction as the capacity market and what is proposed under the capacity market is long- term contracts for capacity for new generation. We think there's a chance and this is really early exploration for us  that we can through using all core competencies get some benefit from this opportunity.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And so, what we're looking at is potentially developing an option to build a new gas plant and what we're really  thinking, the way our thinking is working is we think our market knowledge, our market expertise makes us  particularly well paced to participate in these auctions and put together a deal that might be attractive. And what  that actually means for us is a relatively low cost options we're talking a few million to develop that option what  we're actually do with it, I mean, I need to make it clear that these contracts go to the project not to the sponsor,  varies what it will be the options from realizing the value from that option. Early thinking, but we wanted to make  you know or aware that we've been thinking along these lines very early days.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So some of our results, there you see ours, I think of it as actually sort of scorecard or tracking, but the themes we  started with profits in line with expectation, but lower because of carbon, particularly biomass very much on track.  And lastly, we wanted to tell you we are having a Capital Markets Day on the 17th of October, if you would wish to  join us.

file: DRXL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 29July2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the overall theme, good operations for the first half. But we have, as expected, got reduced profit.  Biggest single factor in that was UK carbon tax. Very good progress on our biomass transformation. You know  now over 20% of our electricity generation is from renewable sources. I would note a much bigger percentage than  the overall share of renewables in UK generation. And we're supplying enough renewable power to fuel 2 million  households, not insignificant.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, two key cardinal rules whenever we buy biomass. One, there is no depletion of carbon  stock. That means in the terms of forest fiber that actually we take it from forest where the rate of harvest is no  greater than the rate of growth of that forest. The second is that it is truly a low carbon fuel. And, no doubt, we  have to measure all our biomass from the point of origin right the way through to the supply chain, the point of  delivery at Drax. And we only buy biomass that delivers major carbon savings.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We're now in the seventh year of having our leading edge or actually world-leading sustainability policy. We only  buy biomass that is compliant with that policy and we audit our compliance with a third-party, PwC.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We look forward to the introduction of mandatory standards in the UK which we now expect to be in place in  2015, but we are also working with the six largest biomass generators in Europe to create pan-European  standards. These will be voluntary standards and what we're introducing is certification systems to support those  standards. And we hope that to be in place by the end of the year and certainly next year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of operations performance, another good period. The coal performance, 85% availability, slightly lower  forced outage rate than last year. I think you all know that what we target long-term is a 5% forced outage rate, but  we'd expect it to be above or below in any year. 82% load factor. That means we were running 95% of the time  we're available, again, reflects the highly competitive position of our coal units.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Biomass. I have to take you back in history here. It was only at the end of last year that we actually connected all  the bespoke systems for our converted unit. So that means that this period is the first time we're reporting on a  converted unit that is really running on properly scoped systems.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: During the period, we also commissioned our second high biomass unit. This is an enhanced co-firing unit that  burns 85% or more biomass. We're still in commissioning of that unit. It's complicated by the fact that we're using  the unit or have used the unit for our low NOx trials, to trial our low NOx solution for the Industrial Emissions  Directive or IED. We're also using it actually for fuel trials.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So the combined performance of our converted unit and our enhanced co-firing unit are the statistics we show  here. 76% availability. I would note that it looks like a rather high planned outage rate and the reason for that is it  covers all the works for conversion. It also covers the planned works for the IED or NOx emission trials. We also  continue to make steady and good progress with our unit optimization.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of market trading, gosh, we're still suffering from this mild, windy winter, overhang of gas, you'll have  seen gas prices coming off and that having a direct effect on power prices. In recent weeks, what we've seen is  really quite a movement in the merit order. So what I thought I'd show here is the spread. So the dark blue is the  coal plant. It goes from the most efficient to the least efficient. The light blue is the gas plant, again, most efficient  to least efficient. And what we've done is we've shown their spread in the context of today's market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So the first two bars, obviously, our ahead market. And what you see is efficient gas plant is now commanding a  higher spread than low-efficient coal plant, and that means that it's dispatching ahead of it. That actually moved  quite quickly. So if you look at winter 2014, what you see is coal is well ahead of all gas plant in the merit order at  today's prices.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Industrial Emissions Directive, I was going to keep this quite simple. I suggest you ask Peter some questions in  question time about the technology, particularly ZoloBOSS which is pictured here. But what really happened to us  in this last six months is we spent, I think, the best part of five years identifying the optimal technical solution.  And optimal is about good technical performance and low cost. And what is very pleasing is the trials this first six  months have actually demonstrated that we can now have a high confidence that our solution is going to deliver.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So now we've moved on towards implementing it. And what is it going to deliver? The first thing it's going to  deliver is full compliance with the Industrial Emissions Directive. It's 2020 and beyond, so that's beyond the  transitional national plan. We're going to – we believe that our coal units and our biomass units will be  unconstrained with this solution. We will maintain the flexibility of both our coal units and our biomass units, and  Tony is going to talk a bit more about that because it's a real profit opportunity for us. And we will have a  reasonable flexibility on how we source our coal. So it's a good solution for us. It's low cost and we are now  confident it's going to deliver what we need to be a good generator with both biomass and coal.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The other project we're making good progress on is carbon capture and storage. We started really at the beginning  of this year, the full feasibility. It should take two years and it's progressing very well. Some of the details or a high  level view of the project is given in this slide. I think the real message from us is we think this is really good  technology. We believe we will only invest if it's an attractive investment for us and we expect it to be. And  attractive means there's a good risk return/reward for us and for government. But also, we think it can create  some really interesting strategic options for Drax in the future, so we're very encouraged by this. Again, questions  to Peter. He's the champion of this one.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So now on to regulation, our area of somewhat complexity at the moment. I thought I'd go through it unit by unit  by phases because it really has become quite a maze. And I wanted to start with what we are confident in. We are  confident that we're going to convert three units to biomass. We're also confident that our coal units will continue  to sell power into the wholesale and retail market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The units we convert to biomass will – at a minimum, two will be supported by the Renewables Obligation at 1.0  ROC and one will be supported by an investment contract, and that investment contract is subject to State Aid  clearance, and I'm going to cover that a bit later on. So our base case is quite clear. Two units supported by 1.0  ROC, one unit with an investment contract, and three coal units earning revenue in today's market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So let's look at the upside because our job is to try and improve on that base case. Let's talk of the coal units first.  So we were somewhat surprised when the government changed its view on the eligibility of second unit  conversion. And as I believe you all know, we decided to challenge that decision. And the way you challenge  government when they've made a final decision is through the courts. The court found in our favor in July.  Subsequently, the government issued us with an investment contract, conditional on the successful final outcome  of our legal challenge because they're appealing it and also conditional on State Aid clearance. So for that second  unit conversion, there is still a chance that we'll have the benefit of an investment contract with all the associated  protection of a private law contract and revenue certainty.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second upside for our biomass unit actually comes through our fourth unit conversion. And we're making  good progress on both our construction plans for that unit conversion as well as our sourcing plan. And we're  targeting this conversion to become operational in 2016/2017. What we don't know is how the unit conversion will  be supported.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: There are two ways they could be supported, either by the renewables obligation or by a CfD. You will have seen  that, last week, the government announced its first budget for the enduring CfDs, which will be awarded this year,  a very, very limited budget. And in the context of that limited budget, it's not surprising that there was no budget  for unit conversions. Unit conversions are, by definition, very large renewable projects. Look at the fact that we  already are producing a very significant percentage of the UK's renewable power.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So at this point, I'd like to just pause and talk about State Aid approval. Any investment contract we have, or CfDs  indeed, will require specific project State Aid approval. The UK needed to secure both State Aid approval for the  whole CfD regime. That's the investment contract or early CfDs, as well as the enduring CfDs and specific project  approvals for each of the large generation projects.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Last week, the EU announced the first set of approvals under that State Aid clearance. And I wanted to make three  points about that announcement. Firstly, the EU approved the whole CfD regime. And it really is to DECC's credit,  their view of that regime. So what EU said, and I was going to quote it word for word, is that it's a fine example of  how to promote decarbonization of the economy with market-based support mechanisms. True praise for a well  thought-out scheme.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second part within that approval is it's very clear that the EU thinks it's appropriate and right to support  biomass conversions with CfD mechanisms. So there is no policy objection for supporting biomass conversion.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The third part of that approval, which is of interest, is the EU approved all the offshore wind projects in the early  investment contract, but none of the biomass projects, neither the conversion nor the dedicated biomass. This is  exactly what we expected. We've always given guidance that we expected approval to come in the second half of  the year rather than the first half of the year, and that's because, with offshore wind projects, there are an awful lot  of them across the EU. Not the case for biomass. So we'll require further work because it's a more specialized  technology and actually, to be honest, a newer technology at the moment for conversions. So there is  encouragement, however, in terms of the approval of the offshore wind, and that's actually the EU's view of that  whole CD or investment contract award process.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And again, I want to quote that the selection of projects was done in an open, transparent, competitive and non- discriminatory way. That's really important because that's about what's a fair process is the right process. And the  fact they have such a good view of the offshore wind is encouraging for the approval of our converted unit  investment contract because they went through an identical process.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, let's move on to the coal upside. So in terms of the coal, the first upside is the capacity market. When the  early designs came through on the capacity market, we decided it was not a good opportunity for Drax, and there  were two reasons. The first reason was the penalty risk was too high and the penalties themselves were too high  and the second was the revenue opportunity was not good enough to reflect that penalty risk. So, actually, for a  long time, we were very pessimistic about this market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: That has changed. I think the government has listened well to industry, recognizes the importance of having good  security supply and we now believe this represents a very attractive – or an attractive opportunity. We don't know  about pricing yet for our coal unit and we expect to bid our coal unit into the auction later this year. The other  upside is, of course, CCS, our strategic project for the future.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, how does this regulation then transfer into how we actually deliver? In my mind, this year, it's all about  laying the foundations. It's about laying the foundations to be able truly to convert three units of Drax and actually  being prepared with the execution plan to convert the fourth unit. So what we expect to do is complete the  construction of the base works at Drax, leaving just the connections outstanding. We will have 6 million tonnes of  port capacity and rail capacity available and we'll build further on that the full three units. We have already  finalized our IED solution and we are now implementing it.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So what about 2015? Well, 2015 could be a very busy year. First thing is, if we haven't converted the second unit  this year, we will do it in 2016 and we'll do it because we have an investment contract, and the commissioning  window for that investment contract starts in April 2015. We will complete our US construction and we will start  supplying our own wood pellets to our own port through our second converted unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And in addition to that, we may well choose to commission our third unit. That is all about the timing of the  biomass supply, our progress on biomass contracting which has been somewhat disrupted recently. I'll cover that  in a minute. So the third unit conversion under its investment contract, the commissioning window is from July  2015 through to July 2016. What we expect to – we would hope to also be is start being underway with the work to  convert our fourth unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Then in terms of biomass fuel supply, we maintain our cost guidance of £8.10 a gigajoule. That does include our  very extensive foreign hedging – foreign exchange hedging program, been in place for quite some time now. We've  made really good progress with near-term volumes. But to be honest, this is about short-term disruption in  demand with some of our European competitors. So we now have over 5 million tonnes of biomass procured for  the current ROC year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We continue to evaluate the increase in our own pellet production. This will be subject to funding capacity and  actually the credit rating of Drax and maybe as I go onto that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The projects that are under construction, we're very pleased. They're on schedule to budget. Just to remind you,  the reason why we like having our own pellet plant, there's three main reasons. Firstly, it gives us the opportunity  to optimize the technical specifications of the pellet. Secondly, it's all about timely and reliable supply. And  thirdly, and this is the really strategic part, is it enables us to consolidate biomass supplies both from our own  supplies and third parties through single port into larger ships. And that's all about lower cost of the port, lower  cost of the shipping and, most importantly, increase – a lower carbon footprint. So very good on all accounts.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We're also working on the same concept on the East Coast, a port or ports that will be fueled by a combination of  Drax pellet plants and third-party supplies, ports get larger volumes through a single port. So that's where we are  on biomass supplies.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And then before I hand over to Tony, I just wanted to stop for a second because I think sometimes you can get so  focused on business delivery that you risk forgetting why you do things. We embarked on this biomass  transformation strategy because we truly believe it's good for the climate, good for the consumer and good for the  UK. And I'd like to make it absolutely – again, I'm going to quote, that the government thinks the same.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So the government's position on biomass is clear as stated just last week in DECC's Stakeholder Bulletin. What  DECC said is there is a clear role for biomass conversion as part of the renewable energy mix. There's no mystery  why this is the case because there are three strengths to biomass. The first is that we are significant in delivering  carbon savings. So with four units operating at Drax, we'll be saving 16 million tonnes of carbon compared to our  coal operations. And I think you all know we're a very strategic asset needed as a generator in the UK for quite  some time to come.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of consumer benefits, we are a very cost effective renewable. And a recent National Audit Office enquiry  into the whole investment contract allocation process concluded that biomass generation has half the support of  offshore wind, really cost-effective renewable, but we're cost-effective with benefit, and those benefits is we're  flexible, we can meet changes in demand and supply, and we are reliable. And I think that the bottom graph paints  the perfect picture. What that shows is from the month of January, the output of Drax, the gray, nice, reliable,  consistent; and the output of wind, very erratic. We've got an unusual climate.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Clearly, we remain in the heart of the transitional period with regulatory hurdles still to clear. But our investment  plans are well on track, which fundamentally strengthen the business. And in this area, we continue to evaluate  further biomass supply chain investment opportunities which can add value to the group.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The financial foundations of the business remain robust and the balance sheet is in good shape, although EBITDA  at £102 million for the first half is 15% down year-on-year where we have absorbed an additional £35 million of  carbon tax of the UK's carbon price support mechanism, and this leads to underlying earnings per share of  £0.094.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to depreciation which is £42 million at the half-year, up year-on-year with increased investment. Depreciation  charges will continue to increase over time as we commission and operate our new biomass facilities. And for  2014, the charge will be in the range of £80 million to £85 million which was guidance given to you at our prelims.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Net finance costs of £15 million reflect the biomass funding work. With the new facilities we have in place and  fully drawn this year, we expect underlying finance costs for the full year to be in the region of £30 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Total net power generated is 12.9 terawatt hours, a small increase on last year's level of 12.6 terawatt hours. And  the average achieved price for our electricity sold in the wholesale market is £51.30 per megawatt hour, also  slightly up on last year, with the timing of our hedges providing some protection from recent power weaknesses.  Revenue also includes sales of ROCs and LECs up year-on-year, as you'd expect. Another income which is broadly  similar to last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So then on to cost of sales which at £1.1 billion are up 50% year-on-year. And within cost of sales, £351 million  related to fuel costs with average fuel costs of £27.20 per megawatt hour, which is up 5% on last year. Remember,  though, this is a net number which includes the benefits of ROCs generated through burning biomass.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: As I said before here, the accounting is a little complex, so a full reconciliation of our fuel and ROC reporting is in  the appendix in your pack. But the principle itself is straightforward, to match the cost to the benefit of burning  biomass.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to carbon, as already noted, the carbon tax has driven down – driven our gross margin down significantly with  a charge of £49 million this year compared to £14 million last year. The carbon tax rate increased from £5 per  tonne to £10 per tonne in April this year and it was payable only from the second quarter in 2013.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On the positive side, increased biomass generation has pushed down our carbon allowance purchases by over 1.6  million tonnes. That, combined with the reduction of cost of carbon allowances this year, has partially offset the  impact of the higher UK carbon tax.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And moving down the table, the cost of power purchase has more than doubled to £350 million in the first half,  and this could well have an increased importance for the group. The growing level of intermittent generation in  the UK is providing valuable opportunities to capitalize on the flexibility of the Drax plant. And I'll come on to  more of this in a moment.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to operating costs, total costs of £102 million are £6 million up year-on-year. And our full year guidance  remains unchanged at £220 million, which includes higher operating cost in our US business where we will begin  to commission the new pellet plants and the port facility later this year. This is partly offset by lower maintenance  costs at the power station where we have one unit with a major planned outage in 2014 compared to two last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to capital investment, total capital costs for the biomass transformation remain on schedule and budget. Asset  additions in the first half were £123 million, which includes £88 million for the biomass transformation. And  looking forward, the chart on the right here illustrates our CapEx outlook for the next three years. The biomass  transformation for the three units should be completed in 2015.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Looking a little further out, we continue to evaluate further additional biomass supply chain investments  including further expansion of our own pellet production where we target double-digit returns on investment, but  as importantly, these assets strengthen our supply chain, securing high-quality pellets with efficient and cost- effective logistics.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So back to this year, for the full-year, we expect total capital expenditures to be in the region of £200 million,  although it could be marginally ahead of this if we sign up and accelerate the investment in a third pellet plant into  this year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So both Dorothy and I have mentioned unit flexibility, which is one of the key strengths of our power station. As a  result of the investments we are making, this is true of both coal and biomass units. And we expect it to command  increasing value going forward.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: To explain, as the wind generation increases, so too is the level of inflexible plants on the grid. Installed wind  capacity is already at around 12 gigawatts. And National Grid estimate that by the end of the decade, the level of  wind capacity will be similar to the level of overnight demand in the summer. That's around 20 gigawatts which  will make it harder and harder for the grid to balance the electricity system supply and demand. This will provide  flexible power plants such as Drax with the opportunity to add incremental margin through balancing and other  systems support activities. And we've already seen a high level of balancing support this year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So I'll use a recent example to illustrate the opportunity. The chart shows the output of one of our units through  the nights on June 5 this year. Well in advance of that day, we had forward sold, at full load, baseload power,  which is the gray line, at a typical market price for the overnight period. And the day itself, gas prices had fallen  and the wind speeds had increased, driving up wind generation on the system, forcing down the overnight power  price. And with that price, below our marginal cost of production, we can make more money by not generating. So  we reduced output to the minimum stable load of 200 megawatts, which is the blue line, and brought back the  power needed to cover our contractual position. And in doing so, we added the first piece of incremental margin.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In facing a high volume of inflexible wind generation on the system, National Grid had to reposition some of the  flexible part in order to provide the requisite level of balancing reserve and response. And thanks to the flexibility  of our own plant, we were asked by the Grid to increase the unit load to 300 megawatts. That's the green line. And  in doing so, we were able to sell the incremental power to them at an average price well in excess even of the initial  forward baseload sale. And that further enhanced the profitability.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So in that one night, through providing these services, we were able to capture incremental margin of some  £100,000 above our originally contracted position across the plant. But, clearly, that's not huge in isolation, but  over the course of a year, these activities can make a meaning contribution to profitability. And to emphasize, our  biomass units are just as flexible as our coal units. And we do believe these opportunities could very well increase  as we progress through this decade.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So back to the results and on to cash flows and starting with working capital with a total net inflow with £64  million. Now, there are two significant components to this and firstly biomass stocks. With the commissioning of  both our enhanced coal-firing unit and the new on-site dome storage, stocks have increased by 300,000 tonnes to  600,000 tonnes so far this year, leading to an outflow of £39 million. And to note, a good proportion of these  stocks do still remain offsite held in temporary facilities close to Drax.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The remaining working capital inflow, some £103 million, is driven by an increase in creditors and accruals, most  notably for carbon and the ROC obligation at Haven. The ROC and LEC outflow represents an increase in the  balance sheet value of ROCs and LECs generated so far this year, less the value of those assets sold during the  period.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And you can also see from the chart where we have now drawn in full the new £100 million loan facility completed  in May with M&G. This loan is available to fund the development of a third pellet plant if we proceed with that  investment.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So summing up, we had good operations in the first half, but profits were down year-on-year due to the increasing  cost of the UK carbon tax. Our balance sheet remains in good shape, providing a robust platform from which to  complete the transformation of the three units, which we expect to do by 2016.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And more broadly, the capital we are investing is delivering a much stronger business for our shareholders, a  business which will be well placed to benefit from structural changes in the UK generating capacity. And we are  evaluating further investments in the biomass supply chain, which could have the potential to create significant  incremental value for the group.
