texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Before we go into the presentation, I would like to just say a few words about the  change to the Climate Change Levy. As you all know, our business is about long-term investment in large capital  projects. And the UK needs this investment, because we need reliable power to be provided across the country  24/7.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Over the – over the past years, there has been increasing intervention in our sector by government and regulation.  And for this reason, to make investments with confidence, we need to be confident that government will keep to  its commitments. The Climate Change Levy was set up in 2001. Exemption was provided for renewable generators  to Levy Exemption Certificates or LECs. The value of a LEC was set and it was increased by inflation every year for  the subsequent 15 years.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: During that period, the government made a number of changes to both medium and the level of support for new  investments in renewable generation. We had the ROC banding review. We had FiT reviews. We had the  introduction of the CfD program. For every single one of those reviews, the government considered that the LEC  income was a material income stream to the new investor in renewable generations, and they used it to offset part  of the support that would otherwise be required under a ROC or a FiT or a CfD support. It's that constant and  consistent treatment of the revenue stream from the LECs that actually gave the whole industry a very, very big  shock when the budget is renounced that there will be no exemption from August this year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So we've got three parts for the review, and I'm going to start with operations and business review or rather an  overview of that. So in terms of pure operations, we've actually had a very, very good first six months – very high  generation from Drax Power, a dramatic increase or a significant increase in our renewable generation through  biomass, strong steady sales growth from Haven delivering our sales targets. And I'm very pleased to say we  produce large quantities of pellets in the U.S. and slip the ship from here to the UK.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, I would remind you that biomass is only a good renewable if it is sourced responsibly  and sustainably. There are two very, very important criteria for this. One is that there is no depletion of carbon  stock. So in terms of the forest, what it means is that the fiber, the rate of extraction of fiber from that forest is no  greater or less than the rate of growth of the forest. So the forest itself is not diminished.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The second important criteria is that it delivers real carbon savings. And to deliver that, the carbon cost from  point of origin all the way to the power station must be low enough to deliver both of those savings. We are now in  the eighth year of buying biomass in accordance with our world leading, and really is world leading, sustainability  policy. And that requires that we meet both those two criteria and other criteria such as protecting biodiversity. All  of our biomass that we buy is compliant with this policy, and our compliance is audited by PWC.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We look forward to the introduction of mandatory sustainability standards by the UK government, and we expect  that to come in later this year. And it's been a very busy six months for the sustainable biomass partnership. This  is the partnership of the seven large biomass generators in Europe. We've been working together with  stakeholders to develop a common sustainability standard and a certification process for those standards. We  launched that standard in Brussels this year and now we're into full implementation. We expect the first  certifications by the end of the year, and the standard has been designed so that all biomass that is certified by  SBP will be compliant with the UK mandatory standards. And as you might expect, we've already started the  certification process for our pellet plants in Louisiana and Mississippi.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving on to generation. As I said at the beginning, very high generation. And you can see that from the top chart.  Close to 40% of our generation was from biomass, very much higher than the same period last year where it was  23%. We actually have converted a third unit to high biomass. That came online at the beginning of July and it will  burn 85%-plus of biomass. It's what's termed an enhanced co-firing unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Soon after we brought that unit online with high biomass, we took off our first converted unit for its first major  overhaul as a biomass unit. So for us, this was a very important point in our biomass journey, because it's the first  time we've done a major overhaul and therefore can do a really detailed inspection. So I'm pleased to say that now  we're a few weeks in, that that's going very well, no concerns, no surprises, which is actually very good news.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving onto fuel procurement, there is quite a change in our fuel sourcing for coal. In recent years, we've been  buying 40%-plus UK coal. We now expect that to fall dramatically. It's partly due to quite a large scale of closure of  coal production facilities or mining facilities in the UK, and that's about the viability of the UK mines. But it's also  because we are increasing our procurement of low NOx coals in preparation for the introduction or the  effectiveness of the industrial emissions directive, which comes into effect in January 1 next year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In biomass, we've seen very unusual market conditions in the near-term market for biomass. We are very well  contracted for 2015, and that reflects the fact that there's been a very healthy spot market. The main reason for  this is there was a very warm winter in Continental Europe. It was also warm in the UK, but we use very little  biomass for heating. But in Continental Europe, a lot of biomass is used for heating. By way of example, in  Germany, 15% of their heating comes from biomass. So if you have a warm winter, what that can lead is to surplus  biomass on the market, and we've taken advantage of that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We're less well covered for forward purchases, and this is all about fueling the third unit. That does require new  investments in pellet plants, and we're looking forward to the EU approving the CfD to underpin the investors'  confidence in those, and making those investments. We are in contract negotiations, and the pricing was, same for  those contracts, is very similar to previous pricing, so there is no change to our guidance on biomass costs.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of commodity markets, as you know, we've had continued weak commodity markets. UK Power price  continues to be set by gas prices and gas prices are low. The chart, I think you will all understand the chart on the  bottom right. It shows the merit order of the fossil fuel plant, which dispatched after nuclear renewables.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are effectively the top of the blue bars, the most efficient coal plant in the UK. As you can see, we're top of the  merit order for the fossil fuel plant and not only the prompt order forward, but at much weakened spreads  compared to prior years.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of regulation, I think you've had my piece on the Climate Change Levy, so I won't go on about that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We look forward to engaging with the EU once they have concluded the Phase I investigation. I'm sure most of  you, if not all of you, saw that last week, DECC published its conclusion to grandfathering consultation. As  expected, no new conversions will – to biomass from coal or gas, if you chose to do that, will be grandfathered  from – if the conversions happened after December 2014. There is one exception and that's projects that has been  granted an early CfD and are going through a state-aid process. So that, of course, covers our third converted unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So what does it mean for Drax? Well, our first two units were converted before December 2014 and are fully  protected by grandfathering. If we should have to or choose to convert our third unit under the RO, it will be  protected. If we do further units, the strong signal from DECC is that they prefer further units to be supported by  CfD rather than by the RO. And whether we will have an opportunity to be converted under a CfD will depend  what happens to the CfD program going forward. And we don't expect to have further guidance on that until the  autumn.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of the capacity market, National Grid's winter outlook had what I think is quite a striking statistic. If you  exclude the supplemental balancing reserve and equivalent the demand side management, the D-rated capacity  margin this winter is a mere 1%. It rises to 5% if you include both those reserves. But I would remind you if the  government or if National Grid needs to use those reserves, the spot price for power goes to £3,000 per megawatt  hour, a price never seen in the UK.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of the capacity market auction, the rules are now out. We are reviewing our strategy and we will pre- qualify in August. What is notable about the market is the level of capacity required in this auction is significantly  lower. It's about 45 gigawatts. But there is a good reason for that, because about 6 gigawatts one contracts under  the first auction for new build and it's expected that that capacity will be online indeed operating for every year by  the time we get to the delivery period for the second auction.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving onto Haven, I will remind you again that Haven is all about a credit efficient route to market for our  power. Very good period for Haven, 7 terawatt hours of sales and more importantly 13 terawatt hours contracted  for the next 12 months. We've made particularly good progress, so pleasing progress with our large contractor –  our large contracts to industrial and commercial users. Some of you may have seen the publicity or the  announcements around our award of the Thames Water contract, this contract will generate around £0.5 billion  of sales over its five years, and we are very pleased to2 go on the contract.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Haven has been hit by the change in the Climate Change Levy. We are reviewing what our strategy is for the  business in our sales strategy, but it's not going to be a very quick review. And the reason is that this has changed  the competitive dynamics in the market and we need to take time to assess what is going to be our competitors'  response to work out what our own response should be. We can't do it in isolation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of Drax Biomass, as I said at the beginning, we have shipped large quantities. So into a bit more detail. So  the project is on budget and generally on schedule, but one of our pellet plants, Amite, is slightly delayed.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our port facility is fully commercial and operating very well. In terms of the pellet plants, large quantity is  produced. We actually produced our first pellet at the start of the year. And for both pellet plants, we've actually  shift the quantities from the pellet plants all the way through to the power plant and burnt them in the boilers.  And that's very important because now we are confident that whole of that supply chain works.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Morehouse pellet plant, fully commercial. Amite was hit by some really bad weather events during construction,  and we've been trying to catch-up, but it turns out that we didn't quite manage it. But actually, we expect to do our  performance test, the final commercial operation either this week or next. We'll see how it goes, but it certainly  will be commercial by the end of August.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are continuing to evaluate the third or additional self-supply options. The third pellet plant is at the top of our  list on this. We probably would do this in partnership with others, and our lead project or our lead idea is to have  another pellet plant that will feed through Baton Rouge, all about this concentration and efficiency of the supply  chain.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Thank you, Dorothy, and good morning, everyone. Before going to the numbers, I wanted to make a couple of  opening comments. We set out the detail of our biomass investments in 2012. As we drove towards the conclusion  of our three-unit conversion plans, I'm pleased to confirm that we remain on schedule and within budget to  deliver this commitment. Throughout this major transformation, we've delivered good operational performance,  supplying around 8% of the country's power requirements and making a major contribution to UK electricity  system stability. We're supplying increasing levels of biomass generation, and we'll save 12 million tonnes of  carbon per annum when the transformation is complete. In doing so, we're creating a stronger business,  protecting the group from the cost of that carbon and it's these factors which have underpinned our financial  performance.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: I also wanted to pick up here on our U.S. business, Drax Biomass. As Dorothy said, the Gulf Cluster Investments  are making good progress as they all move towards full commercial operations. The 2015 financial performance  for this business is very sensitive to the ramp up of pellet production. Given the profile of commissioning, it is  likely that EBITDA for Drax Biomass will be a small loss this year. But we do then expect the business to move  into profit in 2016 with a full year of operations.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Gross profit in Drax Power with £228 million in the first half, up £30 million on last year. This is driven by good  operations, with increased biomass generation protecting the business from the increasing costs of the UK carbon  tax. In terms of the detail, I thought it would be helpful to bridge gross profit with this waterfall chart, but I would  note that the full tabular analysis is included in the appendix.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Net power revenue, which includes sales to Haven as well as the revenue and costs associated with power  purchases, increased by £40 million in 2015. This comprised higher net power sales of 14 terawatt hours at an  achieved power price of £49.90 per megawatt hour this year, compared to 12.9 terawatt hours at £51 in 2014.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: As I said, good operating performance has been the platform for very high levels of generation. We did experience  a small decrease in achieved power prices, but the timing of our hedges has provided some protection from the  significant fall in the markets at the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: I should also point out that we have captured good incremental value in the front and balancing electricity market  so far this year. We said before that with more intermittent and inflexible generation on the UK system, we expect  the flexibility of Drax Power Station to become an increasingly important profit driver for the group. That  certainly has been the case in the first half. And we do expect to say more on this in the future.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: On to net fuel cost, which comprise the cost of coal and biomass plus the value of ROC and LEC support earned in  the period. The accounting here is a little complex, so a full reconciliation of our ROC reporting is included in the  appendix. But the principle is straight forward: matching the cost with the benefit of burning biomass.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: The average cost of coal and biomass was £41 per megawatt hour in H1, compared to £37.50 last year, reflecting  the increased level of biomass in the mix. And the average value of renewable support generated was £46.40 per  megawatt hour compared to £44.10 per megawatt hour in H1 2014, which reflects one of our units running as an  enhanced co-firing unit last year, and therefore, earning lower ROC support during that period. So with the  increased levels of biomass generation, together these items drive a decrease in net fuel costs of £19 million  compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: On to carbon. As I said, carbon continues to have a negative impact on our gross margin. The carbon tax rate  increased from £10 per tonne to £18 per tonne in April 2015, resulting in a charge of £75 million in the first half,  which is an increase of £26 million on H1 2014. On the positive side, increased biomass generation has pushed  down our carbon allowances purchases by more than 1 million tonnes, which combined with the reduction in the  cost of these allowances, has partially offset the impact of the higher UK carbon tax charge.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Finally, other movements include an increase in grid charges, another consequence of the growing level of  intermittent generation on the UK system. So as a result, when all of these factors are taken in aggregate,  generation gross margin was £228 million, up 15% on last year.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Turning to gross profit at Haven Power. Haven delivered net sales volume of 6.8 terawatt hours, up over 20%  year-on-year at an average price of power sold of £92.30 per megawatt hour, compared to £91.60 per megawatt  hour in 2014. This results in revenues of £629 million, up a £116 million on the prior period.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In cost of sales, power purchases were £353 million, an increase of £48 million following the growth in sales  volume, but also net of a fall in the average price paid for power to £51.90 per megawatt hour, down from £54.40  per megawatt hour last year, reflecting the changes in the wholesale market over the period.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Grid charges in our retail business include the costs of distribution, transmission, and system balancing. And  renewable support costs include the cost of meeting our responsibilities under the RO and small-scale feed-in  tariffs. The rates for most of these third-party charges has increased again in 2015, driven partially by the increase  in intermittent generation on the UK system.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: From the back of these increased rates and our sales growth, grid charges and renewable support costs have  together increased by £66 million to £268 million this year, an increase of 33%. And it is worth noting here that  total third-party costs now represent over 40% of the cost of supply.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving on to capital investment. Our biomass transformation is now well advanced, and our capital investment  plans remain firmly on track. The chart draws together the transformation investments, which include the three- unit conversions, U.S. investments and IED compliance. You can see that by the end of 2014, we had invested  around £550 million. To complete the project, there is further investment to come of approximately £130 million  in the 2015 to 2017 window, being largely implementation of our IED solution as well as finishing the Gulf Cluster  facilities in the U.S. this year.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: So we will complete the transformation within in our original cost guidance of £650 million to £700 million. And I  would like to note here that in doing so, we have absorbed significant additional expenditure that was not  included in the original guidance, such as our investment in a fleet of biomass rail wagons, which are now an  integral component of cost-effective UK logistics.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Back to the detail of the first half. Total asset additions were £54 million. Looking forward, we still expect total  capital expenditure for 2015, including transformation CapEx, to be in the region of £150 million. In total, this is  unchanged from the guidance that we gave earlier in the year. However, it does include some acceleration, about  £5 million of our IED-related investments, balanced with opportunities we have identified to reduce CapEx in  other areas. Our testing has shown that some IED technology can be installed with limited offload time, which will  allow us to complete the installation earlier than originally anticipated.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Overall, this year's forecast comprises around £95 million for the transformation, £30 million for biomass unit  enhancement, which we have previously discussed with you, and the balance for ongoing maintenance CapEx.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Our reduction in coal stocks of 900,000 tonnes, drives an inflow of around £60 million from inventory levels.  With coal stocks still at 1.3 million tonnes, and only three units now operating on coal, we do expect further  reductions into 2016. Second, seasonal reduction in trade receivables, reflecting lower sales in the summer,  leading to an inflow of approximately £65 million. And finally, the balance and inflow of around £40 million is  driven by an increase in creditors and accruals, including the ROC obligation at Haven.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Under the transitional rules associated with the CCL change, we expect substantially all of the LEC value to be  recovered through sales of levy exempt power generated before July 31. And looking at the ROC balance, as you  know, we can't face a meaningful delay between generating ROCs on the one hand and receiving the related cash  compensation from ROC sales on the other.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We also have a commodity trading line, which allows Drax to transact prescribed volumes of dark green spread  trades without the requirement to post collateral. These facilities are rated BB+ by S&P and are all components of  the work we've done over the last few years to structure our business, financing, and trading arrangements to  operate successfully as a sub-investment grade entity.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: So summing up, against a backdrop of weak commodity prices and regulatory disappointments, we have delivered  solid financial performance in the first half, underpinned by good operations, supported by the biomass  conversions, and with the value of Drax Power Stations flexibility becoming increasingly evident.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We've also seen good cash flow generation. The balance sheet is strong with net debt of £40 million in cash and  £282 million on hand at June 30. However, our outlook for the second half is weaker: the impact of the LEC  removal; full effect of the increased carbon tax; the first biomass unit's major planned outage, which offsets some  of the benefit of our third biomass unit operating in H2; and weaker spreads recognizing that there is less value in  the forward hedge today than at the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Michael Scott
texts.profession: Finance Director & Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: And finally, looking further ahead, 2016 will benefit from completing the transformation. We will be operating  three biomass units, and we will have a full year of production at our U.S. pellet plants.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Michael. Okay. So I wanted to say a little bit about the UK generation system, I suppose it's the way to  put it. You're all very familiar with the government's three policy objectives: affordability, security of supply, and  carbon abatement, climate change, lower carbon, whichever way to put it. And policies aimed at getting the right  balance between these objectives have led to quite a dramatic change in our electricity system. And that's shown in  the top chart on the right.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the case of security of supply, it's not just about having enough power to meet demand on a cold winter's day.  And in the following slide, I'm going to explain that better.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the case of climate change, it's not just about EU's 2020 targets. It's also about the UK's climate change  budgets.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And in the case of affordability, where we're talking about supported technologies, which are low carbon  technologies, it's not just about the direct cost of that support because an awful lot of our costs are socialized  through actually grid costs.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Some of you will recall, we did a similar study last year. We compared biomass through our generating units with  the typical offshore wind farm. And we looked at what the cost comparison in 2020 or the savings or not savings  in 2020 by identical capacity of three units and the same capacity wind. And what that showed was a saving of $3  billion of biomass compared to offshore wind. So I think you understand why we think it's very important that  whole cost of different technologies is understood rather than just direct support.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving on to more about security of supply. There we go. As I said, security of supply, it's not just about having  enough power to meet demand on a cold winter's day. It's about having a stable system. And there are four key  services that National Grid requires for a stable system. And all of them are provided by generators within the  electricity system.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The first is reserve. And there are two ways. You have to provide and ease reserve. Firstly, it needs to have power  stations that can come quickly up in generation. If there is an imbalance of supply and demand, it means that  there's a shortage of power. And then you need the exact opposite as well, power stations that can quickly drop  generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Then you have voltage control. This is all about an ability to push power around the system to deliver where it's  really needed.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The cost of supporting the system through these services is going up. And there are two very good reasons for this.  One, we have a much tighter capacity margin. So quite simply, there's less spared generation capacity around to  provide these services. But the second is the increase in intermittent generation. And as we all know, that's going  to be increased, go even higher, as we go forward.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So report about biomass within the whole system. I don't know if any of you read. There are reconsultation. But  there's a quote in there, that I'd like to give you. The government remains committed to sustainable biomass  generation, which is an important part of the UK's energy mix and plays a central, transitional role in our strategy  to de-carbonize the electricity grid.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Recent actions make one question government support for biomass conversions. Removal of the LEC support.  Removal of grandfathering. What this reflects is very tight budget control by DECC and also real confidence that  the projects they have on their plan will actually be delivered, be it nuclear, be it new renewables.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We questioned that. Like any projects, some succeed, some don't. And we would remind government that there's  real value to additional biomass generation. We've already been through why it's good for the UK system, very  good for the environment. Drax is now Europe's largest decarburization project. Major, major carbon savings. We  just saved 20 million tonnes of carbon.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's good for the forests. We do help keep these forests alive. We buy this low-grade fiber. And that's critical to the  economics of some forests. Nowhere do I think this is more obvious than in our plants in Louisiana and  Mississippi, where there have been closures of pellet mills, of food processing plants which has really, really left  these forests without market. And a forest that doesn't get enough revenue, actually becomes a defeated forest. So  overall good for the forest and were good for the consumers. I just went on over just what – as I just said.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So we believe, this is going to become more and more evident. And of course we believe, we've got significant more  greater role we could play to the benefit of the UK's consumer, the electricity system, and the environment.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: To sum up, it was a good first six months from an operational point of view. I can't say it's been the most pleasant  time thereafter. The biomass transformation, a big project launched many years ago that we're coming close to  completion on time and on budget.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But I would say that we need to preserve that option value because I think the changes that are going to happen in  the UK generation mix will mean that it comes more and more apparent the true strategic value of Drax and the  value we can deliver to the UK system.

file: DRXL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 26July2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Generation business, we hit 20% of UK renewable power, now producing 70% of our electricity from  renewable sources, which is quite a change from over a decade ago. And the other thing which is quite notable  about this period is we have this continuing effect of a change in our revenue profile, and really the reducing of  our dependency on commodity prices. And Will is going to go through that in more detail when he goes through  his section.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And our production of compressed wood pellets at Drax Biomass has been growing going very well, the plants  and the port are operating well. So, now we're looking at options for growth for that business. So start as always  with safety and sustainability. Safety and sustainability are absolutely at the center of our operating philosophy.  Very good period for safety, well into the top quartile, safety performance and this good performance is across the  business in the UK and the USA.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, I think the absolute, most important thing is responsible sourcing of our fuel for biomass  generation. I'm going to put here again, a bit like a lecture, I'm sorry, but they are very important, is our five key  principles. We never work in countries that lack regulation. We never cause deforestation. We never source from  areas that are protected. We only take wood from working forests that grow back and stay as forests and all we  require that all our suppliers go through very tough screening and sustainability orders that are independently  audited.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We adhere very strictly to our sustainability policy and what that ensures is that we deliver true significant carbon  savings when we generate with biomass. One of the things that has been very positive over this period is the  progress of the sustainable biomass partnership. If you recall, this is the group of major biomass generators, who  have clubbed together to create a certification system for sustainable biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We now have over 100 applicants for that certification, the vast majority of biomass producers, but it also includes  traders and end-users, essentially so we have certified – people certified in the whole chain of custody from origin  to plug. And that's a very, very high take up and it's very clear that SBP is actually going to be the certification of  choice with the vast majority of this market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The other pleasing development in this period and in terms of sustainability is our reduction in nitrous oxide  emissions, which went down 60% compared to the same period last year. Two main reasons for this, one is the  increase in biomass generation, but also we have invested in state-of-the-art NOx abatement technology, so 60%  reduction.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: There are three key factors that are driving this, particularly in the last year-and-a-half. One is the growth of  renewable generation, and very specifically intermittent renewable generation. The second is the closure of  significant amounts of large coal plant, and that was large generating plant that was reliable and flexible and that's  what's important, the reliability and the flexibility. What that means is, we're now well pass the tipping point on the  intermittent renewables. They're no longer a minor factor in the market that can just be absorbed by the whole  market. They have become a significant determinant in some key market dynamics, and I thought I'd go through  some of these.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So first let's go through wholesale market pricing. Two – sorry, that's the third factor, the third factor is the  introduction of capacity markets. So we've had increased renewables, closure of reliable flexible plant and the  introduction of capacity markets. So, what does that mean for the wholesale price. The two factors on the  wholesale price are firstly the renewable. What you have is you have subsidized renewable generation  substituting for fossil fuel generation and what that – defect that has is in depressing wholesale market prices.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The second factor you have is the capacity markets, whether that be the strategic balancing reserve or the  capacity market itself and what that reduces is scarcity pricing in the market. But as we've seen this depressing  effect on the wholesale market, what we've seen grow is the market opportunity for system support, and that is a  real opportunity for a generator like Drax bid through biomass and coal, we are reliable and flexible as a  generator.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, the first effect, it actually comes back to the capacity market. So, the capacity market is all about securing  power for cold winter day. We're an active participant of that market and what it gives you is secure fixed price  income for being there to generate when the power is needed. The second effect is the wider effect on the system  and these are the parts of the market that are actually administrated by National Grid. And before I go into that  detail, I'd like to talk a bit or illustrate a bit what's happening with the market dynamics and that's what this chart  shows you.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, what we have on the chart is the blue line is maximum potential inflexible generation and we consider that to  be inflexible renewables, particularly in intermittent renewable, wind, nuclear and CHP. So, maximum potential  inflexible generation. The green is when you add solar to that maximum potential. The grey shaded area is a  typical profile of demand on a summer's day, starting at midnight and ending at midnight. The grey dotted line is  the same for winter's day.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, I draw your attention to a summer period from midnight to 7 am and what you will see is that the summer  overnight demand in that period is lower than the potential inflexible generation. Now, we all know an electricity  market cannot be out of balance. We also know that an electricity market has to have generating plant on the  system that can flex up and down to reflect changes in supply, be it changing wind or a plant dropping off the  system, but also changes in demand.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We also know that electricity in the market needs a relatively stable frequency and it needs reactive power. It  needs many things for system stability, and this is the challenge, but also the income opportunity of keeping the  system stable now we have more inflexible plant on the system. So, over the six months, two notable  developments. Firstly, the reduction in the providers of Ancillary Services through the closure of that large coal  plant that I mentioned earlier. The second is that what we're seeing is much more volatility in the balancing market  with prices going from minus £100 to plus £500 per megawatt hour over the period. This represents an  opportunity for any generating like – generating plant like Drax but, of course, we think we're the best, but it's truly  flexible and truly reliable.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's not surprising that National Grid has now come out saying that within four years, they expect this market  opportunity to double from £1 billion to £2 billion. I was trying to think of a way to scale this for you, and I'm going  to give you a very inaccurate comparison, but it gives a sense. Imagine, in electricity system, which was supplied  purely by fossil fuel and that fossil fuel only spread somewhere between £5 megawatt hour and £10 megawatt  hour. Then the size of that spread income over a year for the whole market will be about £2 billion, about the  same size that we are now talking about is the potential for the system support market. But commodities are also  relevant, so we thought to say just a little bit about what we're seeing in the commodity markets, which do remain  challenging albeit that they have improved over the period.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Gas is driving our power price and the gas market future is uncertain because we haven't yet reached peak  supply. We don't expect that to 2017-2018, but what we're seeing in today's market is a broad balance between  supply and demand for global gas including LNG, and what that has meant is that there is some tension in the UK  market. And that's because there are concerns about the disruption of the operation [indiscernible] (10:16) and  also of course we've had quite substantial coal-to-gas switching.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The UK power price is very much driven of gas. It's the key determinant most of the periods in the market. But  what we are saying is the market is now pricing concerns on capacities. So, it's assuming that less efficient gas  plant is going to run over the winter adding that extra premium in the market for winter spreads, which is attractive  for us, of course.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Over to operations. As I said, we are now providing 20% to the UK electricity. Our biomass units run very well  over the period. Right now, we have one down of a major maintenance. What we've been particularly pleased by  is the operation of our supply chain. This is very important because biomass is not a liquid fuel. So, having an  efficient and effective supply chain is very important, and when we design the supply chain, we did design in  optionality. So, we could be absolutely confident that we have the biomass at the plant when and where required  and I'm pleased to say we've actually had absolutely no generation disruption as a result of not sufficient biomass.  So, our supply chain is working very well.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We continue work on our future biomass technology and as we continuously say, we stand ready to convert  further biomass units, which we think would be a good part of the future solution to the UK energy sector. Coal,  our work on coal this period has been very much about what should be the right strategy. We said we're going to  work on this at the prelims and it has been our focus.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have designed a revised coal strategy. It's been driven partly by that dispatch I showed you. I mean, we don't  expect much running of our coal units on a pure economic dispatch basis through the summer albeit they will  operate the system support purposes. What we want to do is, cut the right cost base for those units in this revised  world. So, what we've decided to do is reduce some of our operational costs of those units. And specifically for  one of the three units, we're going to reduce the scale of our maintenance when we do our planned maintenance  next year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, we have a restricted outage, not a full outage. This will mean that we'll be less willing to use the unit in the  uneconomic summer period, but we will be available and maintain good availability through the winter period  meeting our obligations under our already contracted capacity contracts.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: During the period, what we've actually seen is incredible flexibility of these coal units. They've been too shifting a  lot. They've been ramping up a lot, and this is all responding to the need in the market. And the other thing, you  will have seen is we announced a new Ancillary Service contract with National Grid in the period for Black Start.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Drax Biomass, now a major producer of compressed wood pellets. The plants in the quarter, as I've said, have  been operating well, very much in line with plan. Our focus here actually is on optimization, we're really very  fortunate, because we are in the whole part – every part of the supply chain, literally from fiber as we say to [ph]  to plug.(14:35)

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And that gives us a unique optimization opportunity, cost quality. And what we're now doing is effectively playing  tunes with that plant and how we work at the power station to get that to the most efficient level possible. It's a  learning experience that I'm sure we're going to benefit from it, as we develop further. What we're also doing is  looking at the potential to grow this business. Ideally, we'd like 20% to 25% of our biomass to be self-supply.  There are real benefits to self-supply in this business. And that would mean roughly a doubling of our current  capacity.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, regulatory. My gosh, what a change in six months. Brexit, new government and to some degree a stalling of  energy policy. We see a new government as a positive for us. Biomass is the most affordable, renewable and  large scale for the consumer. We are flexible, we are reliable, and as you've seen from the earlier slides, this is  becoming a more and more important role to be played in the electricity system. So, we look forward to making  the case for biomass and future unit conversions to the new government.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We really would wish to participate in future auctions for CfDs. And in this context we were very pleased that the  competitions and market authority actually in their recent investigation concluded that future auctions should be  on a technology neutral basis. We believe biomass would be highly competitive, especially if it was a truly fair  auction and based on the whole – the final cost for the consumer.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The one thing we are awaiting eagerly after more than 18 months is the publication of the government's work on  whole system costs. As we've said before we think this will clearly demonstrate that biomass is the most  affordable large scale renewable for the consumer.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of coal, I think this is one of the areas where we're seeing a delay in strategy. We still await publication of  the consultation on coal closure by 2025. This will be challenging to achieve it. We are reflecting in our own  operating regime what we should do if that is the conclusion of the consultation. But, I do think the challenge is  how do you ensure security of the supply and close the balance of the coal fleet in the UK. And with that, I'd like to  hand over to Will.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The decline was the result of lower power prices and the impact of the loss of Levy Exemption Certificates. While  our profitability was poor, several things happened in the first half that improved our performance. First, as the UK  power system changes in the fundamental ways Dorothy has described, we are well-positioned to support the  grid, earning growing income streams from these services.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Second, as part of our strategic shift to biomass, we have diversified both upstream and downstream, and these  initiatives are starting to positively impact profitability. And finally, initiatives to reposition our cost base for this  new environment and to monetize our working capital are both showing good results.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We expect our performance in the second half of the year to reflect an improved operating environment as power  prices have increased, more fundamentally the next stage in our evolution will begin with the approval of the CfD  contract by the European Commission, which we expect in the autumn.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And as I will discuss later, this will form an important part of a significant change in our business from being  fundamentally dependent on the wholesale power price to one with a greater contracted and higher quality  income streams.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We recovered a significant portion of that loss margin through increased Ancillary Services revenue, £14 million,  reflecting our National Grid contract. Improvements in margins at our U.S. biomass business and at Haven, an  additional £14 million and reduced operating costs, £2 million. We expect all of these factors to contribute in the  second half of the year as well. However, those upsides will be offset by the impact of our major planned outage  program.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As Dorothy has described, the changes in the UK power markets are making short-term pricing significantly more  volatile. The chart shows the movement in balancing market prices since the start of the year, with an increasing  level of volatility associated with intermittent generation, and the closure of thermal plants. We can take  advantage of these trends, quickly coming on the system when prices are high, and buying back power when  prices are low; it is our flexibility that allows us to do so.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And as other coal stations close, we are one of the diminishing number of plants that can do this. And to that end  in the first half of 2016, our coal units generated around £25 million of revenue through the balancing market.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Going forward, the exact level of opportunity depends upon the weather, and so, it's difficult to predict precisely,  but we do see this as a fundamental change in the generation market which combined with more onerous penalty  pricing when the market is short of power will create greater opportunities for flexible and responsive generators  to support this system and add value.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As our markets are changing, so our sources of revenue are changing as well as our risk profile. And I'd like to  spend some time going through that. Dark green spreads are low, so coal margins from forward power sales  contribute less to earnings than in the past. In view of this weakness, we now focus these units on operations in  the short-term markets and on the provision of Ancillary Services where we see greater opportunities to capture  value.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Given the low forward curve and therefore the reduced downside risk, we have a limited hedge on our coal units,  allowing us to benefit from increases in power prices. And with the addition of advantage coals, we were able to  enhance margins, whilst at the same time reduce load, means lower stock requirements, providing further  opportunities for balance sheet efficiency. In short, the risk on the coal unit is very much to the upside.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On our ROC units, over the next few years, the same is true. We have long-term five-year to 10-year fixed  formula biomass contracts in place with a rolling five-year FX hedge, providing a strong degree of stability to  biomass costs. And to the extent that there is liquidity in the power markets, typically three seasons to four  seasons out, we sell forward the power from these units. Combined with the certainty of one ROC per megawatt  hour, we are able to achieve good visibility of earnings over the next couple of years. At the same time, we  employ gas hedges as a proxy for forward power. Gas is highly correlated to UK power prices, but has greater  liquidity. As such, these trades allow us to extend the duration of our hedging, whilst retaining upside to a tighter  power market.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In short, the earnings on our ROC units are largely fixed through 2017. So, again similar to coal, risk should be to  the upside. This change in our earnings profile is reinforced by the award of the CfD, which will provide a fixed  margin for the third biomass unit, all of which results in improved quality of earnings with greater visibility and  reduced commodity risk, whilst retaining upside to power price improvements.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: I do want to include a note of caution, which is that our fundamental operating risk still remains. So, to fulfill this  plan, we need to operate the coal units flexibly and all of our units reliably. This regime does add greater strength  to our units, which today we have been able to manage well.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For Drax, the changes in the UK energy market offer opportunities to broaden and grow our earnings by  accessing a range of more secure contract driven revenues. At the same time, we will become less commodity  price dependent, while our hedging strategy has allowed us to retain exposure to a potentially tightening UK  market. The two pie charts provide a sense of how things are developing from the pre-biomass environment,  where earnings were predominantly driven by dark green spreads to a future environment with more earnings  diversification, growth and reduced volatility.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let me run through those in some detail. Like coal, our ROC units are exposed to the power market. And as such,  I have presented them in the chart as spread-based earnings. That being said, we are well hedged, as I already  mentioned for the next year or so.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: With regards to the other non-commodity earnings shown in green, those include first the CfD, which provides  fixed price support and excellent cash flow predictability. Second, Ancillary Services, Drax has always been a  provider of Ancillary Services and is well placed to support National Grid and delivering these increasingly  important and viable services, as evidenced by the contract we recently received.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As we've always done, we will continue to control our cost base tightly and look for savings, which we expect to  deliver in two ways. First, as Dorothy has explained, we are looking closely at our running strategy for coal and  this is helping us reduce cost. One good example of that is the plan for a reduced outage on one of our units next  year. We are changing to retain the benefits of flexibility and reliability, whilst reducing our cost base due to the  lower level of running time expected on those units in the market. And secondly, we are implementing a lean  management approach.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Secondly, as we complete the conversion to Biomass and run our core coal units less frequently, given the  prevailing economics, our coal stock will reduce. For example, if we were to assume a 500,000-tonne reduction,  then taking into account the cost of coal and carbon, the working capital benefit would be somewhere again in the  region of £35 million.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to capital investment, our Biomass transformation is now approaching completion and our capital  investment plans remain firmly on track. The remaining investment comes largely from the completion of our  Industrial Emissions Directive Solution. Specifically in the first half, total asset additions were £38 million, which is  in line with our plans.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the full year, we expect investment to be in the region of £80 million to £100 million, in line with our previous  guidance. And that's made up of IED compliance, the biomass unit enhancement program, which began in 2014  and ongoing plant maintenance CapEx.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Regarding our financing, there are no changes to the position that we outlined in February. We don't often  comment on our mark-to-market as those announced do not flow through our underlying earnings. That being  said, the size of the movement, £163 million in the first half was very large, I wanted to mention it. The movement  reflects the benefit of our having hedged our biomass purchases, which are made in U.S. dollars, Euros and  Canadian dollars into Pounds over the next five years. By way of example, our U.S. dollar hedges are in the  $150-plus range, compared to post-Brexit spot rate, which is well below that level.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, to wrap up, first half financial performance was significantly weaker than last year, due to the challenging  commodity price environment and the loss of LECs. However, we have been able to partially offset the impact by  good operational performance, with increased biomass generation, growing Ancillary Services revenues, activity  in the short-term balancing markets, improving profitability at both ends of the supply chain and changes to the  management of our cost base, reflecting the new environment we're operating in.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So with the receipt of the CfD, our Biomass transformation will be complete and Drax will be entering a new era.  Looking further ahead, we're creating a stronger more resilient business with increased opportunities across the  group. We have positioned ourselves well for the changes we're seeing in the UK energy market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, I thought I'd conclude just to follow up on what Will was saying. Think about the future opportunities for Drax.  In terms of our compressed wood pellet business, now well established and what we're looking at is growth  opportunities there both, self supply and supply to third-parties. And biomass generation at Drax, we recognize  and we know that we are a very good part of the solution for the UK and we stand ready and are enthusiastic to  convert other units.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, Andy Koss, I think, known to most of you or, Director in-charge of Drax Power Generation Business. Then we  have Matthew Rivers, Director of Corporate Services responsible for our communications, sustainability and  regulation. And then we have Peter Bennell, who is our director in charge of retail. Peter is really the champion of  taking Haven and from what was a very small part of the group to becoming a very significant part of the group.
