texts.text: We increased meter points year-on-year by over 9% to almost 390,000. Our renewable energy proposition is  doing well, as almost 60% of our sales are now renewable.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: It will enable us to continue scaling the business and offering innovative solutions to customers in a smart meter  world. Finally, we are seeing growing interest from our larger I&C customers for energy services. This is starting  with demand side response, which we can help them provide the grid. Our approach to this market will be very  much customer-led. And we are starting to create the capability to provide the solutions that customers are  looking for.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Good morning everyone. Will has given you a good summary of the Group's performance and I'll now go through  the numbers. Financial highlights, EBITDA of £102 million was lower versus the first half of 2017. I'll come onto  the detail of this shortly. This principally reflects two specific outages in the Generation business offset by growth  in Pellet Production and the B2B Energy Supply.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to the detail of the income statement. Revenue growth principally reflects the acquisition of Opus  Energy and renewable support. I will come on the components of EBITDA in the next slide, but below this figure;  firstly, a charge of £84 million for depreciation and amortization, down £6 million year-on-year. This excludes a  charge of £27 million in relation to coal-specific assets following commencements of work to convert the fourth  biomass unit.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: I'll come on to cash in more detail, which summarize the balance sheet is strong with net debt of £366 million. And  this reflects healthy cash generation from our core operations and working capital inflows. Our operating cash  conversion excluding working capital improvements has been over 65% for the last two years. And this will  continue to increase as the Energy Supply and Pellet Production businesses contributes increasingly to the  EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Okay. I thought it would be helpful here to do a bridge in the first half of 2017 to the first half of 2018. This is the  graph at the top of the slide here. I'll also give you a sense of the key drivers for the remainder of 2018. And these  are the bullet points at the bottom of the slide. So, if we go to the waterfall diagram at the top, Power Generation  was low due to three areas. Firstly, biomass generation where we had two biomass outages in the first quarter.  The first of these was a fire at our biomass rail unloading facilities at the end of 2007, which extended into  January and restricted biomass operations on two ROC units. The second was a non-biomass-related generator  outage in February, again, on one of the ROC units.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Secondly, ancillary services where we received the low level of system support which reflects a specific one year  ancillary service agreement, the provision of Black Start services between April 2016 and March 2017. And lastly  here, a reduction in coal operations reflecting the continued challenging market for coal operations in the UK. In  the U.S., Pellet Production has been strong, increasing volumes of wood pellets produced and sold by 80%,  driving revenue growth and EBITDA of £10 million versus the £4million loss in the first half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, Energy Supply now our meaningful and growing part of the group's earning profile. So revenues increased  from £0.9 billion to £1.1 billion and reported EBITDA of £16 million in line with expectations and this is inclusive of  an increase in bad debt reflecting more challenging operating environment for some customers and the impact of  a tight gas supply during the exceptionally cold weather we experienced in the first quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, central costs have reduced and this reflects tight cooperate cost management consistent with a cost base of  around £30 million for the full year. With regard to other, this is principally the elimination of intra-group balances  related to biomass cargos between the Pellet Production and Generation businesses at the balance sheet [ph]  base (00:15:52).

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, moving to the bottom half of this slide and the outlook for the rest of 2018, where we expect generation to  benefit from improved biomass availability versus the first half. Stronger margins and optimized biomass  generation with the commissioning of the fourth biomass unit, in addition to the start of T-4 capacity payments for  coal.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Given that strong contracted position in place for power sales, we do not expect further value from the improved  commodity environment in 2018, although this does not provide a benefit – sorry, this does provide a benefit in  the future years.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In Pellet Production, we expect growing volumes of pellets from LaSalle and savings from the reallocation of our  offices in Monroe and with a closer operational focus, the opportunity for further reductions in cost per tonne of  pellets produced.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, net cash flow, an area where we remain strongly focused. Small improvement in working capital reflects a  number of things: firstly, a reduction in inventories due to this lower biomass operations in the first quarter of the  year; low receivables due to seasonally low summer sales and an increase in payables reflecting a new corporate  procurement facility; last, increased ROCs held for sale which is typically higher in the first half of the year given  the nature of the compliance period.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to investment, total asset additions in the first six months were £46 million, with our expectations for  the full year remaining unchanged at £100 million to £110 million. This includes £50 million of maintenance and  £30 million associated with the development of the fourth biomass unit conversion.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The balance being focused investment and improvement projects which will support growth and deliver attractive  returns. Just to give a few examples of these is, related to enhancement of our generation assets where we know  that modest improvements to efficiency would deliver fast payback, continued developments of our B2B Energy  Supply IT platform, which we expect to support growth and reduced our costs to customers. And as a part of our  aim to reduce long-term biomass cost, we expect to invest £15 million in a rail spur at LaSalle Bioenergy allowing  us to move pellets cargoes to our Baton Rouge export facility by rail rather than truck.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Once operational, this investment will deliver operational efficiencies and reduce carbon footprint and economies  of scale leading to lower biomass costs and attractive return on capital, more from Will on this shortly. And in  Pellet Production, we continue to target our self-supply capacity of 30%, either organically or through acquisition.  And to that end, we remain alert to sector opportunities.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We have further strengthened our balance sheet with financial structures to support growth. And at the same  time, implemented opportunities to improve operations and profitability, reduce costs and CapEx and optimize the  use of working capital. Through these measures we have put in place the framework to allow us to develop a  strategy for flexible low-carbon growth, aligned with the UK's energy needs, whilst delivering attractive returns to  shareholders.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Den. Okay. So let me just talk a little bit about the delivering the strategies. So, the UK is transforming  to a low-carbon economy. Greenhouse gas emissions are down by 43% compared to 1990, but more needs to be  done to achieve the government's target of 80% reduction by 2050. While much of that will be done in industry,  transport and heat, there's still more to be done in power.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We expect that renewables and nuclear will be 75% of the UK's generation mix in the long-term. They generated  about 50% of the UK's power last year. The other 25% will still need to come from large scale spinning plants,  largely gas but also biomass and other things like pump storage. Coal will soon be off the system.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: This type of generation will earn significant returns not just in the energy market, but from the value of flexibility.  And we see significant opportunities for us in this area. Higher power prices, as well as increasing competence in  the value of flexibility are making gas plants more attractive. And some have begun new projects on that basis.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The capacity market has yet to clear at levels that would incentivize a significant amount of new gas. We continue  to be convinced that it will, but are not sure that the changes made so far by the government will be sufficient to  do so.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Investing in gas is a priority for us, as we believe Drax has a key role to play in providing lower carbon generation  and system support in the UK. This is very much consistent with our purpose. We also believe that we can earn  sustainable and attractive returns for shareholders in this area.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second area is biomass. The conversion of Unit 4 is an excellent project for us and for the system, as we will  now be able to support the system when it needs it the most and importantly, support it with renewable  generation.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In addition, we are working hard to reduce the cost of biomass generation. This is focused on reducing the cost of  our own Pellet Production in the first instance. Because as you know, we procure most of our pellets from third  parties, with contracts that tend to increase in cost over time. Now, while we still have a lot of work to do and there  are many variables outside of our control, fundamentally, I do believe that we have every opportunity to make  biomass economic without subsidy. And I'll talk more about that in a minute.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We will also go into these topics in quite a bit more detail at our Capital Markets Day at the Power Station  [indiscernible] (00:26:25). I'd also like to say a quick word about Carbon Capture. So we have renewed our  interest in that area. We believe it will be a key part of a solution to climate change. That being said, several  things have changed and make us more optimistic that there may be a route through to doing so in a viable way.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: First, the government has reinvigorated its efforts and has called for the UK to achieve carbon neutrality and has  made funding available to see how CCS can help contribute to that. They have also sponsored work to define the  infrastructure, business and regulatory model to enable that. We are closely involved in that process which we  find promising.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Secondly, new technology is becoming available that may make Carbon Capture more affordable. We're trialing  several of those technologies at the Power Station now. And while the work is early, it's again promising. And  finally, there is increasing talk not only of storing carbon, but using it. And ultimately, that could make the model  for carbon capture significantly more interesting. And we are looking at opportunities in those areas as well.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Many of our strategic initiatives as you know are geared towards enabling a coal-free future. And they are  progressing well. The Unit 4 conversion is on track and we expect it to return to service as a biomass unit later  this summer.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We continue to progress the options to build four open cycles and we'll again enter two of those in the capacity  auctions early next year. Our coal-to-gas repowering project has had its planning application accepted by the  Planning Inspectorate. And if all goes to plan, we will be ready to begin building in late 2019.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, we are investing small amounts of capital about £400,000 in Carbon Capture as well as working with the  government to support their efforts in that area. Just a quick word to reiterate the case for the fourth unit  conversion. The capital cost is relatively low. It will cost us about £30 million to convert the unit. And this is  because we are reusing a significant portion of our coal firing infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, overall, this means that generation will only be marginally higher than it was with three biomass units, but we  should be able to achieve higher prices by operating three units when the system needs it most as opposed to  two units all the time.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: By way of illustration, you can see from the chart that peak winter prices are substantially higher than those in the  summer and to the extent that we're now running more in the winter as opposed to on average across the year,  we again should be able achieve higher prices. Finally, having three units available for ROCs also helps us  manage our supply chain and effectively provides insurance against unplanned outages.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Let me provide a little bit more color on how we think we can reduce the cost of our own wood pellets. There's  four areas that we're exploring. The first major one is reducing the cost of feedstock by using more residues and  also over time expanding our fuel envelope to things that go beyond wood pellets.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our Hunt Forest Products is a good example of how we're using more residues and I'll talk that through in a  minute. The second area is improving our logistics and overall processes. And the LaSalle rail spur investment  again is a good example, I'm going to discuss shortly.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The third area is improving plant performance, either performance at the power station. And we are signing an  agreement with Siemens to upgrade our turbines and this will increase their efficiency effectively reducing the  cost of biomass generated power.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And finally, we'll be looking at using technology. So we're exploring ways that we might be able to increase the  yield of our feedstock effectively using technology. Let me tell you how the Hunt Forest Products deal works. So,  they wanted to build more sawmills in the U.S. They make most of their money from selling lumber and the  finished product but residues as in bark, chips and dry shavings are also [ph] an insignificant (00:31:09) source of  value for them.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: If they haven't committed offtake, it clearly helps them with the economics of building a new plant. So the deal that  we've done with them is effectively to sell them some lands adjacent to our biomass pellet plant in LaSalle. That's  again, that's not [ph] an insignificant (00:31:26) part of the economics here.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: But more importantly, we have a long-term offtake agreement with them for the residues, again, at quite attractive  prices, given the long-term nature of the contract. But also given the fact that there's no transport cost i.e. the  pellets or the – sorry, the residues are effectively adjacent to our plants.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And this allows us to change the way that we make pellets. Again, this is very much similar to the dry shavings  projects that we've discussed before. But anyway, we don't need to use the wood yard. As you can see on the  bottom of the chart there, you don't need the chipper and for some of the feedstock, you don't need to use the  dryer.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So effectively, if we build a truck dump and some silos and then add pelleting capacity, we can increase the  capacity at LaSalle and again significantly lower cost than what it would have cost to build initially. And we'll be  looking at doing more of these. We think we can probably do this also at our other two plants.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Secondly, let me tell you about the LaSalle rail spur and again, this is not a complicated investment. We currently  truck our pellets from LaSalle to Baton Rouge. By building the rail spur, we can access the intercity rail  infrastructure, which on a per tonne basis, significantly lower cost than trucking.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We're investing about $15 million, the project should be operational next year and it should save us more than  $10 a tonne. So, given we'll be shipping 0.5 million tonnes a year or more from LaSalle as we grow, the payback  is quite quick and the returns are very attractive.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Before concluding, I wanted to remind everyone of our ambitions for 2025. We believe we can increase our  EBITDA to £425 million in 2025. And we have many different projects underway to help us achieve that. The first,  the growth in our pellet business and the associated reduction in the cost of those pellets, if we can reduce our  costs to a point where biomass is viable without subsidy, that will have a significant impact on that £425 million,  not only in 2025 but beyond.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And secondly, the growth in our B2B Energy Supply business. Third, our open cycle projects and again forth, the  repowering. And our increasing competence in being able to deliver those earnings are fundamentally supporting  our board's decision to announce a £56 million dividend for 2018.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, in summary, we are making a lot of progress as a group. Our pellet business is producing well and costs are  decreasing. Our B2B Energy Supply business is also growing nicely. Our Generation business while it had a  difficult first quarter is well set up for the full year and our new projects are coming along well. So, while EBITDA  was lower in the first half of the year than it was last year, our expectations for the full year remain unchanged.

The business is well positioned for the future with a  robust capital structure, good expansion potential for direct supply through Haven and our  dedicated biomass business is progressing well.

An important focus of 2009 that continues into 2010 is this program of process engineering  improvement, which basically enables us to deliver improved performance at a lower cost.

texts.text: So, what does that mean in terms of spreads? As you think of Drax going forward, you really need to think between those two spreads, and to be  honest, it also has to be the extended peak in the overnight and then initially we think of the whole  equation because we’re no longer a simple baseload-running plant.

The reason why the sales are so  high is that the products that are really liquid in the forward markets are the baseload power  products. And so what we tend to do is we tend to oversell baseload power, and then as we get  closer in on the year, we buyback the overnights and create the shape. So, what we expect is to  actually be selling some – buying back some of the power we’ve already sold. And Tony is going to  take you through the full detail of how we did that in 2009.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: So, if I could quickly take you through the markets, what we have not included here is a slide on  carbon, because we really thought there was a limited update beyond the carbon update we gave  in the interm results in the summer. In terms of power, we have seen a continued reduction in  power demand at least at the high-voltage grid in 2009. What we’re now looking at is across the  two years since the recession really bit is about a 7% reduction in demand. What the top graph  shows is for 2008 – 2007, ‘08, ‘09 weather-adjusted demand and that’s where you can see very  clearly the reduction in demand.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Some of the reduction is – or the bulk of reduction about Drax is driven by the recession. But there  are two other factors that are coming into play. This is at the high voltage grid what we do have is  more embedded generation particularly onshore wind at the low voltage grid so that does reduce  some of the requirement to the high voltage grid and we are making progress. I don’t think quite as  much as we will wish, but we’re making progress in the U.K. with energy efficiency.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: There is substantial new capacity on the system. The wind capacity has now reached about 4  gigawatts. We believe there is about 1.7 gigawatts currently under construction. I know you all are  aware there’s also a substantial need, gas generation capacity 2.2 gigawatts is already on line and  during the course of this year, we expect some further 3.3 gigawatts to be commissioned. The  system is beginning to be very tight, eventually some of 2010 while illustrated by our frequency  response, so I mean tight in terms of support, increased incidences, more reliability of nuclear  generation, it does mean that there is more need of flexibility.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive

texts.text: We did put in this special graph a picture of what can happen with wind. I should practice this by  saying that wind is good for the U.K. It’s very cheap margin across generation. So, it’s good for the  U.K, but it also does require backup power. These – the bottom chart illustrates very clearly that the  backup power is going to be very, very important sometimes at critical times. So the fat lines are  wind generation and the top line is average wind load, the orange bottom line is the wind load on  the peak demand day this winter. The mountains, the blue mountain is classic or is average  demand profile and the orange mountain, however, or red mountain is the demand profile in the  peak demand day this winter. I know there is much reported in the press, but it was an excellent  example of the wind isn’t always there when you want it.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In terms of the gas, the U.K. market certainly in terms of both price and actually supply is still very  much dominated by the global surplus of gas. U.K. gas prices are trading significantly below  continental European benchmark price and that’s really quite far into the forward market and it  really reaching in winter 2000 or reaching parity in winter 2014. The key dynamic for LNG and how  it plays into the U.K. and the pricing has really become between the U.K. and the U.S.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: We do consider this to be quite severe by our market, but it’s very difficult to know when that might  change. Probably, the two most important factors in the near term are the world – as the world  comes after the recession how global demand – gas demand grows and the second is the growth  of the U.S non-conventional gas. Longer term, gas demand in Asia could become a bigger factor.  Some work we’ve been looking at but on by gas strategy shows that new planning permits of new  plants for a gasification plant in Asia is currently running at about 50% of the current global  production of LNG. So, longer term what we may find is – and most of those are in China and India  that Asia does become a larger factor in the market. But that’s not really a near-term phenomenon.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In the U.K., we have really changed rather getting our gas firm and we thought that October to  October was just an excellent illustration of this. The U.K. as we have been receiving a very  substantial amount of LNG now as part of the supply. October 2008, only 2% of the gas came from  LNG, October 2009, 42% very dramatic. And of course, we have got increased demand for gas as  gas plant is running ahead of coal plant and on top of that, we’ve got the new gas plant on the  system.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In terms of coal, it’s funny coal is the – is a very different market to gas. Gas was really driven by  demand particularly in the U.S., in Europe, in Japan and Korea. In terms of coal, coal is driven by  demands in China and India. And China and India now makeup about 50% of coal consumption in  the world. What has happened during the course of 2009 was there was a dramatic drop in coal  consumption by coal generators across Europe, including the U.K., and what that has led to is very  high coal stocks in Europe, record coal stocks in the U.K. In contrast, there has been a very high  usage in China and India and actually a depletion of their stocking position, and what that’s led  them to be at this point with very tight stocks, and what it has effectively meant is that those  elements to sort of orientation of the whole market to Asia and what we’re seeing is actually both  China and India are buying from what we consider really non-traditional sources, natively South  Africa and Columbia, but also more from purchases from last year than has been in the past.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: The coal market remains in marked contango about a 30% premium of 2012 over the weekly  settlement price that we see in the current market and that reflects really a concern that the  production in India and particularly China is not going to meet the growth in demand in both of  these countries and there is a real underlying form of the coal market at the moment is that Asian  demand is acting as a floor to the European prices.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Onto operations, we set targets last year to take £10 million out of our underlying cost base and to  cut capital expenditure to use our resources more efficiently. We have exceeded both targets. We  also set out in 2009 to release cash from working capital, mainly through the reduction of coal       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Moving onto the profit summary, revenues were down 16% at 1.5 billion. The cost of sales, which  comprise fuel costs, power purchases and grid charges were down 14% and 970 million, leaving  the delivered gross margin of 506 million. This benefited from the closeout of in-the-money foreign  exchange contracts, adding £31 million of gross profit in cash. Cash operating costs, which exclude  depreciation and hedge accounting were £151 million, down 11% from a 169 million last year,  leaving the EBITDA 355 million. Major non-cash movements were unrealized losses on derivative  contracts of 130 million compared to a gain of 56 million last year. This comprises of an £80 million  loss in financial coal contracts and the balance being mainly foreign exchange losses. And for  completeness, we also show gains of 376 million to our hedge reserve. This is mainly positive  mark-to-market gains in forward power sales, a function of the weakening market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Net interest was 15 million, down £6 million reflecting lower levels of net debt, albeit higher funding  costs. An after tax charge of 47 million, reported earnings were 111 million compared to £333  million last year. And underlying earnings per share was at 57.9 pence. So, looking at revenue in  more detail, the total of 1,476 million include 66 million of sales through Haven, total net power  generated at 22.6 terawatt hours was down 11% on last year’s level of 25.4, a symptom of market  conditions. In the summer of 2008, it was economic to generation electricity through Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: However, with the weak market conditions in 2009, although Drax is top of the coal merit order,  depressed gas prices let coal at the margin and it was more economic to buyback power in off-peak  periods reducing our generation levels. Market conditions can also be seen when looking at our  average achieved price of power, which was £52 per megawatt-hour, some £6 less than last year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: 6 the system were £20 million, down from £25 million last year, with stronger competition in the  market to provide these services to the grid. And finally other revenues of £7 million are  predominantly from the sale of ash and gypsum to the building industry. And as you would expect,  this too has been a tough market although encouragingly, we did see some pickup as the year  progressed.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: So, moving onto cost of sales, which at £970 million were 160 million down year-on-year. This  includes power buybacks of Drax, power purchases of Haven and grid charges in both businesses.  It should be noted that previously we have classified grid charges for Drax within operating costs. In  fact, grid charges for Drax are marginally down year-on-year. However, the additional grid charges  incurred by Haven lead to an overall increase for the grid of £8 million. Within cost of sales, 693  million related to fuel costs compared to 858 million last year, a reduction of 19%. Excluding  carbon, the average cost of fuel was £25.40 per megawatt-hour, broadly level year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: As already noted, coal prices have been relatively stable this year, notwithstanding a significant  contango in the forward curve seen from the chart on the top line. Including carbon, average fuel  costs were £32 per megawatt-hour, down £1.80 on last year. Carbon has drifted lower, the average  cost of our purchased carbon, some £3 per ton less than last year. Coal accounted for 88% of the  fuel burned, down 7% from 2008 supported by another reasonable year of biomass in the mix of  3% of total by ‘08; but also petcoke, which at 7% of the total reflects the relative discount of this fuel  to coal during last year. In the current market, this discount is eroded. Pond fine, a byproduct coal  mining, was 1% of that fuel mix at around 100,000 tons, compared to nil in 2008. Pond fine has  traded at a 33% discount to coal and our ability to handle this more difficult fuel is a helpful  contributor to the economics of Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: What this slide shows is how we get from bilateral sales to final net sales, which is shown in the  bars and quantified on the left-hand axis and how those factors increased the price we achieved,  which is noted on the line and valued on the right-hand axis. As the chart shows, we made  significant contribution through bilateral buybacks. This is where we have sold forward at a certain  price, but the economics mean it is more profitable to meet our obligation by buying this power back  in the market rather than generate. This is a marginal cost decision, which we take closer to the  point of dispatch. We can trade in this way because of the flexibility we have to turn generation up  or down very quickly. Our units can move from the minimum export limits of 200 megawatt-hours to  the maximum stable export limits of 645 megawatts within 40 minutes, huge flexibility. Within these  short windows, we derive further revenue from the balancing mechanism used by the grid to  balance the system, close to real time. In tight markets and 2010 is shaping up to be another year  we call it margin. This flexibility plays a more important role in the overall financial performance of  Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Operating costs, we have put significant focus this year in reducing the underlying cost base of  Drax, a total cash cost of 151 million compared to a 169 million last year. As noted earlier, we have  stripped our grid charges from operating expenses and these are now included in gross profit. So,  there are several important factors to note. Haven operating costs are some £12 million, which are  clearly not in last year’s comparative. We undertook one plant outage in 2009 compared to two in  2008. This reduced costs by around £16 million, leaving the balance of cost, £14 million less than  2008, a reduction comfortably ahead of the 10 million target we set at the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: 7 more cycling of the plant over the summer, if the market remains tight. This will be a profit-driven  decision which factors in higher maintenance costs as well as the margin befits of two-shifting. We  also have year-one costs at the community energy savings program, SES together with investment  in Haven to grow this business and incremental investment in developing dedicated biomass. So,  overall then, all of these factors would add close to £20 million to the 2009 cost base.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Capital, our expenditure of £92 million this year reflects a £10 million reduction on last year’s level.  Of the 92 million, 59 million has been on the turbine upgrade and co-firing facilities. The major  investment in the turbines has been at the heart of our investment in plant efficiency and reducing  emissions. This investment delivers good returns and we are now just over halfway through this  £100 million program. The biomass handling and direct injection systems, an £80 million total  investment will allow us to co-fire in the region of 1.5 million tons of biomass a year and this will  fully commission in the summer.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Looking ahead to 2010, CapEx will be in the region of £80 million. This completes the co-firing,  upgrades turbines to a further one unit, in addition to other smaller plant efficiency in carbon  abatement projects, which include some early fleet-study work on 2016 IED compliance. We’ve  also made provision for second store pilot plant, following the success of the first in group. We also  intend to invest in the IT systems at Haven, as we look to develop sales into the industrial and  commercial markets.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Cash flow, two specific items to focus on, working capital and tax. So, firstly working capital. A  negative move of 33 million largely reflects the buildup of coal stocks and 2.1 million tons last year  to 2.8 millions tons at the end of December. We continue to plan ways to release cash from this  asset, which has a balance sheet value of £163 million. The tax, we had a net tax refund of £19  million. This reflects a £48 million repayment from the inline revenue in respect to 2008, offset by  payments and accounts in respect to their liability for 2009. And to remind you, we had a funding  structure in place since 1999 the Eurobond debt structure, from which the Group derived benefits  from efficient tax planning. Adding to new tax rules and following advice from legal accounts where  we took the decision to wind this structure up effective from the end of December 2008. This  decision was taken to protect cost benefits in the region of £150 million. In addition, this action has  crystallized significant tax losses around £800 million equivalent to around 220 million of cash tax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: 8 To be clear, a downgrade of our debt is neither desirable nor we think justified. However, the  important thing is that we can now manage the consequences. And in this regard, we are held by  the common mark-to-market, which is well in excess with £300 million, it will take a significant  swing in commodity prices to quickly erode this position. Over and above this market factor, we  have also taken proactive steps to refine our trading strategy, which will reduce the MTM exposure.  For example, moving back to a three-year hedge position, which will have the bold shape of 60, 40,  20 through more deals for power, coal and carbon with the same counterparty. That’s leaving us  exposed to the smaller darkroom spread delta rather than the individual components, which  inevitably have greater volatility.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: So in summary, we’ve been traded into a strong headwind, but have achieved very solid financial  performance and strengthened our capital structure. We’ve exceeded the targets we set on costs  and capital control for this year. And we’re trading considerations that put pressure on cash such as  the surplus coal position, we’ve compensated for with other actions. We go in 2010 and indeed  2011 and 2012 very will hedged, a good position to have in these difficult markets. And also, debt  levels are modest, the business model is now more resilient to a downgrade of our debt rating if  that were to happen. Finally 2010 is the first year of the new dividend policy where 50% of  underlying earnings will be paid by way of dividends. So I’ll now pass you back to Dorothy.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive  So, in terms of regulation, we believe that we’re or we appear to be entering a period of change.  There is no question that the U.K. power market structures are challenged in the context of the  government’s key objective of security of supply and carbon abatement. I think it’s probably worth  saying that these are both areas where we think Drax has a really significant role to play. We also  have news to report, Project Discovery brings out quite a lot of the issues and I think possibly the  most important or one of the key issues for Drax or central to it is the fact that – at the moment  there is no economic run for capacity that’s available to support intermittency. And I think the  market does need to provide some sort of run for capacity if we’re going to have the adequate  support that you need for intermittency.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: The uncertainty on IED and how that is going to be implemented actually continues. We had hoped  there have been some resolution last year, but I’m sure you all are aware there is a new energy  commissioner at the EU. He was seeking a very rigid implementation of IED that would have quite  serious scare of supply implications not just for the U.K., but for a number of the other countries  within the EU. I don’t think we’re likely to get any clarity on this until later this year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In terms of biomass, I think in terms of regulation, it’s first worth mentioning the role of the  government sees, or declares, for biomass. If you read the government’s renewable energy  strategy, you will see that it’s – to meet its target in 2020, it is assuming that 30% of that renewable  energy will come from biomass both in terms of electricity and heat. But biomass is a key  component of the government’s renewable energy strategy. However, the support for biomass is  not necessarily consistent with achieving those targets. In terms of dedicated biomass, the whole of  the industry of developers who have dedicated biomass were surprised when the government       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Prior to that point, there had been actually publications in response to consultation and discussions  with ourselves and others including the Renewable Energy Association that has indicated quite  different position. What this has caused in some – quite a violent response from the industry,  because it’s very difficult to make an investment decision when you don’t even no what the rope  band is going to be in the first year of operations, because the rope bands are due to change in  2013. But also I think an understanding in government now that this is a very serious issue and it  will restore future investment. So what there is actually now is a working group between industry  and government trying to find a solution to this issue. So, we feel moderately optimistic I think is  probably right – right way of putting it that there will be an appropriate regulatory clarity for us to go  forward with the dedicated bonus.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In terms of co-firing, the position is very different. We do feel that the government has not got the  right policy on co-firing. Co-firing has enormous potential and what has changed I think over the last  few years is the technology on co-firing has progressed and progressed. So, now it is quite possible  to convert whole units of power stations like Drax and there really is the opportunity for the U.K. to  use its existing investment base of some of the coal plants to deliver some very significant volumes  of renewable energy. The policy simply doesn’t address this. There still is account from co-firing,  despite an expert report advising that actually that was not appropriate and would not damage the  renewable market be lifted. And we have – we have been frustrated by lack of appreciation of  government of the role co-firing can play, but we have been encouraged by some very recent  engagement with government.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: And last but not least, dedicated biomass. We remain on schedule in the investment case for this  business by the end of this year and we think of there being three critical components to the  investment case. The first is that we have a robust commercial structure and that’s underpinned by  sound engineering. The second is that we achieve mid-teens returns on the investment we put into  it. And the third is that we have regulatory power strategy on the support we need for this type of  renewable energy. We continue to work very positively with Siemens on this and have been very  appreciative of our partnership with Siemens. Across the different aspects of the business  development, we are making very good sound progress, so in terms of construction, our pre- qualification for the construction contract went well acknowledged with the pro-tender. The other  part of construction is an engineering design and what we’ve been conducting is a lot of transparent  to actually ensure that the equipment of the plant will have the capability of meeting our multi-fuel  strategy. And we’ve been very, very encouraged by that. I think even the equipment suppliers have  been quite surprised by the results on the degree of flexibility we will achieve.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In terms of permitting, we’re now well advanced with the permitting on the first two sites. We were  very pleased when we got unanimous support not any of the local, but county council level for both       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: 10 those formats and that now is well in process and we expect the current comments during the  course of this year. The third site will be permitted under the new permitting regime. We are still in  commercial negotiations on that site, but we do have secure grid connections and actually we’re  well advanced in the early permitting work.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: In terms of fuel procurement, there is another – we’ve made substantial progress. We now have  offers for over 5 million tons of term contracts for these plants. We actually only need about 1.3  million tons per plant. What we are pursuing is this multi-fuel strategy. We think that’s key to long- term viability and we have made good progress albeit it’s always going to be relatively modest  volumes on our energy crop program in the U.K. and now we have over 100 contracts signed with  growers of these energy crops.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Thompson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Okay, shall we start? Good morning and welcome to the Drax 2009 Preliminary Results. For those
texts.text: Underpinning all of this procurement is sustainability and we really do believe that sustainability is  key to the viability and the long-term sustainability of this business. We went public with our  sustainability policy about 18 months and we have worked very hard, in the context actually of the  fuel we bring in for co-firing to ensure that we that we are implementing that. What we have now is  we’ve conducted audits of all our major fuel supplies and that’s done by external party and that  includes full life cycle covenant analysis. And what we’ve found very encouraging is that we are  actually delivering over 85, 87% carbon savings relative to the coal we burn at Drax. But  sustainability is key and central to how we target the procurement on biomass.
