texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: We continue to make progress through the year on our biomass generation capability. I’m actually  very proud that we actually were the largest renewable generation facility by output last year, not by  a small bit, but by a factor of two across the whole UK when you compare to all other facilities, not  a small achievement for what people think of as a coal plant. And then finally, we really do believe  that we stand ready to expand our renewable generation capacity from biomass if we have the right  operational support.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: What I would like to bring to your attention is we do not target 3.4% as a sustained forced outage  rate. We think the right number’s around 5%, and that’s a combination between cost effectiveness  and operational performance. And so 5% is what we’re targeting and that’s the result of very  extensive benchmark in analysis of our own equipment.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: We had an 80% load factor, very high compared to the rest of the UK coal plant average, which  was at around 35%, and there are three main reasons for that. One is our high efficiency compared  to all other coal plant in the UK. The second is our cost-effective [inaudible] of the grid. That’s really  on the flexibility. And the third is the continued progress we’ve been making on burning at what we  call advantaged fuels and more of that later.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: The only other thing I would like to bring out is we actually thought that in December particularly, we  really demonstrated the value of being a reliable generator. And we continued smooth operations –  sorry, throughout December – I’ve got something in my throat. And that was despite the UK  experiencing the second coldest winter since record began in 1659, which is really something. But  more particularly at Drax, we actually had sustained minus fifteen degrees, which is really very  cold. But we continued in operation working smoothly.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: 2 It was quite a major project year for us. We implemented the fourth of our turbine upgrades. These  are never easy, you’re retrofitting new equipment onto old equipment, but it came in on time to  budget and it’s working at guaranteed performance level. That brings us to two-thirds of the station  being upgraded now. So we’re well above 39% efficiency of base load.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: We also had a number of smaller projects which were really aimed at improving our fuel flexibility.  Some not so small; one is a biomass co-firing facility, but also others. And what we’re really  targeting is burning fuels other than the standard bituminous coal, and we’ve seen quite a variety of  range that we’ve managed to increase this year. And then finally, we did commission the co-firing  facility.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: The co-firing facility is really quite a facility. It’s the biggest co-firing facility in the world. We’ve now  had nine months of operations. We fully commissioned it in June and it’s been working very well.  We are pleased with its performance. It accounts for – together with our other biomass capability, it  gives us a capacity of 500 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And we produced, as I’ve said, the highest renewable part per output of any facility in the UK. But  we did not operate it at full capacity. We actually did operate at a slightly higher capacity than we  expected, and that’s because we’ve benefited, as well as been hurt a little bit, by higher coal prices,  which means that there has been some more biomass that’s become economic.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: But essentially, the level of reg which was fought at the moment for co-firing, which is essentially  just half the ROC, isn’t enough for us to buy the scale of biomass we’d like to buy. But we know,  with further support, there’s really ample supplies available.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Co-firing is not just about the facilities we have at Drax. It’s also about having a really efficient and  effective supply chain. So alongside the co-firing project at Drax, what we’ve actually been  developing are the supply chain facilities as well along, with our partners.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And we now have a 70,000 tonne port storage facility at Port of Tyne with – equipped with matching  rail-loading facilities. We’ve invested in bespoke biomass rail wagons for the rail fleet and that  enables us to bring in the biomass in a very cost-effective and low-carbon way. And we continue to  operate our – what we think of complementary investment – a 100,000 tonne per annum straw  pelleting plant.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And I must say that we do still follow absolutely rigidly our biomass sustainability policy. We think  that’s very important, and all our biomass is procured on the basis of that policy.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: In terms of the trading position, this is an update of our position. I wasn’t going to go through it in  detail. There’s very little movement since – that we last gave an update in December. We maintain  our hedging strategy of broadly hedging 60, 40, 20, one, two, three years in advance. [inaudible]  the dark green spread. And we’re pleased to note that actually Haven sales now account for 11% of  our forward hedge.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: I thought I’d quickly go through the markets. Should we start with the power market? Power market  prices continue to be driven by gas. But probably the biggest determinant of dispatch at the present  is the efficiency of the plants. [inaudible] graph attempts to illustrate is what that really does in terms  of spreads.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So, if we look to the far right, the dark blue bar is the spread of efficiency of the coal fleet, and it  goes from the low-efficiency plant at 31% to the high-efficiency unit, not quite a whole plant yet,  which is Drax, at 40%. And then the light blue is the spread of efficiency for the gas plants, going  from the low-efficiency plant at 42% to the high-efficiency plant newly commissioned at 56%.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: If you then look at that graph itself, what it actually shows is the range of spreads for the range of  efficiencies across the four. And if we look at the front first or the front month, what you can see  from the top of the graph is the highly efficient coal plant, Drax, and the high-efficiency gas plant  are effectively dispatching neck and neck.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: If you look at the bottom of the bars, what you see is the low-efficiency gas – coal plant is  dispatching ahead of the low-efficiency gas plant. And what you see as you move higher in the  graph is the improved competitive – competitiveness of coal compared to gas as we go across the  forward market. And that’s really driven by what happened in the gas market. What I think this does  illustrate is the real challenge. I mean, look at those spreads being faced by the low-efficiency gas  plants and also certainly in the near market by the low-efficiency coal plants.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: The other thing, I think, worth bringing out about the market is actually what’s been happening  about wind. I mean, there’s now enough of this data to get quite a good picture about what wind  load factors would be, certainly for onshore wind. And what historic data now shows is there’s  consistently a load factor of around 24%, 25%. That is actually lower than most of these projects  thought when they first were built.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: What – what we’ve also all – all aware of, is there have been very good illustrations that the wind is  not always there when you need it. The best example, probably, was this winter that – that       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: 4 December where I quoted, we had the second coldest December since the records began in 1659.  It also was the lowest wind month since 2001.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: In terms of the gas market, I think many in the market have been surprised by how resilient gas  prices have proven to be despite a very, very strong supply position in the international market. In  the UK, in the summer, the prices were supported by lower than expected flows of LNG and higher  exports through the Interconnector.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: In the winter, I think what was noticeable about the Drax gas market is it didn’t go into distress. I  mean, we did have very high demand for it in this cold December, and the gas market coped well; it  was the combination of – of fast flows from the storage and also reliance on LNG.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: What is quite remarkable about the gas market is what’s happened to pricing trends and that’s what  we’ve tried to illustrate with the two charts on the bottom. One shows you the prices across the  market in April last year, when we last gave our results. And the right one shows you the prices in  February. And the three lines, the dark blue line is the European Benchmark Price, the oil index  price that underpins long-term contracts in Continental Europe. The red line is Henry Hub, the gray  line is the UK gas price, and the blue line is what we call the coal switching price.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And I think the movements are quite clear so the UK gas price has moved much closer to the  European Benchmark, significantly away from Henry Hub. But what also seems to be happening is  that the coal switching price appears to be forming a floor to the UK gas price. To be honest, the  logic for this is somewhat tenuous because the UK is not an island market; we’re strongly  influenced by international factors. So it is surprising that there’s proving to be a phenomena, but it  has been a phenomena for the last few months.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: In terms of coal, to be honest, it’s a very similar story to our interims. This really is a market where  pricing is strongly driven by what’s happened in China. So what we thought we’d give you in this  presentation is a bit of a picture of why that’s quite such a magnitude. So what we’ve given is the  statistics for the steam coal market. And the international traded steam coal market is about  700,000 tonnes and that’s out of a total world consumption production of just over 6 billion tones.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And that has a direct impact on prices, most especially when you combine it with other Asian  demand, most notably in India. So what we’ve seen is we’ve seen the markers of main tide, driven  from Asia; what we’ve really seen is coal flowing from all over the world into the Asian markets, be  it Colombia, be it Russia, be it South America, and even now the U.S. Prices have flattened out  somewhat; that really actually shows the near term coming up, that’s the most. And it is in contrast  to the gas market, where actually we’re seeing the forwards higher than the front.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: We have maintained our drive on cash supported by high generation and the associated fuel burn,  which has provided the significant conversion of coal to cash. Further strengthening our balance  sheet posit, with net cash of £204 million at the year [inaudible], £117 million of which is currently  ring-fenced in proceeds from utilizing Eurobond tax losses. And in line with our policy to distribute  50% of underlying earnings, total dividends for the year will be £0.32 per share or £117 million,  more than twice the level we paid in respect to 2009 earnings. And this incorporates the final  proposed dividend of £0.179 per share.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Moving on to the profit summary. I’ll cover the components of EBITDA shortly. So, below this figure,  unrealized losses on derivative contracts, a non-cash item of £61 million is the mark-to-market  movements on the financial coal contracts which don’t qualify for hedging in. Depreciation of £52  million includes the first six months charge for our co-borrowing facility, after its successful  commissioning this summer.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Looking now at revenue in more detail. The total of £1.6 billion includes £124 million of sales  through Haven, compared to £65 million last year. Total net power generated at 26.4 terawatt hours  is 17% up on last year’s level of 22.6 terawatt hours, which reflects our strong availability and  dispatched economic through 2010 and particularly during the unseasonably cold weather at the  beginning and end of the year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: This incremental volume was captured at relatively low margins, but has released significant cash  from coal stocks, which I’ll cover in more detail shortly. The average achieved price for our  electricity sold in the wholesale market is £51.60 per megawatt hour just slightly down on last year.  This is a blend of higher prices locked in for 2010 through the accelerated hedge we entered the  year with, offset by the additional sales volume cashed at lower prices on trades placed June 2010.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Moving on to other income; firstly, ROCs and LECs; and you do need to look at the balance sheet  as well as the income statement to see the full picture here. So with income – so with income, we  recorded ROC and LEC sales of £23 million against £39 million in 2009. But we hold on the  balance sheet of £33 million ROC inventory compared to £12 million last year. The income on  these will be recognized when they are sold in 2011 at a price likely to be close to the balance  sheet value. The overall ROC increase, as you would expect, is driven by the increased biomass  burn this year. However, to a degree, this is offset by the fact that we now receive half of ROC for  co-firing, whereas last year, for parts of the period, we did receive a full ROC.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Cost of sales, which at £1.1 billion, about 13% year-on-year. This includes power buybacks at Drax,  power purchases at Haven and grid charges in both businesses. Cost of sales; £841 million related  to fuel and carbon cost, compared to £691 million last year, an increase of 22% driven by our high  generation volume. Grid charges and other cost of sales of £91 million, about £19 million year-on- year. This includes grid charges of £28 million incurred at Haven, compared to £12 million last year,  reflecting the growth in this business as well as the timing of the acquisition, which occurred  partway through 2009.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Average costs, excluding carbon, is £25.70 per megawatt hour, a small increase on the year. Coal  prices were relatively stable throughout the year, although did increase laterally when severe  weather in a number of regions across the world resulted in supply constraints. This tick up can be  seen in the top chart.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Including carbon, average fuel cost of about 31 – of £31.90 per megawatt, similar to last year. The  average cost of our purchased carbon requirements was £1.70 per ton less than last year. With our  progressive hedging strategy, when carbon contracts to cover this year’s liability in 2009 when we  sold the related power. In comparison, the 2009 costs reflects contract prices which were mostly  locked into during 2008 when prices were higher and that can be seen in the lower chart. So  overall, despite a challenging bit, we delivered a gross margin well ahead of last year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Haven operating costs were some £16 million, compared to £9 million last year, reflecting our  ongoing investment in that business and the timing of acquisition. With the remainder of the cost  increase for the group, down to the first full year cost of our CESP obligations, the Community  Energy Savings Programme, our guidance for 2011 costs is an increase of £25 million. £20 million  of this reflects investment in growth; growing the Haven business, dedicated biomass and, most  importantly, research and development work on increasing the level of biomass burn at the Drax  site. Should we receive the appropriate level of government support to increase significantly the  level of biomass burn at Drax, we want to be in the best possible position to grow this business as  quickly and efficiently as possible.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: For capital, we invested £59 million in 2010, around £37 million which was progressing the  upgrades to our turbines and completing the investment in biomass co-firing; which, as already  noted, was commissioned on time and in line with budget. We expect total CapEx for 2011 to be in  the region of £40 million. So over the last two or three years, we have made very good progress,  managing the [inaudible] business, and I thought it would be interesting to spend a few moments on  this now.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: This slide shows that recent performance improvements in operating and capital cost control have  not come at the expense of plant performance, and that Drax compares very well to other coal fired  plants around the world, not only in relation to operating performance but now also in terms of  running costs.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So we look at slightly more detail. In terms of plant performance, the blue line in the top graph  demonstrates how our forced outage rate has trended downwards since 2007, with a resulting  improvement in plant availability, illustrated by the gray line.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: In terms of cost, the horizontal bar chart at the bottom summarizes the results of the Independent  Global Benchmarking Study performed by Solomon Associates. The study compares the cash cost  of operating around 100 coal plants [inaudible] and the world, all 550 megawatts or larger, between  2007 and 2009. That’s our worldwide peer group. In this context, cash costs exclude fuel and  carbon, but includes all other operating and capital costs with the data normalized for outages.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Cash flow; and really, principally, working capital. The main element relating to coal stock, which,   just to remind you, increased by 700,000 tonnes in 2009 when an [inaudible] unit outage and weak  market conditions combined to leave our generation levels lower than expected. This position is  now reversed with a 17% increase in generation bringing stocks down from 2.8 [inaudible] million  tonnes in December 2009, to 1.2 million tonnes by the end of the year. This contributed £84 million  of total inflow of cash from working capital.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So, in summary, we have delivered strong financial results here, with increased profitability  underpinned by strong operational performance. However, commodity markets remain challenging  for all fossil fuel generators. We enter 2011 with support from forward power sales of 18 terawatt  hours, a significant portion of which were executed on more attractive terms than we could capture  in today’s market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: On regulation, we thought you might be interested to know what Drax’s position is on the EMR. So I  thought I’d go through it point by point. First, on the proposal by the government to introduce feed- in-tariffs in the [inaudible] of the renewables obligation, we are strongly supportive of this. We think  it’s going to be – or create a more level playing field for new entrants and independents like Drax to  invest in renewable generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: In terms of capacity payments, we are very pleased that the government recognizes that essentially  the UK’s energy-only market will not provide what is necessary for security to supply. However, we  do feel that the lead proposal is too little too late and that more is required quicker; and specifically  more needs to be done to address what is going to be a growing intermittency problem within the  UK generation base.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: 9 And then finally, on the – well, sorry – and then the carbon floor; the floor we also should cover  quickly, which is the emission performance standard. The carbon floor, not surprisingly, I – we don’t  think this is a very good proposal. Actually, it’s a particularly worrying proposal for those low- efficiency coal plant, [inaudible] efficiency gas plant.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Those plants were also – which I spoke of earlier when we were talking of – about the spreads.  Those plants are also going to be hit with retrofit or reduced generation requirements for IEDs,  particularly bad for those plants; not good for Drax, although it does support our strategy of  boosting Drax’s efficiency, which has been key and central. And it also supports our strategy of  carbon abatement through going on biomass generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So why are we opposed to it? Well, if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to go on a little rant now and then  I’ll finish. Firstly, we think it’s a very poor investment signal for low-carbon generation. That’s  supposedly its purpose, but everyone agrees, because it’s an indirect price system, it actually is an  inefficient way to encourage low-carbon investment.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Secondly, it commits the UK, at the moment – it commits the UK consumer to pay the highest  carbon price in the world for their electricity and that is going to damage competitiveness and it’s  going to be hard on the cost of electricity for the average household.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Thirdly, it doesn’t reduce carbon emissions across the EU. And that is because the EU ETS is a  finite scheme. If we use less carbon in the UK, that will depress the price of the EU ETS allowances  and that will allow more carbon to be emitted elsewhere in Europe.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And finally, it will lead to windfall profits paid for by the consumers for existing nuclear, existing  renewables and to gas generation whenever coal is price setting. So, fundamentally, we think it’s a  poor proposal.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: The fourth component of the EMR is the Emissions Performance Standard. This only applies to  new coal plant and really has little impact on the sector, we believe, at the moment.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Moving on to biomass, and more specifically, the renewables obligation. This is the other key part  of regulatory change this year, because the government is going through quite a substantial  banding review. So we start at the beginning of 2010; we were very concerned at the start of 2010.  We did not detect in government a real interest biomass. Government had confirmed that there was  going to be – remain a cap on co-firing biomass through fossil fuel plants. And we’d just been told  there wouldn’t be grandfathering for dedicated biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: But to be honest, the picture changed very quickly because we found rapidly in the early months of  2010, we had more and more engagement with government on biomass. And it became very clear  that government really wants to understand the role that biomass could potentially – could  potentially play. And we think there really has been real made – progress made, and there was  potential for more progress.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So the obvious areas where there have been progress, is the UK through 2010 designed, consulted  and decided on sustainability standards for biomass. There’s another to be introduced and they’ll  be mandatory from 2013. We think this is really important. There’s no point in having renewable  biomass generation if it doesn’t come from sustainable sources.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: Certainly, the government determined the dedicated biomass plant should be grandfathered and if  confirmed, they’ll be grandfathered for a sustained period.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And essentially, they’re giving consideration for two things: one, is what we call an enhanced co- firing band, and what that would mean if it was introduced is you’d have a band for co-firing that  addressed not just the fuel cost but also the expense, the capital expense of increasing your co- firing below – above say 5%, or the minimum amount that doesn’t require much investment. The  second is they’re looking at putting a new band for conversion, perhaps transforming our fossil fuel  plants into renewable plants.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: We think this is very, very positive. We have been working, as you know, on converting units at  Drax, but the ideal route for us would be to do – to actually reach higher biomass generation at  Drax to enhance co-firing. And the reason is that it will allow us progressively to move through to  becoming a dominated – dominated by biomass generation, and then ultimately to 100% biomass.  And what you can do is you can use all that core knowledge as you increase the percentage of co- firing to understand how to optimize the biomass use through Drax – through Drax power station.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So, government’s been considering, they haven’t finally decided, and we don’t know the detail; we  don’t know if they do introduce it what will be the level of support. But we certainly are very  encouraged by the engagement and the discussion we and others are having with the government  on the potential for more biomass burning through coal stations. And it must be said this is a cost- effective, reliable and flexible renewable. So, it’s attractive for the UK and is a very good solution to  the 2020 target. That’s our view, of course.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And what are we going to do in this time while we talk and wait? Well, what we think is very  important is we invest in research and development. This is really what Tony was talking about.  And what we’re going to be doing, investing in is in two things. We’re going to be continuing to  progress our work on dedicated biomass which is progressing smoothly, but slowly, perhaps I  should say, with Siemens Project Ventures, and we’re going to do more testing work on co-firing.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And I should say we actually have already had some good test results from co-firing. So, we have  for very short periods managed to test at 20% co-firing, and the units performed very well. We also  have actually tested at 100% co-firing, but only at very low loads. So, it’s only indicative. It doesn’t  really tell us what the real performance will be.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: However, all this enthusiasm needs to be tempered, because I need to make it absolutely clear; we  will not invest in additional biomass generation unless we have the right level and appropriate level  of regulatory support. And it isn’t just about the financials. It’s also about the whole spectrum. It’s  about the grandfathering, and it’s the provision of that support, how it’s tested and everything else.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: 11 So, it is all in the detail. But certainly, in terms of the government position on burners, we feel  there’s been quite substantial movement during the course of 2010. Then the other two-part  regulation which we’d like to talk about starts with the Industrial Emissions Directive. This is what  brings the new NOx limits. That’s the most important part of it, in 2016.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: The attractive – the positive side of that is actually the right solution is very dependent on what is  the pure mix in 2016 and beyond. And obviously, until we know about the support for biomass, we  simply cannot say what is going to be the fuel mix. So, it’s very positive that we now are confident  we don’t need to make a decision on this until the middle of next year. In terms of carbon capture  and storage, I’m sure you would have seen that we are one of the parties who’s – who have made  an application for NER funding, or an application to government that could be passed on to an  application for NER funding for our CCS project to Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: This is a new build project where our application is in partnership with Alstom and National Grid. It  is based on oxy-fuel firing. We actually have done an awful lot of work on CSS at Drax, and we  think with current technology, it simply isn’t cost-effective and competitive to retrofit. It’s not a long- term solution, we don’t think, but we are very interested in oxy-fuel technology. We do think it’s a  very good technology, and that’s why we’ve entered this competition. But there is a caveat. We  would only go forward with the project if the government is willing to give the right level of financial  support, and there is a really robust commercial structure, because this is essentially new  technology and a high risk involved in it.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: So, to bring it to a conclusion, 2010 was about operational excellence, good profitability  underpinned by the strong hedge, enhanced by a good operational performance. We’ve made  progress on biomass, both in terms of what we’ve burned; the largest renewable generation output  of any facility in the U.K.; but also in our dialog with government. We feel there is a greater  understanding and appreciation or potential appreciation of the role biomass could play.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everyone. Shall we start? For a few who don’t know, so I thought I might start
texts.text: And we’d like to leave you with the message that we stand ready to commit to greater biomass  investment and generation if the right regulatory support is in place. And with that, I’d like to take  questions.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Biomass remains absolutely central to our strategy and core to our strategic ambitions. We made really good  progress in understanding our potential for biomass burning at Drax during the course of 2011 and we stand ready  to turn Drax into a predominantly biomass-fired power station if we get the right support from government.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We had an 80% load factor. That actually represents a 91% utilization when we're available. Our load factor is  really notable compared to the other plant in the thermal fleet in the UK. The average load factor for the gas plant  was 40% and the average load factor for all the other coal plant was 34%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: There are three main reasons for this. First is, we are the most efficient coal plant in the UK, but the second is that  we are a very competitive asset for grid support. So that's another reason which drives a higher load factor. The  third is we have worked very hard, over many years actually now, to really increase our capability to burn  advantaged fuels. That's anything other than the standard bituminous coal that delivers a financial advantage to  us. All of that drives that higher load factor.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We had a very busy year for projects in 2011. We installed the fifth of our six turbine upgrades. And the last  turbine upgrade we'll install this year. Again, it was on time to budget and it's meeting guaranteed performance  levels.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: It's worth maybe reflecting a bit on this upgrade program. It has cost us – or will cost us when we complete it,  £100 million. It's going to save 5% of our fuel bill. Our fuel bill in 2011 was £1 billion. Now, if you set aside

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And there are three reasons for this. The first is that, from 2013, we no longer have National Allocation Plan  carbon allowances. The second is, from April 2013, we have the introduction of the carbon floors or, as I think of  it, the carbon tax. And the third is we hope and expect that we're going to significantly increase our biomass burn  and biomass costs are multiples of coal. So this efficiency upgrade has been very, very valuable to us.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, we place a high priority on our capability to burn what we call advantaged fuels. This is  economic biomass and actually unusual coal solutions, pond fines being one of the examples. We burnt 9%  advantaged fuels in 2011 and this is an area where we will continue to do a lot of work and, in fact, we're very  hopeful we're going to be burning some attractive petcokes during the course of 2012.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our Goole pellet plant is now in its third year of operation. Time passes quickly. And we originally brought this as  a straw pellet plant. We actually have modified the plant, so it can also process energy crops. And it has proved to  be – it's working very well and it's a very cost-effective source of UK biomass for us.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of the co-firing facility, first, so we actually only operated it at less than 50% load factor for commercial  biomass. And that reflects the fact that biomass is – most biomass is simply not economic at half a ROC. We did  actually run it more than that. We have very good availability for the facility. And the higher running was all about  research and development. And we burned actually 700,000 tons of biomass on a commercial basis and 600,000  tons of biomass as research and development on an economic basis.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of contracted position, we have advanced ourselves for 2012 in the last six months and also made some  further sales for 2013. 2014, as I said at the opening, remains very low liquidity, little visibility. It could be an  unusual year for us, 2014, because we'd hope to be able to increase significantly our biomass burn that year. What  we have been doing is we've been doing a lot of work on what would be the right trading strategy for Drax if and  when we become predominantly biomass business, but still more thought and reflection is required on that. One  of the pleasing things about this – of this slide is that Haven now accounts for 20% of our forward sales, which is a  good statistic, we feel.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of the market, let's start with the power market. Again, as always, the predominant influence has been  the gas market. But it remains very, very important, the efficiency of a plant as to how it dispatches and the  economics of its return. So what we've shown, again, here is what the efficiency means across the forward  markets.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So if you look at the graph, at the far right, what you see is the bands of efficiency. The coal plant in the UK ranges  from a low-efficiency 31% up to the top efficiency which are those upgraded Drax units at 40%. Gas plant ranges  from a low-efficiency of 42% up to a top efficiency of 58%, which are those newly built, newly commissioned gas  plants.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And what you can see is that at those different efficiencies, you see the margins they command in the different – in  the forward markets. So if you look at the day ahead first, what you can see is coal plant is dispatching well ahead  of all the gas plant. If you go further across the forwards, this advantage is eroded, but you still have the top- efficiency Drax units dispatching ahead of all the gas plants even though they have just been commissioned. And it  brings your attention that those spreads in 2013 include the carbon floor or carbon tax, so we are looking at a very,  very difficult market for gas plant, and that's why you've heard of retiring – sort of more like withdrawing of some  of the low-efficiency gas plants, and you can see why it's a difficult market.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving on to the gas market, gas prices have fallen over the last six months. And it's all about the weather or  that's probably being the largest factor. If you look at the top chart, that shows you – the blue line is what the  average – historic norm is and the gray shows you the actual temperature. And apart from that cold snap we had a  few weeks ago, it really has been a warm winter, and that leads to an overhang of gas.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The two bottom charts show you what – how the UK market is doing relative to the international market. So it  compares July with February. The red line is the US gas market. The dark blue line is the continental benchmark  price. This is the oil index price. The gray line is the UK gas price and the blue line is the Coal Switching Price. I  think the most notable development is the – or the widening of the differential between Europe and the US. It's  pleasing that the UK gas price has kept its linkage or its tendency towards European gas price and is not looking to  the Coal Switching Price for support.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On to regulatory, so I suspect if all know that the government published in October the long-awaited proposals for  the new band under the Renewables Obligation to become effective in April 2013. We were very pleased that there  is clear support through this consultation for co-firing and conversion of coal stations using sustainable biomass.  And the reason that support is there is there's clear recognition that this is a truly cost-effective renewable for the  UK and can deliver a lower cost renewable solution for the end consumer. And we thought that was a very positive  aspect.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: There are two new bands for biomass through a coal station, conversion and co-firing. They're set at the same  level. That was done intentionally to allow the larger stations, stations like Drax, to be able to convert unit by unit

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The band will set – or the proposed level for the band is 1 ROC. For dedicated, the proposed band is 1.5 ROCs  falling to 1.4 ROCs for stations accredited in 2016 and later. Our response to the consultation is that at 1 ROC, we  would co-fire more, but we will not achieve our full potential to really deliver cheaper renewable power to the UK.  And we need only a moderate uplift to achieve that full potential.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: For dedicated, at 1.5 ROCs, we think that is really challenging for an independent generator. And we have reflected  that challenge by actually stopping our project on the Drax site and we're looking at options for our project on the  Immingham site.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So what have we been doing? Research and development. So, at the beginning of the year, what we did was we  took the existing co-firing facilities, we modified them and modified some other parts of the plants, so effectively  we could firm very high levels of biomass through a single unit. And that's what the year has been about in terms  of biomass research and development. It's been trials through the single unit of different concentrations of  biomass, different types of biomass. And that's partly about understanding the technical – how the equipment  works, but it's also about understanding the complex chemistry between different biomasses and coal. And on the  complex chemistry, we've been well supported by a number of our UK universities for which we're very  appreciative.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We haven't quite finished. We've got a bit more work to do on burning some more unusual or exotic coals and we  also have work to do on what is the NOx or nitrous oxide performance with biomass, and where that links in is it's  all about what is the optimal solution for the Industrial Emissions Directive if we're going to be compliant post- 2016.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, having – we still have work to do, but there are some very clear early results. And the first is that we are  absolutely confident that we can burn higher proportions of biomass, well over 50%, on a totally reliable basis.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The second, which is really pleasing, is we can do that with good flexibility. So that is about being a competitive  asset for grid support. We are confident now we can sustain that quality of grid support, burning higher  percentages of biomass.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The third area where we've made a lot of progress, but we've still got more work, is we've really advanced well our  understanding of the chemistry. This builds on the seven, eight years of burning biomass at Drax, but we have –  this is the first time we've really done at these high percentages.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The final result will not come out probably until the second half of next year and that's when we'll actually really  know what are the final things on efficiency and load ranges. We're actually – the chemistry is all about fuel  envelopes. And fuel envelope is all about optionality and value. So we'll have our conclusions on that, although I  suspect, in truth, it's going to be ongoing for the next ten years. But we'll have the main parts of the conclusions  and enough to know what is our fuel optionality which will then optimize beyond that.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And finally, and very important, what is the biomass/coal NOx performance. This all sounds as though it can be  all conclusive and easy, but actually it's all linked in to the regulatory. Because the regulatory support will drive  the fuel envelope and that will drive the plant performance and the biomass co-firing conversion capacity. So it is

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of investment, you may have seen from our announcement that we now think of it in two phases. The  first phase is all about securing value from our existing facilities, so we've already committed as a Board to £50  million expenditure at the Drax plant on basically increasing our capacity to co-fire. The reason for this is to  qualify for enhanced co-firing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Currently, the proposal is that you have to burn 15% biomass. Our capacity is 12.5% maximum. So what we're  doing is we're installing the facilities and storage that enables us to co-fire at 20% and comfortably hit that  proposed hurdle for enhanced co-firing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The second part is that we would only invest the additional money we need to invest, the £450 million, if we  actually get the right support from biomass – from government. Now, the second investment is about two sets of  things, and I think probably I should cover that after I've gone through the fuel slides. I'm sorry. This is not what I  was meant to do.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Okay. So let's do fuel sourcing next. No change to our position that we can't tell you anything about our biomass  sourcing. This is a highly commercially sensitive area, and we are not willing to give the details of it. But I would  reiterate that biomass is an immature supply chain and often the solutions are bespoke.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of our sourcing strategy, there are four main sort of strands to how we source. The first is we buy pellets  or we intend to buy pellets on a long-term contract basis. The second is we contract the fiber, so this is  unprocessed biomass, and generally actually, normally, these contracts are with strategic forest partners, so that's  all about really good fiber security.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Where we have contracted for fiber or are planning or will – or conditional contracts for fiber, what we are looking  at is to complement that with Drax pellet investments. And what that is about is having a foundation supply of a  really secure biomass sourcing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In addition, we're still and we will always be active in the shorter term and spot biomass market. The key to us  getting value for that is all about this fuel optionality, so when I was talking about the chemistry, the wider the fuel  optionality, the more we can create value for ourselves through the spot market. It works on the long-term market  as well, but it's particularly important in the spot and short-term market.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And then, finally, we continue to work on developing UK sources. UK sources are limited. We will import the vast  majority of our biomass, and a lot of our work on UK sources is actually about energy crops.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We will be sourcing from a diverse set of geographies, but we do expect an early concentration in North America,  probably the most developed biomass market at the moment. And when we source, our strategy is to balance  flexibility with security of supply.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I thought it might be good to give you a picture of what these long-term contracts are. Typically, they're seven to  ten years. Typically, they're fixed price. And by fixed price, I mean it's a price that's set and then it has a level of  indexation. And that indexation is normally to the indigenous inflation rate and some fuel component. And the

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Sustainability remains absolutely core to how we procure our biomass. Our biomass has – we – our sustainability  policy has been in place for many years now, and we carbon-footprint all the biomass we burn. You probably know  that the UK is going to have mandatory sustainability standards for biomass for power generation from April  2013. We know from the results of our 2011 audit of our sustainability compliance that we would meet – have met  in 2011 those mandatory standards.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: This is an area where we think the – we have some concerns about the proposals the government has for  sustainability in the consultation. But what I would say about that, and actually for the whole of the consultation,  is government has been very, very open to industry in this process, and we've been very pleased with the access,  and they've really tried to understand what we need for sustainability and what we need for security of supply.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And now we go back to the slides that I started earlier. Okay. So we're going to – we are – we have embarked on a  £50 million investment, and this is all about having the capacity to meet the enhanced co-firing level, and it's  about securing value from our existing facilities. It doesn't take us much further than that. If we want to be able to  go further, we need to invest up to £450 million. And we will only do so if we get the right support from  government. And that's about substantial modifications at the Drax site, increased storage, but it's also about  those pellet plant investments I was just talking about. And that's about this foundation strategic, secure supply of  biomass.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The other future developments, just quickly wanted to touch on, Industrial Emissions Directive; given the right  support from government, we expect to be compliant with this. By support, I'm saying – because it is linked to our  biomass position as well. We've been working on this for years, extensive feed studies, we're coming to a  conclusion, and we're pretty confident we understand the solution. We need the final results that the biomass  trials for NOx. We believe the costing is around £200 million. We know it will involve some SCR but it will be  complemented by other technologies. It won't be solely an SCR solution.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of carbon capture and storage, we're currently, in partnership with National Grid, Alstom and now BOC,  part of the competition – the European competition to support new CCS across Europe. Our proposal is for a new  build oxy fuel plant at Drax. It links in with National Grid's proposal for a pipeline network in the Humber Valley.  So it's very synergistic. We hope to be able to participate also in the new UK government competition when we  understand what the conditions are for that in the coming months.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, thank you, Dorothy. And you've just heard that preparation for our biomass expansion is now well advanced.  So I'll start by going through our current estimates of the capital costs for these investments. But again, I'm sorry  to be repetitive, but this is hugely important. Progression of our plans is dependent on securing appropriate ROC  support and proving a strong investment case.  So looking at the principal components to this potential investment, Dorothy described the two phases of the  development of our biomass capacity. The first, enhancing our current facilities with additional storage to enable  enhanced co-firing qualification, which secures the benefit of our existing co-firing investment and generates a  healthy return in its own right. That should be completed this year and will cost around £50 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second phase, increasing our capacity to become predominantly biomass with significant additional  investment in fuel storage, handling and other plant changes would be in the region of £250 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So when adding to the £50 million Phase 1 investment, this gives us £300 million total investment in on-site  storage and distribution facilities, along with necessary boiler and plant modifications. We are also evaluating  investment in pelleting facilities overseas. If we conclude that the best way to secure the right fuel at a good price  is to invest directly in these facilities, then we estimate the likely scale of capital required to be £150 million to  £200 million. These plants would not only need to provide fuel security, but also deliver an attractive return in  our own right to lower fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Clearly, we've done a lot of preparatory work around financing and we do continue to evaluate a number of  opportunities, but we are confident with an appropriate level of ROC support underpinning a strong investment  case, these plans should be financeable. And we can begin to transform Drax into a predominantly renewable  generator.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, first, our financial results and the profit summary. I'll come on to the components of EBITDA, but below this  figure, unrealized gains on derivative contracts, £89 million, is the mark-to-market movement on items not  qualified for hedge accounting. And this again is largely driven by financial coal contracts. Increased depreciation  of £57 million compared to £52 million last year reflects a full year's charge for our co-firing facility which was  commissioned in the summer of 2010.  Net finance costs of £28 million included a number of one-off items and accelerated charges associated with our  summer refinancing. Underlying costs actually are close to half of that figure. And for 2012, under the current  financing structure, we expect finance costs to be around £10 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So looking now at revenue in more detail, the total of £1.8 billion includes £275 million of sales to Haven  compared to £124 million last year. Net power generated was 26.4 terawatt hours and this is high relative to our  historic average, but consistent with last year, reflecting our strong availability and plant dispatch economics over  the past two years.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The average achieved price for our electricity sold in the wholesale market is £55.60 per megawatt hour, up from  £51.60 last year. And that benefits from higher prices locked in for 2011 through the hedge we entered the year  with, together with the additional sales captured at higher prices on trades placed during the year, with power  prices generally higher through most of 2011, until the unseasonably mild weather hit in the fourth quarter, trends  driven by the gas market which can be seen in the chart.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to other income, and firstly ancillary services and their payments to Drax by the grid to support the  balancing of the system are £17 million, down from £35 million in 2010. And this decrease is a reflection of the  firm frequency response contracts we had in place for the National Grid in 2010, but not 2011.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Other revenues of £8 million in both years are predominantly from the sale of ash and gypsum to the building  industry. And for ROCs and LECs, we recorded sales of £65 million against £23 million in 2010. The increase, as  you would expect, is largely the result of our higher biomass burn.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, as you know, if we go ahead with our biomass expansion, ROCs will become a much more substantial  component of our income. So I thought it will be helpful to spend a few minutes now looking at ROC cash flows  and accounting.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Firstly, a reminder of how ROC cash flows typically work. Electricity suppliers meet their requirement under the  renewable generators or by paying a penalty, the buyout fee. The buyout fees are later aggregated and paid back or  recycled to those suppliers who do surrender ROCs. The scheme or obligation is measured in annual compliance  periods running from April to March.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Because of the way the rules work, the cash flows associated with surrendering ROCs or paying buy-out fees  typically take place around six months after the compliance period ends. So a renewable generator can face a  significant delay between incurring the cost of producing renewable power; in our case, the higher cost of biomass  fuel and receiving a related cash compensation from ROC sales.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: At Drax, historically, we have recognized the benefit from ROCs in our P&L accounts only at the time the ROCs  are sold. And that's usually on a similar timing to the cash flows, but to some considerable time after the ROCs  were generated. So starting this year, we will change our accounting to bring forward the benefit of the ROC  support into the period of generation, providing a better match with the related biomass fuel costs. This new  accounting treatment brings us into line with other renewable generators, but more importantly, it is an  appropriate policy for Drax, particularly if biomass, and therefore ROCs, becomes a more meaningful component  of our business and earnings.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Whilst adopting this change in 2012, it will not have a significant impact on our earnings profile until the level of  ROC support for biomass is increased in 2013. And one final point to mention here is that we are exploring  options to accelerate what cash flows, so that they show a better match with earnings. This is treated into the work  we have been doing around funding our biomass plans which I covered earlier.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So on to cost of sales and fuel costs, which is £1.3 billion, or up over 20% year-on-year. This includes power  buybacks at Drax, power purchases at Haven and grid charges in both businesses.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Within cost of sales, £1 billion related to fuel and carbon costs compared to £841 million last year, an increase of  21% with higher commodity prices and a more expensive fuel mix. Grid charges and other cost of sales of £142  million are up £51 million year-on-year. The increase is almost certainly – almost all in retail where grid charges  and other costs have risen as we grow sales through Haven.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Average fuel cost, excluding carbon, is £33.30 per megawatt hour, up from £25.70 in 2010. And this increase is a  function of both fuel mix with biomass 9% of the total compared to 6% in 2010 and higher international coal  prices. Including carbon, average fuel cost of £38.70 per megawatt hour, up from £31.90 in 2010, with the average  cost of our purchased carbon requirements down £0.60 per ton on last year. And this follows the collapsing  carbon prices in the second half of the year, driven by an anticipated oversupply in Phase 2 of EU ETS. And you  can see this in the lower chart with prices now at their lowest level for two years. So when all of these factors are  taken in aggregate, we delivered a gross margin which was down 9% on last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So the increase of £8 million reflects investment in growth, investing in the Haven business and research,  development and planning work for increasing the level of biomass at Drax described earlier. And I'll touch on  that again in a moment.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our 2012 guidance for operating costs is £205 million. £20 million of this is a direct result of the planned double  completion of our biomass R&D work will add a further £10 million. And finally, cost inflation of 5% follows three  successive years holding underlying costs level.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to CapEx, with the existing co-firing facility complete, expenditure was lower in 2011. Asset additions  were £45 million, £8 million of which was progressing the turbine upgrade and £5 million was capital investment  incurred to facilitate the biomass combustion trials.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our preliminary guidance for capital expenditure for this year is around £100 million. This includes the final unit  of our turbine upgrade program and, importantly, £50 million to enhance our existing co-firing facilities – Phase 1  of the investment I described earlier. If we continue into Phase 2, we will give further guidance as to how this  investment will be phased.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So it's been an important year of biomass R&D work at Drax. So I wanted to spend a few moments summarizing  the financial impact of this work. As just described, we incurred capital cost of £5 million, modifications to our  existing direct injection facilities and installing new conveyors and fuel-handling infrastructure. £3 million was  charged for operating costs, which included taking expert's advice in areas such as biomass, combustion and  chemistry. And our estimated gross margin hit was £11 million including the commercial loss on burning 600,000  tons of out-of-the-money biomass, which without the trial would not have been incurred.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In total then, the trial cost just under £20 million in 2011, of which £5 million was capitalized and the remainder  charged to the P&L account. But this work has been incredibly valuable, placing Drax in the best possible position  to deliver a step change as quickly and efficiently as possible in the levels and volumes of biomass we burn, if  support is set at the appropriate level.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So moving on to cash flow and, first, working capital, coal stocks increased by 200,000 tons in 2011 to stand at 1.4  million tons at the end of the year, which together with the impact of higher coal prices, contributed £24 million of  the total outflow of cash from working capital of £51 million. Tax cash of £68 million reflects payments on account  in respect of our liabilities for 2010 and 2011. So after other cash movements of capital expenditure, debt service  and items of equity, the closing cash balance was £233 million, with the previously ring-fenced cash tax saved  from utilizing Eurobond unwind losses now released to the business.

texts.speaker: Dorothy C. Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The only thing I would add to Tony's financials summary is that biomass, as I think you all know, remains a  priority and central to our strategy. Progress across the work streams for biomass was very good in 2011 and we  really do stand ready to transform Drax into a predominantly biomass generator, if we get the right support from  government.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We'll start with the major themes, 2012 we think was a good year for us. We delivered profits in line with  expectations and once again was underpinned by very strong operational performance. We entered 2013 with a  very good hedge, a good strong hedge, but we are expecting reduced profitability in 2013 and the key reason for  that is carbon. We've – in 2013, from April, we stopped having a national allocation of carbon allowances under  the EU ETS. And in 2013, from April, we have the UK carbon tax, the first year of the UK carbon tax. And both of  those will impact our profitability.  The other thing about 2013 is that we expect it to be a very busy year. And the reason we expect it to be a busy year  is we now have the mandate, means and expertise to implement our biomass transformation strategy.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of availability, we had 86% availability at the power station. That was from a combination of a 4.8%  forced outage rate and a 9.6% planned outage rate. Two of our units had a major plant outage in the year. Our  forced outage had a rate which is just ahead of our long term target which is 5% and I would remind you we've set  that 5% through extensive growth benchmarking and actually it's global benchmarking, and what we're trying to  achieve is exactly the right balance between excellent operational performance and cost effectiveness, so we're  very pleased with the 4.8%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our load factor was 82% that means that 95% of the time we were available to generate, we generated. And that is  a quite a number because we only generate when it's economic to do so, and what it really reflects is the true  competitive position of Drax. Drax has a very highly efficient coal station, we have very good unit flexibility and  actually we, I believe, have very good use or judicious use of attractive alternative or advantageous fuels. So very  high load factor given the availability.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: During the year, we completed our high and low pressure turbine upgrade on time to budget and these upgraded  unit – turbines are working very well. We're very pleased with it. We're actually about to launch another upgrade  program, and this time it's our intermediate pressure turbine, so each unit has one intermediate – it has one high  pressure, one intermediate and three low pressure.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now the efficiency gains we get from the intermediate upgrade are slightly lower and we're only going to  implement the upgrade on the units we intend to convert to biomass. And the reason why that makes sense is  because biomass is so much more expensive than coal. It's roughly three times the cost of coal as a delivered fuel.  So we're launching that upgrade this year. We start with the first unit and it will cost us about £20 million in total.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving on to Haven, I'd just like to remind you that the strategic value of Haven to the group is that it's very much  about a credit-efficient route to market for our power sales. Our key strategy for Haven is to grow the business, so  we have a lot of access to this credit-efficient route to market. Our aim is to grow it to a 10 to 15 terawatt hour  business by 2015 and we're very pleased with our performance in 2012 in delivering this growth. I actually – sorry,  I meant to mention that as we drive for this growth through to 2015, we do expect to make modest losses because  we will be investing in this growth.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Haven's business proposition is all about really good customer service, and so we're really pleased for the second  year in a row to be rated number one by Datamonitor for customer satisfaction in the SME, the small and  medium-sized enterprise, part of the market. We are beginning to develop a good reputation also in the larger  industrial and commercial market, but as many of you already know, we are a more recent entrant to that market,  so it will take time for us to develop our reputation.  This slide shows you our contracted position. We are very well hedged for 2013, as you can see, and we're about  40% hedged for 2014. What you can also see is the expansion of our fixed fuel position and a lot of that represents  our advance biomass purchasing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: There's been quite a change in the context against which we trade. And I should make it clear that when we trade,  we trade to hedge our physical position.
