So our trading is really about hedging. The change in context, there are  three. Firstly, we really do have the mandate to now implement our biomass strategy. What that means is when we  hedge, when we trade forward, what we're looking at is a business where we will have a biomass generation  business and a coal generation business. So we need a strategy that fits with that.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The third factor, not really a change, but something I wanted to bring to your attention, is about power market  liquidity. The power market trades about four seasons forward, but when you get to season three and four,  liquidity drops quite dramatically. We, actually with the introduction of the UK carbon tax, have almost put a limit  on that because actually the carbon tax is always only announced in the budget. So that means that today, we don't  know what is going to be the carbon tax in summer 2015, which means if you choose to sell power in summer  2015, you're taking a risk on what will actually be the carbon tax.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: When you put those factors together, what we've done is we've designed a new trading strategy or hedging strategy  for the business. And, in fact, there are two strategies, one for our coal business and one for our biomass business.  With our coal business, it's on balance or it's relatively a short strategy. Going forward, our strategy is going to be  to hedge two to three seasons forward. And again, we will have a strategy that's about fixing the dark green spread.  So when we sell the power, we'll look to fix the coal and carbon. The timing of actually when we do our sales is all  about what is the spread attractiveness, what is the market liquidity and credit efficiency of the trade.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our biomass business, by contrast, is a relatively long strategy because it's all about security of supply of the fuel  and control of that fuel cost. And I would remind you that when we generate from biomass, we generate ROC and  LEC certificates, and those sterling denominated and go up with UK inflation.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our biomass, we generally contract – we contract it almost predominantly in foreign currency, and it's generally  over 7 year to 10 year tenor, and normally, actually always, it's against a fixed indexation formula. And that  indexation formula can contain a combination of local inflation, fuel, sometimes freight and sometimes fiber. We,  in fact, have some contracts that don't even have the fiber in it.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: What we've put at the bottom chart, which we thought might be useful, is just an illustration of what it might look  like for U.S. pellet from the South delivered into Drax. So that shows you the type of makeup of that indexation.  What we do with the biomass, we try to control the cost as much as possible. We do it through this fixed formula  that we will have in the contract, what we also do is we hedge where we can. So we will hedge the foreign currency,  we will hedge when it's sufficient the fuel exposure, and we'll hedge the freight.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: When you look at the biomass and you look at our ROC and LEC revenues, it's quite largely – the cost of biomass  is quite largely, not wholly, covered by those revenues. But we only really fix the bark spread when we sell the  power. And, actually, similar with our coal strategy, when we fix that bark spread, is all about market  attractiveness, liquidity, and credit efficiency.  And with that, I'd like to hand over to Tony who is now going to take you through the financial revenue.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Dorothy. So it's been an important year for the group and I will spend some time focusing on our  funding and credit arrangements following the refinancing last year and also the economics of the biomass  transformation we are now executing. But I'll start with the financial highlights for 2012.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our balance sheet and cash position is strong with net cash of £311 million at the year-end enhanced by the  refinancing work in 2012 which established a robust financial platform with which to execute the biomass  transformation. I'll go through those items in more detail shortly.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: But first on to the profit summary. A year-on-year increase in gross margin reflecting strong plant performance  and a record level of generation at the power station with significantly higher operating costs with the planned  double outage and the cost incurred accelerating our plans to convert the first unit to biomass and this has driven  EBITDA down year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Below this figure, unrealized losses on derivative contracts, which is a non-cash item, of £36 million. This is the  mark-to-market movements on the foreign exchange contracts and financial coal not qualifying for hedge  accounting. With increased currency hedging associated with our biomass contracting, going forward, there is  potential for significant volatility on this line.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Depreciation of £58 million is in line with last year. It's worth noting that depreciation charges will increase over  time as we begin to commission and operate our new biomass facilities, and for 2013, the depreciation charge will  be in the range of £65 million to £70 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The average achieved price for our electricity sold in the wholesale market is £51.30 per megawatt hour, down  from £55.60 last year. You can see the trend in power prices in the chart on the right.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to other income, firstly, ROCs and LECs. Within income, we recorded ROC and LEC sales of £36  million against £65 million in 2011. Clearly, we burnt much less biomass in 2012 driving the reduction in ROC  sales. But to see the full picture you also need to look at the balance sheet where ROC assets fell from £32 million  at the end of 2011 to £19 million at this year-end, reflecting ROC sold as well as those utilized at Haven.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And just to remind you, we did change our accounting policy for ROCs at the beginning of 2012 to better match  the value generated to the period in which the biomass was burned. But as we barely breakeven at half of ROC, the  new policy has had no impact on 2012 results.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Ancillary services and other revenues are broadly similar year-on-year. Although during 2012 certain coal  inventories held at port were sold to a third party at a price close to the balance sheet value. And that's for stock  management purposes and that did result in additional sales of £17 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So on to cost of sales, which at £1.3 billion a 5% lower year-on-year which includes power buybacks at Drax, power  purchases at Haven, and good charges in both businesses. And within cost of sales, £929 million related to fuel  and carbon costs, a decrease of 9% year-on-year with high generation, but lower average fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Average fuel cost excluding carbon of £30.60 per megawatt hour, down on £33.30 last year primarily as a result of  the falling coal prices and fuel mix with less biomass burn in 2012. Including carbon, average fuel costs are £33.70  per megawatt hour, down from £38.70 in 2011. With the average cost of our purchase carbon requirements down  only £6.30 per tonne compared to £12 last year, this is a result of the collapsing carbon prices in the second half of  2011, driven by an anticipated oversupply of the EU ETS.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: You can see these trends in coal and carbon prices in the two charts with both at their lowest level now for almost  three years. So when all of these factors are taken into aggregate, we delivered a gross margin £511 million, slightly  up from last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So onto operating costs, where total costs were £213 million up £46 million, we previously guided to a full-year  operating cost increase of £38 million for 2012 which included year-on-year increases of £20 million is a direct  result of the planned double outage together with a structural uplift in business rate charges. Further planned  increases resulted from R&D investment in biomass that is construction of the work related to trials which was not  capital in nature.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And after three successive years of holding underlying cost level taking some inflation into the cost base. We did  incur additional operating cost of £8 million over and above this original budget. As soon as the final pieces of  ROC support regulation were confirmed in October, we accelerated our plans for the first unit conversion. And as  a result, we incurred additional maintenance system and other costs. But this work has been incredibly valuable,  placing Drax in a position to convert our first unit to biomass in April when the support levels is increased to one

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our guidance for total operating costs for 2013, another double outage year, is £215 million which includes further  investment building Haven and our U.S. business. This is offset by the conclusion of CESP, the Community  Energy Savings Program, which eliminates approximately £5 million from our cost base.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to capital investment, and importantly to start here, total capital costs for the biomass transformation  remained in the range of £650 million to £700 million around half of which is the fuel delivery, storage and  distribution systems and plant modifications required at Drax site to allow us to handle 7 million to 8 million  tonnes a year of biomass which is enough for a three unit conversion with the balance covering two separate  streams of investment. Firstly, the development of upstream supply chain infrastructure that is two U.S. pellet  plants delivering a total of 900,000 tonnes per year of pellets, and a U.S. port facility with export capacity of up to  £3 million tonnes a year. And secondly, to cover potential work towards compliance with the Industrial Emissions  Directive which is in place from 2016.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Dorothy will update on the key milestones for the biomass projects and our progress to-date shortly. But in terms  of the financial results for 2012, total asset additions were £224 million, and that includes £180 million for the  biomass transformation as well as the final installment of our HP/LP turbine upgrade.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Looking forward, the next two years will be characterized by significant capital investment and construction  activities, and whilst the precise phasing will depend on the timing of our U.S. investments, we currently estimate  total capital expenditure for 2013 will be in the range of £250 million to £300 million which includes  approximately £50 million for plant efficiency and other non-biomass related projects.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Cash flows, within working capital where the total outflow was £35 million we increased biomass stocks to  400,000 tonnes which was £30 million of the outflow. This is building fuel stocks ahead of the first unit  conversion in April. Much of this stock is held at ports or in temporary storage close to Drax. We also increased  coal stocks by 200,000 tonnes to stand at 1.6 million tonnes at the end of the year. However, falling coal prices  has resulted in a small net inflow of cash for the year of £11 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Just a moment to look more broadly at working capital going forward, there will be outflows as we deliver our  biomass plans. We estimate each unit will require some £40 million to £50 million factoring in increased biomass  stocks ownership and payment terms.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now moving onto funding and debt facilities and to recap on the refinancing, following the agreement of £100  further £100 million term loan facility with the UK Green Investment Bank and we financed a revolving credit  facility.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally before concluding, I wanted to take a moment to reflect on the economics of the biomass transformation.  And here I draw your attention to this chart. The dark green line represents the capital investment profile for Drax  from just after listing and looking into the future. And the blue line is an EBITDA profile. Now one obvious but  very important caveat here is profiles do not constitute long-term profit or CapEx guidance. For example, if power  prices collapse, under an extreme scenario, our financial performance would of course be negatively impacted.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The chart is illustrative, reflecting the general shape we expect to see over the next few years under most  scenarios. And it does illustrate the most important point we want to make and that is after a period of declining  profits driven down by the increasing cost of carbon emissions and relatively modest levels of CapEx.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The significant investment required over the next two years to execute the biomass transformation has the  potential to unlock a substantial improvement in profits and cash flow generation from 2015 and beyond, and  restore the business to the levels of profitability and cash generation seen after listing, but with a more secure long  term future. Of course, before we get there, we need to deliver the capital investment on time and to budget.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And as recognized in market forecasts, profits in 2014, 2013 and 2014 will be below recent levels impacted by the  increasing costs of carbon as we move into the Phase 3 of the EU ETS with no free carbon allowances for the UK  power sector and as the UK carbon tax kicks in.  In addition for 2013, we do expect one-time costs for the first unit conversion of around £20 million, and this is  not come at the in consensus forecasts. These costs will be incurred within gross margin and mainly relates to the  use of temporary biomass storage facilities, I described earlier, along with the impact of expected lower units  availability as we initially run in temporary mode, Ms. Dorothy will discuss shortly.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So to sum up, we delivered solid financial performance in 2012, but importantly last year, we secured the  financing required to support our growth plans and establish a robust platform from which to execute the biomass  transformation which has the potential to deliver substantial profit and cash growth from 2015 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Thank you. Okay. So now let's talk about our biomass transformation. And first I'd like to say is about  transformation of the business, but in reality it's a very large project that we simply need to execute very, very  well. And I'd remind that it's a project that we've had the benefit of many, many years of planning, 10 years of  experience of burning biomass. And also as we go through this, I think you'll come to see that this project,  actually, is already in advanced execution.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now the key to successful delivery of any project is that you have timely delivery of all the different components of  that project. And the four critical components we think of this project are biomass sourcing, U.S. investments, UK  infrastructure and the work we're doing at the Drax site. And what we're going to go – what I'm going to go  through is those four components and how the milestones for those four components fit together on what we're  tracking to actually monitor whether we're indeed delivering this project the way we intend to deliver it, which is  very well and on a timely basis.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So let's start with sourcing. The absolute starting point of sourcing biomass for Drax, actually should be for  anyone, but particularly for Drax, is that you start with sustainability. You need to verify that your potential  biomass is indeed sustainable. We established many years ago leading sustainability standards. And when I said  leading, what happened was, we took the best of forestry and other sustainability practices and designed bespoke  biomass sustainability standards.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The core to this sustainability standard is delivering real carbon-savings and protecting our biodiversity. We  carbon footprint all the biomass we burn, we're now in the fifth year of carbon footprinting our biomass and, as  many of you know, we do external audits to confirm our compliance with our sustainability policy.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So sustainability is right at the core of how you buy your biomass. We're very pleased that the UK has now  legislated sustainability policy for the UK. The UK standards are expected to become mandatory later this year.  One of – within those standards, the government has chosen to grandfather, the greenhouse gas saving to the  limit you need to achieve up to 2020. We think that's very good news, and they're also currently consulting on  what is the limit beyond 2020.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The other small bit I wanted to talk about in this context, sustainability, and is wider than that, is biomass is still a  new market and we need to set robust standards on how that market trades. And I'm pleased to say that we and  the other major consumers in the industry and actually the producers all working together to develop those robust  standards, which, I think, is very important.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So in terms of supply chain development, I think you probably know that we have secured the unit the biomass we  need for the first unit, which as Tony said, we're going to be converting in April this year. We've made good  progress on the second unit. We've got over a million tonnes of additional biomass, so that means for 2014, which  is the year we're thinking of converting the second unit, we have over 3 million tonnes of biomass secured now  and we're already in negotiations not only for the balance we need for the third unit – for the second unit, but also  the biomass we need for the third unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: What we've put up here is the names of four key suppliers of our biomass, Enviva, Green Circle, Pinnacle and  Plum Creek. The first three are all pellet producers, North American pellet producers. Plum Creek is a large  forestry company and actually what they'll be supplying us is with fiber. And actually Plum Creek is the supplier of  those underpinning contracts that we mentioned in our last results to actually form the basis of our fuel supply for  our pellet operations that we're going to be building in the U.S. Gulf and in the Gulf of Mexico.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Really, really important in the supply chain is to get the UK logistics right. There is no point if you can buy the  biomass, but you can't receive it and deliver it to the power station. Two key components to that, one is what we  do with ports and the other is what we do with rail.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the port, we already are using the facility that was developed for us by Port of Tyne. It's now got the  capability for up to 2 million tonnes. We're building an extra million tonne facility at Port of Hull. We've agreed  with Associated British Ports that they will build for us a 3 million tonne facility at Immingham Port. We already  actually bring biomass in smaller quantities through various other ports in the UK and we're in negotiations for  additional port facilities. So that's an overview of our port strategy.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of rail, actually, this is quite interesting. We've been working for some time on designing a more efficient  way to bring the biomass into Drax because the biomass is much less dense than coal and most of our rolling  stock, which would carry something like biomass is designed for coal.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So what we've done is we've designed biomass wagons, bespoke biomass wagons. We think these are probably the  first bespoke biomass wagons in the world. And we have our first ones under fabrication. When you take the  design of these wagons and you add it to the work we've been doing on actually our own rail infrastructure, we  expect to have the capabilities to carry 50% more biomass per train once we have these wagons in operation. And  that's the combination of more capacity on the wagons and also longer trains. So that is really important. It limits  – it reduces our use of the rail network, it's more efficient, will bring into Drax a very positive development, we  think.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So that's what we're doing on the supply chain. The next thing I wanted to take you through is the U.S. We've now  setup a business in the U.S. We call it Drax Biomass International. We've hired quite a strong team there. It's a  combination of local experts. So we've hired – and we've been very fortunate, I think, in the staff we've found.  We've hired local experts in everything from fiber procurement to construction management, operations  management, logistics, all areas where we need real strong expertise.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We've complemented that with transferring people from Drax in the UK. And we have transferred people in the  financial control. The team is led by an individual, Chuck Davis, who has got extensive experience in bioenergy in  the U.S., but actually fortunate for us, experience of the UK electricity market as well, so a very good combination,  very strong team.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: At the end of last year or towards the end of the last year, the board, our board approved the investment in two  pellet facilities and the port facility that Tony provided – described. The pellet facilities are both 450,000 tonnes  per annum capacity and they're located in Morehouse Parish in Louisiana, and Amite County in Mississippi. I'm  sure are well-known to all of you. The fourth facility will be in Baton Rouge just off river.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our target is to start construction at the first pellet plant this summer. The second pellet plant should start three  months later. And if we do achieve that target, and this is all about getting construction right, so we may slip, but  if we do achieve it then we will go into commercial operation in the winter 2014-2015.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Next onto what we're doing at the Drax site, so there are three components of what we're doing at the Drax site,  first is all about rail unloading and storage. Second is taking the biomass from the storage and delivering it to the  unit. And the third is the modifications we do to the units themselves. In terms of capital cost and program, the  modifications to the units probably – is very much the smallest component, but it will deliver material advantages,  that's the part, actually, we prefer to keep somewhat confidential, but we wanted to tell you about the first two.  And we thought the easiest way to do that was to actually give you a movie.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So we made that video this month, and I think you can see from that video that we're not ready with new systems  to fuel our first unit. What you have ahead of you is the schedule for the first unit. What we're going to use for the  first unit? If you remember back in, I think it was 2008 through 2010, we've built co-firing system, a very large co- firing system. And what it had was it had the rail and road unloading, it had limited storage and then it had the  ability to deliver biomass – to mill biomass and then deliver it safely to the unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Over the last year-and-a-half, I suppose really, we've been investing in that system so we can use it to fuel a single  unit well. That's how we're going to handle the first conversion. It's that and the storage, Tony mentioned, because  we don't have enough storage just on that co-firing, so we've contracted some additional external storage.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now the thing about co-firing system is it was always designed as a secondary fueling system. It wasn't a fuel –  coal fueling system. So it's designed on the basis that if we didn't have the biomass, we just add some extra coal  because it was the co-firing. The problem with the converted unit is we don't have that option. If we don't have the  biomass, we simply don't generate.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now the relevance of this is because we designed it as a secondary fueling system, it doesn't have the level of  redundancy that you'd normally have in a coal fueling system which means there are more single points of failure.  And that means that we're likely to have lower availability of our fuel delivery system than we will have when  finally those systems, you saw in the video, come available.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the new, sort of, what I think of is the proper systems, actually the co-firing system is a perfectly  proper system, it's just not designed for the coal fueling system. In terms of the new system, we expect the fuel  delivery, the bit from storage into the unit to come on in November and we've actually designed that so that can  link through to the co-firing reception facilities, so we can use it from November.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And we expect the first stage of the rail unloading and storage to come through in December. So what we expect is,  by the end of this year our first unit will be running on the new systems, the ones you saw on the video. They won't  be complete. And what I wanted to take you through then next is the whole milestone schedule.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: If you put – think of those four areas I've talked about, how that fits into the milestone schedule. And I need to  start by explaining our, sort of, tactical approach. And our tactical approach is that we want to have the technical  capability to convert units in 2014, 2015 – sorry, 2013, 2014, and 2015. Now when we actually convert those units  is wholly dependent on the biomass sourcing strategy and how we secure timely or the timing it takes for us to  scale the biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So when you work through the schedule, what you'll see is technically, we're going to be capable of that conversion  2013, 2014 and 2015, but actually in terms of our sourcing strategy, we think it's right to indicate that the third  unit could well only come into play in the ROC year 2016, 2017. We will try and accelerate that, but it just depends  how the biomass market develops.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So in terms of sourcing, we need 2 million tonnes for the first unit, that's secure and in place. We need 4 million  tonnes for the second unit, as I've said, we're well advanced on that, we'd say we need 6 million tonnes for the  third unit and that's leaving a certain amount to the spot market and storage fluctuations.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Rail wagons, fabrication schedule is ahead of you, we will not get our first wagons until 2014. If you remember, for  the co-firing facility, we actually modified some coal wagons so they could use – carry biomass, so we're  comfortable with the first unit conversion because we will use these coal wagons not quite sufficient, but perfectly  safe and good for use of biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the new biomass systems that you saw in the delivery, we talked through the first two components, the  next is actually construction schedule, the storage for two units should be available in March 2014 and storage for  three units will be ready when the whole construction program of that large construction at Drax completes, which  we expect to be in the third quarter of 2014.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, the last bit of the jigsaw is the Industrial Emissions Directive and what is our design for the Industrial  Emissions Directive. Now we expect to reach our conclusion on that by the end of this year. Now, I think you know  that EU has made some quite good flexibility accommodations in how the IED is implemented when it starts in  2016. We have spent years now developing the engineering solutions to that.  We are unable to finalize our solutions because we really need to understand the NOx performance of these  converted biomass units. So from the minute we start generating on a purely biomass basis in our first converted  unit, we will be doing the work to understand the NOx performance and how that feeds into our IED solution.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The only other thing I wanted to mention before we close is our longer term, even longer term strategy objective  and that's CCS. We are part of one of the parties bidding into the UK competition. We're doing this in partnership  with Alstom and BOC.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We're very pleased, actually, with this project. We're quite enthusiastic about it as a CCS solution. It's an oxy-fired  new built plant at Drax is the proposal. Where we stand is if we get through to the next stage of the competition  the proposal is that the government will provide funding for detailed frontend engineering and design studies as  well as the, sort of, commercial framework. That's expected to be a two-year study and most of the funding will  come from government. We'll know in the coming months whether we are indeed awarded this, so expect it, I  think, around Easter. And the only other thing I'd point, I'd say is that the CfD is the back bone of this and we've  very pleased with the commercial realism of the government as we talk through the CfD structure.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So we bring it to a conclusion, good performance in 2012, profits in line with expectation, we've entered 2013 with  strong hedge, but high carbon, the first year of the UK carbon tax and we are in advanced execution, I hope you'd  agree, on our strategy to transform the business into a predominantly biomass generator. And with that we'll take  questions.

file: DRXL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 18February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So let's start with the major themes of the results. We're very pleased with our results for 2013. Y ou all have seen  this morning that our profits announced are ahead of expectations and that's having increased guidance towards  the end of the year. We did have lower profits all due to higher carbon costs but it was a year of good operations  both for coal and for biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We entered 2014 with a notable weakening of the market but with strong plans to increase our biomass  generation. And actually that's what we think is most notable about 2013 as we really made a big step forward in  our journey to transform Drax into a predominantly biomass generator. We are now confident that we will be a  predominantly biomass generator in 2016. But I think, most importantly, we are now confident that in terms of  output and efficiency, we're not going to just deliver good performance from these units. We're going to deliver  excellent performance and this performance is going to surpass our expectations at the time we put together our  investment proposition for this biomass transformation. So the real message today is we have made really  significant technical progress in how we are going to operate these units going forward.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of coal performance, our availability was 84%. We had a 6.8% forced outage rate for the year. What that  shows is we had a marked improvement in the second half of the year. I don't know if you recall but the first half  of the year was 7.6% forced outage rate. We're still targeting 5% as our long-term forced outage rate and we see  that is top quartile performance. And we would expect to now repair it to be above or below that. Our load factor  was 80% and what that really just shows you is the highly competitive position of Drax's coal units.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Biomass performance. Always, a bit more complicated, the picture for biomass performance. So we converted the  first unit in April and we ran it on temporary fueling systems until we started commissioning the new bespoke  systems in October. We ran that commissioning through October, November, December, and by the end of the  year we were operating this unit solely on the new systems.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: As we started the year, we were actually constrained because of these temporary fueling systems on our maximum  output on a sustained basis. And that green graph shows you our dispatch. And what yo u can see is under the  temporary fueling systems, our maximum output was around 550 megawatts most of the time. As we started to  commission the new bespoke systems, we started to deliver the 585 megawatts and actually indeed, by the end of  the year, we were delivering over 600 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our load factor was lower, 7 5%. I think we made very clear that this was going to happen. This is all about  commissioning the right logistic support. We didn't have it all in place for the start of the year. We've got a lot  more in place now but we've got to go through the first half of this year to get really up to where we want to be.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Little bit on markets. Y ou'll have seen from our announcement this morning and actually many of you would have  been watching the markets earlier or during the year, is since the start of the year we've had a notable weakening  in the markets. All of our – a very warm winter. What has happened is we've had a falling of gas prices. There's  quite a high storage position on gas and that's fed straight through into the power m arket. Unfortunately, it's been  warm and windy. So what we've also had is actually higher than expected wind generation so that actually has led  to a softening of ROC prices as well. And you can see it just in the end of the graph from the top, the falloff in that.  And that will affect our profitability this year and Tony will take you through that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of our traded position, you can see that in the bottom chart on the right, and our trading strategy – at the  moment, our trading strategy is unchanged. So the coal strategy is all about near-to-medium term power sales and  when we sell the power we fix the dark green spread by fixing the cost of coal and the cost of carbon.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our biomass strategy, very different. It's all about securing fixed price, long-term of the biomass supply. So  security of supply and confidence in what that cost is going to be, and then nearer -term, matching that with the  sale of the ROC and the power position. We do believe we're going to be entering into a CfD world. And so what we  have designed is a new trading strategy based around CfDs. We're not implementing that until we execute our  CfDs but it's very similar. The key difference is our top priority is that security of margin on the CfD. So that would  drive the start of our trading strategy and then we will have a coal and ROC trading strategy, not dissimilar to the  strategy we have today.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And what it is is they're designed to give price certainty. So if there's a CfD strike price for each technology, if the  power price is below the CfD's strike price, then there's a payment to the generator. If the power price is above,  then we sell our power in the market and have to make – pay the difference to the counterparty. So what we  effectively get is a steady income stream and that strike price is indexed to inflation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The government has not yet setup the full long-term CfD regime and that's going to be the support mechanism for  all renewables going forward in the UK – or all generation renewables, I should say. What the government wanted  to do is avoid an investment hiatus. So what they decided to do was put in some early CfD contracts or put in place  some early CfD contracts in advance of this enduring regime. 27 projects applied for these early CfD contracts. We  had two applications for our next two converted units. 16 were deemed eligible but it became very clear, I think,  pretty early in the process that actually, the pot of money available  for these early CfDs was smaller than the  contracts, the 16 projects would have required. So what the government had was a very, very complex, very  detailed application process and they ranked these projects to deliver that affordability.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Firstly, that the CfDs are a key to the policy framework for the UK in delivering its renewable commitment to t he  EU. They're absolutely pivotal for delivering that obligation we committed to many, many years ago, that 15% of  our energy will be from renewable sources by 2020.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second is that the CfDs for renewables are relatively short tenures, or short-term contracts. The longest is 15  years and the shortest are the CfDs for biomass conversions which are 12 years or less because the end date for  biomass conversion is 2027 .

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So let's go on to what we're thinking about with biomass. Our biomass – our schedule for future conversions is all  about delivering the next set of investments through the supply chain and that is underpinned by the CfDs. So our  timetable of conversions is very much driven by the CfDs and let me walk you through it year -by-year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So starting with 2014, our focus really is on delivering good performance from our existing converted unit. And  what we plan to do is we're going to modify another coal unit and we're going to have that coal unit run as an  enhanced co-firing unit, burning up to 85% biomass or more. This is going to be a combination of a revenue  earning unit and actually a rather sophisticated test bed. We're going to use it to test further what agricultural  fuels we can burn and what range of woody – technical specifications for wood pellets.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Very important, what we're going to do with this unit in 2014 is we're going to trial a low NOx solution. So we're  going to trial selective non-catalytic reduction and we're going to trial low NOx burners. What we will also use it  for is to build up our biomass supplies for our next unit conversion. And our next unit conversion is scheduled for  April 2015. And 2015 could be a very busy year for conversion because the earliest date that we will convert our  third unit is actually the fourth quarter of 2015 itself. If we do convert that earlier and we're really unsure about  the timetable at the moment, it's all about the CfDs and underpinning that supply chain. The load factor of that  unit will depend on the supply chain development.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And what I would say is if you look at the forward markets, see a biomass unit running at 40% load in winter 2015  makes as much, if not more, profit than a coal unit running unconstrained. So it doesn't – we are quite prepared  to run these units at less than full load and convert a little bit early. So the way we think of the world is in 2016,  we're confident we're going to have three units operating on biomass and we're very hopeful that we'll be well  advanced with plans for converting a fourth unit and that fourth unit will be supported by an enduring CfD of  which more later.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: But the real point of interest is what have we been doing on unit optimization. As you would expect, from when we  first converted our unit in April, we have been working really, really hard on how we can get absolutely the best  performance out of these units. And it is difficult. It is complex. It's about multi-faceted optimization, it's about  fuel delivery, it's about airflows, it's about heat balance. Actually, Peter can answer questions on it. He's much  better.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And what we expect to deliver is an output of 630 megawatts using standard biomass, actually up to 645 megawatt  with very high calorific biomass. And the challenge to Peter and his team is whether we can actually find a solution  to do that with standard biomass, but 630 megawatt is what you should really work on. And an efficiency  reduction 60% less than we previously expected, so an efficiency reduction of just 0.5%. We have actually put in  the systems on a temporary basis to deliver that already on our first unit conversion. We need to make the  investment for that to be on a sustained basis but we already expect to deliver that performance on an average  basis in 2014 for the first converted unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: There are two catches there. The first is that having better combustion means that actually our NOx emissions  from these converted units is much higher than we expected. So we actually had lower NOx emissions when we  had lower output and lower efficiency which is why we are doing the trials this year to actually retrofit SNCR and  low NOx burners, and we are going to have to invest more in this area than we had expected.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second catch is we actually genuinely did not believe this was possible. So we've designed all our logistics and  supply solutions on 585 megawatt maximum output. And what that means is we simply don't have the port  capacity. We don't have the rail capacity. We don't have the biomass supplies to support this higher capacity. And  it's going to take time for us to put in the solutions to deliver that and we ne ed the early CfDs to underpin those  solutions. So we see it's going to take at least this year and next year to solve it. So we will be constrained by  logistics and biomass supplies relative to the 630 maximum output.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: When we put it altogether in terms of availability, if you take the technical availability from the fact that we are  learning how to run these units, you add in the logistics constraint. We think the effective, the real availability  taking both logistics and technical into account will be 80% this year and next – but by the time we get to 2016,  our year of full delivery, it will be very – we expect the availability on the biomass units to be very, very similar to  the coal units, 85% to 90%.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of fuel supply, well, it won't surprise you that we remain totally confident that we can get all the biomass  we need for three-unit conversions, and indeed four or five conversions. Our price guidance on it is totally  consistent. We haven't seen any movement in that. So in today's money, we expect our delivered biomass to cost  £8.10 a gigajoule. We've made good progress in the near-term. We have over 4 million tons secured for the ROC  year commencing 2014 and we've made very good progress on our negotiations for the third and fourth units. We  do expect the biomass to predominantly come from North America. That still is our major source. We're hopeful  for some additional supplies from Europe and we may well have our first early volumes from Latin America but it  will be small relative to the North American volumes. What's becoming very clear to us is there is real value for  Drax in having our own pellet production and so maybe if I go on a bit and talk a bit about that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: First, in terms of what we're building today; two pellet plants in the U.S. south, one in Louisiana, one in  Mississippi each 450,000 tons and a port facility which is 3 million tons and that's about aggregating with third - party suppliers through our own port facility. Project's going very well, on-time and budget and I thought you  might have a bit of a chuckle at the ports – the technical solution for the port. Some of you might have noticed that  it's somewhat similar to our storage solution at Drax. That's the port, Baton Rouge, so anyway. But they're very  small or at least they're less than half the size of the domes we have at Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: What we have been assessing very carefully through the year is the benefits of having our own pellet production  and there are many benefits. Firstly, we have good control over quality, technical specification which is important.  Secondly and I think maybe the most important is about timely and secure delivery. Timely is the important part  of that. And thirdly, if we strategically locate our own pellet production, what we can achieve is more aggregation  benefits. We can have more biomass pellets through single ports and on larger ships and that will delivers value to  the group.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So we are looking with what we're pursuing as options for up to 2 million tons additional pellet production by  Drax. We expect that mainly to be wood pellet capacity in the U.S. with associated ports. We are looking very early  stages on expanding our store pellet capacity in the UK. We're not sure whether this is all about the agri trials we'll  be doing this year but that is one of our cheaper biomass fuels and we think it's good to make more investments in  the UK.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of logistic, I think the most pleasing thing about last years or early this year as well is we've negotiated or  executed our first long-term freight contract direct to Drax. Often our biomass has been delivered at port in the  UK. Now we have more and more biomass that actually we're having to arrange for its delivery from port in the  U.S. The contracts we've secured cover about 20% of our production for a three -unit production. What's  important about this is we've secured a long-term hedge through these contracts and that is unusual, because  typically, for this type of contract, about a third of the cost of the contract is indexed to some oil product. And we  have a hedge for that component through these contracts which is all about the strategy of having security of price  for our biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of on-site storage, our first dome is operating well. It's come in at slightly above the rated capacity which  we're pleased at. The second dome is in hot commissioning which for those of you who  don't know what that  means, it means we're starting to put pellet through it and we expect by the third quarter to have all four domes in  operation. And many, many wagons under fabrication and the wagons are actually proving very, very good; very  pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, we continue to procure against our industry -leading sustainability policy. We're now  into our sixth year of carbon foot printing our biomass. So I'm absolutely confident we're delivering a low carbon  fuel. I'm also absolutely confident that the biomass sourcing we have will meet the carbon requirements of the UK,  mandatory requirement that come in in April 2015 or are designed to come in.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The UK is still working on the mandatory requirements, or mandatory standards. They have set out the general  principles and it won't surprise you that these fit well with Drax. And that's – the reason is it's all about good  sustainability. This is no rocket science. This is actually being a responsible citizen. So we're very pleased with the  UK principles, they meet our principles.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of IED, I've already mentioned that we are going to be trialing on our enhanced co -firing unit. But a low  NOx solution in terms of SNCR, selective non-catalytic reduction and low NOx burners, we're doing exactly the  same on one of our coal units. We see this as our lead solution. We expect – all our analysis shows that the test will  go well and produce the desired results. In fact, we've done some test burns already in some smaller facilities. But  we are retaining an SCR option just in case something comes up that we are not aware of.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: CCS, we were very pleased to execute the CCS contracts with government towards the end of the last year. We're  now in full feasibility work for this and this really is full feasibility. It's engineering, it's commercial structure, it's  financing structure. We expect it to take about two years and at that point we will take the decision whether or not  to go forward with this investment and that would all be about whethe r the risk reward balance is right and the  government support which they've been very clear about is indeed committed to this investment.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of the capacity mechanism, the market design is also ongoing but there's a little more definition available  here at the moment. And actually in the current design, we're not confident that this creates an attractive  opportunity either for our coal unit or new build gas. In the case of the coal units, it really is a question of the  penalty risk versus the potential reward. In the case of the gas unit, a new build gas, I think this partly reflects our  view on forward spreads. So we do have a concern as to what will be forward gas spreads in a power market  whether it's pretty high degree of renewable penetration and nothing significant amount of renewable generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The other area I thought I should briefly talk about is carbon price support. I'm sure you have heard that there  have been discussions – I'm not sure how you put it – communication maybe about maybe whether the defined  trajectory through to 2020 and beyond might change. We can't give you a view on this. I think we'll all be waiting  with great interest what comes out in the March budget. But what I would say is we have always felt that this  trajectory was unsustainable for the UK, if it was not matched by a similar global policy and of course, an EU  policy. It simply is too expensive for the consumer and it's too expensive for our industry.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Dorothy. In 2013 we delivered solid financial performance. EBITDA of £230 million is in ahead  of expectation but it is 23% down year-on-year, and this wholly reflects much higher carbon costs. In fact if it will  not for this increase, the EBITDA would have been comfortably ahead of last year. Underlying earnings per share  was £0.353, which drives a dividend of £0.176 per share, £71 million. This is in line with our policy to distribute  50% of underlying earnings and incorporates a final dividend of £0.089 per share which is £36 million. Our  balance sheet and cash position remains strong with net cash of £7 1 million at the end of December.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Into 2014, as Dorothy said, markets are weaker following the mild winter we've been having. But the bigger  picture, the capital investment for our biomass transformation remains on schedule and to budget. And we are  well along the path in transforming the group and with it, the value proposition for our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So on to the detail and I'll start with the profit summary. I'll come onto the components of EBITDA and below this  figure, unrealized losses on derivative contracts which is a non-cash item is £110 million. And this is mainly the  mark-to-market movements on foreign exchange contracts which do not qualify for hedge accounting. Whilst  most of our significant biomass contracts are priced in dollars, we have in place a very extensive currency hedging  program covering all contracted biomass as well as a substantial proportion of forecast purchases for the future.  And this provides us with a significant degree of protection from sterling weakening against the dollar and  represents a critical component of our hedging program, de-risking a huge exposure for the business.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Onto depreciation which is £65 million is up on last year with increased investment. Dep reciation charges will  continue to increase over time as we commission and operate the new biomass facilities. And for 2014, the charge  will be in the range of £80 million to £85 million. Net finance cost of £23 million reflect the biomass funding work  and with our term loans fully drawn down, we expect underlying finance cost to be marginally higher in 2014.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Further down the P&L account, reported earnings of £52 million against the £164 million last year with a decrease  driven by the higher carbon costs and the unrealized FX loss. And finally as noted, underlying earnings per share  stripping out the impact of hedge accounting, £0.35 compared to the £0.52 last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Onto total net power generated which is 26.2 terawatt hours compared to last year's record level of 27 .1 terawatt  hours. And it in part reflects the higher forced outage rate in our c oal business and the impact of the first unit  conversion to biomass. The average achieved price for our electricity sold in the wholesale market is £51 per  megawatt hour which is very similar to the last year. And you can see the very stable power price tr end in the chart  on the right. Revenue also includes ROC and LEC sales, of which more in a moment, with ancillary services and  other income broadly similar to last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So on to cost of sales, which at £1.6 billion, up 27 % which includes power buybacks a t Drax and grid charges in  both the Drax and Haven businesses. And within cost of sales, £7 60 million related to fuel cost including £62  million for the carbon tax which is charged as a levy on coal deliveries. Excluding carbon, this is a decrease of 12%  on the year with lower generation and lower average fuel cost of £27.9 per megawatt hour down from the £30.60  last year and this mainly is a result of falling coal prices which you can see in the chart.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Also you should know our average fuel cost is a net number which comprises the cost of coal and biomass burns,  less an estimate of the value of ROCs generated through burning that biomass. When the ROCs are sold at a later  date, the sales value is recognized in revenue, covered on the previous slide. And the  original estimated value of  ROCs generated is charged against cost of sales which you can see lower down the table here.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: A full reconciliation of our ROC and LEC reporting for the period is included, again, in an appendix to your slide  pack. So the accounting can seem a little complex but the key point here is that we are simply matching the cost  with the benefits of fuelling our boilers with biomass.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now on to carbon, and as I said at the outset it is the increasing cost of carbon which year -on-year has driven  down our gross margin and you can see this very clearly in the table. With the loss of free allowances under Phase  III of the EU ETS, we've had to buy all of our carbon this year and this has pushed up our carbon purchases by  over 7 million tons which has increased carbon costs by 50% to £124 million. And including the carbon tax of £62  million, this increases cost of sales by over £100 million year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to operating costs, with total cost of £215 million broadly flat on the year and in line with the guidance we've  provided. Our operating cost guidance for 2014 is at £220 million. This includes higher operating cost in our U.S.  business where we will begin to commission the new pellet plants and port facilities later this year, p lus around £2  million on our carbon capture and storage project and taking inflation into the cost base. This is partly offset by  lower maintenance cost of the power station where we have only one unit on a major plant outage in 2014  compared to two last y ear.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Capital investment, where total capital cost for the biomass transformation remain on schedule and to budget. At  an aggregate level, the guidance we have previously provided for these investments is £650 million to £7 00  million. And as a reminder, that covers three areas. It covers the three unit conversions at Drax and all of the  subsidiary infrastructure. It covers the two U.S. pellet plants that we're currently building plus the port facility,  and it covers a provision for the cost for IED compliance.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Looking specifically at 2013, total investments were £290 million, of which £230 million was around the biomass  transformation. And for 2014, we expect total CapEx to be around £200 million which includes £140 million for  the biomass transformation and £30 million for the biomass unit optimization work, and I'll come on to that  shortly. Looking forward, the transformation for the three units should be completed by 2015. With IED, if trials  prove successful, we estimate a solution will cost between £7 5 million and £100 million over the period out to  2017. And we expect total biomass unit optimization CapEx to be in the region of £90 million for the next three  years, which incorporates the £30 million I've just noted for 2014.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, and I will speak more on this in a moment, we are evaluating further investments in the biomass supply  chain and a fourth unit conversion. Decisions on these potential investments have not yet been made and  therefore are excluded from the charts shown.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, on to cash flows and starting with working capital where the inflow was £64 million, there're several  significant components to this. Firstly, fuel stocks for coal, an increase of 600,000 tons led to an outflow of £49  million. And this resulted in coal stocks of 2.2 million at the year-end. To remind you, we did build up stocks  ahead of a rail outage in the summer where fuel deliveries were suspended to allow for work to be completed on  the rail loop upgrade required for the biomass infrastructure development.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Biomass stocks were around 300,000 tons, a significant proportion of which was held in temporary facilities close  to Drax. And just a reminder that as we look at working capital going forward, there will be outflows as we deliver  our biomass plant and the new storage systems become operational. As previously noted, we estimate each unit  will require some £40 million to £50 million factoring in increase biomass stocks – biomass ownership and  payment terms.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So back to this year, the remaining working capital inflow around £106 million comprises an increase in creditors,  mainly carbon tax and also balances in Haven which are driven by the strong sales growth in that business. ROC  and LEC assets represent an increase in the balance sheet value of ROCs and LECs generated d uring the year, less  the value of those assets sold during the period. Tax includes cash payments of £18 million to settle liabilities.  That's a repayment to Drax for R&D tax relief of £7  million. So after other cash movements of capital expenditure,  debt service and dividends, the closing cash balance was £287  million with net cash after borrowings of £7 1  million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: On to financing and working capital, and the chart here shows our existing debt facilities which I think you're  familiar with. And these reflect the financing work completed to secure the funding that we need for the biomass  transformation. There's just one new thing to update here. In terms of the tools we have to manage our cash flows,  I'm pleased to note that we have now completed our first ROC monetization facility, and that's with Lloyds Bank.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So as you know, because of the way the ROC scheme works, we can face a meaningful delay between incurring the  cost of biomass and recognizing the benefit of generating ROCs in our P&L on one hand , and receiving the related  cash compensation from ROC sales on the other. This facility allows us to sell ROC receivables to the Bank  through immediate payment, thereby accelerating the related cash flows. This facility has a limit of £80 million  and is competitively priced.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Okay. So you've heard this morning that we are evaluating a number of biomass related investment opportunities.  So just to provide a little background on this, firstly, the three converted units. We've been evaluating technical  improvements to drive fuel efficiency further; investing some £90 million will secure a 0.8 percentage point  improvement on current converted unit efficiency levels. This will give a 2% reduction in our fuel requirement  which comes up to around £25 million per year saving for the three biomass units. So the payback on efficiency  alone is less than four years. And that excludes the additional 90 megawatts of capacity these investments secure.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: This investment is in the guidance I provided earlier, and now on to three areas we are evaluating which is not in  that guidance and we will consider based on the returns and value creation; firstly, a conversion of a fourth unit to  biomass. This is an obvious priority. Timings here are driven by regulatory support levels as well as biomass  supply chain development. On to biomass pellet plants, here we are developing options for additional own pellet  production of up to 2 million tons a year. The objective here is to secure high quality pellets, optimize pellet plant  efficiency which again brings down fuel costs, and actively manage fiber inputs which optimizes the physical and  chemical characteristics of the biomass fuel.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our focus remains on North America where we see the potential for attractive double-digit returns, but we are also  looking at the opportunity to expand in our UK pellet production which can deliver some of our most cost effective  biomass fuel.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, to sum up, a lot is going on. Building on the foundations we are now laying, the biomass transformation has  the potential to deliver considerable further value to the group by driving up fuel efficiency and output, additional  unit conversions and upstream in the supply chain. Drax is very well-placed as an early mover in an industry,  which is still young and ripe for optimization.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So before concluding, just a moment on capital structure and distributions. We are considering what the right  capital structure should be for a biomass-dominated Drax underpinned by CfDs. And there are a number of  factors we will take into account.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Okay. So we've given you a lot of new information today and we thought it would be helpful to draw th e threads  together in one place, particularly for the key areas of biomass transformation.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So if we start with biomass technical performance, we now expect output from a converted unit at 630 megawatts.  The efficiency is just 0.5% points lower than coal, and as we move through the transformation, average unit  availability will be around 80% for 2014 and 2015, rising in 2016 to between 85% and 90% which is equivalent to  our coal units.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving on to the schedule for increased biomass generation, we expect to run a unit as an enhanced co-firing unit  from May 2014, and this will burn high levels of biomass and earn support at 0.9 ROCs. We are targeting April  2015 when the CfDs become effective for full conversion of the second biomass unit.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And a third converted unit could be in Q4 2015, which will be earlier than previously planned. The load factor for  this third unit will be somewhat dependent on the development of the biomass supply chain. And finally, for  completeness, I have summarized the other guidance we have provided today in the lower part of that table.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So to conclude on the financials, 2013 earnings are ahead of expectations, reflecting good coal and biomass  operations, but down as expected year-on-year due to the increasing cost of carbon. Looking forward to 2014,  markets are currently weaker. But from this May, we will significantly increase our biomass burn with enhanced  co-firing through our coal unit.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: More broadly, the transformation investments are on schedule and to budget, and we expect two units to be fully  converted under CfDs in due course. We are progressing additional work to optimize the performance of these  biomass units, investments which deliver strong returns. We are also evaluating further biomass investments,  most notably a fourth unit conversion and also upstream assets in the supply chain, which have the potential to  create significant incremental value for the group. And finally and importantly, our balance sheet remains strong.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, before we conclude, I just wanted to paint a picture for you because we look to 2016 as being the year that our  transformation has delivered, and it's a year in which all of our units will be operating in a reliable and flexible  way. We will have three units operating as biomass units, two under CfDs, one under the RO and they will be  performing at truly world-class standard in terms of output and efficiency. What we also haven't mentioned today  but I'll mention now is we know now that the flexibility of these units were miracle in terms of range, but what  actually we're expecting is a faster response time. So that will be very good for a market with increased  intermittent generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We would expect to be producing 1 million tons of our own biomass between our wood pellet plant in the U.S. and  our straw pellet plant in the UK, and well on our way to increasing that to 2 million or 3 million tons through  further investments. Our logistics supply will be secured through long-term contracts with ports, long-term  contracts with freights and our own fleet of bespoke biomass wagons.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our coal units will be compliant with IED and they'll be well placed to support the UK as we face a tightening of  capacity from 2016 onwards. Our retail business, we believe, we will have delivered the growth we're expecting to  deliver and it will have a strong sales proposition based on renewable power, good customer service and  transparent pricing.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And I really would like to remind you of something which is very important and that is that biomass is a cost  competitive renewable, it is low carbon and it is reliable.
