So it's good for the consumer, it's good for the climate  and it's good for security of clients. And with that, we'll take questions. Y eah.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And what we're going – how we're going to manage the group going forward is three businesses with their  management teams, and then with some group support. And actually, I have the whole management team here.  So, the three businesses are Drax Biomass, our U.S. biomass product processing and supply business; Drax Power,  our UK generation business; and Haven Power, our UK retail business.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Then, in terms of the three businesses, let's start with the largest, Drax Power. Sorry, Andy, will you get up? Andy  Koss is the – or will be the new CEO of Drax Power from the 1st of March. Then, we have Haven Power, Peter  Bennell, who has currently been CEO of Haven Power for a little while now, ever since its beginning or inception.  And then, thirdly, Drax Biomass; now, Drax Biomass, Matthew Rivers, who's actually both Chairman of our U.S.  business and Group Director, responsible for sustainability. He will have group responsibility for our U.S.  business. But we have just appointed a new country president for the U.S. He also starts from the 1st of March.  He's called Pete Madden and he comes to us from Plum Creek, and we're very pleased to have found him. So, now,  on to the – and by the way, if you got any questions at the end, we're all here to answer them.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On to the agenda. So three sections. We're going to cover a business review, which I will cover. Tony will then take  you through a financial review. And then, I will give you an update on where we are with our biomass  transformation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, 2014, a difficult, difficult year. We had really significant regulatory headwinds. We had a major deterioration  in the commodity markets in which we work, where we trade, and that all weighed very heavily on our share price,  so a tough year. But in the context of that tough year, we actually had a really rather good year in the areas of the  business that we can control. So, in terms of those three businesses, Drax Power, we're making really good  progress on delivering our biomass transformation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Haven Power, keys to Haven's success for us at least for strategic value is growth, and Haven actually delivered  exceptional growth last year. And in terms of Drax Biomass, construction is going well and we're right on the cusp  of commercial operations. So, good in terms of what we control, but a difficult year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, I want to start again on the detail with safety and sustainability because good safety and sustainability  management really is at the core of our operational trust. So, it's very, very important. In safety, we had a year of  contrast, to be honest. We had our best-ever loss time injury rate, and that's kind of the major statistic that all  industries watch. And that was really good progress.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, I'll remind you that biomass is only a low carbon renewable if it is sourced responsibly  and sustainably. So two key conditions. One, that there is no depletion of carbon stock; and in terms of a forest,  what that means is that the rate of harvest of the forest is no greater than or equal to the rate of growth of the  forest. And the other important condition is that this is truly low carbon. And what that means is that carbon cost  from the point of origin all the way through to the point of burn is low enough that you're delivering major carbon  savings.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And I think you all know we've had this really robust sustainability policy for a long time, included in that is that  we buy carbon footprint all the biomass we burn. We're actually in our eighth year of carbon footprinting the  biomass we burn. But for the first time, we're actually showing you what the results of that carbon footprinting is.  And that's what the bottom table here shows.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So our average lifecycle emissions for biomass we burnt in 2014 was actually only 34 grams of CO2 per megajoule.  That's really very small compared to the lifecycle emissions of our UK source coal which we then burned which is  280 grams of CO2 per megajoule. It's also significantly lower than what is going to be the UK mandatory cap  which is 79 grams of CO2 per megajoule. I have to say there actually we do expect that 34 to go up somewhat. And  the reason is that actually a lot of our early biomass we got from quite close [ph] coastal (05:36) locations.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As we get the next sets of biomass, including our own plant, we're actually a little bit further inland, that leads to  higher cost and higher carbon cost as well. So – but all our biomass is procured to be compliant with the UK  mandatory standard, so within that cap of 79 grams of CO2 per megajoule. And we expect those standards, those  UK government standards, to become mandatory in October this year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's been a very, very busy year for the sustainable biomass partnership. I don't know if you remember, but this is a  group of seven UK – European biomass generators, so seven large biomass generators, and we've been working  together. And what we've been seeking to establish is a common sustainability standard for biomass and a  certification of that standard to demonstrate that we are complying with it. And I'm very pleased to say that that  will be launched, both the standard and the certification process, just next month.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Also, it's designed so that all biomass that is SBP certified will be compliant with the UK mandatory standards.  And it's our intention at Drax that we will now transition once it's launched to 100% of our biomass being SBP  certified. So that's sustainability.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On to the actual operational performance. First, let's look at Drax Power. In terms of generation, what you have in  the top-right box are our output numbers in terms of net sales. And what that is all the sales that were not –  excluding those sales that were matched by market purchases. And what you can see is our biomass generation is  close to 30% of our total generation, so a significant increase in our biomass generation in 2014.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We now have actually 33% of our capacity is biomass because two of our six units are 100% biomass fueled. So we  would expect that number to go up this year, or that percentage. In fact, it will go up more than it might appear  just by having two units because we expect well into the second half of the year to convert our third unit.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Convert is probably not the right word, to modify our third unit. So we start those burnings higher and higher  quantities of biomass. We may even, depending on timing, convert that unit this year, or if not, we'll convert it  next year. So we expect high biomass – much higher biomass generation this year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What you won't see here is we've left out the availability statistics because we do think the key performance data  actually is our sales from the different generation forms, coal generation and biomass generation. But if anyone  has any questions on this, the technical data, we have Peter here to answer all of them for you.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of the capacity market, the UK held its first capacity auctions last year. We bid in two of our coal units.  I'm pleased to say, they both secured a capacity contract. It's a one-year contract for performance year 2018-2019.  And they'll each run roughly around £10 million or the value of the contract is about £10 million.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We didn't bid in our third coal unit. We still have hopes to convert this to biomass. If we don't convert it to  biomass, then we would see if there is indeed an additional auction, which we know there will be, to bid that in the  year-ahead auction for capacity support in 2017-2018.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's been a very, very uncertain year 2014 for the future support for biomass conversions. Our two key units that  already are converted are supported by one grandfathered under the renewable obligation. Our third converted  unit signed a contract, an investment contract or Early CfD – or we signed. The unit didn't sign it – signed a  contract – an investment contract with the government.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The only other thing I want to mention is carbon capture and storage. This project is now well into the second year  of its feasibility. We're making good progress and we think that we're still well on schedule to make an investment  decision in 2016.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A quick look at the market. I think most of you know all about this. We've had a major deterioration in our  markets. We've had some upturn recently which has been encouraging. Probably, the larger single factor has been  the fall in the oil price. But we've also had another really warm winter. So what that means is there is a real  overhang of gas storage. And you can see the effect of both of those very clearly on the gas price on the top right.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have had a further weakening in the coal market, which was to be in the benefit of our coal spreads. And what  has all translated to in terms of dispatched [ph] merit order (12:05) and everything is shown in the bottom graph.  And I think most of you have seen this before. But just quickly, far right, what that shows you is the installed  capacity of the different types – of the two different types of thermal generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So in terms of coal, that's the dark blue. The high-efficiency coal plant is basically us, and the low efficiency coal  plant that's now in the mid-30s because [indiscernible] (12:26) is closed. And then, the lighter blue is the range for  gas. Again, high efficiency gas plant, around 55%, low efficiency gas plant, around 42%. Again, we've had two site  closed, so that's narrowing in.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then, what it takes is those efficiencies translate through the prices in the markets and shows what spread  those efficiencies can command in the market. And what you can see very clearly for the prompt and all of the  forwards we are the lead unit. We are the top of the merit order or lead units. But actually, when you get to  summers where you can see as high efficiency gas is ahead of low efficiency coal or lower efficiency coal. So what  we're seeing actually is a tightening of the spreads. And you see that in [ph] work (13:09). It's our expected  profitability this year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And fuel, well, the main thing I want to say about coal is we've got a very, very different pitch-in nowadays. We  used to burn roughly 50% domestic coal, 50% international coal. The domestic coal producers over the last few  years, particularly the last two years, have really, really been challenged and very, very difficult to compete for  domestic coal at international prices. And what we've seen is quite a dramatic reduction in domestic production.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: That's been also reflected in our purchasing, so we've had a decline in our domestic coal, increase in our  international coal as a proportion. We also, actually, are working hard on getting some low-NOx coals to help us  with our compliance with the Industrial Emissions Directive.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of biomass, 2014 was a very, very unusual year. The reason it's an unusual year is there was real disarray  in Continental Europe in some of the structures and supports for biomass demand. So what that meant is some of  the larger biomass generators actually had quite a reduction in demand. That combined with this second really  warm winter.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Actually, quite a lot of biomass demand is purely for wood pellets to go into boilers for hospitals, schools, houses,  depends which country you're in. And what that has meant is unusually, there have been quite large quantities of  biomass available on the spot market. And fortunately, we were in a very good place to buy them.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, what we have done is we have actually bought 6 million tonnes of biomass contracted for the 2015-2016 ROC  year, and that's really a result of these short-term phenomena. It's not what we expect to be the case of the spot  market going forward. I mean, normally, we would struggle to buy 100,000 tonnes, 200,000 tonnes in the spot  market in any year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So actually, what we do with our third unit conversion, it's really important we secure those longer-term contracts,  and that's what we're working on now. To be frank, if we all had had a CfD in place that would provide that  stability of income, I think we would have solved it. We're still working on it. We're confident we'll get there. It's  not a risk, but it's harder and it's taking longer time. Probably, it's going to be expensive as well, and more  expensive, but anyway. So, we've got lower biomass contract from 2016-2017. We're confident we'll get there, but  it's work in hand.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of biomass cost management, I want to make something quite clear that we still have our strategy of  trying to fix as much of the biomass cost as we can in advance. And we do this both for contracted purchases, and  this is very important but also forecast purchases. So, we actually have an extensive foreign exchange hedging  program because almost all our biomass we buy in foreign currency.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We hedge five years forward on both contract and forecast, some of that [indiscernible] (16:22) in the money, so  we're a little bit out of money at the moment. We also do that with oil. We do it with freight. Again, contract and  forecast for oil and freight. Definitely that's the money. Sorry, Tony, but it is. But the principle is that what we  want to have is that security of income. So, that's the main thing I want to say on the cost management.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: All right. Now, we get lots of questions on forestry economics. And I confess I'm not an expert, so any further  questions, please direct them to Matthew Rivers who is a forester and is an expert. But we thought we'd give you  an illustration of forestry economics in the context of the U.S. South. So, the tree shows you roughly the market  value or market cost of the different types of fibers. Now, what we burned is only low-grade wood, and that is  typically fillings, harvesting residues, or sawmill or wood processing co-products, which is basically sawdust and  chips. So, that's what we burn.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the U.S., most forests are grown for sawlog or timber. That's the really valuable product of the forest. That's  what drives the life cycle of the forest. That is the key product. We are on the byproduct or the low grade product.  And the line at the bottom – a wood that pays, stays – it sounds trite, but it actually is really important. If a forest  is not economic, it will not be – it probably won't be well managed, and it may even be [ph] clear field (17:51). If a  forest, an attractive economic return, then what you're going to be able to invest in is good forestry management  and keeping that forest alive.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We would hope, and actually we believe in quite a few of our sourcing situations, that we provide a critical extra  income, albeit not a big one because we're the low grade cheaper end that enables that forest to become an  economic forest, therefore, an attractive investment to the owner, therefore, a forest which is going to be well  managed and sustained rather than wholly managed with a low yield, or even [ph] clear field (18:27).

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: One thing we have done today is we've put on our website for more data than we've ever put before about our  biomass sourcing. And I thought I'd give you just a little bit of it here. What you see in the table is where our fiber  comes from or some data on our fiber in terms of the geography it comes from, but also the type of fiber it is. What  is really notable about last year is the high percentage. They're close to 40% of our biomass that came from co- products or sawdust and chips from wood processing and wood mills.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: That actually is going to decline – that percentage will decline. You know it will decline going forward, not least of  all because this is only a minor source for our two pilot plants since they come online. But it's a very high  percentage of what I'd call essentially a waste product from another industry. And a very good example, I think, is  the fact that we really do source low-grade fiber.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The other thing I would note is that 80% of our biomass comes from North America. Of the U.S. biomass, all of it  comes from the U.S. South. And I just want to draw your attention to that very last bullet point. We estimate that  100 million tonnes is the level of the surplus of the forest production in 2013 compared to the harvest. I mean, we  just dwell on that number. It just shows why we've ended up sourcing in the U.S. South because the forest are  growing far greater, and then the rate in which they're being actually depleted or used.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Drax Biomass Inc., our U.S. business, we are on-time, on-budget, and we're at that very exciting stage of starting  commissioning. Amite is well into commissioning now. Indeed, we've produced first pellet. Indeed, I'm told by  Peter, we produced pellets last night. Morehouse is just starting commissioning. They're commissioning the log- line, and both are on schedule to complete. Amite, we expect towards the end of March and Morehouse is likely to  be around June.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What I would say is that when you commission a pellet plant, you bring it into commercial production, but it's not  necessary at full capacity. We've seen – we know from our competitors and all of the work we've done on other  pellet plants and actually, our suppliers as well, it should take us a good six months to get from first commercial  operations to full capacity. We actually have competitors who have taken a lot longer than that. But our target is to  do that within six months.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Baton Rouge port facility is what we call pellet-ready. In fact, it's received its first pellet from a third-party  supplier. And we just need to get that up to a large enough volume to justify a ship, and we will be shipping our  pellets out of Baton Rouge.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Okay. So, thank you, Dorothy. We laid out the detail of our biomass investment plans in 2012. And I'm pleased to  say that we are on schedule and within budget to deliver this commitment. In doing so, we have created a  fundamentally stronger business. We are delivering increased levels of biomass generation with the converted  units, saving some 8 million tonnes a year of carbon versus coal; and in doing so, protecting the business from the  cost of that carbon.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So, I'm pleased to report, during the year in which trading and regulatory conditions have been very challenging,  EBITDA of £229 million is flat 2013 and marginally ahead of expectations. In delivering this, we have absorbed an  additional £59 million of carbon tax, the UK's carbon price support mechanism, which is levied in our coal  generation. This leads to underlying earnings per share of £0.237 to having a dividend of £0.119 per share or £48  million. This is in line with our policy to distribute 50% of underlying earnings and incorporates a final dividend  of £0.072 per share or £29 million. And our balance sheet remains robust with net debt of £99 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So, on to the detail of the profit summary and our comments to the components of EBITDA. Below that figure, the  exceptional charge of £20 million represents the net settlement reached in connection with CESP, the Community  Energy Savings Programme. Unrealized gains on derivative contracts, which is a non-cash item, was £66 million,  which is the largely the positive mark-to-market movements on foreign exchange contracts, which do not qualify  for hedge accounting although somewhat offset by the negative mark-to-market on the oil hedges that we put in  place.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So, on to depreciation, which are £80 million, is in line with guidance, up year-on-year with increased investment.  Depreciation charges will continue to increase over time as we commission and operate all of our new biomass  facilities.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: For 2015, the charge will be in the range of £100 million to £105 million. Net finance costs of £29 million reflect  the funding requirement to deliver the biomass investment. And with the new facilities now in place and fully  drawn, we expect underlying finance costs for 2015 to be at a similar level to this year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So, moving back up now to gross profit, Dorothy described the operational performance of our three business  units, Drax Power, Haven Power, and Drax Biomass. So, I'll follow that format, starting with the gross profit in the  generation business, Drax Power. Our total power sales were £2.1 billion compared to £1.7 billion in 2013. Now  this includes sales to Haven Power, as well as the revenue associated with power purchases.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Net power sales of 26.7 terawatt hour is a small increase on last year's level of 26.2. And the average achieved  price for every electricity sold is £51.30 per megawatt hour, very slightly up on last year with the timing of our  hedges providing some protection from the recent power market weakness.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: On to cost of sales, we have £1.1 billion related to fuel. The average fuel costs of £40.30 per megawatt hour  compared to £32 in 2013 reflect an increased use of biomass. ROC and LEC support is a deduction from cost of  sales and represents a value of ROCs and LECs earned in the period through biomass generation.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: The accounting here is a little bit complex, so a full reconciliation of our ROC reporting again is included in the  Appendix to your pack. But the principle is simple, and that is to match the cost with the benefits of burning  biomass.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: On to carbon, as already noted, the carbon tax has driven our gross margin down significantly, with the charge of  £118 million this year compared to £62 million in 2013. The carbon tax rate has increased from £5 to £10 per  tonne in April, 2014, and it is payable only from the second quarter of 2013.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: On the positive side, increased biomass generation has pushed down our carbon allowance purchases by over 3.5  million tonnes. So when combined with a reduction, the cost of these carbon allowances has partially offset the  impact of the higher UK carbon tax.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: We've frequently highlighted the consequences of a growing level of intermittent generation in the UK system  including power price volatility and increased grid charges. However, this is also providing a valuable opportunity  to capitalize on the flexibility of the Drax plant through balancing and systems support activities, and we continue  to believe this will be of increasing importance in the future. So, as a result, when all of these factors are taken in  aggregate, generation gross margin is £433 million, broadly flat on last year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Moving now to gross profits at Haven, where we delivered net sales volume of 11.8 terawatt hours in 2014, up  almost 50% year-on-year. As a result, revenues increased to £1.1 billion compared to £751 million in 2013, with  the average price of power sold £92.40 per megawatt hour, broadly flat year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: In cost of sales, power purchases increased to £629 million, up from £455 million in 2013 with the growth in sales  volume. And the average price paid for power fell to £53.30 per megawatt hour, down from £56.20 last year,  reflecting changes in the wholesale market over this period.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Grid charges in our retail business include the cost of distribution, transmission and system balancing, and rates  charged by network and system operators for these services have all increased, driven in part by the increase in  intermittent generation in the UK system. So, in total, grid charges increased by 51% to £253 million, partly on the  back of our sales growth as well as these increased rates.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Other retail costs include the cost of meeting our obligations under the Renewable Obligation and small-scale  Feed-in-Tariff schemes, the rates for both which increased in 2014. Retail costs also include the cost of LECs  required to deliver our Levy Exempt Power to our customers. Approximately half of the power sold by Haven is  levy-exempt, so the associated cost of LECs sold has increased as sales volumes have grown. So, worth noting  here, the total third-party costs, that is grid charges and other retail costs, together now represent over 40% of the  cost of supply.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Now, onto group operating costs, we had total costs of £220 million, up £5 million year-on-year and in line with  the guidance we've given. Guidance for 2015 is £240 million, and this increase reflects the start of commercial  operations in our new U.S. pellet plants and port facility. The operating results for this business, Drax Biomass,  for 2015 is very sensitive to the ramp-up of pellet production. And I'll come on to that in a moment. And once  operational, in the future, I will review separately the profit of Drax Biomass as a third business unit alongside  Drax Power and Haven.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So onto capital investment. As I said at the outset, our biomass transformation is now well advanced and our  capital investment plans remain firmly on track. This chart draws together the transformation investments, which  include the three unit conversions: the power plant, the U.S. investments and IED compliance. You can see that,  after CapEx of £140 million in 2014, we have invested around £550 million so far, and with further investment to  come of approximately £130 million in the 2015 to 2017 period, being largely the implementation of our IED  solution, as well as finishing the original Gulf Cluster facilities in the U.S. this year. So we will complete the  transformation within our original cost guidance of £650 million to £700 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: I would like to note here that, in doing so, we have absorbed significant additional expenditure that was not  included in the original guidance such as investment in our fleet of biomass rail wagons, which are now a very  important component of cost-effective UK logistics.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So back to the detail of last year, 2014 asset additions including the transformation CapEx of £201 million. And  looking forward for 2015, we expect total capital expenditure to be in the region of £150 million with around £90  million for the transformation and £30 million each for biomass unit optimization, which we have previously  discussed, and maintenance CapEx. For 2016, investment will be lower, less than £100 million as the  transformation winds down but with a similar level of optimization and other plants CapEx.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Looking further out, as we have previously talked about, we do have an option for an investment in the third pellet  plant in the U.S. Gulf. Here, only in our own pellet plant and port strengthens our supply chain, securing high- quality pellets. With efficient and cost-effective logistics, work on this third pellet plant is well advanced, but the  final decision on this investment has not yet been taken. If we do proceed, we expect total capital investment  would be around £100 million, a similar level to the first two plants. And we continue to evaluate further  investments in the biomass supply chain.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Finally, we are progressing the carbon capture and storage feasibility study. An investment decision will be made  in 2016 and be dependent on successful funding, appropriate support and a return on investment which is  commensurate with the technical and commercial risks of the project.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So, onto cash and starting with working capital where the total net outflow was £58 million. Biomass stocks are  the main driver of this. With the ramp-up of our biomass operations and full commissioning of onsite facilities,  stocks have increased by 300,000 tonnes to 600,000 tonnes, leading to an outflow of some £39 million. And to  note, a good proportion of these stocks are offsite and upstream in the supply chain.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: In terms of the U.S. business, the table shows the start dates for commercial operations of the two new pellet  plants. The 2015 financial performance for this business, Drax Biomass, will be very sensitive to the ramped up  pellet production. Given the profile of commissioning and ramp-up in 2015, it is likely the EBITDA performance  of Drax Biomass will be a small loss this year, moving into profit in 2016 with the full year of operations.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Finally, in terms of generation, we do expect to operate our third unit at higher levels of biomass burn from  quarter three this year. Clearly, the support mechanism for that unit is not yet determined, depending on the  outcome of the EU State Aid process. But we can operate the unit as an enhanced co-firing unit under the RO. And  ahead of further clarity from the EU, that would seem a sensible planning assumption for your modeling.

texts.speaker: Anthony James Quinlan
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: So, summing up, 2014 has clearly been a tough year, with regulatory disappointments and weak commodity  markets. We've got backdrop, we delivered solid financial performance very much supported by the biomass  conversions and underpinned by good operations. For 2015, whilst the current earnings outlook does reflect a  weak commodity markets, in the longer term, the biomass transformation has created a much stronger, more  resilient business. And our balance sheet remains robust, providing a solid platform from which to complete the  transformation for the three units.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of the timetable going forward, we're still confident we'll deliver the transformation in 2016. This has  really been quite a journey. And the way I think of it now is that we're already at the end of this journey or towards  the end of this journey in terms of implementation. And so we are confident that, by the time we are in 2016, we  will be a predominantly biomass generator.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And someone questioned me about that the other day, and they said, well, how is that going to be when you've  only got three units on biomass and you also have three units on coal? And the reason why we talk about being  predominantly biomass generator is we plan on our biomass units running at about a 75% load factor.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On our coal units, we expect the load factor to come significantly less than that as more and more tightening  happens on coal restrictions in terms of high carbon tax and other things. So, that's why we think of ourselves as  being predominantly biomass. In terms of the transformation project itself, the key things this year is one, as Tony  said, bringing the third unit to high biomass, maybe even converting it, delivering the operational – our  operations in the U.S. facilities, the three U.S. facilities, and [ph] important (43:49) logistics remain very, very  important.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What we also would expect to have next year, if we haven't converted the third unit, we will convert it in 2016.  And, of course, our U.S. plant will be well in operation and we may well have invested in the third pellet facility.  We call it Pike in the U.S. that would feed into the Baton Rouge.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, why does biomass make sense? I thought I'd just do a little dwelling on why biomass is just the best solution  for everyone. So, if we start from the UK's point of view, do you know that after a unit conversion is the biggest  carbon reduction project in the whole of EU. It's a massive, massive project and we thought the best way to  describe it is that it's going to save the same amount of carbon and taking 3.3 million cars off the road.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And you probably don't know that you just find out about it from a short Google search that we have 35 million  cars on the road in the UK. Well, that's the numbers registered in something like 2013. So, actually, our project is  the same as taking roughly 10% of the emissions in cars on the road just away, massive, massive carbon reduction.  And what's very important, it does it at a low-cost basis.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And last year, Frontier Economics did a report comparing biomass conversion costs to offshore wind because  those really are the marginal decisions for large capacity that the UK Government faces. And what that report  found is our three units, if that electricity generation was provided by offshore wind rather than our three  converted units, by 2020, the additional cost would be over £3 billion.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The government has come to a similar conclusion. We know that from a different analysis that there was a  question in the House of Parliament a few months ago, and Minister Rudd answered, and what her answer was –  and the question was, what's the cost of carbon reduction for different technologies? And her answer was that the  cost of 1 tonne of carbon saved by a biomass conversion is somewhere around £50, £60. By comparison, 1 tonne  of carbon saved costs roughly £200 from an offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And there's a really good reason for this, actually, there are three, I think, good reasons. One, biomass conversions  do not need billion-plus new grid connections. The grid is already there. It's an efficient use of existing asset.  Secondly, biomass units do not need backup power. They are reliable. We will operate them 24/7. And the third is  that biomass units do not need general system support because they are flexible. We can adjust the output to meet  the requirements of the system. And also, we can provide the reactor for power, local power.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: All of those are costs that you don't see when you compare the [ph] difference thought (47:12) whether it's under a  CfD or ROC. So that very real cost that we the consumer or we the country pay. And I think it's because of these  two things, the fact that actually it's massive in terms of carbon savings and, secondly, it's very cost effective, and  that's why the government is still very committed to having biomass as a key part of its renewable solution for  2020.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And what does it mean for our investors? Well, we embarked on this strategy because we really believed in the low  carbon economy, but we also believed that we would have more and more of a challenge of operating as a high  coal generator. And what our investors did is that they supported us in that strategy. They supported us in the  transformation strategy, and the way they supported us is the fact that they supported us making really major  investments.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And I think we can see some of the return of that investment. When you compare, that's what the graph shows,  are earnings if we've just been a coal generator in 2013, 2014 compared to our actual earnings as a partial coal  generator and a partial biomass generator. And that, I think, justified quite to a large extent why we went down  this strategy.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, and with that, I'd like to bring it to a conclusion. As you've heard from both Tony and I, fiscal challenging year  last year, but the areas that we could control went well. And as you, I think, have just heard from me, I really do  believe that biomass is a very good renewable. I don't think it's always fully appreciated. But I am confident that as  the UK system becomes more and more dependent on wind generation which is intermittent, solar generation  that's intermittent, the true benefit and the true value of biomass will come through, and I'm very hopeful that  that actually will support further unit conversions at Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, welcome to our 2015 results. I'd actually like to start by introducing Will Gardiner, who joined Drax almost  four months ago from CSR. So, welcome. And then also Andy Koss, who is now a member of the Drax board and I  think already familiar to quite a few of you.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So with that, I'll start the presentation. We've divided this into three parts this time. And in terms of the overview,  I think everyone knows it's been a very, very severe deterioration in the commodity markets and quite a  challenging regulatory environment. And that's really provided the backdrop to 2015, but we've had a very good  operational year. In terms of Drax Power, we have actually changed very much how we run that both business,  particularly with respect to coal. And we've made very good progress in mitigating actions in the context of these  difficult market conditions.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: At Haven Power, we've now reached our target [ph] levels (1:01) of sales, so the target level for the business, so  that is pleasing. And in Drax Biomass, we've moved from being a construction project into an operational  business.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, I wanted to make a few points on sustainability. The sustainability of our biomass  sourcing is something we take very, very seriously at Drax. And I just want to be clear that we never take wood  from any forest that is in decline. We do not cause deforestation. We never work in countries that lack proper  regulation. We only source wood from forests that grow back and stay as forests and we never source from  protected areas. Those are the key principles that underline our sourcing of biomass.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Last year, the sustainable biomass partnership, this partnership of seven large industrial biomass users, has made  very good progress in developing its sustainability standards. Those standards were launched towards the  beginning of the year and we now have approved our first certification bodies and biomass producers. And indeed,  SBP is now handling something like 60 approval applications.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We expect SBP to very much become the global standard for biomass sustainability. And we were very pleased  when in December last year, Ofgem confirmed that all biomass that is certified by SBP will be compliant with the  UK mandatory sustainability standards. And those standards became mandatory with effect from the 1 of  December 2015.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Sorry, I forgotten most important chart. You see there, there's a chart showing how much wood is used as a sour ce  of energy across the EU. The light green is the wood as a percentage of total energy and the darker green is wood  as a percentage of renewable energy. And I think what's notable that is where the UK stands, it's number two in  that chart, and in this competitive ranking, sits behind countries such as Greece and France.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: All right. On to the markets, as I started, very difficult commodity markets. Indeed, in terms of coal spreads, we're  seeing the lowest margins for well over a decade. In terms of biomass spreads, there also has been a significant fall  and there's a very good reason for that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our costs and supplemental income from biomass are essentially fixed. Our biomass we buy under long -term  contracts with fixed indexation, so that leads to a gently rising price, but essentially quite flat. And then in parallel,  the ROC is set each year and goes up with inflation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: By contrast, the UK power price moves with commodity markets. So when that power price falls, we tend to see a  fall in biomass spreads and when that biomass – when that power price increases, we see an increase in spreads.  So, as you can see from the directory of power prices, what we've seen is a decline in biomass spreads.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have been looking at our trading strategy in light of the market conditions. We do continue to hedge our  renewal obligation units 18 to 24 months ahead. We are hedging our CfD unit on the basis of the season average  reference price. But in terms of the coal units, we have changed our tactic and we are shortening our hed ge on  those units, more likely to sell the output from those units in the near-term or indeed the prompt markets.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So on to operations. I'm very pleased to say that at the end of 2014, in the last quarter, we became a  predominantly biomass generator, with two units fully converted under the renewables obligation and one unit  operating as an enhanced co-firing unit. For the year, the percentage was 43% of electricity from biomass  generation and 57% from coal generation.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In regulation terms, as I said earlier, UK sustainability standards are now mandatory. And we are confident with  our compliance with these standards because I think, as many of you know, we already have very, very well  established assurance processes to ensure that all the biomass we procure is from sustainable sources and low  carbon.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our CfD contract, which was awarded in early 2014, is now in the Phase 2 investigation by the EU for State aid  clearance. We really look forward to talking directly with the EU on this investigation. That was no t permitted in  Phase 1. And indeed, it's only permitted in Phase 2 at the end or after the Phase 2 consultation and that  consultation will close early next month. And we continue to press for support for more biomass conversions. We  stand ready to convert more units and we believe others are also interested, now that it's been demonstrated that  the biomass technology works well, is safe, reliable and flexible.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On to retail operations. Sorry, I missed out coal. That's not good. Strong operations from our coal units, but as I  said at the beginning, a real change to how we're operating these units. The strong focus is now on flexibility and  capturing value from flexibility and reliability. There's something I need to explain here. When you're operating  units at a very high commercial load, then there's limited optionality because you're making money from that high  margin. When you're operating units in markets where there's limited commercial margin, then you've got much  more opportunity to make value from flex ibility. And that's the world we find ourselves in today.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And the actual system support market is becoming bigger and bigger. This is now about an £800 million market.  Some of that is for very bespoke services, such as storage, but there is an increased need for reliability and  flexibility from reliable and flexible generation, such as the Drax coal units. And that's because we have an  increasing penetration of intermittent renewables, typically solar and wind, and in addition, we have a continued  generation from nuclear power, which, of course, is inflexible. So that presents an opportunity for Drax.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of regulation, we have now participated in two capacity markets. Two of our coal units have been  awarded capacity contracts in both of the first two auctions. We will participate in the T-1 auction with the third  coal unit, if that unit is not already converted to biomass. We do look forward to engaging with government on  their consultation for the closure of coal by 2025. We are reviewing the strategy for our coal units in the context of  both this consultation and what is happening in the commodity markets. We have always been a believer that  there is a finite role for coal on the system, and indeed, that was the underpinning of our biomass strategy a nd  why we thought it was so important.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: One of the big changes in this market is with the removal of the Levy Exemption Certificates, that removed from  the market, actually, both domestic and business, any renewable product. So we have worked hard to int roduce a  renewable product into this market and we are pleased that many of our competitors are also doing that. But we  believe we've got a very good bespoke renewable product because the renewable product we offer to businesses is  backed by biomass generation, so it's 100% renewable power, 100% of the time. And that is something Haven will  be working hard to develop over the coming year.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And finally, Drax Biomass, we've moved from construction to operation. I'm pleased to say the port facility is  already working at full capacity and we are making good progress with the pellet plants, at building them up to full  capacity operations on a sustainable basis. We did have or have had a really difficult winter. So, so much rain and  that has hampered some of our progress, but still the progress is pleasing.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the final quarter of 2015, we realized the first step in our journey by becoming a predominantly renewable  generator. There's more to be done, but Drax has a strong position with lots of opportunities.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As coal stations shut all around us, Drax continues to generate around 8% of the country's power and is an  increasingly critical contributor to the UK's electricity system stability. In addition, there are many opportunities  in the global biomass arena and we are uniquely positioned to take advantage of those.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The reported earnings of £56 million includes two further non-cash items. As you know, we always strip out the  impact of unrealized gains and losses on derivative contracts from underlying earnings. And this year, we have  also excluded a one-off asset obsolescence charge of £109 million, being the write-down of the flue gas  desulphurization or FGD plant on our biomass units. And this reflects the low level of sulphur emissions now  confirmed from those units and represents a further environmental benefit of biomass generation.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Given the current market environment, this was a finely tuned decision and dependent on some key assumptions.  First, it is based on our current operating model, as the accounting standards do not allow for any enhancements,  such as conversion of further units to biomass, which, as Dorothy mentioned, we stand ready to do. Second, it  includes the assumption that we receive the CfD at £100 per megawatt hour. And third, we assume that the  economic life of the power station remains unchanged, extending to 2039.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Central to this assumption is our belief that Drax will remain hugely important for the security of elec tricity supply  in the UK for many years to come. This does require that if necessary, a suitable level of economic incentive will be  available to support future renewable generation. And in that regard, it is encouraging to note that in the longer  term, as the biomass market matures, it may well become competitive without subsidy support, provided there is a  robust carbon price and an equitable allocation of whole system costs, a subject that Dorothy will cover shortly.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, moving on to gross profit. While changes to gross profit at Haven and Drax Biomass were not significant, the  decline in gross profit at Drax Power by £44 million was the biggest driver of reduced EBITDA in the year. This is  driven by the severe fall in commodity markets, the lack of remo val and the higher cost of the UK carbon tax. We  have worked hard to mitigate these headwinds and I will draw out, as we work through the detail, especially on  the next page, where I describe the value we can achieve by operating flexibly to support system  stability.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Net power revenue, which includes the revenue and costs associated with power purchases, decreased by £54  million in 2015. While generation levels were similar to 2014, we did experience a decrease in achieved power  prices. However, the timing of our power hedges has provided some protection from the significant weakness in  the market since the start of 2015.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On to net fuel costs, which comprise the cost of coal and biomass, less the value of ROC and LEC support earned  in the period. With increased levels of biomass generation in the associated ROC and LEC support, net fuel cost  decreased by £41 million compared to 2014. Some of this decrease was also due to our use of advantaged fuels,  low cost coals and other products, which trade at a discount to international prices.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: It is important to note that, as we said at the half year, the removal of LEC support resulted in a reduction in our  EBITDA in the second half of the year of £30 million. And so without that, we would have seen a significantly  greater benefit from decreasing net fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On to carbon, the carbon tax continues to have a negative impact on our gross margin. The tax rate increased from  £10 to £18 per tonne in April of 2015, resulting in a higher charge. But on the positive side , increased biomass  generation has pushed down our carbon allowance purchases by more than 3 million tonnes, which has limited  the net incremental year-on-year carbon cost to £31 million. So taken as a whole, these changes resulted in  generation gross margin of £390 million, down 10% on the prior year.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: I thought it'd be worthwhile to explain how we benefit from the flexibility and reliability of the Drax Power Station  to improve profits last year. The operating environment for coal generators is as tough now as it has ever been,  with an adverse regulatory backdrop and the lower spreads since Drax's listing in 2005. We have adapted quickly  to these market conditions to generate more revenue from shape creation and balancing market activity, as well as  ancillary services.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: It's the flexibility of the station that allows us to operate this way, and as other coal stations close, we are  increasingly alone in our ability to do so. We have the ability to change levels of generation quickly and to choose  whether or not to generate so that we capture value when prices are high and avoid costs when prices are low.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So the chart on the right, which shows 2015 power revenues on £1 per megawatt hour basis, is a simple  illustration of this. Starting from the left hand side, we made forward power sales at an average price of just under  £48 per megawatt hour. And then the blue bar, accounting for around £2 per megawatt hour or approximately  £15 million includes the value we earn through buybacks and near-term activity, which typically comprise either  shape creation or operating in the balancing market and by selling ancillary services.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So what is shape creation? In certain low value periods such as overnight in the summer, when demand is low, the  price of power may well be below our cost of production. Where this is the case, we can buy back that power in the  market, and by choosing not to generate, add incremental margin above our previously contracted position.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Higher levels of intermittent generation on the UK system have resulted in more power price volatility. So,  opportunities to buy back power to enhance margins are becoming more and more frequent. Nearer to the point  of delivery, the balancing market provides a further profit opportunity. The National Grid must reposition flexible  thermal plant, which might not otherwise be operating to balance the system and provide the services necessary  for stability, which cannot be provided by inflexible or unreliable plant. Of course, much of the power price  volatility driving these opportunities is dependent on the weather and so very difficult to predict.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Ancillary services, providing other support to grid such as black start capability, or Firm Frequency Response, is  another area where we see increasing potential to add value, and these services are also vital to grid stability. They  have historically been provided by fossil fuel plant and with a further 8 gigawatts of coal having announced, it will  be leading the system this year, the value attached to them could also increase.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, now on to group operating costs. Total costs were £240 million, broadly in line with expectations, and up £20  million year-on-year, reflecting the commissioning and ramp-up of our U.S. operations, as well as the additional  maintenance costs associated with last year's outage works. 2015 was a record year for plant outages with [ph]  four (22:49) taking place, including two IED outages, and the major overhaul of a biomass unit, which we were  delighted to complete with no unusual deteriorations identified.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to capital investment, our biomass transformation is now approaching completion and our capital  investment plans remain firmly on track. By the end of 2015, we had invested around £640 million. Further  investment to come is largely the remainder of our IED solution and will take place in 2016.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, we will complete the transformation within our original cost guidance of £650 million to £700 million. And I  would like to note here that in doing so, we have absorbed significant additional expenditure that was not  included in the original guidance, such as investment in our fleet of biomass rail wagons, which are now an  integral component of cost effective UK logistics.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: If I look at 2015 specifically, total asset additions for the year were £174 million. This includes acceleration of  some IED-related investment, as well as some of the biomass optimization spend. Overall, 2015 additions  included around £90 million for the transformation, £40 million for biomass optimization spend and the balance  for ongoing maintenance CapEx to ensure the efficient and flexible operation of the station.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the future, total investment will be lower as the transformation winds down, a trend you can see in the chart.  For 2016, we expect investment of between £80 million and £100 million, comprising completion of IED  compliance, completion of the biomass unit enhancement program, which began in 2014, and ongoing plant  maintenance CapEx.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On to cash, starting with working capital, where the total inflow was £75 million and there are two key  components that I will draw out. While we were able to reduce coal stocks to 1.4 million tonnes, our biomass  inventories increased to 900,000 tonnes, resulting in a combined net inflow of £20 million. With weaker power  prices, we had an inflow of over £50 million from lower receivables.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The ROC outflow of £86 million represents an increase in the balance sheet value of ROCs generated in 2015, with  a third biomass unit co-firing during the year, less the value of those assets sold during the period. So if one adds  the changes in ROCs to the changes in working capital, the position was broadly neutral for the year. And we  would expect something similar in 2016.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So in summary, against a backdrop of severe commodity price weakness and regulatory challenges, we delivered a  creditable financial performance in 2015, underpinned by good operations, supported by the biomass conversions  and with action taken to mitigate the headwinds.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking forward, we expect the pricing environment to continue to be difficult and the LEC removal will have a  full year impact in 2016. The biomass transformation has created a stronger, more resilient business, which will  receive further underpinning from the CfD once we receive EU State aid approval.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition, we will continue with our focus on finding new sources of value, both for our coal units and to  leverage our biomass expertise. And we will continue to implement opportunities identified to improve operations  and profitability, reduced costs and CapEx, and optimize the use of working capital.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Okay. I just wanted to cover a few slides on the energy market and the role of biomass. I think we all are very  familiar with the trilemma that the government is seeking to solve. What is new is the government's proposed  consultation to take coal off the system by 2025. We believe this is difficult, challenging, but doable.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's difficult because today, particularly today, 35% of dispatchable generation in capacity terms is from coal and  some of that is already under threat and we're in a system that has tighter and tighter capacity. New gas will no  doubt be part of the solution. That will need to be supported by the capacity markets because there is not the  appetite to invest on a purely speculative basis in new gas without clear support, but it will take time to build the  required gas, given the expected or potential closures of coal.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What does that mean for the consumer? Well, that scarcity pricing will be passed through to the consumer and so  will be the extra costs of supporting the system.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What do we think the solution is? Well, no surprise there. Part of the solution, not the whole solution, but the part  of the solution we do believe is conversion of more coal units to biomass. And as I showed in an earlier slide, the  UK lags significantly behind the EU in the deployment of wood as a good form of renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So why do we think biomass is such a good solution? One of the major reasons we think this is because it's not just  reliable and flexible, but it's also the most affordable large scale renewable. To understand the affordability of the  technology, what you need to understand is what is the whole system costs of that technology.  And that's not just  the direct cost of the energy, but it's also the complete system integration costs.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, I don't know if you saw, but we published last week a study by NERA and Imperial College. That built on the  work that both those institutions had been doing for the Climate Change Committee. What that study showed is if  there is a competitive auction for renewable technologies, there could be a saving for the consumer of £2 billion  and that assumed there was a 500 megawatt biomass conversion within successful in that auction.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We actually think that was a rather conservative assumption. And the reason is, that's based on their central case  and their central case is consistent with the Climate Change Committee view on what is going to happen to system  flexibility in terms of technologies other than just large-scale generation. That assumes that we are going to deploy  CCS, a little bit of a challenging assumption in today's regulatory environment. It assumes that storage in the UK  is going to double and it assumes that there is a dramatic increase in demand side response.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We think a more realistic scenario is NERA and Imperial's analysis of what is the system flexibility today. And  that's what the table there shows. It shows the different system integration costs for all the different large-scale  renewables, based on today's flexibility in the system, actually with one exception, we still assume that CCS goes  forward.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And what you can see from that is the system integration costs of biomass are actually negative, a reflection of its  reliability and flexibility, compared to high system integration costs for the other technologies. It also shows the  total cost. And that's based on DECC's own levelised cost analysis. Of course, that has been supplan ted in the case  of some of the technologies by the subsequent CfD auctions, but I don't think it changes the conclusion. And the  conclusion is that biomass is the cheapest large scale technology.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: NERA in their report had two solutions to how you have really competitive renewables at an affordable price for  the consumer. One is that you have renewable auctions based on whole system cost which requires that complex  analysis be difficult and long to implement. But the second solution they have is very simple, easy to implement  and delivers about 90% of the benefit to the consumer, and there are two components to it. The first is that new  renewable investments have the opportunity to participate in the capacity market auctions. And the second is that  there is a single auction for renewable technologies through a CfD auction, but there are two components to that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: First, that all technologies have exactly the same length of contract or term of contract. And secondly, that all  technologies have exactly the same reference price under the CfD and that is the season average price. And the  reason they recommend the season average price is that will require the intermittent technologies bid into their  direct energy price the risk of intermittency. That's not what happens under the CfDs today. Biomass pays on the  basis of a season average reference price, but the intermittent technologies, the reference price is day ahead. So  that means that actually it's the consumer rather than the generator who's paying for that price volatility risk.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I just wanted to end with a slide looking at how Drax kind of fits into this all. I think I've already made it clear that  we believe that there's a greater and greater reliance on reliable and flexible generation capacity in the UK. We see  in the near-term very much that our coal units have an important role to play and that they are part of the  transition to a lower carbon future.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our biomass units, as you know, we've now implemented the largest de-carbonization project in Europe or  indeed, we will complete the largest de-carbonization project in Europe this year. Our new biomass technologies  do indeed deliver sustainable sourcing, logistics and operations. And what's really good about biomass is it's part  of the solution. The more you have reliable and flexible biomass, the more you can support greater wind and solar  because it's complementary to the intermittent technologies.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We do continue to work on biomass technologies. We've spent quite a lot on research and development and people  time and also some expenditure. And the reason we're doing this is we're very keen that the next unit we convert is  even more competitive. And we're confident that the work we're doing now will deliver an even better solution and  deliver a cheaper renewable product for the consumer in the future or for future conversions. So we do believe  that biomass is part of the solution and we stand ready to convert more units.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, just to wrap up, 2015 very difficult year, no question that 2016 is going to be a very difficult year. There's also  no question that we are now the world leader in biomass technology, throughout the supply chain and in the  generation. And we stand ready and are alert to opportunities to capture value from that expertise. There is also  no question that Drax is a reliable, flexible generator at a time when the UK system is under more and more stress,  and we would hope to create value through that opportunity and also deliver security of supply to the UK.
