texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, let's start with a general overview of 2016. As you all know, our EBITDA was £140 million and it was  significantly down on last year. There were two strong drivers in that: one was some very challenging commodity  markets, particularly in the beginning of the year; and also the loss of income from Levy Exemption Certificates.  Within our Generation business, we had a very good operational year. We were pleased to finally secure state aid  approval for the CfD in December, and also to finally complete the conversion of our third unit. 65% of our  generation was from biomass, which we were very pleased with. What was good about the Generation business  is that we really did capture value from our flexibility and reliability, supporting system stability, and that was a key  mitigant in those downward factors of the commodity markets [indiscernible] (01:57) and also the delay to the  approval of the CfD.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Sustainability is very, very important to us that the compressed wood pellets we burn are not only low-carbon, but  always sourced – the fiber that goes into them is always sourced from sustainable sources. We, many years now,  have had a very robust sustainability policy which we adhere to strictly. We are fully compliant with the UK  mandatory standards and I'm pleased to say our performance on terms of a low-carbon fuel was particularly good  last year. And you can see the average there, 34 grams of CO2 per megajoule on a life cycle basis, and we're  very pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The other area where we made very strong progress last year was actually in our NOx emission reductions,  nitrous oxide. Biomass for compressed wood pellets are a naturally low-NOx fuel, but we also have installed  additional NOx reduction equipment for our coal generation, and that brings us into compliance with the Industrial  Emissions Directive, and the combination of higher generation from compressed wood pellets and this new  emission reduction equipment means that we are more than able to halve our emissions of NOx from the plant in  Yorkshire.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, going through the three different businesses, actually four in total when you – if separate coal and biomass. In  terms of Retail, we now have a really well-established challenger in the I&C market in terms of Haven, sales of  14.6 terawatt hours, and pretty steady revenue at £1.3 billion. It was a very good year in terms of operation. We  had good credit quality for our customers, low bad debt, and a pleasing level of renewable. But the real way you  can see it being a good delivery year is the improving profitability of this business, and we very much expect that  trend to continue.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, biomass generation, we now have three fully converted units, two supported by ROCs, grandfathered ROCs,  one supported by the CfD. We are the only large-scale flexible, reliable, renewable generation in the UK. We are  the largest single source of renewables, and indeed you can see there, we produced 12.7 terawatt hours of  renewable power at 16% of UK renewable electricity. But the costs to the UK, just purely in terms of support  costs, we were only 10% of the support costs when you look across all the renewables used in the UK.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Coal generation – my gosh, it feels to me the days are long past when we were a base load operator operating  throughout 365 days a year. Our coal generation is completely different now. It's all about system support. It's  about providing system stability when the system is under stress or providing necessary electricity when there is a  capacity shortage or a real need for extra generation and you can see that in the dramatic fall in our coal  generation. Last year, we did 15 terawatt hours. This year, we did a mere 7 terawatt hours. But what's most  notable is the difference in the number of starts on those units, we've gone from 150 starts last year, up – sorry,  2015, I'm getting my years muddled, to 400 starts in 2016.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We have bid two of the three units into the capacity market in all of the auctions, and we have also bid in our three  little gas units at the Drax site. We secured capacity contracts in 2017 through to 2021, securing £18 million of  income. We have participated, as with many others, on the consultation on potential coal closure by 2025. We are  now of the view that we expect our coal units to close as coal generation units in 2025. And for that reason, we've  chosen to accelerate the depreciation of coal-specific assets. So, this isn't actually the generation plant itself, it's  everything that is bespoke to coal, and a perfectly good example is our coal handling systems for receiving the  coal and delivering it and storing the coal.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, in terms of wood pellet production, the U.S. plants are working well as it's both the production for pellets and  also the coal facility. Our focus here is very much on reliable production, but really low quality pellets at cost,  that's the key getting the cost of these pellets down. And also using our presence in supply chain to optimize  value across the Group, and that was well illustrated by our choice to curtail production in 2016. So, Drax Power  could take advantage of distressed cargos at a very, very low cost.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: There are significant benefits to self-supply. This flexibility is one, but it's also about reliability, quality,  optimization, there are many benefits. So, we are targeting 20% to 30% self-supply. What that means is  essentially pretty well doubling our current capacity. We have two initiatives underway near-term of this. One is  actually an incremental investment in the existing plants. So, these plants have a capacity of 900,000 tonnes per  year, we are going to be spending £10 million on increasing that production capacity by 150,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: This has got two advantages. First, it's quite straightforward; it's a very low cost for incremental capacity. But the  second is actually the more important; it's going to enable us to use a much higher percentage of secondary  residues in the production of those pellets. And those secondary residues are a very low cost, are lower cost than  normal of raw material to make that compressed wood pellet. And the secondary residues, what I mean is the by- products of wood processing industries, the most typical of which is sawmills.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The second initiative is there are a number of distressed pellet plants across – within the U.S. and actually in  Europe as well. And this is because as we've had three warm winters in Europe, a bit colder this year, but there  has been a shortage of demand that has put financial pressure on this, particularly cash flow pressure, and some  of these distressed plants, we expect to come up for auction or sale. And if they are of the right quality of  equipment, then we are interested purchasers, and we see that as a real opportunity to increase our own capacity  and self-supply.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, let me provide a little bit more detail on 2016. There is a full income statement in the appendix, and I'll discuss  EBITDA on the next page, but I wanted to mention the couple of other items on the income statement. So,  underlying EBIT was £27 million, a reduction of £34 million versus 2015. In addition to the lower EBITDA, this  reflects depreciation of £113 million versus £108 million the year before, which reflects increased depreciation of  our biomass investments.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to page 13, I thought it would be helpful to step through the key components of our net cash flow. In  addition to EBITDA of £140 million, we had a working capital inflow of £63 million, and the largest driver of this  inflow was the utilization of the Retail receivables deal that we discussed at the half year. We still have significant  working capital on our balance sheet and we expect to work that down over the next few years as coal stocks  decline and the cash flow benefits of the CfD flow through to the balance sheet. We're also working on additional  initiatives that should help further. Capital expenditure of £93 million reflects the completion of our three Biomass  unit conversions, and our total net cash flow was £95 million with closing cash of £228 million, and again, a  modest level of net debt.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So turning to 2017, and some of the themes that we see there. So 2016, we delivered the biomass conversions  that we commenced in 2012. We navigated challenging commodity markets and began to implement our new  strategy focused on improving the quality of earnings and enabling long-term growth. And in 2017, we expect to  see the first fruits of that strategy with both strong earnings growth and higher quality earnings.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, first the CfD, it provides a firm long-term base on which to build. Secondly, we expect to grow profitability in  both our Retail and Biomass Supply businesses where earnings are not so commodity price dependent.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Third, as the grid continues to require support to maintain stability, we expect to capture significant value through  both our coal and biomass units by supporting this system with their responsive generation. Fourth, we should  see an immediate benefit from the purchase of Opus Energy, which we were pleased to complete last week. And  finally, as Dorothy mentioned, we continued to explore the opportunity to purchase distressed pellet plants.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our strategy will require disciplined investments to support both our existing business, but also to deliver our  strategic objectives. This includes changing our approach to our coal operations where we expect to make more  targeted investment in the context of the government's consultation on the closure of unabated coal generation by  2025.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So while the units continue to play an important role in system support up until that time, we expect that from  2025, the coal infrastructure will not be required. So, accordingly, we are accelerating the depreciation of our coal- specific assets. And to be clear again, as Dorothy mentioned, this only includes the coal-specific assets, not the  generating assets themselves where we still see value and remain ready to convert to biomass with the right  support.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, what that means is that we should be – we expect to be significantly cash generative over the course of the  next years, but we also believe we have significant investment opportunities to invest at a value significant – give  us a return significantly above our cost of capital, as we've done at the end of last year with both Opus and the  rapid response gas projects.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: CapEx is expected to be in line with 2016 reflecting investment to support our strategy. So, while biomass-specific  CapEx will decline, as Dorothy mentioned, we are investing in additional pellet capacity at our plants in the U.S.,  as well as in new systems at Haven. In addition, we continue to invest in Generation to ensure that we can deliver  the flexibility that is central to our strategy. Looking beyond 2017, we would expect long-term core CapEx, again,  still to be around £50 million.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: As I previously mentioned, depreciation will increase significantly to around £160 million per year, and that  increase reflects two things. First, the capitalization of assets following completion of the biomass conversion and  our U.S. supply chain. And second, recognizing the government's consultation on the closure of unabated coal  generation by 2025. We have accelerated the depreciation of the common coal plant at the Drax site as I  mentioned before. And again, to be clear, these are not the units themselves, rather a coal system specific  [indiscernible] (25:44) conveyors or handling systems.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So to sum up, so 2016 represents a turning point for Drax. We delivered good operational performance,  completed the biomass conversion and launched our new strategy. Commodity markets continued to be difficult,  but we finally received our CfD, which should underpin long-term, high-quality earnings growth going forward. And  with the launch of that new strategy, we actually completed two acquisitions to support it, and we're looking at  further acquisitions of pellet plants in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So then let's look at the Generation market. We've talked about this before, but there really is an increased need  for system support. The statistic National Grid put out is system support crossed £1 billion in 2015, it's expected to  be £2 billion by 2020. And it's very clear, why that is necessary, closure of large thermal plant, 11 gigabits since  2012 alone, and the growth in [indiscernible] (28:23) be it onshore wind, offshore wind or solar.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So what's our response to this. Our first response is to make sure, we've got the right investment in our biomass  and coal units, so they maintain a higher liability and then high flexibility. Our next response is to look at what the  market really needs beyond what we can provide from within our existing plans and that's what drove us to  acquire these four projects to these rapid response gas generation projects that come from zero to full-load in just  10 minutes, and if they're warm, it's only in 5 minutes. So that's our response to that part of the market.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The compressed wood pellet market is a bit more complicated. As I said before, these three warm winters  mitigates a little bit by this cold winter has led that market to be really under stress at the moment from a supply  point of view. And that's what we're seeing in the market, we're seeing supplies in real financial difficulty.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: By contrast, both Netherlands and Japan are actively implementing policies which will increase significantly the  demand for biomass. And what we expect that to do is to lead in a few years time to increase demand for  biomass. I should say what's our response to this. So near-term, targeting 20% to 30% self-supply, essentially, as  I said expanding our own production by some small targeted investment, but also looking at an opportunity to  purchase some of these distressed assets.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, what are our priorities for 2017? Coal, absolutely coal, is to deliver excellence in the base business. Very,  very important. We need to maintain our focus on that. And then, it's all about delivering these attractive growth  opportunities that are going to be delivering enhanced returns. So, let's start with Opus.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: What we will be doing is we will be terminating – or we're – actually we've already given notice, but there is  flexible time on when we actually terminate the different arrangements – Opus' supply arrangement for gas and  electricity from a third-party provider. We will be bringing that contract in-house. In future, our direct supplier will  provide all the power and gas to Opus as it does today provide all the power to Haven. And that's going to be the  key synergy because that is quite an expensive contract to be kept with a third party.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, the next thing we will be looking at is these rapid response gas turbines. And the initial work this year is all on  getting them ready for construction. So, it's about scoping the construction arrangements, holding a tender for  those construction arrangements, very attractive time to tender for new build in the market at the moment  because there's very, very, very limited gas build going on, so attractive opportunities in terms of enthusiastic  suppliers.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We'll be perfecting the payments and perfecting the permits. And it's all also about the connection points, making  sure you have the right connection points for into phases, into construction. We expect to bid two of the plants into  this year's capacity market. And we will build the following two probably into 2019.

texts.speaker: Dorothy Carrington Thompson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And then the third area, the third area is buying distressed pellet plants at a very significant discount to new-build  and creating a cheaper source or a new additional cheaper source of wood pellets for our wood pellet generation.  And then finally, we will always remain – two things; we stand ready to convert further units. And as I said, we're  working on technologies to bring those new converted biomass units in at a lower cost. And we will continue to  engage with government on this. This is the lowest-cost large-scale renewable, and we do believe we have a  further role to play. And we will look for other opportunities consistent with those market themes that we think will  yield attractive returns.

file: DRXL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 27February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, I'm delighted to be here for my first set of results as the Drax CEO. Let me tell you how I see 2017 for the  group. Drax is continuing to transform itself, from the largest coal-fired power station in the UK to an integrated  low-carbon energy company. During 2017, we made progress across all areas of the business strategically,  operationally and financially.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We achieved several milestones in 2017. We acquired and successfully on-boarded Opus Energy. Evidence of  that was our delivery of £29 million of EBITDA, in line with our plans. We acquired LaSalle BioEnergy and began  commissioning in November 2017, which was two months ahead of plan.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We received government support for the conversion of a fourth unit to biomass. And we positioned ourselves well  for future investment in gas generation as we progressed the repowering at Drax Power Station and our options  to develop four new OCGTs. While we did not receive a contract in the latest capacity auction, we intend to enter  two of the projects in the auctions coming up in December.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Let me remind you of how we intend to do that. First by achieving our goal of 30% self-supply, we expect to grow  the EBITDA of our Pellet Production business to at least £75 million. Secondly, as we move off coal, we're adding  a fourth biomass unit to our generation business. When combined with our options to develop gas-fired  generation, we expect to deliver more than £300 million of EBITDA from our Power Generation business.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, we expect to continue growing our B2B Energy Supply business as it has done over the last decade to  achieve at least £80 million of EBITDA. We made an excellent start towards delivering those objectives in 2017.  Financially, we delivered EBITDA of £238 million in Power Generation, £29 million in B2B Energy Supply, and £6  million in Pellet Production. We also made progress on our strategic targets. We purchased and commissioned  LaSalle BioEnergy moving to 1.5 million tonnes of capacity relative to our goal of approximately 30% self-supply  or 2 million to 2.5 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We work with government to get support for the conversion of unit four to biomass, and we purchased Opus  Energy and delivered on our first year business plan. At the same time, we successfully managed our balance  sheet so that net debt was 1.6 times EBITDA, allowing us to announce today a £50 million share buyback and  deliver on our commitment to deliver returns for shareholders.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Let me move on now to the operations and business review. Safety and sustainability are at the core of what we  do. We work in challenging environments. Both coal and biomass must be handled carefully or they can pose  significant safety risks. We had a small fire in our biomass handling facilities at the power station in December.  Most importantly, no one was injured in the incident.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: While there's limited biomass operations on two units for about four weeks, the team at the power station worked  very well to both mitigate and then repair the damage. And overall, our safety record continues to be outstanding  and in line with prior years.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The biomass that we use must be sourced sustainably to ensure that it delivers the appropriate level of CO2  reduction, while at the same time, we support the habitat in which we operate. And we continue to deliver on our  commitments to sustainable biomass.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Corporate responsibility is important to us. We have recently become a member of the UN Global Compact and  we have significantly increased our reporting on sustainability on our website. By continuing to work safely and  sustainably, we're building a long-term business that delivers growing returns to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: 2017 was a transformational year for Drax biomass. For the first time, we delivered positive EBITDA, £6 million,  which is a £12 million increase on 2016. We increased our production by 35% to 822,000 tonnes. And during the  fourth quarter, began producing consistently at nameplate capacity at Morehouse and Amite, our first two plants.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We also completed our dry shavings projects on time and to budget of £10 million, increasing capacity by 75,000  tonnes at each plant. These projects also help us significantly reduce the cost of production, thereby moving us  towards our long-term target of making biomass viable without government support.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We purchased and successfully recommissioned LaSalle BioEnergy. The total investment including upgrade of  £50 million is approximately half the cost of newbuild plant. We are already ramping up and on some days are  producing at levels close to our other plants. As a result, we now have about 1.5 million tonnes of our own  capacity, closing in on our target of 2 million to 2.5 million tonnes or approximately 30% of self-supply.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We will continue to develop projects to expand our capacity at our own sites. These projects have excellent  returns and have the added benefit of reducing our pellet production cost. And we will also look opportunistically  at acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: One final note. In January, I made the decision to move our U.S. headquarters from Atlanta to Monroe, Louisiana.  We already have a regional office in Monroe, which is located close to our three existing plants in the U.S. Gulf  Coast. This was not an easy decision to make, and we will treat all our people fairly and I'd like to thank them for  their contributions. The change is driven by our desire to promote efficiency and reduce cost to help achieve our  long-term goal of making biomass viable without government support. Looking into 2018, our goal in Pellet  Production is to continue growing towards our nameplate capacity of 1.5 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: 2017 was an excellent year for Drax Power. We delivered a £64 million increase in EBITDA, largely the result of  having the CfD for a full year. We continue to be the UK's largest single source of renewable energy at 13  terawatt hours, a small increase over 2016. Importantly, this represents 65% of all of our generation. And today,  coal-fired power sales are just 9% of the group's revenue. We play a critical role in supporting the UK power  system, as demonstrated by the £88 million that we generated from system support and flexibility.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Looking into 2018, our goal is to continue driving operational excellence with high biomass availability to generate  the necessary baseload power for UK security of supply and flexible coal to support the system when needed. As  always, safe operations throughout the plant are a top priority.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: 2017 was also a transformational year for our B2B Energy Supply business. For the first time, we delivered  positive EBITDA £29 million, a £33 million increase on 2016. Both Haven Power and Opus Energy delivered  positive EBITDA and we increased meter points by over 10% to 375,000. Opus Energy delivered in line with plan  and began the journey to realize the key financial synergy of the acquisition by in-sourcing both electricity and gas  supply. Opus also is named Utilities Provider of the Year at the British Small Business Awards, a great  achievement in a year of significant change.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: The energy supply market continues to be in flux. In the B2B sector, we have an ongoing opportunity to grow our  market share whilst retaining our strong margins. At the same time, we look forward to completing our system  implementations at Haven Power, which will enable us to drive down cost over time. This is the first step in  building a consolidated B2B Energy Supply platform.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Okay, moving on to the detail in the income statement. Revenue growth principally represents the acquisition of  Opus Energy and renewable support under the CfD mechanism. I'll come on to the components of EBITDA in the  next slide, but below this figure, firstly, a charge of £182 million for depreciation, amortilization (sic) [amortization]  (00:14:44) and disposal. Of this, depreciation and amortization was £166 million, up £57 million year-on-year,  principally reflecting the accelerated depreciation of coal-specific assets as well as a £37 million amortilization  (sic) [amortization] (00:15:01) for the newly acquired intangible assets in Opus Energy.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, I'll come on to cash in more detail, but to summarize again, the balance sheet is strong, net debt of £367  million, which is below our target of 2 times net debt to EBITDA. This reflects very healthy cash generation from  our core operations and working capital inflows. Our operating cash conversion has been around 65% for the last  two years and will continue to increase as the Energy Supply and Pellet Production businesses contribute  increasingly to EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Okay. I thought it'd be useful here to provide a year-on-year bridge for EBITDA, which has increased by £89  million, with significant improvements across all three areas of operations. A full income statement is included in  the appendix. But in summary, Power Generation was up £64 million, benefiting from one unit operating under the  CfD mechanism, which helped offset a reduction and achieved seasonable power prices. And ancillary services of  £31 million, a £16 million lower year-on-year reflecting black start payments received in 2016.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: It's noteworthy that in 2017, we created £88 million of value from system support services and flexibility, a  combination of balancing market activities, ancillary services, and advantaged fuels. Now, with more intermitted  and inflexible generation on the UK system and the removal of thermal generation, we expect the flexible and  reliable attributes of our existing and new generation options to become an increasingly important and profit driver  for the group.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, taken in aggregate, Power Generation EBITDA was up 37% on 2016. Energy Supply, now meaningful and  growing part of the group's earnings profile, saw revenues increased from £1.3 billion in 2016 to £2 billion in 2017.  And reported EBITDA of £29 million, this is in line with our guidance and an increase of £33 million on 2016. This  increase reflects the acquisition of Opus Energy and the improved financial performance from Haven Power  which was ahead of plan.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Now, in the U.S., Pellet Production has made good progress, increasing volumes of wood pellets produced and  sold, driving revenue growth and EBITDA of £6 million versus the £6 million loss in 2016. [ph] Raw fiber  (00:18:51) procurement, transportation and processing comprise the majority of cost of sales. And as such, this  remains an important area of focus and an opportunity.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Through incremental investment in plant enhancements, we expect to see further benefits from efficiencies and  greater utilization of lower cost residues. Whilst total operating costs have increased, this is a reflection of an  increase in operations in Amite, Morehouse and the Port of Baton Rouge, along with the addition of LaSalle  BioEnergy.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our Power Generation business has index-linked revenues to 2027 under the CfD and ROC mechanisms. In  2017, these represented 37% of total Power Generation revenues, up from 23% in 2016. Combined with our long- term biomass procurement contracts and rolling five-year FX hedging program, this provides a growing and  predictable level of EBITDA subject to maintaining high levels of operational performance.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We have an important role to play in system support and expect this market to grow. Over the period 2017 to  2022, we expect to receive over £90 million of capacity payments and any developments of new gas generation  will be underpinned by a 15-year capacity agreement.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Lastly, our Energy Supply business is profitable, providing predictable and growing sales in the B2B market and  contributing to EBITDA growth.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, the cash flow, where we delivered strong generation across the businesses driven by growth in EBITDA, most  notably from a CfD mechanism. We also saw a significant cash inflow from working capital totaling £148 million.  Now, there are two components to this. Firstly, as a result of our third biomass unit transitioning from the ROC to  the CfD scheme, we saw a reduction in the number of ROCs held on the balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Moving to investment, total asset additions for maintenance and improvements for the year were £133 million, in  line with guidance, of which £69 million related to maintenance. We expect this to be around £50 million to £60  million in future years but recognizing that this will vary from year to year, reflecting the needs of the businesses.  Improvement and optimization was £64 million related to a number of projects, which we expect to deliver  significant incremental value across the businesses, organically increasing the capacity of our Pellet Production,  consolidating Energy Supply operations, and optimizing Power Generation.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Strategic investments include our acquisition of Opus Energy for £367 million, and £48 million for the acquisition  and upgrade of LaSalle BioEnergy, which is currently in commissioning. The latter was an attractively priced  asset, which once fully operational will increase capacity and support our strategic objective of good quality  pellets at the lowest cost.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: For example, enhancements to our generation assets where we know that modest improvements to efficiency will  deliver fast payback, and the development of our Energy Supply IT platform, which we expect to support growth  and reduce our cost to serve customers. In Pellet Production, we continue to target a self-supply capacity of 30%,  either organically or through acquisition. And to that end, we remain alert to sector opportunities.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, to sum up, we have delivered a strong financial performance with increases in EBITDA and cash across the  group. High-quality earnings are coming through from the long-term renewable revenue under the CfD and ROC  schemes as well as in our Energy Supply business.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Den. So, I wanted to just spend a little bit of time talking about how we are planning to deliver our  strategy. And it starts with the context, the UK is transforming to a low-carbon economy. By 2050, it's legally  bound to reduce carbon emissions by 80% across generation, transport and heating.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And the first step in this journey is the decarbonization of the electricity sector, where substantial progress has  been made. 2017 was a breakthrough year as low-carbon energy sources, renewables and nuclear, provided  50% of power generation in the UK while coal accounted for just 7% of the generation mix compared to 43% in  2012.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Much of that new generation is wind and solar, but biomass has an important role. It is the only source of  renewable power that can support the system, operating when the wind is not blowing and the sun is not shining.  We expect this system to become increasingly volatile with higher peak prices and lower even negative prices at  the bottom of the market. And this will create opportunities for flexible generators like Drax.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Beyond 2027, biomass needs to become viable without government support, and that is one of Drax's long-term  strategic goals.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, the low-carbon economy will require new solutions for transport and heat. And 2017 also felt like a  breakthrough year for electric vehicles. While adoption is still low, enthusiasm is high, and it is an area that we are  exploring with our business customers.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: A stable and secure energy system requires a range of different services, not just megawatts and megawatt  hours. It requires low-carbon electricity and system support in the balancing, prompt, and ancillary services  markets. Historically, this was provided by a conventional plant, which meant that effectively system support came  for free. Many of these assets are now coming to the ends of their operating lives and being replaced with  intermittent renewables.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: To put it into context, over 13 years, 2012 to 2025, more than 30 gigawatts of coal and gas is expected to retire.  That's seven Drax power stations. This will lead to increased price volatility and insufficient system support. And  as such, we believe that new gas will be required and in the first instance, we believe that the low capital cost,  fast-response operating model of OCGTs is a good fit for the grid, meeting peak demand and providing ancillary  services.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So far, the capacity market has not brought forward the type of generation that will provide the security of supply,  the flexibility, and the system support that's needed. The failure to develop the right sort of capacity will increase  the need for action on the part of the system operator. And within five years, National Grid may be required to  take corrective action in 60% of periods to manage the grid to provide inertia and backup, alongside the  management of frequency and voltage issues.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: In this changing energy system, Drax's Power Generation business has an important role to play, both with our  existing biomass generation, as well as our new gas projects.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: With regards to biomass, we're very well-positioned to provide ancillary services and system support. And as you  know, during 2017, we secured government support to convert a fourth unit to biomass. We plan to complete the  work on this unit as part of a major planned outage later this year. The investment required is around £30 million,  making it a very low-cost solution. We'll achieve this by utilizing older biomass infrastructure at the power station,  which was built in 2010 for coal firing.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We expect to run the unit at periods of high demand, which are often those of higher carbon intensity, supporting  the system when it is most needed. While we will not receive a significant number of additional ROCs by  optimizing our running regime, we believe the investment will be attractive. This is an excellent solution for Drax,  for government, and also for the consumer and shows what can be achieved by collaboration between  governments and industry. Over the longer term, we need to continue driving down the cost of biomass power  generation, and it is our ambition to ultimately make it economically viable without government support.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Beyond biomass, we're developing four options for OCGTs in Central England and Wales. These assets can go  from cold to full load in minutes, making them good support for intermittent renewables and also a source of  ancillary services. We made excellent progress developing these projects during 2017, reducing our expected  capital and operating costs, and we will continue to do more during 2018. We believe these are the right assets  for the system and expect to enter the first two projects again, and the capacity auctions later this year.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Finally, with coal closure by 2025, we're developing options to repower our remaining coal units to run as CCGTs.  We are currently going through a planning consultation process. No investment decision has been made at this  stage, but we could participate in the capacity auctions as early as 2019, which could see one of those units on  stream as early as 2023. And crucially, by using existing infrastructure, we expect the cost to be significantly  below that of a newbuild CCGT.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Having spoken about how our generation strategy takes advantage of our experience and position in the UK  system to drive future growth and value, as well as having described our strategy for our Pellet Production,  growing to 30% self-supply and using our position across the supply chain to deliver the lowest cost pellet, I now  want to talk about our B2B Energy Supply business, Opus Energy and Haven Power.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Our B2B annuity continues to strengthen both by number of customers and value. Following the successful  onboarding of Opus Energy, we're in a great position to leverage and grow our challenger brands. Today, we offer  both great service, as well as renewable propositions. And these are at the core of our offering and are driving  growth.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: With the line blurring between generation and supply, we also have the opportunity to help customers on their  own energy transformation. We now support over 20% of the UK's smaller generators, from wind farms, to  batteries, to anaerobic digesters, gain access to the market, and we manage almost 2 terawatt hours of  renewable generation for our customers. And as we continue to grow and take advantage of the synergies  between energy supply and generation, we have identifiable opportunities to strengthen our gross margin. This  has started with our insourcing of gas and power and is already delivering benefits.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: Beyond that, we need to keep innovating. We recognize that customers are demanding more control and new  ways to interact with suppliers, and we are responding. We've taken a digital-first approach to the design of all of  our technology. Smart meters have been delayed in the industry as a whole, but our program is well underway  and ready to accelerate once the meters become available. We see this as critical as the data that smart meters  will create becomes a catalyst for change with new ways to support customers with their energy efficiency  propositions.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: And underpinning our overall B2B supply business will be our investment in technology. We are building a retail  energy platform that can take advantage of a changing energy market. But we're not waiting. We're focusing on  efficient operations today. Opus already has a very competitive cost to serve, and we are starting to apply that  model across our supply business.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: So, in summary, we have a strong business with growing EBITDA from all areas of the group. In Pellet  Production, we are commissioning LaSalle as part of our self-supply strategy and optimizing production to  produce good quality pellets at the lowest cost. In Power Generation, we are focused on running the power  station safely, efficiently and with high availability. We're developing a fourth biomass unit to provide additional  long-term renewable revenues alongside system support.

texts.speaker: Dwight Daniel William Gardiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Drax Group Plc
texts.text: We continue to develop our gas projects and we'll enter our first two OCGTs in the auction again in December. In  B2B Energy Supply, we expect continued growth in meters and EBITDA from Opus and Haven, alongside the  development of systems and platforms to support long-term growth and efficiency.
