texts.text: Consolidated CapEx went down 25%, as referred before, or 3% increase, excluding the cash grant impact,  reflecting higher expansion CapEx in new hydro in Portugal and lower expansion CapEx in wind.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to regulatory receivables in Page 10, we can see that they increased €313 million versus December 2013,  mostly due to Portugal, driven by the already known ex-ante tariff deficit; higher special regime production in the  first quarter, namely, wind, which was very strong; the delay in terms of the CO2 cash receipts for the electric  system; and slightly lower demand than expected.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

EBITDA in this quarter in EDP Renováveis also includes new  generation taxes in Spain, €11 million; and a one-off gain in U.S., €14 million.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thank you, Miguel. So what we have clearly is an improvement on the visibility of EDP medium term free cash  flow potential. And so, at this stage, and what concerns the prospect for 2013 in terms  of operating outlook, we see, of course, that it's difficult to be – very difficult to expect all the quarters to be at the  quarter in what concerns either on wind, that's obvious.

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, at consolidated level, the net profit breakdown, we can see that after the 0.8% decline of EBITDA, net  depreciations and provisions decreased by 2%, as the combined impact from the increase of wind farms'  accounting useful life and also new capacity in operation, namely wind and hydro. texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: We see in terms of market, favorable for coal and adverse for gas, no news at this stage, but basically due to the  percentage of coal, I think that relatively it's good for – in terms of relative terms, it's good for us. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So overall, what we will see is that first half resilience, discipline on CapEx, discipline on OpEx, with the exception  of slower implementation, I've been saying every single time, on costs. texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, moving to the last division, Brazil, starting for some market environment in the second quarter in Brazil,  we would like to refer the positive news on the significant decline in terms of electricity rationing risk as a  consequence first of the slowdown in terms of electricity demand growth, which was stronger in first quarter, but  slowed down in the second quarter; and also some improvement in terms of hydro's water level, unfortunately not  in the South East region, which is the most important one, but at least in the South region, which is helping to  reduce this pressure and risk.

texts.text: Finally, the acceptance period of our tender offer of the EDPR at €6.75 per share will end up by the end of next  week. By August 4, we will have clear visibility on the exact impact of the net debt from the combined deals of  natural gas disposal plus the tender offer of EDPR.

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, let's move to slide 2. As I refer, the first half was marked by adverse weather conditions regarding hydro  production, something that we all knew since the beginning of the year. Overall, sale for the period for the first half of 2017, our  hydro production was down 7.8 terawatt hours and around 4.5 terawatt hours lower than average historical  average.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Note that the second half of the year, and I think it's important as we speak, which includes the seasonal dry  summer season is structurally less relevant for hydro volumes than the first half of the year. And on top of this, in  year-on-year terms, the first quarter last year was very, very dry, so it's a much easy comparison base. So,  overall, although our first half recurring performance was significantly penalized by low hydro, this is a short -term  weather impact which does not affect our recurring EBITDA forecast forward.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In Iberia, EBITDA fell by 22%, including of course the 43% decline in Generation & Supply penalized over the  stress by the low hydro and higher power prices environment. texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: If we move to slide 4, outlook for 2017; I would point that given the ongoing portfolio shuffling, this is a transition  year for EDP towards business structure simplification. We have already stated this previously when we  announced the deals. And then 2017 financials will be positively impacted by one-offs from the significant  disposals and also some negative weather effect in the first half of the year. These one-offs and weather-related  impact will not impact financial performance in the following years and allow us, as we speak, to continue highly  confident that we will deliver financial performance fully consistent with the targets established in our 2016-2020  plan.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of recurring EBITDA, the negative impacts from weak hydro volumes in Iberia in the first half and the  deconsolidation of the gas network in the second half, coupled with the positive impact from higher wind and  hydro installed capacity and efficiency improvements should lead to an EBITDA in the region of €3.6 billion.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Slide 8: main growth projects. In terms of our growth strategy, we remain faithful to our focus on renewables,  mostly in the U.S. and of course regulated electricity networks. texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.text: In terms of CapEx, we see a 3% decrease to €1.16 billion. Basically, we are talking about the new hydro capacity  execution in Portugal and Brazil and wind outside Iberia. In terms of disposals, we have €600 million for the first  nine months. We have our HCGs, the gas transmission in Spain and the 49% transaction with CTG related to  EDPR in Portugal assets. The net debt fell by €100 million, 1%, to €18.1 billion by September. This includes of  course the dividend, almost €800 million, the regulatory receivable already mentioned, and the expansion CapEx  of around €7 00 million.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So overall, I think that we have once again a resilient quarter. I think that – and what depends on us both on that  regulatory base, but also energy management. Also costs, we are doing what is e xpected from us. So we are doing  our job. In what concerns, we are reaping the benefit of our portfolio approach in renewables. We are also  extracting the benefits of our focus in Brazil. And of course, we are already impacted by the adverse regulatory  changes that have been happening on the Iberian market.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Okay. Thank you. Regarding weather and market conditions in Iberia, in the first nine months of 2013, they were  marked by strong hydro and wind volumes mainly in the first half 2013, which are quite positive for our  generation needs. Note that in the first half 2013, the low pool prices and EDP's strong position on client s  supported the good energy management results. While in the third quarter 2013, these market conditions changed  as the pool price was higher at the level of €60 per megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of electricity consumption in Portugal, it grew by 1.9% in the third quarter of 2013 in line with the other  recent positive lead key indicators. I would highlight also that this is the first quarter of demand year -on-year  growth since the fourth quarter 2010. And on top of that, the more recent data in October 2013, dem and in  Portugal rose 1.3% year-on-year, so showing signs of stabilization in terms of demand evolution.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of EDP's operating performance in the period, installed capacity was flat year -on-year, as the new  capacity in terms of hydro in Portugal, coal in Brazil, and wind out of Iberia was compensated by the impact of the  decommissioning of the Setúbal fuel oil plant. Power production rose 14% mostly due to rainy and windy weather  conditions in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to page 10 regarding CapEx. It fell by 3% or a 5% increase when we exclude the €91 million cash grant in  U.S. Expansion CapEx in the period included the ongoing construction works of the 5 hydro plants in Portugal, of  which 61% of CapEx was already incurred and also reflects lower expansion CapEx in wind as projects in Poland  and Romania are now in final stage and new projects are still in early stages regarding U.S.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: The second deviation was a deviation of €0.2 billion related to no cash-in of revenues from CO2 auctions in the  period. These revenues should be fully collected in the fourth quarter of the year , although they are being  impacted by the decline of the CO2 prices. Finally, we had also a negative impact of €0.1 billion related with lower  than expected demand in the first nine months of the year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Taking a look on the performance business area by business area. We can see that market conditions for  liberalized generation in Iberia were impacted by a 2.5% decline on Iberian electricity demand and also a 37 %  decline on thermal power demand due to lower demand and strong hydro and wind resources in the first nine  months of the year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Our liberalized power plants in Iberia showed a 3% production increase as hydro weight rose from 15% to 36% on  rainy weather and new hydro capacity namely Alqueva II. And also, there was a strong decline in thermal load  factors on the back of lower residual thermal demand with mainly o ur CCGT growth factors falling to 4% in the  first nine months of the year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Overall, EBITDA overall liberalized energy activities in Iberia stood flat year -on-year as the adverse regulatory  development and lower profitability of thermal plants were fully o ffset by the lower sourcing costs, along with the  benefits of our loan position in clients.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to EBITDA in terms of long term contracted generation activities in Iberia, it fell by 11% in the period,  impacted essentially by the decommissioning of our Setúbal fuel oil plant in December 2012. We had also the  positive impact from the stronger increase in mini-hydro production in the period, which partly compensated the  negative impact from Setúbal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In regulated energy networks in Iberia, EBITDA fell by 5%. The major driver was the lower return on RAB in the  electricity distribution in Portugal, which was driven by the indexation of these rates to the five -year CDS of  Portuguese Republic, which recorded a decline in the period.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thank you, Miguel. To talk about the outlook, of course, we need to mention some of the most recent measures in  the sector, especially those that are fresh in Portugal. Even if we have already talked about this with all of you, I  would mention something about this again. Basically, I'm talking about kind of fiscal package and the kind of  second energy package.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: On page 30, what we mentioned is the fiscal measures that are today introduced in the state budget for 2014 still  to be approved late November by the government. But the government proposal is clear. It's an extraordinary  contribution by the energy sector in 2014. The sector impacted is electricity, gas and oil. The measure is 0.85%  non-deductible tax on fixed tangible and intangible assets.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And clearly, you have exemption that we'd like to stress. The power plant is not yet in operation beginning of next  year. Plants with license are awarded through competitive processes. And also especially wind, mini-hydros, and  biomass. And last but not the least, all the CCGTs that work less than 2,000 hours in 2013 and fortunately we have  a lot.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So clearly, the exemptions are common sense, either because there were sectors that have already disagreements,  for example wind with repayments of exemptions. So clearly, there was an agreement on this. And also, the assets  that are clearly affected by the market conditions like CCGTs.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So it's important to say that of the €150 million of expected proceeds, €50 million or one -third is to be allocated to  tariff deficit reduction and energy efficiency measures. In terms of tax, we have already stated we expect an impact  of around €45 million through EDP. But we still have to see if it's the final version approved by the government.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Second energy package, page 31. What we would like to stress is this is clearly a complement to the first package  that was presented in May 2012. With some optimization measures, something that we find very reasonable in  terms of clawback of eventual gains made by Portuguese generators. In 2014, clearly the impact of this, let's take  into consideration the tax package of us. So the provision here estimated depends very much on what we have  mentioned prior in terms of tax package.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Then I would also like to mention regulatory receivables in Portugal. As we have already mentioned in previous  presentations, we expect the peaking in December 2014, so next year, peaking at €5.3 billion. It's the first ele ment  that I would like to share. So exactly, what we have been stating to the market. We see that the increase of  seasonal receivables in the third quarter was quite small, so only €70 million, considering no revenues of CO2 in  sales.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And we should stress two things, stress an improvement of electricity demand and CO2 prices. But especially, the  fact that in the 2014 ERSE proposal, we see a 2.8% increase. So once again, we are respecting the rules of inflation  plus between 1.5% to 2% increase. And expecting inflation is 1%, it means that this proposal we expect, what was  mentioned the basic tariff increases to absorb and to assure the conversion to zero towards the end of the decade.  That's an important element.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Another important element on the right side of the slide is that we have around a €1.6 billion deficit, the one that  what created in 2011, 2012 and 2013 that are clearly available for securitization. And the interest rates associated  made credible that we could do something in the market. That's all in 2014 and we will be looking forward to work  on these fronts. We have also €1.5 billion to be created in 2014 to be collected onwards. So clearly, we have  visibility on the sustainable systems, converging to zero in 2020. And with the third proposal, we 're expecting  what is critical with tariff increases to absorb these deficits.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of wind power, clearly what we need to know exactly is the impact of the new remuneration scheme in  Spain. We actually need to know it by the end of November, we have visibility on those rules. In terms of the  Iberian regulated energy networks, we don't expect anything new in 2013. And then we can discuss if we want to  later on with some of these expected 2014 evolutions.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So resilience delivering on deleveraging, quality of our asset mix, diversified portfolio and risk management is  clearly what we have been doing. And we, even with this CapEx guidance adjustment, show that we are serious,  strongly committed to the deleveraging up to 2015 targets. So thank you and then let's go for the Q&A.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The EBITDA in Iberia, ex-wind, is up 2% year-on-year. Basically, why? Not only because of the strong hydro, but  mainly because of energy management; and I would like really to stress this, the tight cost control that more than  compensated the regulatory cuts. So, whenever you have a challenging sector, you do whatever you have to do.  And clearly, this lowering costs that are below the 2013 costs is an important measure.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, the big change was in Brazil. EBITDA is down 29%, including 8% impact of the real depreciation against the  euro. If you take, in any case, and I think it's important, the one-offs, let's say, of the capital gain in Jari, and the  DisCo tariff deviations, that are basically a transfer, a delay of EBITDA, the EBITDA went down by 13%, all of  these penalized by the drought. So, two years without rain in Brazil, and we have been flagging this since the  beginning of the year, can have a material impact and it's the case. In terms of net profit, we are basically flat to  close to €7 90 million, more than 1% decrease.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The net investments were €1.1 billion. The CapEx is focused on wind and hydro, wind in the U.S. and hydro in  Portugal. And important is that we have been – being successful in the assets rotation policy, where I believe we  were one of the first to give value to this, in terms of value creation with us and also cash funding of the growth of  the company. And we have €400 million proceeds that, as I mentioned, will be received towards the end of the  year and beginning of next year, both typically in the U.S. market and also in France.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, overall, I think that we performed very well and what depends on the company, namely energy management  and costs were able to compensate the very lousy year in Brazil because of what we  expect to be a non-recurrent  no-rain situation.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Thank you, António. Good morning to everybody. So, we'll start looking at the evolution of the EDP's generation  mix in the period. As you can see on page four, we continue see an increasing in the weight of hydro and wind in  the generation mix of EDP, which is now 7 0%. For this, we had a positive contribution from the commissioning of  a new wind capacity in Romania, in Poland, in Italy and in Canada. In terms of shutdowns, EDP closed all the  thermal capacity in Portugal, which at the end leaves our total installed capacity to remain flat.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Power production went up 3%, supported by rainy weather in Iberia, particularly in the first half of this year; and  also, additional production from the new wind farms that were commissioned in the period.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EBITDA decreased by 3%, going down by 1% if we exclude the ForEx impact. ForEx impact mostly related with  the 10% depreciation of the Brazilian real against the euro. This is – in terms of breakdown, Iberian activity's,  excluding wind, showing a resilient performance. EBITDA contribution from Brazil was materially affected by the  drought situation in the country, while the EBITDA at EDP Renováveis results from the already referred new  remuneration scheme in Spain and also the very low power prices at the beginning of this year in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to slide six, now talking about efficiency, we can see that our operating co sts went down 2%. In Iberia, our  OpEx fell by 1%, resulting from the ongoing implementation of our corporate -wide efficiency program, OpEx III  and also a positive impact from head count reductions.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: At level of EDP Renewables, our operating costs were flat, excluding ForEx, which is a good result considering the  4% capacity increase. In Brazil, operating costs in local currency rose 3%, which is less than half of the 6.1%  inflation in the period.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to slide seven on our net investments, they amounted to €1.1 billion in the period, focused on the  completion of our five new hydro plants under construction in Portugal and also on the construction of 700 new  megawatts of wind capacity, which we are now building mostly in the United States and also in Brazi l. And all  capacity is already contracted to sell energy through long-term contracts.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Regarding regulatory receivables owed to EDP, they decreased almost €100 million this year, with the decline in  Portugal, benefiting from the €1 billion of securitizations made all in the first half of the year, under very good  market conditions. In Spain, we benefit also from a decline following the implementation of several regulatory  changes in this country; while in Brazil, regulatory receivables rose by more than €100 million, given the extra  costs which our distributors, Bandeirante and Escelsa, are supporting with [ph] extensive (12:33) thermal  generation and which are not being fully covered by the contributions made by sectorial funds.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EDP's net debt stood at €17.5 billion, with our investments and operations being fully funded in local currency to  mitigate ForEx risk. The 19% weight of U.S. dollar-denominated debt, which funds our U.S. wind power  operations, was one of the major issues impacting the net debt evolution in this quarter, as you can see in the next  slide.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Below this 3% decline of EBITDA, we can see that depreciations and provisions fell by 5%, benefiting from the  extension of useful life of some of our thermal plants in Iberia. Net financial costs which includes  also results from  associates, decreased 15% on a lower average net debt, also better equity results from Pecém coal plant in Brazil  with recovery of some penalties paid in the past.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We had less profits attributable to minorities on lower profits at the level of EDP Brasil and EDP Renewables. And  overall, these items together, also with the Extraordinary Energy Tax, which is in place in Portugal since in 2014,  lead to 1% decline of our net profit to €786 million.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving now to the analysis of the performance of our business areas and starting in slide 18 with the market  environment for electricity in Iberia in the period. We can see that hydro and wind production levels in Portugal  and Spain were clearly above the historical average in the first nine months of 2014, and also in the same period of  last year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of demand, the electricity demand in the first nine months of the year went down 0.9% in Iberia as a  whole. As we can see on the right-side picture, we can see that the summer was particularly bad in terms of  demand, essentially because of mild temperatures.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EDP's generation fleet in liberalized markets increased its production by 17%, with a good contribution from the  increase of hydro production, plus 46%, following the transfer of some three hydro plants that were previously  contracted through PPAs until December of last year and which are now in the liberalized market, and also the  referred rainy weather, namely in the first half of the year. Regarding thermal load factors, there were no material  changes versus last year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EBITDA of EDP's liberalized activities in Iberian market rose 40%, supported by the referred transfer of the three  hydro plants from PPAs to free market. We had also the positive contribution from the 21% decline in average  generation costs on higher hydro production and also the adequate risk management in energy markets, namely  based on our long position in clients, which helped our results.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving on slide 23 to our regulated energy networks in Iberia. In terms of EBITDA performance, it has some one - off impacts related with the Collective Labor Agreement in Portugal. Excluding this, our adjusted EBITDA went  up 1% in the period, driven by a 2% increase of EBITDA from electricity distribution in Portugal, which was  supported on a very good performance in terms of operating costs, which fell 7% in the period, more than  compensating the 30 basis points decline in terms of the rate of return in the activity of distribution.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of the EBITDA of EDP Renewables, it decreased 6%, penalized by the 19% decline of EBITDA in Iberia  and, more precisely, the 33% decline of EBITDA in Spain, with revenues in Spain being strongly penalized not  only by the new remuneration methodology, but also the extremely-low pool prices, particularly during the first  half of the year. This negative impact was not fully compensated by the 4% capacity increase of EDP Renewables  and also the 4% increase of average selling price in the United States.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In Brazil, in third quarter 2014, our operations were impacted by an adverse market environment, in which hydro  plants under PPAs had to buy around 15% of their contracted volumes in the spot market, given the low hydro  resources.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Adjusted for these items, EDP Brasil EBITDA went down 13%, penalized essentially by around R$180 million  realized losses with low GSF in generation, resulting from the drought.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of demand, the electricity demand, the regulator forecast a 0.5% increase for this year and 0.8% increase  for next year. And let's remember that for each 1% change on demand, it implies only more or less €2 million on  EBITDA.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, elasticity here is quite small. But clearly, this small increase on energy demand estimations follow the  anticipation of higher growth in Portugal, this is at Portuguese GDP, in any case, below the growth of GDP.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We could see an increase in the first half of the year, typically because of the seasonal effect of rain and wind, but  then lowering in the second half, and then, clearly, going to the path of converging to zero by 2020, except for the  tail of the first bond issued in 2009.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At this stage, it's important to stress that, as I stated at the beginning, the tariff increase proposal of 3.3% for  normal low-voltage clients, so I think it's important. So, clearly, [ph] we're expecting (26:44) the 2% above  inflation and we see this as an important condition for the stability of the system.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And what concerns the outlook? Let's talk about 2014, and when we talk about 2014 year-end, as it was the case  until now, it depends very much on Brazil. We have today in the reservoirs level almost at the same level as in  2001. We have been following rain daily, but it has been raining especially  in Minas Gerais, where it is important  in the last days. That's good news.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But as we have seen, this has implied that the October load factor was 91%, we expect to be, on average, 90% for  the last quarter. We expect the PLD to be kept at the high level o f €770 – R$770 per megawatt hour. It's not euros  as it's mentioned here, so if it would be, we would have a problem.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We'll also have the introduction of tariff flags starting January next year. So, it's important because it gives  immediate reaction with variable tariffs to high-energy costs. This is very important instead of delaying these on  an annual basis.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, what can I say? Resilient business model in a challenging environment, with sound performance, delivering on  what should be delivered in terms of efficiency and energy management. And we have been – clearly being on  time and on cost, and even anticipating some relevant projects like the Jari in Brazil, keeping the low -risk profile,  keeping the assets rotation policy, the deals with CTG that were estimated in Brazil, lower regulatory receivables,  keeping the strong financial liquidity. So, overall, we see with a slight improvement of net profit, we keep the  guidance with slight improvement for net profit.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: For 2015, we maintain our vision of a year that is better than 2014, but a lot of it will depend, of course, in the next  [ph] few (33:04) months in Brazil because this can have a material impact, with more or less rain in Brazil already,  have an impact in 2015. But for now, we don't have any reason to change our vision for 2015.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And this growth is supported basically by what? By new capacity commissioned by EDPR, so in renewables, a  recovery of EDP Brasil, and we will see this very strong in the third quarter of 2015. And, of course, as is natural,  some dilution of the weak hydro production and low energy management results that, of course, were very  important in the first half of this year. In any case, this was partially compensation by better thermal production  in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And I will also at this stage want to highlight the following, costs. We have a 3% year-on-year reduction in Iberia.  We have a 2% increase in Brazil ex-Pecém, yes, I think it's also a very strong figure considering the inflation in  that country. And, of course, I would also like to highlight the reduction by 4% on the OpEx per megawatt in  renewables. So it shows how committed we are in putting more efficiency always, being already the reference I  believe at the Iberian level and also in renewables.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second, our installed capacity rose by 8%, we're talking about almost 2 gigawatts of capacity. The current assets  under construction, basically wind and hydro, should imply the commissioning of 2 gigawatts in the next 12  months and, of course, this contributes to reinforce our portfolio with competitive assets and stable returns due to  the nature of those assets.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In what concerns Portugal, I see that in the first nine months the electricity system created a surplus. I think that  we have seen through the two last quarters has shown this. So, once again, it proves what we have been stating for  a long time is that the sustainability of the system and that we are at the peak and we will see a reduction from  2016 onwards into the target of around 500 in 2020.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I think also very important at this stage is that on October 15, as every year, as the regulator proposed tariffs for  2016 and this includes a 2.5% average tariff increases and €400 million decline in the electricity system. So we are  expecting basically the conditions for the sustainability, namely, what's concerns tariff increases and it's already  recognized this decrease on the deficit, I think it's important. So the proposal is fully in line with the commitments  to reduce the system debt, it has been consistent and it's going for already more than three years.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the next slide what we see, I think it's important looking into the future in terms of prospects. We need to  consider what? We expect that four hydro plants conclude or are close to conclusions in Portugal, by the way,  essentially pump and storage, to have a positive contribution mostly for the next summer onwards.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, typically, I think we should highlight this, hydro is – always take time, but when they are there, they are  important. At the same time, we have already achieved a significant level of hedging in the liberalized generation,  which, of course, reduces significantly our exposure to spot prices in 2016.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In renewable, we should benefit from the gradual delivery of new capacity that was already committed. And even  in a small part of the business with exposure to power prices, we have implemented a sound hedging policy.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of net reduction, a typical question, we have a positive trend supported by the measures that we have  been structurally taking. A material reduction in CapEx following the completion of the four hydro plants in  Portugal, a consistent decline in regulatory receivables in Portugal and, of course, further steps in the execution of  the partnership with CTG that we can talk in detail later on.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And, by the way, in the this period just to, I think as you can see here, we have commissioned 11 gigawatts with  PPAs or feed-in tariffs, so clearly reducing future exposure to market volatility.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of slide five, this goes beyond 2015 with a stronger impact on financials from the close to 2 gigawatts of  capacity to be added by 2015, we are talking about more or less 500 megawatts of hydro in Portugal, 1.1 megawatts  in renewables, more or less half new and of course half of ENEOP consolidation and of course the 360 megawatts  of Pecém. And all this with a low risk approach, long-term contracted.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of slide six, I think that sometimes we don't announce this enough. Our intensive investment program in  renewables in the past should allow us to increase the average residual life of the generation portfolio. I think it's a  relevant item when we discuss about Europe and the European sector.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: By 2017 we should have reached a capacity generation portfolio with more than 75% of our capacity being wind  and hydro, just 10% weight of coal in compliance with DeNOx and immaterial exposure to nuclear plants.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So I would like to talk about – before passing to Miguel – I think it's an important reminder. I think we have a  distinctive equity story. The balance between growth and deleveraging, the controlled risk, the attractive returns  and basically the visibility on profitable growth driven by renewables, we know where we are growing, our most  earmarked projects.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Thank you. We can move now to slide nine. As it was already referred, our nine months 2015 results were  penalized by weak hydro and wind volumes in our key markets versus a very strong nine months 2014.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Our hydro and wind production went down 16% in the period resulting from hydro volumes in Brazil ramping  down 18%, hydro volumes in Iberia ramping down 38% and the reduction of wind and solar volumes on a pro  forma basis by 4% when excluding the generation output from new capacity even though hydro and wind has  represented 59% of EDP's generation mix in the first nine months 2015.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Our EBITDA went up 10% year-on-year impacted by some one-offs, which when excluded imply a 5% growth of  adjusted EBITDA. This 5% growth is explained by a 16% growth of adjusted EBITDA at the level of EDP  renewables which reflects the recovery of prices, the new capacity, but also some positive ForEx as we'll see later.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EDP Brasil also improved adjusted EBITDA by 49% as a result of negative tariffs deviations in distribution in the  previous nine months. Also the consolidation of Pecém since May, but still losses with hydro deficit both in the  nine months of 2014 and 2015, and finally, of course, the negative ForEx from the Brazilian devaluation.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In Iberia, our regulated networks showed a 1% year-on-year increase in adjusted EBITDA, while generation and  supply EBITDA went down by 13% penalized by weak hydro volumes and energy management results versus very  strong in the first nine months of 2014.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of overview of Iberian market in the first nine months of 2015, we can see that electricity demand went  up 2.3%, on a mix between a recovery of the economy and some favorable weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Hydro production went down 35% with the hydro coefficient in Spain at 0.70 versus 1.20 in the first nine months  2014 what implied that the coal and gas production had to increase in a combined way by 30% in order to face this  increase in demand and lower hydro production, which supported also an improvement in terms of pool price,  plus 27%, to €50 per megawatt hour, with gas extending its role as marginal technology in the Iberian market.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Regarding EDP in this market context, our liberalized generation portfolio showed a 19% increase in terms of  production, with coal and gas production compensating the decline in hydro volumes.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Note that in terms of our PPA/CMEC generation, the deviation was in the first nine months of 2015 close to zero  in coal, while in hydro it amounted it €80 million, mostly due to hydro volumes 32% below average.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of our liberalized activities in Iberia and in terms of our market positioning, if you look to the left years,  we can see that EDP's market position is characterized by a significant weight of hydro in its generation mix. Also  a long position in sales to final clients versus our own production and this tends to imply low energy management  gains in dry years as it happened in this first nine months of 2015.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: As a result, as we can see in next page, adjusted EBITDA in generation and supply in Iberia showed a 13% decline  year-on-year, with EBITDA from liberalized activities going down by 23% penalized by higher average generation  costs on lower hydro volumes also significantly less gains on energy management even almost non-existent in the  first nine months of 2015 and also higher generation taxes on higher production volumes.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to regulated energy networks, we can see that both EBITDA and adjusted EBITDA go down by 1% year- on-year. Of course, the adjusted EBITDA excludes the capital gain on the disposal of Gas Murcia, an €89 million  gain, and this 1% decline on the adjusted EBITDA reflects essentially the lower return on RoRAB in Portugal on  lower Portuguese government bond yield, and also the sale of Gas Murcia which, both impacts were partially  compensated by higher efficiency achieved at our subsidiaries.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to EDP renewable, we can see that EBITDA of EDPR went up 22% or 16% when adjusted for one-offs  increasing in North America by 13% in euro terms including a strong positive impact from the dollar, €49 million,  but also some negative one-offs by the amount of €41 million. Excluding these one-offs EBITDA in dollars rose by  6% supported by a 2% increase in average selling price and a 4% growth in terms of production.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to Brazil, we can see that there was a clear improvement in terms of the environment of the Brazilian  electricity system in the third quarter 2015, namely, through a significant decline in terms of GSF losses. As we  can see, EDP Brasil GSF losses net of hedging went down to BRL24 million in the third quarter significantly  supported by a decline in terms of the spot price PLD and also an improvement in terms of GSF meaning that our  hydro plants were able to produce to levels closer from the contracted levels.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Also the hydro reservoirs are now more than 10% above what they were last year by the same period, opening a  good and a more optimistic scenario for the next month although we know that we are starting the rainy season  over the next couple of months.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: When we look to EDP Brasil's adjusted EBITDA we can see that in distribution adjusted EBITDA goes up 9%  supported by tariff increases while in generation adjusted EBITDA goes up by 44% impacted by Pecém  consolidation since May, plus BRL244 million, the negative – including the negative impact from GSF losses,  losses of €314 million in the first nine months of 2015 and losses for BRL212 million in the first nine months of  2014. But also in this year some favorable seasonal allocation of electricity sales volumes given the recent decline  on PLD.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EDP Renewables, we see a 6% increase of costs in terms of local currencies, but if you consider the 8% increase in  average installed capacity, we see that adjusted OpEx per megawatt recorded a 4% decline year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Overall, we continue to implement the OPEX III efficiency program, which achieved in the first nine months of  2015 €132 million of accumulated cost savings or plus €22 million versus the same period last year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to net investments. Our focus continue on the long-term contracted wind, hydro and also on regulated  networks. So as we can see, expansion investments showed an increase focusing on wind with PPAs and feed-in,  mostly at the level of EDPR U.S. operations.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: While in Portugal we continue to focus on concluding our pump and storage capacity under construction where  we have achieved a completion rate of 91% for the four projects which are now in the final stage of completion.  And in terms of maintenance investments it amounted to €360 million mostly allocated to regulated energy  networks in Portugal, Spain and Brazil.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to the recent evolution in terms of the Portuguese electric system, we can see that there was a slight tariff  surplus, again in the third quarter 2015 reinforcing the trend in the previous quarters. So this tariff surplus for the  first nine months of the year is now €55 million supported by demand recovery, normalized wind volumes and  stable pool price.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: More than that, the regulator's proposal for 2016 tariffs assumes a 2.5% increase in average tariff for low voltage  and also a €0.4 billion decline in terms of electricity system debt for 2016 fully in line with previous expectations.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We see also a slight increase in Spain related with the tariff deficit in the gas system. And in Brazil it remains flat  in euro terms, but it increased by BRL228 million due to higher energy costs.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We are booking the full annual amount of the extraordinary energy tax in Portugal of €61 million in both years.  And in terms of non-controlling interests you see an increase which is essentially related with higher allocation of  net profits to EDP Brasil minorities following the gain on the Pecém acquisition. Overall, we see a 4% decline on  net debt and an 18% decline in adjusted net profit during the period.

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding investment and disposal. We maintain our conservative approach. We continue executing the  investment program previously announced, focused on wind power and the PPA generation.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Over the last years, we have persistently developed a diversified number of potential wind farm projects in this  market. And we are now in the position of reaping the fruits of their consistent work, taking advantage from the  clear visibility of the PTC's framework until 2020.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Slide six, let's go for our growth investments. We have strong visibility on our growth CapEx up to 2018. With our  new wind and hydro projects in the constructions or already contracted, representing a 13% increase on our  electricity generation capacity until 201, through the commissioning of additional 3.7 gigawatts.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding Hydro Portugal, we are now finishing the two last remaining plants under construction. texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding disposals, following the recent completion of the sale of 49% stakes in wind farms in Poland and Italy  to CTG, we have already executed 60% of the planned amount of EDPR asset rotation and the CTG deals from  2016 up to 2020. texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to slide seven, supply activity. Here I would like to highlight the continuous strengthening of our energy  supply platform namely in the retail segments. texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moreover, after they go live in 2015, [ph] and (17:32) significant investment that we made in CRM system, we  have reached significant improvements on customer satisfaction resulting in 27% reduction in the number of  clients per customer. We consider that an  integrated view of energy supply and electricity generation is critical strategy in order to reduce exposure to  volatility in wholesale energy markets and to preserve our low risk business profile.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding wholesale prices, we saw recently significant increases, that's more evident in the short-term. For  reasons not only Iberia, but also for our neighbor friends. texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: As you will see, renewables okay. Brazil okay. And, of course, this reduction is explained by the generation and  supplies we will see. texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, let's see the – on slide 3, the impact of the abnormally low hydro resources in Iberia in 2017. As you can see,  hydro production fell by 6 terawatt hours in the first nine months of 2017 following the hydro production 43%  below average versus last year's 66% above average, when you compare the first nine months.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And, as I already mentioned, prospects for the first quarter are not bright. October was the driest month in the last  20 years, with hydro falling 7% below historical average, and by the end of the month, there was still a  generalized drought situation in most of the Iberian Peninsula, meaning also that the hydro reservoir at an  abnormally low level for this time of the year, better in Portugal and in Spain, but in any case lower than average.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Slide 4. I think, it's important to talk about asset allocation strategy. Over 2017, we have continued to readjust our  asset mix through significant investments in renewable assets with long-term contracts mostly in the U.S., Brazil  and Mexico, with significant disposal concentrated were in the Iberian market and namely the disposal of gas  distribution and a minority stake in wind farms in Portugal in line with our long-term strategy regarding the trend in  a new geographical mix. So, we have been moving, of course, geographies. Note the cash-in of €500 million of  the sale of gas distribution in Portugal occurred only in October. So, I think, if – we need to note this.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to slide 6, electricity distribution in Portugal: new regulatory period. On October 15, the Portugal electricity  sector regulator has published its proposal for electricity distribution and [indiscernible] (09:55) supply regulators  revenues for 2018, with a total amount of €1.076 billion. This means first that we have now a good visibility on the  regulatory framework for the 2018-2020 period, during which we will be entitled with a return on regulated assets  of around 5.85%, which is linked to the evolution of the 10 years Portuguese bond yields.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: The main drivers for this new way of efficiency efforts are: first, the extension of the Zero Base Budgeting to  several of our major divisions, following the success cases in EDP Brasil and the strong case also in generation in  Portugal, so we will extend this to all the other business units; second, further improvement on O&M  management, mainly on generation plants in Portugal, moving from an availability-focused to a market flexibility- focused, for obvious reasons, and continue the improvements at EDPR that were strongly proved already in the  last two years; third, a strong focus on digitalization and automation; fourth, finally a reinforcement in terms of staff  restructuring program.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Slide 9, update on asset allocation for 2018-2020. Moving forward, EDP has the competitive advantage versus  other European utilities of having a strong visibility in terms of investment opportunities at attractive returns,  focusing two main areas: renewable. We have PPAs and feed-in-tariff assured by the amount of [ph] 0.8-gigawatt  (15:25) for 2018. Regarding the 2019-2020 period, EDPR has already secured PPAs and feed-in-tariff for an  average of 200 megawatts per year, and we are in an advanced stage to deliver the 2020 target present in our  business plan, to which we count on the positive prospect for our strong renewables development in the different  platforms that we have.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Second, on the second front, in Brazil, we will build five electricity transmission lines, which should represent BRL  3.1 billion on investment, more or less €800 million, of which 95% will be until – between 2019 and 2021. And I'd  like just to mention that, this investment will have an expected EBITDA contribution by 2021, close to the EBITDA  lost with the disposal of Naturgas, although representing a much lower investment. It's almost three times less  relating to the EBITDA that we will be receiving.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Slide 10, update on 2017 guidance following the harsh second half market conditions. We estimate that this  Iberian electricity market, namely in terms of much lower than average hydro volume, combined with very high  power price for the second half of the year, should represent negative impact in the range of €70 million to €80  million in the second half – sorry, the second – two quarters in the last quarter of 2017.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: I'd like to highlight also that our stable dividend policy with the dividend as far as you know is not impacted at all  by any of these adjustments, due to the weather-related effects in 2017. This is clearly a firm commitment.  Concluding, we plan to provide you with a strategy update during the second quarter of the 2018, which will  provide visibility on our financial targets already post-2020.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thank you. Starting on page 12 with an overview of Iberian market in the first nine months of the year, we can see  that it was marked by a 56% reduction in terms of hydro production, which was compensated by a 47% increase  in terms of coal and gas production, which together with increase of fuel costs lead to an increase in terms of  average pool price of plus 48% year-on-year to €50 per megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In this environment, as we can see in page 13, our Generation & Supply division in Iberia saw a 9% reduction in  production, following a 59% reduction in terms of hydro production, which together with the increase in terms of  fuel costs and also some regulatory costs implied an increase in terms of average production cost by 95% to €33  per megawatt hour. Combine this with the increase of average selling price to customers, which was much lower,  so 2% year-on-year, this resulted in a 39% decline in terms of EBITDA to €518 million.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to Regulated Energy Networks in Iberia, [indiscernible] (20:50) of course for disposals, gas distribution in  Spain closed the sale on July 27th, and more recently, the disposal of gas distribution in Portugal sold on October  4th. So, on a pro forma basis, we can see that the electricity distribution in Portugal and Spain EBITDA went  down by 1% year-on-year, negatively impacted essentially by adjustments from previous years, while the OpEx,  just for the energy networks, showed a very positive performance going down by 1% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to EDP Renováveis, which represented 37% of our EBITDA in the period, we can see that the installed  capacity has increased by 10%, mostly due to U.S., Mexico and a little bit of Brazil, with justifying the 10%  increase in terms of production. In terms of EBITDA, as we can see in page 16, EDPR EBITDA increased by 17%  overall, supported by EBITDA growth in North America, so namely U.S. and Mexico, Brazil and also the 1st farm  down in our Moray wind offshore project in UK.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: At the level of EDP Brasil, we can seen in Page 17 that recurring EBITDA in local currency was slightly up by 1%,  benefiting from an integrated hedging strategy for the whole business portfolio. This has mitigated the negative  impact from weak hydro conditions, particularly in the third quarter of 2017 with hydro reservoirs at 19%, GSF of  62%, and PLD at BRL 436 per megawatt hour.
