texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thank you, Miguel, and good morning, everybody. Thank you very much for participating in this results  conference call. So, over this first nine months of 2019, EDP has basically continued to execute its strategy of  growth in renewables in Brazil, also implementation of efficiency improvement measures and preserving the low  risk profile of our business.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of renewable resources, hydro production, and we won't be detailing this, showed a significant recovery.  But on the other hand, the relevant wind resource through our wind farms stood at six years record low in the third  quarter and so we continue to see decline in revenues per megawatt as expected in renewables. So, until now,  good water and bad [indiscernible] (00:03:23) in the sense that the wind was not blowing.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, our operations in Brazil showed a strong performance, benefited from significant operational  improvements both in distribution and generation, and I stress this from the successful low risk integrated  approach of our hedging strategy in energy markets. All in all, our recurring net profit rose 2% to €570 million,  positively impacted by the 14% decline of interest costs, following the decline in cost of debt by 40 basis points to  3.7%. Note, at this level that the reported net profit is significantly penalized in this period by the €285 million one- off provision that we have decided to do now due to an alleged past overcompensation in the contractual CMEC's  revenues at some of our generation assets in Portugal.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, our net debt stood at €14.5 billion in September 2018, 4% lower than September last year, reflecting the  7% growth of our recurring organic free cash flow to €1 billion, the payment of €700 million annual dividend to  shareholders in last May and the acceleration of the net expansion CapEx to €1 billion, from which more than  90% was allocated through renewables with long-term contracts.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, in more detail, on the slide 3, in terms of the renewables what we see. We saw a gradual improvement of  hydro resource in Iberia since the beginning of the year and after two very dry months of January and February,  hydro production for the first nine months managed to improve to 20% above historical average. This compares to  a very dry period last year, which justifies 87% increase year-on-year of the hydro production. On the other hand,  as I've mentioned, over the first nine months this year, wind resources evolved in the opposite direction reaching  the bottom in the third quarter or six years record low with wind resources being 11% below the long-term  average.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So moving to Brazil, in Brazil, EBITDA in local currency grew 19%, propelled by our low risk hedging strategy on  hydro volume and energy prices. Good results from our program from deduction of commercial losses, always  important in Brazil in distribution; and the maintenance of high availability levels in generation, which is particularly  important in the current high power price environment. So it has more value to be there when you are needed.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In renewables, EBITDA excluding forex impact, went down 9% year-on-year, reflecting not only wind resources  4% below long-term average in accumulated period of the first nine months, but also the decline in the average  revenue of per megawatt hour, a trend, as you know, associated to the increasing competitiveness of renewables  project more recently commissioned and also the expiration of PTCs for wind farms in the U.S. that have reached  the end of the 10-year period and as it was already totally expected and shared with you.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, recurring EBITDA in Iberia fell slight by 1% as the positive impact from the 83% increase of hydro  production was fully offset by the €53 million increase of taxes in generation also known and the €116 million  decline of regulated revenues in distribution also already known.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Strong performance on operating costs on the slide 5. I'd like to stress this. Moving here what we see. Our  operating costs excluding forex impact show the 1% nominal growth in the period in which our generation  capacity grew by 3% and the number of customers connected to our distribution grid rose by 1%. Region-by- region, in Iberia, OpEx fell by 2% in nominal terms and almost 3% in real terms, particularly remarkable  considering 1% increase both in the average installed capacity and the number of energy supply customers.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In renewables, core OpEx per megawatt excluding forex and one-offs rose 3% year-on-year, reflecting essentially  the build-up of our O&M internalization strategy and ongoing investment that we see as strategic and that we are  sure that will allow us to achieve very significant efficiency improvements in the near future. So, we're explaining  the self-performance strategy and the important medium term of this [ph] choice (00:09:33).

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: On slide 6, overall, our recurring net profit rose 2% to, as I mentioned, to €570 million, benefiting from lower  financial cost and the natural dilution of at bottom levels of forex impact given our low risk approach of funding  operations in local currency. Recurring net profit increased by 4% in Iberia as the hydro recovery and OpEx  nominal reduction was not totally offset by the adverse regulatory change I already mentioned in Portugal.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to the guidance on slide 7, we maintain our guidance for EBITDA in the region of €3.4 billion, which  reflects what? First, the seasonal improvement of renewable resources in the first quarter of the year, the recent  recovery of the Brazilian real and also the positive impact from some shutdowns of stake at some of our  renewable assets, in line with the capital optimization and value crystallization strategy that in recent years has  become a recurrent part of our renewables activity.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Now, I would like to talk about each of the business basically. On slide 8, what we see, a strong improvements of  fundamentals in Iberia. And I would like to highlight three key issues. One, the first one is energy prices over the  last 12 months. We saw strong and steady recovery also because of CO2, while we have more than doubled in  this period, this together with the recovery of thermal costs such as gas and coal has contributed to an increase of  electricity price in Iberia for 2019 by more than €14/megawatt-hour. So, we are talking about a 30% increase. This  is obviously positive news for the long-term performance of our renewable portfolio also in Iberia, where we have  a combined annual production of hydro and wind about 20 terawatts-hour.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Second, we have also seen positive developments regarding the demand recovery, with the cumulative electricity  consumption growing by almost 5% in Iberia over the last four years. Now that is – that in the first nine months of  2018, growth demand in Portugal was above 3% year-on-year. On top of that, the recent announcement of  Spanish government regarding reduction of marginal taxes in generation is a positive signal to reduce the fiscal  burden in the system with positive impact for companies and consumers.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And finally, I would like to highlight the recent improvement of visibility regarding the next regulatory period in  Spain for the allowed returns to electricity networks and renewable energy as recently published by CNMC.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Brazil, regarding the execution of our long-term strategy of low risk and profitable growth, let me update on the  evolution of our operations in Brazil. First, we have implemented an integrated hedging in energy market through  the utilization of several instruments, such as the GSF insurance option [indiscernible] (00:14:30) contracted  some residual generation volumes by closing financial position in [indiscernible] (00:14:36) energy markets.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And last but not least, by the optimization of the positions in energy markets by our generation assets and by our  supply division. This strategy allows us to keep a low exposure to volatility in hydro volumes, GSF and the energy  prices [ph] PLD (00:14:53) and even to beat significantly these adverse factors through the optimization of our  integrated market position as it was the case in the first nine months.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to renewables. We continue to be focused on the execution of our organic growth, securing long-term  contracts and EDP Renewables has currently secured 3.4 gigas of PPAs and feed-in-tariffs for new wind and  solar capacity to be commissioned over the next year.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: This year, we expect to install a total of by 0.9 gigas, of which 0.2 gigas were commissioned in the first nine  months of the year and we are currently 900 megawatts under construction, of which 700 megawatts to be  commissioned in the last quarter and 200 megawatts to start operations at the beginning of 2019. For 2019 and  2020, we have secured long-term contracts for 1.7 gigas of new capacity, of which almost 60% in U.S. taking  advantage of the last couple of years in which the new wind farms in U.S. will be entitled to 100% of the PTC's  incentives for the next 10 years.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moreover, we have already secured long-term contracts for 1 giga of renewable capacity to be commissioned  post 2020 being relevant and I would like to stress this that solar projects represents already 40% of these  contracts of new capacity, reflecting our strategy positioning in the increasing competitive renewables technology.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding offshore winds, the Moray East project in UK in which EDPR has almost a 57% stake will be equipped  with 9.5 megawatt (sic) [950 megawatt] (00:18:30) Vestas turbines and is now reaching the final investment  decision stage, in line with the schedule to reach full commissioning in 2022.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In France, the development of our two projects, Noirmoutier & Le Tréport, with a total capacity of 992 megawatts,  in which EDPR has a 43% stake, is advancing well with the granting of several required permits and we continue  to track – in track to reach a final investment decision by 2020 with full commissioning expected to occur between  2023 and 2024.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So if we move to slide 13 what we can see is that our focus on renewable energy has continued in this period with  the renewables installed capacity increasing by 3%, which means that the renewable energy in total now weighs  74% of EDP's installed capacity and two-thirds of the generation mix. So already very skewed to renewable  energy. In line with this, the renewable production increased 25% in the nine months of 2018, also benefiting from  the strong recovery of hydro resources in Iberia over the last year, so again reinforcing this idea of very much a  CO2 free portfolio.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: If we move to the next slide, talking about EDP Renewables, so the average capacity has increased 6%, the  EBITDA of EDP Renewables decreased 12% to €869 million, including a negative forex impact of 3%. Excluding  the forex, EDPR EBITDA would have decreased by 9% year-on-year as a result of several different variables,  which I'll just talk about. On one hand, as I mentioned, the installed capacity rose 6%. However, this increase of  the portfolio was offset by much weaker wind resource in the period, as António mentioned just a little earlier. It  was 4% below the P50 scenario and it hit the six-year low, as was mentioned.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving on to slide 15, so here talking about generation supply in Iberia. So excluding the 2017 share of lower  CMEC final adjustment, the EBITDA increased by 24% to €640 million, boosted by the strong recovery of the  hydro resources since March 2018. So, as a result, the hydro production has increased by 87% to 11.1 terawatt- hours in the first nine months and accounted for 42% of EDP's own production. This prompted a 20% decrease in  the average sourcing cost to €26 per megawatt-hour, which can also be seen here.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Slide 16, EDP Brazil EBITDA in local currency reached to BRL 1.952 million, that's a 19% increase, mostly fueled  by the efficiency improvements, but also the successful hedging strategy in energy markets. In terms of  efficiencies, the trajectory of decreasing non-technical losses in this most recent quarter was in our DisCos. Our  Pecém coal plants also had a very strong performance in these nine months as we were able to manage  availability levels well above the contractual benchmarks and that translate into an availability premium of BRL 98  million in the period. So this compared to penalty of BRL 13 million in the nine months of 2017.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, worth noting that these good results came mostly from the integrated energy management strategy, which  the net amount of BRL 186 million in the nine months and represent an increase of BRL 135 million.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So moving on to slide 17, talking about regulated networks. So excluding the gas distribution networks, which  were sold last year, the EBITDA from the regulated networks in Iberia fell 19% year-on-year to €477 million. So  this decrease reflects mainly the performance in Portugal that represents 77% of the EBITDA on this segment.  So, the OpEx in Portugal had a very good performance. It's basically dropped by 4% year-on-year despite the 4%  growth in volumes distributed. So I think here a very strong focus on cost reduction, OpEx efficiency and that's  definitely something we will maintain going forward. However, this still was not enough to compensate for the  impact of the regulatory review in Portugal, which mostly justified a 12% decrease in regulated revenues.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, regarding this expansion activity, just note that it's mostly dedicated to construction of new wind capacity [ph]  and also (00:27:23) transmission in Brazil. It also includes investment in Celesc, the sale of 20% stake of the  Moray offshore wind farm in Scotland and also the sale of Costa Rica, which is a small hydro plant in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So the net debt results were positively impacted by the reduction in regulatory receivables during this period of  approximately €200 million, prompted by the sale of the tariff deficits and also just a general good performance of  the electricity system debt. So, it had approximately $500 million of surplus in the period. As a result, the stock of  debt in electricity system reached €4.2 billion in September 2018 benefiting from this increase in demand in  Portugal and also past cost cuts.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So moving on to liquidity on slide 19. Liquidity and debt maturity profile, here essentially the key issues are total  available liquidity is around €6.3 billion as of September, including €1 billion of cash and equivalents and €5.3  billion of available credit lines. So, this covers our refinancing needs beyond 2020, so relatively prudent. I would  like to highlight that on top of the €750 million bond issue that we did back in June had a yield of 1.67%. We also  did the securitization of the €900 million of electricity tariff deficits in Portugal. But then, I guess, the news from  this quarter is really the EDP issued its first ever green bonds €600 million, seven-year maturity and a yield of  1.96% and which I think it was very well received by the market.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Secondly, a positive impact of €52 million from results of forex and derivatives that were essentially tied to the  evolution of the dollar against the euro. Finally, also included in the financial results is the €15 million gain on the  sale of 20% stake in the UK wind offshore project, which is part of our recurring sell-down strategy and we also  had the negative [ph] sign of (00:30:06) €15 million from bad will related with the acquisition of Celesc.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving on just onto the final slide, so slide 21. Reported net profit amounted to €297 million in the nine month of  2018. Obviously, this significant year-on-year decline was very influenced by the one-off impact, and António  mentioned that earlier in the call. So, essentially, we had €558 million from the sale of the gas distribution in Spain  last year, which was booked in the third quarter, which obviously was a one-off. In this quarter, we decided to take  €285 million provision against the alleged overcompensation on the contractual CMEC revenues of some of our  generation plants in Portugal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Stilwell de Andrade
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Excluding the gas distribution in Iberia in the nine months of 2017 and these one-off impacts, net profit in the nine  months of 2018 increased to 2% to €570 million. So, as we've seen over the course of this presentation, it  essentially benefited from the strong improvement in financial results and associates, which increased by a total  of €156 million in the nine months. So, overall, this positive evolution of financial results together with the  underlying growth in Brazil and hydro recovery more than compensated the decline in EBITDA prompted by the  regulatory changes in Portugal [indiscernible] (00:31:36) wind resources and forex.

texts.text: We have already invested 2.2 in 3.2 gigawatts under construction by 12 2009, or by December, we  have already, we have under construction a huge park, a huge fleet this is important for our future.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So costs down, liquidity and it brings us to a stabilized debt.  It’s 14 billion, with the net debt over  EBITDA below four. If you account for the regulatory assets and if you exclude the payment of the  gas assets for, the Gas Natural assets, that were billed then on the 31st of December of last year.  So I think that we have committed, we were committed and we have delivered also in all these  fronts in terms of costs, liquidity and debt.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Brazil, also significant declines in terms of controllable operating costs as a result of efficiency  efforts, also with the contribution from the asset swap concluded in September of 2008.  And in  Renewables, a growth in line with expansion of the installed capacity. In terms of our corporate- wide efficiency program, OpEx, we have a target for 2012 of €160 million of annual cost savings.  We continue on track and in fact our target for 2009, which was €96 million, was beaten by €13  million, so we are above this target and continue moving to achieve the target of 160 million by  2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our reported EBITDA was down 2% year on year, essentially because of non-recurrent negative  impact from fuel procurement in 2009, with a negative impact of €44 million, which is fully hedged  and compensated at level of financial results in current, previous, or next quarters.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If we exclude this impact from EBITDA, adjusted EBITDA was up by 5% and this growth in EBITDA  is justified by the Desox investment in our Sines coal plant, which are also remunerated at the  return on assets of 8.5% – these Desox facilities were installed in 2008 and 2009; an increase in  terms of mini-hydro output, with a very strong growth in the fourth quarter 2009; and some increase  in installed capacity and also higher than contracted level of availability in our plants with  PPA/CMEC in Portugal, which had a positive impact.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going to slide nine in terms of the liberalized energy activities, which the weight in our EBITDA  increase to 19% in 2009, we can see that we showed a 60% growth of EBITDA this year.  This very  strong performance was justified by much a stronger decline in terms of average purchasing prices  in the pool and a strong decline also in average generation costs, compared with just a slight  decline in terms of average selling price.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In fact, we have reinforced ourselves to clients, so the bulk of our energy sold directly to clients and  given that we a have flexible generation fleet which can decide to work or not to work depending on  the opportunities in the pool market, we managed to benefit from this decline in the pool price  through increasing purchases in the pool.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In gas, also to note that our EBITDA in gas supply went up by 60%.  Here, also, we benefit from a  higher weight of residential segment than the Spanish average and this resulted in an improvement  in terms of unit margins in 2009 versus 2008, although with a downwards trend over the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of our power plants, our output went down by 11%.  This decline is a result of the  opportunities that we got in the pool price, which was in several hours cheaper than our generation  cost.  Nevertheless, I would like to highlight that our plants, our thermal plants, were much more  active in the restrictions market, ancillary markets, namely in the fourth quarter with the increased  volatility in terms of the system which is related with the increasing weight of wind in the electricity  system in Portugal and Spain.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also, of course, that we have this flexibility to reduce our output in coal and in gas and replace it by  purchasing in the pool  because we are in a terrible situation in terms of pressure from take or pay  in terms of gas contracts, which allow us to do these reductions in terms of our output.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Even with these declines, we continued to show load factors both in coal and in combined cycle  above the Spanish average.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In coal, we continue to benefit from the burn of blast-furnace gases, so we have an integration with  a fuel plant in our Aboño coal plant, which of course give us much lower generation cost.  And in  combined cycle that we have a strong presence in Portugal.  We benefit from a better market  environment in terms of reserve margin in Portugal than in Spain.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to regulated energy networks, the reported EBITDA was down 9%.  Here essentially, as we  referred before, we have several positive, one-off items in 2008. If we exclude these one-offs,  adjusted EBITDA in fact went up by 10% year on year.  The explanation is on a 5% increase in  terms of regulated revenues, controllable operating costs going slightly down by 0.2%, and also in  terms of human resources restructuring cost.  They are lower in 2009 than in 2008, so 13 million in  2009 versus 38 million in 2008.  So a very strong performance also in terms of regulated energy  networks, if we exclude the non-recurrent impact.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Still in regulated energy networks, of course that demand of energy in our networks was down both  in electricity and gas, but it is important to note that even in 2009 we showed a growth in terms of  demand from the residential segment, which is the segment more important for the distribution  networks, given the existing regulation both in Portugal and in Spain.  In terms of efficiency ratios,  there were significant improvements essentially justified by the continued improvement of cost  control.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If we move to page 14 and focusing wind power, our subsidiary EDP Renewables, as already  reported but only to review the key highlights: So installed capacity 23% higher, output 40% higher,  of course the EBITDA went up 24%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 nevertheless we were penalized in the merchant generation by the lower prices in U.S., penalized  by declining demand and lower gas prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to consolidated financials and to slide 19 where we have the consolidated CapEx, we can  see that consolidated CapEx still amounted to 3.2 billion with maintenance representing 20% of  this. The key driver of expansion CapEx continued to be wind power with close to €1.7 billion of  expansion split by U.S., Spain and in rest of Europe, of course, with a strong weight for Portugal,  Romania and Poland.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But also in Iberia generation, we had a significant investment, namely in hydro power in which we  moved on with the current construction of fixed hydro plant.  We invested €400 million in hydro  power in Portugal.  Note that the profitability of this hydro power continues, reinforced by this recent  increase of the instability in the system which is expected to grow with the increasing weight of wind  in the system.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also important to highlight that by December 2009, we had already €2.2 billion invested in the  current generation plant under construction, which amount to 3.2 gigawatts, of course that with  wind representing the bulk of it, but also hydro growing significantly. These plants under  construction, they represent 16% of EDP’s installed capacity by December 2009. So, of course, this  €2.2 billion are not generating EBITDA.  They have a weight, of course, in net debt, but they will  generate EBITDA in the next years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We maintained our ratings for the three agencies in the A region and the net debt to EBITDA stood  at 3.9 in 2009 excluding regulatory receivables and excluding the payment for the Gas Natural  assets on December 31, 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to 2010 and always to give some overview in terms of current market scenario, we can see  that on page 26, that in terms of demand of energy in Iberia, we see signs of recovery already in  January and February, with, of course, with a positive impact from weather condition, but even  adjusted to weather conditions, we continue to see an improvement.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nevertheless, in terms of prices, as you can see in slide 27, this demand increase was not enough  to support prices, especially because we have also a big increase in terms of hydro production and  wind production during this winter, which of course lead to a lower demand for thermal generation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nevertheless, it’s important to note that there is an increasing demand for backup generation  services due to security/balance reasons. Of course, that, this is good for our thermal generation,  which can – of course, it’s working less in the daily market, but it’s working more in restrictions,  ancillary services and other markets with different prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: What is our current situation regarding our liberalized activities?  In page 28, we can see that we  have – for 2010 we have already contracted 100% with clients all our expected output. The average  price continues in the region of €50 per megawatt hour versus the current forward curve of 38 and  the average thermal spread lost is €10 per megawatt hour and note that this €10 per megawatt  hour is before any kind of optimization, so replacing own generation by pool prices if that  opportunity exists, and if could also [inaudible] ancillary services and any presence in a restrictions  market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In wind power, our subsidiary I’ve already talked about it, but our scenario is production growing  more than 35%, maintaining a limited exposure to market price in the region of 20%. And moving to  the more stable Iberian regulated networks and long-term contracted, so in networks. we have –  you already know the regulated revenue for 2010.  They were already set by the regulators, so we  have €1.7 billion of regulated revenues. So here, we expect to, even let’s say in the more mature  areas, we expect to continue to show in 2010 EBITDA growth above 5%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So balanced portfolio, as you see the fact that we have as everybody knows a lot of regulated  assets and long-term contracted assets it’s very important for the stability of our cash flows. You  see regulated network and long-term contracted in Iberia, the EBITDA is growing 10% year-on- year; the favorable returns, the efficiency improvements, and of course the new assets, so we are  capturing already the value of the new assets in North Sea and in also Spain the gas assets that  have performed better than we expected when we bought those assets. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This is very important because of the regulated electricity market in Iberia was very challenging. As  you know, we already expected a very tough market, the market if anything it was only slightly  tougher than we expected and we have – as we have already foreseen a contraction of hedged  thermal spreads and lower arbitrage gains. So, the effect of this tough Iberian market as we are  less exposed even if it’s of course an issue is less an issue for us because of all the regulated and  long-term contracted assets that we have in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The second is of course Brazil. Brazil has been the most exposed relatively wide for the amount of  maturity in Europe. Brazil represents now 18% of our EBITDA and also because of increase of  electricity demand very positive and evolution of exchange rates we have an increase of 22% year- on-year. So, Brazil is delivering what we wanted to it to represent in our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Here what I would like to stress is the reinforcement of the regulatory stability in the Spanish  market. It was for a long moment an issue during 2010. And now it’s settled, it’s important for us  and for all the players. And the second is the fact that we have signed and by far we are number  one in new PPA universe markets, 841 megawatts in U.S. and 555 megawatts just in the last  quarter. So we have made huge efforts, competitive efforts in terms of reducing our merchant  percentage and I think that it’s a very good time for our portfolio. At the same time, more for gas,       corrected transcript

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The second is efficiency. As you’ll see we have kept the net OpEx over gross profit ratio at 28% is  the best in the industry in Iberia. So once again, we have very well performed on the cost reduction fronts.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: CapEx wise it’s clear that we have been doing what we are told in the markets. It stayed at close to  €2.7 billion, a reduction of €600 million year-on-year and 74% was in expansion CapEx of which  almost 80% in wind and hydro. As you know we have already committed to further CapEx reduction  to around €2.2 billion in 2011 and €2 billion in 2012. We have already stated this and we are  committed to this CapEx reduction. Therefore, the forecast we will see the ratio of CapEx over  EBITDA decreases very sharply between 2009, ‘10 and ‘11.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to slide six on efficiency, you can see that the ratio of OpEx over gross of EDP remained  flat at 28%. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Portugal and Spain, we saw also the clear recoveries of electricity demand, so, with demand  growing 4.7% in Portugal and 3.3% in Spain. In Portugal, we are already above 2008 demand  levels. In Spain, we are still slightly low – below that in gas let’s say the gas market was penalized  by the higher hydro production and lower CCGT output. Note that the strong growth in Portugal is  essentially driven by strong demand growth from export industries, namely pulp and paper and  chemicals.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to the long-term contracted generation Iberia, which represented 24% of our EBITDA, we  are talking essentially about our long-term PPAs and CMEC systems generation in Portugal. So this slight improvement in terms of EBITDA is related with the stable return on  assets of 8.5% pre-tax real.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We had some positive impacts from higher fuel procurement results and the negative mini – it  includes the negative impact from the 1% decline of installed capacity with the end of the PPA for a  small fuel oil plant that we have named Carregado.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The special regime had a strong positive impact from the – strong increase in the output from mini- hydro and an increase of 46 megawatts in terms of installed capacity.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Regarding the evolution of final price of electricity also marketing spend, we saw also first that we  had strong arbitrage opportunities in the second quarter 2009 and in – during the first half of 2010  even that the spot price was below our hedged generation cost that you can see in the right-hand  picture. Nevertheless, these arbitrage opportunities that had significant impact in our results in  second half of 2009 and still we’ll be reaching the first half of 2010, they were not relevant in the  second half of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In gas retail sales, essentially, the growth is driven by more competitive sourcing mix on spot gas  purchases that is based on an opportunistic way and also the opening of the Portuguese free gas  market, in which we have reached already a 28% market share in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving to regulated energy networks, which represented 26% of our EBITDA, we can see that we  showed the 13% growth of EBITDA with Electricity Portugal EBITDA going down 1% year-on-year.  Nevertheless, it includes some negative impact from the lower tariff adjustments and from higher  costs with human resource restructuring. Adjusted for that, EBITDA would have grown by 4%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Spain, the strong growth of 30% is driven especially by the improvements in regulations on a  record it gives way to 2009. And some gas in Iberia still we have the positive impact from the  inclusion of the assets acquired in Spain and the gas distribution assets in Murcia and Cantabria,  but also even EBITDA pro forma excluding these acquisitions would be at around 25%, which  reflects the organic growth performance of our gas network.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 electricity distributed volumes. And in Generation & Other, 1% decline, which reflects essentially  the dry weather conditions in the second half 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Consolidated financials, in terms of CapEx reached close to €2.7 billion with maintenance  representing 26%. We can see that in terms of Wind Power which continues to represent the bulk  of expansion CapEx. In 2010, 79% of expansion CapEx was made in wind and hydro power. And  so we planned to reduce our CapEx to €2.2 billion in 2011 and €2.0 billion in 2012 following the  cuts in wind U.S. expansion.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of construction in progress and hydro concession payments; so the total is €2.2 billion,  which includes essentially the concession payments made. In terms of construction in progress  now the big chunk comes from our Pécem coal plant in Brazil, which should be finalized by the end  of this year, starting operations in January 2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In wind, we have right now 590 megawatts under construction and hydro construction in Portugal is  growing. With 2012 we expect to have already three plants under construction with an expected  EBITDA of €40 million. So for 2012, if we sum the coal plant in Brazil plus the hydro in Portugal, we  expect €150 million positive impact from new capacity on EBITDA in 2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And I would like to stress where, and as we are talking about figures, I would like to stress the  highest score in the second, in risk management, in stakeholder engagement, in price risk  management, in scorecard measurement systems, in human capital development and, of course,  the rest comprise biodiversity and we report the climate. And we think that typically the way we  approach risk, how we manage people and show that we have been really changing the way how  we do business and how we communicate with our all stakeholders.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s see for 2011. We should start, first issue is always what about the Iberian market? And the  issue is the Iberian market is range – has a tough market. The liberalized market is going to be  tough. As you see, the wholesale energy prices, forward prices for 2011, for the end of 2011 are flat  compared to what they were at the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And at the same time, you have forward energy markets for 2011. It have been categorized in  terms of inputs. At the same time, the demand is slightly recovering in Spain, and once again,  Portugal that was already in 2010 above 2008.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: You have a 1.2% decrease. If you adjust by climates and working days, it’s minus 0.5%, so less  than half of this figure. But it shows that demand will be relatively – probably relatively flat with a  slight increase in electricity in Spain for the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So the name of the game is tough market with residual demand for thermal power production, and  thermal spreads being kept at low levels.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So we will go through forward contracting of electricity sales and fuel costs to keep risks down, and  as you know here, it’s a moment where you capture all the value of having lots of long-term  contracted generation, especially impacted by this mix in the Portuguese market, so very different  from the other players in Iberia.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator

And as you see, we are growing in market  especially in Poland, also in Romania where the selling prices are well above portfolio average. So  overall we see a positive increase in 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Regulated network it was stable. Visibility is the key word. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I would also like to say that we are also today having a good visibility to 2012 in the sense that as  we all know, we have a huge investment program in projects. So you will have the new PPA coal  plant in Brazil plus three new hydro plants in Portugal and only for this we expect an impact of €150  million positive impact on EBITDA for 2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the same line, in terms of commitments with the financial and adjusting to what is the sector of  the energy markets, we are lowering our CapEx in 2012 for – to a €2 billion level. And we target the  full cash dividend of 18.5 cents per share, in line with the previous guidance. So I remember that  this guidance was given in July 2006, and we have been until now always increasing as agreed at  that moment the dividend.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For execution of our ongoing investments, we’ll have cash flows with attractive returns. Controlled  risk, we will be keeping merchant wind low especially in U.S. market of course. texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So to wrap-up, what we have in 2010, the improvement of returns, increase on EBITDA and in net  profits, wind power in Brazil were key growth drivers, at the same – safe and sound financial  management contributed to an increase in net profit. We have been focusing on sectors, countries,  in technologies that are delivering better returns compared to other technologies and I think its  profitable growth, this asset allocation, I think is smarter. And at the same time keeping the  controlled risk on the projected activities, on market diversification, on the CapEx reduction, on the  liquidity, so keeping this low risk is DNA of the company. And bearing this in mind, assets, already  talking about the dividends for next year of course we are going to propose to the annual  shareholder meeting a dividend of $0.17 per share, which represent a 10% increase year-on-year.
