texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of regulatory receivables, in 2011, we had an increase of €204 million to €1.647 billion by December 2011  in terms of the weight in our net debt, combining that from, first, a higher-than-expected system costs in Portugal  and Spain due to, first, higher-than-expected energy costs, but also lower hydro production and also a weaker- than-expected demand.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of net debt evolution, net debt increased 4% or €0.7 billion in 2011, with the increase being driven  essentially by, first, regulatory receivables, which has increased €0.2 billion as we referred before versus an  expected decline – versus decline which was initially expected. So, it wasn't from in an increase. Note also that we  have this low second half 2011 securitizations in Spain and the high oil prices which explains this increase.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of operating performance in our liberalized energy activities in Iberia, in page 17, we can see that  production declined by 11%, essentially due to lower concession rates of combined cycles and lower hydro output.  But note that coal – there was a significant increase in terms of coal production due to more competitive costs and  the new law on Spanish domestic coal that was published in 2011.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of the financial performance in our liberalized energy activities in Iberia, you can see that average selling  price increased by 17% to €57.5 per megawatt hour. Nevertheless, this increase was not enough to compensate the  increase in average sourcing cost by 26% to €49.7 per megawatt hour, meaning that average unit margins fell 17%  to €8.8 per megawatt hour and justify the 13% decline in EBITDA in this business area.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of major divisions, you can see that in terms of electricity in Portugal, the recurrent EBITDA increased  1%, as low demand and low inflation input in tariffs balanced lower controllable cost. In terms of electricity in  Spain, excluding the gain on the sale of – to Red Eléctrica of electric transmission assets, recurrent EBITDA  increased by 3% on federal regulation. And in terms of Gas Iberia, our EBITDA increased by 11% on both increase  of number of supply points and volume growth.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to – in terms of efficiency in regulated energy networks, we can see that EDP showed a 10% decline in  terms of OpEx per network – per kilometer of network, and then 9% decline in terms of OpEx per connection –  per connected customers, and at the same time, showing higher quality of service. So, the equivalent interruption  time in electricity distribution in Portugal went down by 35%, down to 75 minutes in 2011.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of assets and funding, in terms of our asset portfolio, our installed capacity increased by 88% in the last  six years, driven by greenfield wind and hydro power capacity additions, and increasing the average residual  useful life of our portfolio from 16 to 24 years.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of our portfolio, in terms of long – in terms of average residual life, you can see that hydro and wind  technologies with the longer useful life, represents 65% of our total portfolio, providing the sustainable cash flow  stream over the next 24 years on average without need of replacement CapEx.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of page 35, we do also an update in terms of the energy sector measures set by the MoU with IMF, the  European Commission and European Central Bank, in which I would say that most of the points were already  done and qualified, so namely the parts of privatization, the parts of elimination of special rights, the part of –  referred before in terms of liberalization.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of outlook for liberalized activities. Despite of weak demand, the low hydro reserves supports thermal  production, namely coal, which have been working very strongly in January and February, and the low coal and  CO2 costs have improved the clean dark spread. On the other side, in terms of combined cycles, the higher oil  prices are deteriorating the spark spreads.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Overall, we expect net income of our liberalized activities in 2012, we have already committed all our coal sourcing  commitments, and for now, 80% of the gas commitments through the sales in wholesale and retail markets that  you can see in this slide 37.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In page 38, we can see that in terms of CapEx, we maintain our commitments, so €2 billion, from which the key  components of the expansion is Brazil hydro and wind as it was already in 2011. And so, we expect to maintain the  previous commitment.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of CTG partnership, the closing of the deal, it's now expected to occur in April, and we maintain the  target of the sale of the first €800 million of equity minority stakes in wind farms to be concluded in the first 12  months after deal closing.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: We see growth, of course, more in line with what makes sense in a moment like this; 6% year-on-year and the 11%  on wind power. This growth is selective. Basically, we are talking about wind, water in Portugal and Brazil.

file: EDP - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 6March2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thank you. So, good morning, everybody. Thank you for your presence in this conference of our 2012 results. The  first word that I would like to use is, of course, in a tough environment especially due to challenging Iberian  market conditions not only in terms of demand but also in terms of the regulation as everybody can recognize but  also due to non-recurrent items in Brazil, we presented resilient results, with a decrease of 3% on EBITDA to €3.6  billion. Of course, these negative effects on Iberian market and especially non-recurrent in Brazil that, all along  the year, people were not even mentioning whenever we met in one-on-ones on any conference, everybody was  keeping this – always on the bright side. But non-recurrent items exist. It was strongly compensated but not  totally by healthy growth in renewables. So, once again, resilience due to the portfolio effect. So, if in 2011 the  bright news were coming out of Brazil this year, the good news were coming from renewables sector,  compensating mainly for the lower Brazilian figures.  In this year, we have a division of 880 megawatts, typically, wind, hydro in Brazil. Two-thirds of which in new  hydro and wind. So, clearly, keeping the same focus on value-creation projects on these two technologies that, as  you know, in terms of earnings are more protected than other technologies.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of highlight of the period, I would also like to start mentioning the fact that we were at the €2 billion  CapEx, lower 7% year-on-year, namely for fewer expansion projects in wind power, especially in the U.S. market;  and clearly, the fact that we went down the road once again as committed [indiscernible] (05:20) concerns, the  deleveraging through disposals.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: We closed deals for €800 million of disposals, out of which €600 million will be received only in the first half of  2012. But it's clearly gas business, wind business, the deal with Enagas, the deal with Borealis, and the deal with  CTG signed at the end of December. All of this, as committed, showing that we don't have any indication of doing  what we saw in terms of disposal.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: We must also recognize clearly the issue of regulatory receivables going up a bit more than €1 billion in 2012 in  Portugal. €300 million of this €1.1 billion increase due to dry weather. So, clearly, an increase that is slightly  above what we would expect because of a very low dry year where we were below at of what is a normal idle year in  Portugal. At 48%, to be more exact, 48% of what is a normal year. Fortunately, this winter has been totally  different.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, electricity system sustainability agreement is being respected and, clearly, we see receivables. We feel  comfortable with the soft landing and to be fully paid by 2020 based on what I was mentioning always, 1.5% to 2%  increase above inflation. And as you know, it was a decision for 2013 by the regulator.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Our business model is clearly different, and we have a lower sensitivity to energy market. Of course, we suffered as  everybody with the changes that can occur whenever regulators or government don't need to be anti-cyclical. So,  clearly, 2012 a year where we were protected by our strategy, where we are separate from regulation and non- recurrent element in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thanks, Antonio. So, starting to move now to 2012 operating headlines, we can see that installed capacity rose 1%  in 2012 while oil production has declined 6% mostly due to dry weather in Iberian Peninsula.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of operating costs, they rose 3% year-on-year at consolidated level. In Iberia, operating cost rose 2%  impacted by higher commercial cost resulting from the ongoing energy supply liberalization process. At level of  the EDPR, operating costs, 13% up or 10% excluding ForEx, in line with the output growth of EDPR. While in  Brazil, operating cost rose 5.8% in local currency, in line with inflation in Brazil. Note that in 2012, we have  accomplished our OpEx III target savings of €75 million. And we aim now to anticipate our 2014 targets for 2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: CapEx in 2012 fell 7% to €2 billion following a slowdown of wind power capacity expansion. Note that expansion  CapEx in 2012 was 100% in new wind and hydro capacity plus the new Pecém plant in Brazil which has a PPA  with Brazil electricity system.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to regulatory receivables. They increased €1.1 billion in 2012 mostly explained by a similar increase in  Portugal. This increase was driven by an increase of €790 million in line with the previously defined by the  regulator and an increase of €270 million due to extreme dry weather in 2012 in Portugal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Our net debt rose €1.35 billion in 2012, mostly driven by increase in regulatory receivables that I previously  referred. Net debt – in first half 2013, we should go back to €0.6 billion of disposals which, include €250 million  received in February 2013 regarding the sale of gas transmission assets in Spain and the previously-referred €360  million of the minority stake in Portuguese wind farms, which is being disposed to CTG, which is pending  regulatory approvals.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Adding to the five-year loan obtained in January 2013 in the amount of €1.6 billion and the sale of gas assets in  Spain which was closed in February 2013, the adjusted financial liquidity stands now at €5.8 billion, which covers  refinancing needs beyond 2014. Excluding the impact – note that this figure still excludes the impact from CTG  investment in renewable minorities and also the China Development Bank €1 billion commitment.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In this environment, EBITDA from our long-term contracted generation in Iberia fell 4% year-on-year, impacted  by some negative one-offs. And also, the lower mini-hydro output, which fell 42% year-on-year. Nevertheless,  adjusted EBITDA fell just by 0.3%, supported by higher inflation, high availability rates of our plants, and the  commissioning of the DeNOx facilities at our Sines coal plant.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of operating performance of our Liberalized Energy Activities in Iberia, our total production fell 13% due  to very low utilization rates of our – at our CCGTs, our gas-combined plants, while higher coal production was  driven by a more competitive costs. Higher hydro output was essentially backed by capacity expansion as the  hydro conditions were worse in 2012 versus 2011.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: On Regulated Energy Networks in Iberia, EBITDA fell 4%, impacted by a €27 million one-off in first quarter 2011  on the sale of electric transmission assets to Red Eléctrica. Adjusted EBITDA stayed at minus 1% year-on-year on  lower regulated revenues from electricity distribution in Spain, following the measures announced by the Spanish  government in March 2012.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to EDP Renewables in page 27, we can see that EBITDA rose 17%, impacted by an increase of 6% of  installed capacity and 10% increase in volumes produced. The increase in actual terms of EBITDA was €137  million driven by the rest of the Europe namely Poland and Romania, Spain and the United States, which roughly  out of the positive impacts comes from ForEx.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding Brazil, we can see in page 28 that in 2012 that market conditions were marked by a strong electric  demand, although the growth in the Southeast region was penalized by a slowdown in term of industrial  consumption. And very importantly, the strong increase of spot prices namely in the second half of the year. This  strong increase in spot prices was driven by a strong decline in hydro reservoir levels due to dry weather and some  delays in commissioning of new capacity, which requested a full dispatch of all available backup thermal plants  increasing the generation costs and also the spot prices.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: This environment affected the performance of – the EBITDA performance of our subsidiary, EDP Brasil, which  showed an EBITDA decline of 15% in local currency penalized by some non-recurrent events. In Distribution, I  would highlight the negative tariff deviations on higher electricity acquisition costs. We're expecting the higher  spot price in the market. These higher costs will be passed through to customers in 2012 and 2014. So, it's non- recurrent impact. And we have also the recurrent negative impact from the cut on Bandeirante RoRAB from 10%  to 7.5% since October 2011.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of outlook, for 2013, and starting for macro assumptions, European Commission has recently revised this  GDP forecast, so new forecast for Portugal and Spain are now minus 1.4% GDP in Portugal, and minus 1.4% in  Spain. As we know, historically, there's a significant correlation between GDP and electricity demand evolution.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: On top of that, we have already the figures for the first two months of the year. So, in the Iberian market, the  electricity demand went down by 6.4%, adjusted for temperature and working days. A slower decline Portugal,  minus 1.5%. And slightly higher in Spain, minus 4.7%. And with the information, our new forecast in terms of  electricity demand in Iberia for 2013 is now minus 2% essentially reflecting the weak macro environment.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Looking to thermal production in Iberia and also looking to the performance in the first two months, we see a  decline in terms of utilization of thermal capacity by roughly 50%, slightly less, 46% decline. This reflects hydro  production coming to normalized levels, so hydro factor in Portugal was very close from 1 in the first two months  of the year, and that renewables production increasing not only due to new installed capacity but also due to very  strong wind resources in January and February. Also, there is further demand decline, contributes to this lower  production of thermal generation in the period.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In page 35, we can see also some figures from the first two months of the year, which means I would highlight on  the left end that power prices in the first two months were lower year-on-year, so 9% decline. So, despite new  generation taxes in Spain in 2013, the average pool price year-to-date is €4.7 per megawatt hours lower year-on- year. And also, I would highlight that the average pool price in Portugal slightly below Spain, which is normal  given the taxes and given the higher hydro and wind resources. But very important, I would highlight that  although the pool taxes are lower, gas has more volatility, so we have high volatility of prices which increased the  arbitrage opportunities namely on pool purchases, hydro pumping/storage, et cetera, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: How do we stand right now in terms of outlook for 2013 Liberalized Activities? So, we have 100% of our  commitment of gas production fully clothed. So, we have fully hedged our coal production. In terms of gas, we  have covered already 80% of our commitment. We continue growing in terms of wholesale and retail sales of  electricity and gas. So, I would say that we are quite protected and we still have good placement in terms of  markets to take advantage of some arbitrage opportunities which can happen, namely through replacement of  thermal production by electricity purchases, operation of the recently commissioned hydro pumping and  repowering capacity in Portugal.  In terms of outlook for regulatory receivables in Portugal. So, we maintained the evolution as expected. So, we  expect an increase in the region of €500 million in 2013. In terms of the first two months of the year, I would  highlight on the positive side in the hydro production which is much better than last year; tariff increases that  were fully implemented; market liberalization with number of clients in free markets increasing faster than  expected. On the negative side, of course, demand, which is slightly worse than expected, nevertheless expected  utilization during the year to minus 2% in 2013. And all the measures that were offered by the government in May  were already implemented, so the cuts on CMEC, capacity payment, cogeneration and the wind agreement. On the  CO2 auction, we have the issue of lower prices in the market, which decrease the visibility in terms of the volumes  and prices of CO2 auctions to be done in 2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: We can see in page 38 that Portugal continues to benefit from a cheaper and more mature mix of special regime  technologies. We have less solar and more cogen versus Spain. So, lower premiums and lower costs with special  regime, which definitely is an advantage in terms of the future evolution of regulatory receivables in Portugal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of CapEx, we maintain our guidance of €2 billion in line with 2012, reflecting the ongoing expansion in  wind. So, we are building – we expect to install 500 megawatts mostly in Poland and Romania in 2013; two new  hydro plants under construction; five hydro plants to be commissioned in 2014-2016; and in Brazil, the  conclusion of Peixe; and, most importantly, the ongoing construction of Jari and start-up construction of  Cachoeira Caldeirão.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: What concerns EBITDA for 2014? We see it clearly above EBITDA of 2011. And the key reasons are related to the  fact that we have been – we will have the first hydros coming out of [indiscernible] (32:33). As you know, the  implicit price on [indiscernible] (32:37) is €25 years, so this will be in the free market of course with higher prices.  And of course, the new hydro capacity that will have an impact, as you know, during 2014, we will have two  hydros, one mid-year and the other towards the end of the year. And of course, wind capacity and especially the  consolidation of ENEOP. ENEOP as you know with the development of the projects with – in Portugal when we  won the bid where we have more or less 400 megawatts, one-third 400 megawatts in the first phase that will go  up and we will have, in 2013, still non-consolidating and in 2014, it will be the first year of the consolidation of  those wind farms after the full project is developed.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, compared to the business plan in May, what I would like to say is basically what is new. We don't see major  changes except for one. In Spain, we have already considered the first wave of new measures. We had already  considered the changes in Portugal but the numbers did not include what happened later. The taxes and, of  And also the recent renewable package in Spain. Then we can elaborate a little bit more on that. But of course, this  will have, even if it's small, but an impact compared to what we expected in May.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And the other figure that changed compared to what we talked in May is, of course, Brazil, namely to rain. As far  as you may know, everything is getting better. The weather was already about 40%. But the very dry rainy season  has already an impact in 2012 and, of course, will still have an impact in the first quarter of 2013. But we see this  being normalized.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: What we see on a five, six-year period, typically five or six years in Brazil, basically, hydro tends to be slightly  above what is a normal year. So, suddenly sometimes you are below. It's the case with the very low rainy season.  So, clearly, we have an improvement also in terms of mini-hydros compared to 2012 because now finally we have  a normal rainy season in Portugal. So, typically we don't see major changes and, of course, Pecém being fully  commissioned during 2013, of course, the full impact on the full year on both – in 2014 will also contribute to a  better year, so flat 2013.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, what we see is a resilient business model, of course, in a challenging environment and the fact that we will be,  in terms of the results, delivering what comes from a resilient performance enhanced by diversification. The fact  that we are – the capacity addition are concentrated in wind, in hydro and in Brazil. We will keep the low-risk  profile with a strong CapEx discipline, lowering as we see in 2012, keeping the commitment before 2013. We will  do the disposal program. We will use, if it's needed, the flexibility in terms of investments in 2014 and 2015.

file: EDP - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 28February2014 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: But in any case, throughout the year, it was not very exciting, but of course, the major negatives on the Iberian  were the regulatory measures with huge impact that were offset by typical three things. Strong hydro volumes, but  mainly what I think that we have been showing to the market consistently, good energy management figures; and  also I would like to stress this is a very tight cost control. Our OpEx in Iberia decreased by 4% on a year-on-year  basis.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of renewables, we have an increase of capacity by 5%. EBITDA only grows by 1%. And the key reason is,  of course, the adverse regulatory changes in Spain that were already accounted. The reforms presented in January  led to the booking of the impact on 2013 second half, and also in terms of impairment, 2013 also include these  figures.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In what concerns CapEx, once again, €2 billion. So we kept the amount that was foreseen and communicated to  the market. And at the disposal level, you already know this, €600 million between gas transmission asset sales  plus the EDPR assets in the CTG agreement, and also some sales to pension funds in the U.S.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So overall, what we have seen is once again the pressure on the sector by regulatory/legal measures that were  basically compensated by what depends on us; energy management, cost control. And I think it's good news,  because when you do what depends on you, it's always better.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: The second part of the year, as we can see in slide five, was marked by a recovery of electricity demand in Portugal.  We had an increase of 2% in the third quarter and 2.2% in the fourth quarter, leading 2013 electricity demand to  increase 0.2% year-on-year or becoming flat when adjusted for temperature and working days.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to page six, we can see that in terms of operating headlines, installed capacity of EDP group went down by  2%, following the commissioning of Setúbal oil plant in Portugal; commissioning of 0.4 gigawatts of wind  capacity, mostly in Poland and Romania; and also, the commissioning of the second group of Pecém. Power  production went up by 12%, especially due to the rainy and windy weather conditions in Iberia during 2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In Iberia, operating cost went down by 4%, clearly below inflation in the period both in Portugal and Spain. At  level of EDPR, operating costs went up by 2% in euro terms, in line with increase of installed capacity; while in  Brazil, operating costs went up 17% in local currency, reflecting restructuring of operations and also due to  commissioning of our new coal plant of Pecém I. Overall, EDP accomplished its OpEx III target savings in 2013 of  €120 million, anticipating by one year its target for 2014.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to CapEx on page 10, we can see that the CapEx went down 2% year-on-year to below €2 billion, in line  with our plan, including €1.3 billion of expansion CapEx related mostly with hydro and Brazil hydro  developments, and also with wind expansion out of Iberian Peninsula, and still with a slight decline in terms of  our maintenance CapEx.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding the evolution of regulatory receivables at the level of Portuguese electricity system, after a €0.6 billion  increase in the first half of 2013 driven by declining demand, strong wind production and high special regime  premiums, we can see that in the second half of the year, there was only an increase of €0.2 billion, benefiting  from demand recovery and normalization of wind production and oil prices. Overall, electricity system receivables  went up by €0.8 billion in 2013, standing still €0.1 billion below our previous guidance provided in the nine- month results.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: By business area, we can see that operations in Iberia faced a market environment marked by strong hydro and  wind volumes, which was clearly positive for EDP's generation mix; and also low pool prices which, taking into  account EDP's long position in clients, provided the conditions to achieve good energy management results.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of electricity and thermal power demand in Iberia, although electricity demand in Portugal was positive  by 0.2%, as we talked before, in Spain, it was still negative by minus 2.2% resulting in electricity demand in Iberia  going down by 1.8%. Nevertheless, this evolution was not homogenous over 2013. So, in fact, in the fourth quarter,  we had flat demand, even with a slight increase of 0.1% versus a decline of 0.5% in the third quarter and a 3.7%  decline in the first half of 2013. Overall, the thermal power production decreased 30%, reflecting the impact from  lower demand, but most importantly, the strong hydro and wind resources in 2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding EDP's liberalized energy activities in Iberia, production went up by 1%, reflecting the increase of the  weight of hydro production from 16% to 32% and also reflecting a strong decline in terms of thermal load factors  on the back of lower residual thermal demand.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: EBITDA in liberalized energy activities in Iberia went up by 11%, positively impacted by 16% decline in terms of  average generation costs, our long position in clients and also the 3% decline in terms of average electricity  purchasing costs. Overall, this division was also negatively impacted by the referred regulatory changes, and also  the low thermal plant profitability in the period.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to long-term contract generation in Iberia, EBITDA went down by 9%, impacted by decommissioning of  Setúbal fuel oil plant and just partly compensated by the strong increase in terms of mini-hydro production in  2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: EBITDA in regulated energy networks went down by 3%, both as reported and also as adjusted, reflecting  especially a lower return on RAB in distribution of electricity in Portugal, which went down from 10.05% in 2012  to 8.56% in 2013 on indexation to five-year CDS of Portuguese Republic.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, moving to our leased subsidiaries. EBITDA at EDP Renováveis went up 1%, as it was already referred.  EBITDA in Iberia was flat, reflecting strong wind conditions, but also the negative impact from the new  generation taxes and from the recent cuts in terms of remuneration in renewables in Spain. EBITDA in the United  States went up by 7%, and EBITDA in other markets went down 7% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of outlook and in slide 32, moving to some update in terms of market environment in Iberia. In the first  two months of 2014, we can see that the negative impact from electricity demand is now much lower than what it  was in 2013. Demand in Iberia went down just by 0.8% as a result of continuing recovery in Portugal, plus 3.2%  year-on-year and lower decline of demand in Spain in the period, minus 1.6%. So the major change versus the  same period last year is the higher hydro production, which almost fully justifies the 47% decline in terms of the  residual thermal demand.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Overall, in terms of EDP liberalized activities, in terms of forward contracting for 2014, so we have already sold  and closed spreads for 100% of our expected coal production. We have already closed the spreads for 80% of our  commitment in terms of gas sourcing, and we have already contracted mostly with final client 23 terawatts hour of  electricity sales at an average contracted price of €55 per megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of profit for devolution of regulatory receivables in Portugal, we would say that this should be positively  impacted, obviously, for the 2.8% tariff increase implemented in Portugal since 1st of January 2014. The  beginning of 2014 is showing also positive signs in terms of power demand and in terms of CO2 prices, which  went up significantly in the last two months. It's also through that the strong volumes in terms of wind production  and low pool prices, which imply higher special regime premiums, should have a slight negative impact.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving finally to an outlook on market environment in Brazil, we can see that hydro reservoir levels are currently  lower than expected. So they were at 40% at the end of January versus 37% at end of January 2013, and 76% at  end of January 2012, a scenario that leads to the recent strong increase in spot electricity prices. This situation  should be compensated by the expected renewal for 2014 of the system implemented in 2013, essentially the  upfront cash payment by CDE fund to distributors which are currently facing a huge and unexpected increase of  electricity procurement costs.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So we're aware of consensus. What we see is that liberalized activities are supposed to be slightly above 10%. The  increase here is also due to the fact of three new hydro plants that were transferred from [CMEC] to the markets.  And, of course, these will have a positive impact because implicit tarrif on the CMEC is lower than the market  price. We have also here the impact from regulatory measures, especially in Spain. But we have also to mention  the strong hedging for 2014, the 23 terawatts sold forward at an average selling price of €55.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In Brazil, you have of course the uncertainty on the lack of rain and what will be the degree of utilization of CDE or  other mechanisms that, as you know, has been conveyed by the Brazilian authorities that they will compensate in  the market. Until now, the solution is not yet presented, but everybody expects that because of the size of the  issue, that will have something similar to what was done last year, even if it's not in the same degree, but we  expect something on that direction.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: And of course, the 50% stake at Pecém, we have, as we see, a disposal of 50% of Jari and Cachoeira. The closing  will be expected towards the end of this semester. Then at wind power, we have the impact of the new additions in  2013. We will be developing mainly in U.S. with PPAs throughout 2014 new projects.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: But of course here, we will have what was already considered in the accounts for the last six months in 2013, the  impact of the regulatory framework of wind farms in Spain. As you know, our market share of the revenues  compared to the market share of the production and especially of the installed capacity, it's interesting for us, and  in a difficult environment, I think, it was – it's a rather relatively good result.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, EDP - Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: If we see distribution year-to-date, Portugal, evolution of five-year CDS would result on 8.4% return on RAB,  slightly lower than last year where it was 8.56%. So not a big change. And as you've seen, the long-term contracted  reduces the relative weight because of the three hydro plants that go into the market, through the finished CMEC.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: What can I say to start? I think there are strong results in a year that was of course, let's say, challenging in terms  of environment, because of the regulatory and legal, special legal changes that were decided in the pas t, and it was  the first year of full impact of those measures. And so, clearly, we anticipated the impact on the accounts of this,  but at the end of the day, I believe that the measures that we have taken management wise, on the front of energy  management, costs and even on the debate of those regulatory issues, I believe that we succeeded in having very  strong figures.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We see the EBITDA growing 1% to €3.642 billion, so better than in 2013. And then, we have these by blocks, so  understanding exactly how the different components move. What can we say? Let's start by Iberia. Iberia, you  have 1% increase in EBITDA, excluding one-offs. I think it's important to stress the very good energy management  results of the year. We, however, also had a positive impact o n the strong hydro. In Portugal, it was 27% above the  average year. And I would like to stress the very tight control at the level of costs that compensate regulatory cuts.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second block, Renewables. Renewables, of course, we have an increase of new capacity, 5% but it was not enough  to compensate remuneration cuts, especially the changes in Spain, that was decided at the beginning of last year.  And of course, lower power prices affected and created one-offs as it was already stressed by EDP Renewables,  one-offs, so higher than expected to the average impact of the new measures.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The third block, Brasil. In terms of real figures, we have 3% increase in euros, 12% in local currency in reais .  Excluding the one-offs, you have a lower 18% EBITDA in reais, basically, due to the impact of the drought.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So Iberia sailing in a good way; Renewables impacted by the new remuneration. In 2014, these are higher than  they will be on a steady state. Brasil, a good year, of course, with the one-offs that must be considered.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So fully in line with expectations, and I think this is important because people tend to be worried with the  sustainability, and clearly, the figure shows that the system is evolving exactly as we have been sharing with the  market.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Net investments €1.79 billion, minus 20% year-on-year, so clearly, focus on the CapEx control and as we have  seen, the hydro of the last five projects, we have more than 85% of that CapEx expected for those hydros. The last  – the current sites that are being developed, 85% is done. And then the second big block was wind mostly in the  U.S. By the way, around two-thirds of the new additions in the two years will be in U.S.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Thank you, António. Good morning all of you. I will start with the evolution of the EDP's generation mix in which  installed capacity went up by 1%, following essentially the new capacity in wind mostly in U.S. In the power  production, we saw 2% increase supported by the referred increase of wind capacity and also the rainy weather in  Iberia. So by end of 2014, wind and hydro represented 70% of installed capacity and they represented 71% of  production in 2014.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to next slide. We can see that 1% growth of EBITDA reflects first resilient performance in Iberia, secondly,  the impact of the drought in Brazil, and third, the lower revenues at the level of EDPR in Spain on the regulatory  cuts.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Overall, our focus in terms of investments program continues on the expansion of wind capacity, now, very  focused in U.S., but also in Brazil and starting in Mexico, and also the conclusion of the five hydro projects that we  have under construction in Portugal, four of them that we expect to complete already in 2015.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: It includes also for the first time in 2014 these extraordinary tax introduced in Portugal for energy operations, so  an extra cost of €61 million at the bottom line. We have also €35 million increase of minorities, both at level of  EDP Brasil and EDP Renewables, which resulted in the net profit of €1,040 million. Note that adjusted net profit  was €905 million in 2014, representing 8% decline versus 2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to the 2014 performance by business area. In terms of electricity market environment in Iberia in 2014, I  would say that it was marked by second half of the year, with much lower wind and hydro volumes versus the first  half of the year, which allowed some recovery both of thermal production and pool prices in the last part of 2014.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of electricity demand in Iberia, it went down by 1.1% reflecting milder weather, both in December and in  the fourth quarter. But when adjusted for temperature and working days, it was flat in Portugal and  it showed a  mere 0.2% decline in Spain.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: On our division for liberalized energy activities in Iberia, electricity production went up 13%, strongly impacted by  the 42% increase in hydro volumes, on the transfer of the three hydro plants to liberalized markets from PPA, and  also the previously referred rainy weather. In terms of thermal load factors at our coal and gas plants, each  showed no material changes versus 2013.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of EBITDA in liberalized energy activities in Iberia, it went up 25% in 2014 versus 2013, benefiting from  the strong hydro volumes, the positive impact from energy management of our long position in clients, which was  stronger in the first half of the year than in second half and also negative impact from several regulatory changes   such as the clawback costs and lower revenues in ancillary services in Portugal and also lower capacity payments  and higher generation taxes in Spain.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to EBITDA performance, in terms of our division of long-term contracted generation, in Iberia, EBITDA  went down 6%, penalized by the previously referred transfer of three hydro plants from PPA/CMEC regime to the  liberalized market. Also, EBITDA in terms of special regime was penalized by lower volumes of production,  following the deterioration of remuneration methodology in Spain.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: EBITDA performance of our division regulated energy networks in Iberia went up 2% year -on-year, and when  adjusted for non-recurring impact, this increase is 1% year-on-year. Per division, we can see that [ph] electricity  now (24:20) in Portugal, EBITDA went up 3%, reflecting tight cost control, even including the lower return on  RAB in 2014 versus 2013. Electricity in Spain, EBITDA down 6% on also lower revenues and regulatory revenues  and revenues from new connections and gas in Iberia, EBITDA was flat essentially including our divisions, both in  Spain and Portugal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In Brazil, our subsidiary EDP Brasil faced a difficult market environment in the fourth quarter 2014. It was  marked by mainly hydro GSF factor of 88% in the fourth quarter, extremely low and strong thermal dispatch that  we implemented in order to preserve the hydro reservoirs. It was marked also in the fourth quarter by several  double-digit DisCo's annual tariff updates in which we benefit at our subsidiary, Bandeirante from a nnual tariff  increase of 22%.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Adjusted for this, EDP Brasil EBITDA went down 18% in local currency, with EBITDA in distribution being  essentially flat, also reflecting flat regulatory revenues without any impact on regulatory revenues right now, and  hydro generation recorded 32% decline on EBITDA, as a consequence of the abnormally low GSF of 91% in 2014,  which imply that we had to buy energy in the spot markets in order to comply with our contracts, and with the net  negative impact net of hedging of minus R$339 million.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Miguel. For the outlook, I think that it's important once again to split among areas. And let's start by  Iberia. Here, the first note that I would like to give is the energy demand evolution. As you see, the real increase in  electricity demand in Spain is to 2% and 2.9% since the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Even with adjusted figures, it's flat in Portugal and an increase in Spain of 2.4%. Y ou see clearly the demand on  gas, and change on the mix because of the lower hydro, of huge increase on thermal demand and lower generation  of hydro generation in Portugal due to a weaker year. That will have a different impact, some negatives, and of  course, some positives, especially on at the tariff deficit level.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As I've mentioned, the dry weather, so lower hydro output, but higher prices. The immediate result is less energy  management possibility, because lower volatility, and of course, the lower hydro is connected with that  phenomenon. Higher thermal demand, better spreads on lower fuel costs and [indiscernible] (30:41) also lower  gas deviation opportunities.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But the overall picture that I want to share with you is that we have already sold 23 terawatt hours at €55. And the  key element is that we have already spreads fixed on 85% of the gas sourcing. So when we're talking about the  lower global demand of LNG, it's important to say that we have already 85% of the gas hedged and 60% of the coal  output and both with better margins than in 2014.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So basically, this diversified generation portfolio and the hedge based on clients reduces the exposure to the  volatility, even in a market where we have less energy management possibility. So clearly, once again, I think  sailing rightly in the market.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Why we are comfortable with these figures? We are still at the beginning of the year, but let's see, demand in line  with what the regulator expected. Pool prices €47.7 in line making sense with the pool price of the full year of €50.  I'll remind you that the fourth quarter is always the one that tends to have lower prices because of weather  conditions, typically. So it makes sense, and also lower special regime production, once again, in line with what  was expected in – with the regulator and also remember the first quarter tends to be a strong quarter in terms of  special regimes.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So the financial sustainability of Portuguese electricity is clearly in fro nt of us. That's important and the evolution  of 2014, and now the evolution of 2015 makes us much more comfortable.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The hydro reservoirs, and let's focus on the key regions, they are at 20% compared to what was higher than 40%  two years ago and 35% last year. So below February 2001, the toughest year since the beginning of the century.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If with 86% that is below the 90% that was in 2014, because we have a much lower PLD, the negative impact on  the generation should be similar. The issue is, if the GSF goes lower than the 86%. For each 1% lower, we're  talking about an impact in terms of EBITDA on EDP Brasil of minus R$37 million, or slightly more than €10  million. But of course, this is the figure that we need to consider if it will happen or not at this stage.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So Brazil, the key issue is well, first of all, what will be the GSF. But I'd like to stress, I'm seeing that is very  important, we're targeting measures that will be defined in the short-term to mitigate adverse impact from this  eventually lower GSF, if it's the case. We are clearly working on measures. We should consider this lower GSF as  one-offs and we'll be working on that front to be sure that we'll compensate, if real to get tougher tha n what we  expected with the 86%.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So after Iberia, after Brazil, one key element. EDP is back to investment grade by Moody's. And I think two key  issues, the tariff deficit securitization, so visibility on the sustainability of the system in Portugal, I th ink it makes  people more comfortable. And also, the fact that we've been working clearly with clear measures on the CTG  partnership on the asset rotation, but also in sale of assets and also on lower investment level. So fulfilling the  commitment that we have presented to the market, and especially, I stressed again in May last year in the Investor  Day.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: What comes under EBITDA? We assume an average hydro year, so lower our arbitrage opportunities. We have  new hydro capacity additions. I remember this 250 megawatts in first half, almost 1 giga in the second half of  2015, with the new hydros in Portugal. In Brazil, we don't assume any rationing at this stage. As I mentioned, we  expect the 86%, let's see.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have the Pecém fully consolidating. What comes under wind? The strong U.S. and new wind capacity. We have  almost 400 megawatts commissioned at the end of 2014. So a lot of additions towards the end of last year. We  have lower exposure to power prices in Spain. I've mentioned that the first quarter last year was tough, because it  was difficult to hedge in a system where we don't know the rules. So we have already 2 terawatt hours hedged at  €47  in Spain for the EDP Renewables.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And we have for Portugal the full consolidation of EDPR, 40% in ENEOP expected at least between six months  and nine months. We have also – I would like to stress – at Iberian regulated networks, the sale of energy assets in  Murcia, with an impact of €18 million on EBITDA with deconsolidation.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Excluding these gains and our non-recurrent, our adjusted EBITDA increased by 2% when compared to 2014.  Where does this growth come from supported of course by the additional contribution of long-term contracted  generation capacity, 1.8 gigawatts, both in renewables and in Brazil? This, of course, relates to 8%, translate to 8%  increase on our installed capacity in 2015. We also show and stress that our 2015 EBITDA was very penalized by  weak hydro production and low energy management, as you will see they tend to be related. And by the way 2016  has started very differently. So it's a negative impact that becomes particularly significant at the bottom line, so  gross new additions and a very bad year – hydro year in Iberia.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of major investment, we need to stress that these figures include the €600 million impact from Pecém  acquisition that of course was not foreseen, but it's a good way to solve a problem, is to tackle this opportunity I  believe and I think it's transforming a problem into an opportunity, and this was partly compensated by 50%  equity content of the hydro, issued in last September.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Third, despite the 8% increase on EBITDA, net profit fell by 12% to €913 million. [ph] The Spanish (03:37)  basically justified the [ph] referred (03:40) negative of the adverse weather and market environment in Iberia. So  it's clearly done in Iberia, but also because of an external result, slightly above €100 million of EDP Asia on  financial results in 2014. So we need to taking this out would be more or less in the same figures. Regarding  dividends, the proposal of the management to the shareholders meeting, they are going to vote of course, is  €0.185 per share, flat to 2014 and fully in line with our commitment on a predictable and sustainable dividend  policy.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So let's talk about the non-recurrent. This year we have a lot, but I would like to say that they are related what I  would like to stress is that, they're related to our asset allocation strategy. So, firstly, we have the acquisition of the  remaining 50% stake in Pecém, which has a long-term PPA contract, a defensive move triggered by Eneva [ph]  financial throws (04:48) as you know. And it was agreed at the peak of Brazil's hydro crisis. And by the way, the  assets and the turnaround is impressive, available – availability recovered from 71% in 2014 to 88% in 2015.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Secondly, we have the 85% – €85 million gain in the disposals of the gas distribution network in Spain. Something  that was out of our region. So it was out of our focus. It's clear here what I want to recall is that we bought these  assets at the EV/EBITDA 9.4 times in 2009, as a remedy for Gas Natural acquisition of Fenosa. And although, we  like networks given the limited geographic synergies, we are – as you know, we are concentrated [ph] in also Spain  (06:16). We sold in 2015 at the multiple of 13 times. So we bought at 9.4 times and we sold at 13 times.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And I think it's important, we have already, in 2016, reinvested 50% of the cash proceeds in acquiring an LPG gas  network in our incumbent region at the multiple of 8.9 times. So I think that the relation of these multiples shows  how we know how to proceed [ph] in your concerns (06:46), asset reshuffling.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, at EDPR level, we have the combined impact from assets [indiscernible] (06:53) which of course  reinforces the rates of long-term contracted renewables in our portfolio, and some write-offs mostly related to the  focus on wind development efforts in the regions with the soundest fundamentals. So, clear, as it was already  stressed in EDP Renewables, we have been very focused. In key markets with key fundamentals, and I think this is  the difference to other players.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So let's see slide four. Regarding our investment plan. As you can see, our focus as it was expected in any case,  continues to be on long-term contract renewables and in regulated networks in our core markets. We are now  finishing our new hydro pump storage in Portugal. Two plants are starting operations in the first half 2016,  Salamonde II and Baixo Sabor. And the last two, under construction, will be ready by end of 2016. I'm talking  about Venda Nova III and Foz-Tua.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Renewables, we are now working to deliver more than 600 megawatts of wind capacity [ph] other PPAs (08:56)  in 2016, of course, mostly in the U.S., where we have been establishing partnerships with long -term financial  investor, but also in Mexico, we are building our first wind farm with a PPA, together with a strong local partner.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Brazil, we partnership with CTG. We are building both wind power plants and two hydro plants, all with PPAs,  with fixed prices updated to inflation. By the second quarter of 2016, we plan to start operation of Baixa do Feijão  wind farm and Cachoeira Caldeirão hydro plant. This one we will start operations more than six months ahead of  schedule. In regulated networks in 2016, we plan to maintain the level of CapEx in our current portfolio.  Additionally, we are acquiring as I've mentioned the Repsol LPG network as a minority stakes in our Iberia gas  network, so focus on a disciplined approach on the regulated networks.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Internal generation, 2016, we are finalizing the investment of the [ph] DNOC's environment (10:02) upgrade of  two most efficient coal plants in Spain. These works will imply two months outage of the plants in 2016, and after  they are finished, 80% of our coal fleet will comply with the more rigorous European legislation in terms of  emission.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then which we have already read as you know on the sale of 49% stake in wind farms in Poland and in Italy.  The closing of this deal and the respective cash-in is expected to happen in the second half of 2016. We will  continue to look for potential new assets, retention deals with financial investors namely EDPR level.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Slide five, hydro. I think hydro is a key element, and especially when we see on a normalized basis, we really need  to consider this hydro situation in Iberia.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, showing more in detail the year-on-year performance in terms of hydro, we can see that EDP production in  Iberia fell by 38%, with the hydro coefficient in Portugal standing 26% below the historical average. This strong  decline had a negative impact on our average generation cost and also results on an energy management lower  than expected. Why? Because as you know, hydro and energy management are related. We like volatility and I  think that clearly at the beginning of 2016 is going, I would say, very well.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Brazil, our hydro production fell by 23% year-on-year due to a 15% hydro deficit, and of course, this is related  with significant GSF losses in 2015 as a whole, when considering the clear recovery observed in the second part of  the year.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, even with the second half much better, the first half as we have seen was quite bad. So we had losses of GSF in  2015. So hydro was a critical element to understand, as we have already stated this. Because the beginning of the  year is always the key, January, February and March are the key months to see how it goes.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Iberia, our regulated network activities suffered with the decline of the regulated return on assets at our  electricity distribution business. While our generation supply operations were, as I've mentioned and stressed,  affected by the weak hydro and of course related also to lower energy management results. The impact of ForEx is  slightly negative by 1% with the negative impact from the Brazilian real being mostly compensated by the stronger  dollar versus the euro.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, with these results of our OpEx III, corporate-wide efficiency program has achieved €170 million of  accumulated annual cost savings, and we are now starting to design a new efficiency program, OpEx IV  is like the  movies, so [ph] a never ending movie, 2Q political for us (15:17), OpEx IV, which we'll share with you in our next  Capital Markets Day in May.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Slide eight, adjusted net profit. And I would like to spend a moment on this. People tend to do sim ple math, and I  think that we should go through this simple math. Overall, our adjusted net profit decreased 17% from €905  million to €7 50 million. I would like to highlight that more than two -thirds of this decline was justified by the  adverse weather and market conditions affecting our generation supply in Iberia with [ph] strong weights on  either on long in (16:05) clients. So this is important to stress, so we are talking more than €100 million. We  estimate that the negative impact from this factor is, of course, as I mentioned, €110 million and we expect to  recover a big chunk in 2016 based on normalization [ph] of weather (16:25) condition. We can say already this  because we are in March. And so, we have already seen the figures of January and February .

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, of course, you take the one-offs, you take everything out and then if you put a normal hydro, you would  consider a normalized €850 million. We have not put it on the slide. But clearly, it's the figure that makes sense to  see as a basis for the year.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Slide nine, guidance. Let's see, we can say that, in terms of EBITDA, we now expect to reach an EBITDA slightly  above €3.6 billion, so in line with the consensus. Why? Recovery of generation and supply conditions in Iberia;  positive impact from capacity additions, mainly in Iberia and Brazil, especially because the new hydros that were  there in 2015, they were there in 2015, but the water was not there. So, not only we have new hydros in 2016, but  also the new hydros in 2015 were there. But unfortunately, they were not producing – they were there on the asset  front, but they were not producing cash flow.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: [ph] EDP on (18:30) new capacity and of course in Brazil with 12 full months of Pecém and the start of Cachoeira  Caldeirão [ph] be (18:36) more than six months ahead of schedule. So, we have these two positives. And in Brazil,  if you want, our vision is clear that the eventual negative impact from ForEx will be compensated by the positive  impact from the end of the hydro crisis. So, we have lower currency, but better hydro. And overall, we expect this  to be balanced.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, slide 10. Wrapping up, I think that it shows the EDP's continuous focus on reinforcing our different profile  among European utilities. We want to maintain a clear visibility on growth base on what we know and do better  and what we have been delivering in the recent past, which is greenfield renewals with PPA regulated networks in  our core markets.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Thanks, António. So, starting in page 12 regarding the performance of the electricity market in 2015. We can see  that electricity demand went up by 1.6% in Iberia, with the split between 1.8% at – in Spain and 0.3% in Portugal  on a mixed effect from economic recovery and mild weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Hydro production, minus 34%, which was compensated by an increase of 27% of thermal production with coal  continuing more competitive than gas. Gas demand, up 6%, supported essentially for demand for electricity  production and this environment leads to the pool price increase by 19% to €50 per megawatt hour with gas  extending its role of marginal technology in terms of the Iberian market.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In this environment, as we continue to next page, our electricity generation operations in Iberia were marked by a  strong increase in coal and gas production, which compensated the decline in hydro volumes. PPA, in terms of our  generation, plants under PPA/CMEC, the gross profit deviation versus market increased to  €160 million,  following hydro volumes 35% below average year and coal benefiting from higher load factors and higher margins.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We'd like to highlight EDP's liberalized activities in Iberia and market position that is characterized by a  significant weight of hydro in generation mix, a long position in sales to final clients versus our own production in  the market, meaning that our energy management gains tend to be reduced in dry years. That was what – exactly  what happened in 2015 with our performance in the liberalized activities being penalized by weak hydro  production with lower gains in energy management.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: As you can see in page 15, our generation and supply Iberia EBITDA adjusted went down 11% or minus €112  million year-on-year. This was a result of av erage generation cost up 22%, immaterial energy management gains  in 2015 and also with the mini-hydro special regime production going down by 45%. This includes also generation  taxes increase by €25 million on high thermal production. This was partially balanced by our electricity supply  business in electricity, in which EBTIDA recovered on lower costs with ancillary services and energy losses.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Looking forward, the recent decline in energy markets reinforces the value of EDP's long position in clients. Not e  that the forward electricity prices in Iberia continue to be better supported than in Northern Europe and the  reasons are that gas is the key marginal technology in Iberia and you also have to consider the existence of specific  power generation taxes in Portugal and Spain. Another important fact in recent market changes is of course the  commodity prices and the coal being more competitive than gas.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Regarding EDP, if you see in page 17, our hedging position regarding forward sales and forward acquisitions for  2016. We have currently forward sales of electricity amounting to 27 terawatts hour, which were sold at an average  selling price of €55 per megawatt hour, so fully in line with 2015 and mostly hedged through residential and SMEs  clients.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In these sales, we have to highlight also the improvement in terms of thermal spreads locked-in versus previous  year, so versus 2015, as we have already closed the sales for respectively 100% of coal sourcing commitment and,  very important, the – around 90% of our gas sourcing commitments for this year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving to the EBITDA performance of our regulated energy networks in Iberia. We can see that our EBITDA in  this division went down 1% or down 4% when adjusted for non-recurrent issues. We're expecting electricity in  Portugal a decline in terms of the rate of return on asset base from 8.26% in 2014 to 6.34% in 2015, which was just  partially compensated by efficiency improvements. In electricity in Spain, slightly higher regulated revenues along  with the increased cost efficiency, while gas in Iberia was marked by the €89 million gain on the disposal of Gas  Murcia, but also the negative impact from the deconsolidation of these assets, which in 2014 have contributed  with EBITDA around €14 million.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Moving now to Brazil. The fourth quarter 2015 was marked by GSF insurance agreement closed in December 2016  and, I would say, the end of the hydro crisis, which leads to a very significant decline in the spot price in Brazil. As  you can see on the left chart, GSF insurance agreement has reduced significantly EDP Brasil risk profile, providing  a significantly lower downside risk in extremely dry years with immaterial impact on upside potential in wet years.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of market environment, the improvement of rainfall in the beginning of 2016 has led hydro reservoirs to  be, today, above 50%. And recently, the government and regulator have announced that the extraordinary tariffs  which were associated to the dry weather to be removed. So, the Brazilian consumers will pay extraordinary tariff,  which is called the yellow flag, during these months – during March 2015. And in April 2016, there will be a green  tariff, meaning that the consumers will not pay any more – any extra cost associated to the abnormal dry  situation.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Demand continues slowing down. It was more negative in the first months of 2016, also benefited by mild weather  and reflecting the slowdown of the macro environment. Inflation forecast for 2016 is now 7 .7%, given that our  activity is essentially inflation linked. These will partially compensate the negative impact from the devaluation of  real versus euro.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Regarding devaluation of regulatory receivables in the Portuguese electric system, we can see that, in 2015, it  showed a tariff surplus of €66 million. So, the first year of tariff surplus in Portugal, leaving the electric system  debt at €5.2 billion. So, better than our previous forecast of €5.3 billion. So, reflecting a clearly good performance  in terms of system debt during 2015. For 2016, the electric system debt is now expected to fall below €5 billion,  despite the weaker demand and lower pool price in the first two months of the year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: In terms of capital gains, we had a different situation in 2014 versus 2015. So, 2014, a significant capital gain of  €118 million. While, in 2015, we have just an impairment in terms of our equity stake in BCP, which has a negative  impact of €22 million. And finally, so, we have lower capitalized financial costs, mostly related with the hydro  projects and the construction in Portugal. And the other line, including the earlier repayment of more expensive  debt, which will have positive impact on future cost of debt and also a decline in terms of gains of tariff deficit  securitization related with the gradual decline in terms of the remuneration of regulatory receivables in Portugal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: I would highlight also that these net profits in 2014 and 2015 include the extraordinary energy tax, so 0.85% on  net expenses in Portugal and we can see a significant increase in terms of net profit attributable to non -controlling  interest, essentially reflecting the increase of net profit both at EDP Brasil and EDPR on gains at our subsidiaries  where we have minority stakes. Overall net profit going down by 12% or adjusted net profit going down 7% year- on-year.
