texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Our EBITDA reached €3.759 billion supported by good performance of energy management, hydro production in  Iberia and the 6% increase in average installed capacity reflecting the commissioning of new hydro and wind  capacity. Our net profits stood also above our provision guidance reaching €961 million benefiting from the  outperformance at EBITDA level but also the 14% decline of interest costs.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: EDPR, contribution to EDP increased 8% as a result of an 11% increase on average installed capacity and wind  volumes 4% below historical levels. So, sometimes we speak about weather and we have seen people have  talked a lot and we have talked a lot about rain in the beginning of the year. But then we have lower wind than  usual and as we see in the last quarter was also weather-wise, was not fantastic. So, it's important to see what  was recurrent and non-recurrent. And clearly, in EDPR, we have this effect.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: But let's take another 30 seconds. Even if you put the recurring net profit at €850 million, a figure that, by the way,  we have mentioned in May, taking into consideration the hydro situation, basically, you would have also 8%  increase on recurring net profit. So, you can pick those numbers, either 8%, either 23%. In any case, both of them  are clearly above the 2% that we have commitment on average to grow between 2016 and 2020 in the business  plan. So, whatever the perspective, whatever the view point, we are clearly above what we have committed last  night.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Outlook for 2017. We continue highly confident that we will continue to deliver financial performance, fully  consistent with the targets established in the business plan. 2016 has proved it very strongly, and we feel  comfortable to do this until 2020. In Iberia, our EBITDA performance will benefit from further growth on activity. In  generation, average hydro capacity will continue to increase with one hydro plant commission in the first quarter  of 2017, and the last one, that still remains under construction expected to be commissioned by the summer.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Although the market environment in the first two months of 2017 marked by low [indiscernible] (15:19) were not  favorable to our portfolio, hydro, we don't anticipate any deviation from our previous expectation for 2017. Let's be  clear, given our strong hedging positions for the year, namely in terms of fuel procurement costs and increasing  EBITDA contribution from our thermal plants. We will continue to also focus on delivering our commitment in  terms of control of operating costs, not only in Iberia but in all the subsidiaries.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: At EDP Renewables level, the expected increase between 7% and 9% of the average installed capacity benefiting  from the capacity additions in 2016 and 2017 will support a sound EBITDA growth. While at the level of EDP  Brazil, the positive impact from Escelsa review will support EBITDA growth in distribution. [indiscernible] (16:15)  terms, we expect a positive impact from the Brazilian real appreciation, taking into consideration the strong  performance versus the euro over the first two months of the year.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, moving to slide 7, and I would like to say on track to deliver the 2020 targets. We are clearly very well on  track. So, I would say we are more advanced than we expected in May in what's concerned delivering those  targets. The delivery of renewables capacity additions continues evolving as scheduled in terms of timing and as  budget in terms of cost supporting and the growth of recurring EBITDA. Note that the growth of 6% in 2016 is the  double of our target, as I already mentioned.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding the leverage, we moved faster than plan regarding the reduction of regulatory receivables, taking  advantage of the market conditions. So, improving significantly our non-adjusted net debt-to-EBITDA ratio and  reducing our absolute net debt figure by 8%. So, I think that nevertheless, the negative forex impact on both  sides, net debt and EBITDA, the anticipation of CapEx in other [indiscernible] (18:08) Safe Harbor growth options  in U.S. that we have been explaining in the area of renewable, and third, some one-off tax and pension plan  payments implied at our adjusted net debt remains still just slightly below for tax, but once again totally consistent  with our 2020 target close to three times.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Thank you, António. I will start with installed capacity of generation and of our portfolio. Our installed capacity has  increased by 4% or 6% on average. Following an increase in terms of the weight of wind and hydro in Portugal,  0.8 and 0.4 gigawatts, respectively, and also the shutdown of one coal plant is Spain.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Regarding electricity production, it increased by 10% following the improvement of battery resources in Iberia and  the new wind and hydro capacity additions and we reached the end of the year with hydro and wind representing  72% of capacity and 65% of the output.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Looking to the market environment in Iberia in 2016, we see that electricity demand went up 0.6%, hydro  production also increased by 42% on a strong growth of hydro production, so 33% above average of the total  average in terms of average hydro a year. These strong hydro volumes justify 21% year-on-year decline in terms  of the average pool price to €40 per megawatt hour in 2016.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to the EBITDA performance of the main business areas, we can see and starting with the generation and  supply in Iberia, we had an EBITDA growth of 13% year-on-year following the referred hydro resources above  average. Our hydro capacity increased 7% and our hydro production in [indiscernible] (22:56) market increased  by 98%.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: But also a good energy management we built with a decline in terms of the average sourcing costs by 23%  following an average generation cost decline of 30%, and the hydro weight in generation mix reaching 43%. We  have also benefited obviously from the long market position on clients with electric production in 2016  representing 56% of electricity volumes sold to clients.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to EDPR, in renewables, EBITDA went up 3%. Nevertheless excluding some gains in 2015 related mostly  with [indiscernible] (24:06) the contribution of EDPR to EDP's adjusted EBITDA increased by 8% based on 11%  average capacity increase, mostly in U.S. but also with some contribution already from Brazil and smaller from  Mexico installed at the end of the year and also a wing production which was 4% below historical average with a  strong decline in terms of wind resources in the fourth quarter 2016.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Finally, in Brazil, also, our recurrent EBITDA in local currency decreased 3%, so here excluding the gains on  assets and acquisitions which were quite significant in 2015 and still relevant in 2016. So, the recurrent 3%  decline includes a strong growth in generation following a strong decline in terms of hydro deficit cost which were  very significant in 2015 but almost immaterial in 2016 and also the Pecém consolidation since May 2015. So, we  have a full contribution of Pecém in 2016.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Distribution, we had a decline given that our operations were penalized by lower demand in the regions of our  concessionary. So, we mainly declined on 5%, which is one of the reasons for higher losses regarding  overcontracted energy problems in distribution.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: So, we have a stronger demand, so 1.5% demand growth. Pool prices are higher and renewable volumes are  lower, meaning that the cost of regulated system with over cost with the renewables and with respect to regime  production, should be lower than assumed for this year, at least that this is indication that we have from the first  two months of the year.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: At the level of EDP balance sheet, regulatory receivables in 2016 went down by €1.5 billion. Big contribution from  Portugal, a decline of €1.2 billion, following the significant amount of sales of regulatory receivables to third  parties and also the referred system tariffs surplus in 2016. We had also the contribution from Brazil, with a  decline of €0.3 billion following energy costs below tariff assumptions in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moving to net investments, our net investments decreased by 30% to €1.2 billion, impact by close to €1 billion of  sales of minority stakes in wind farms in U.S. and in Europe, while our amount of CapEx went up by 10% to close  to €2 billion, reflecting expansion in investments, significant growth in wind due to investments related we've set  with the Safe Harbor clause in U.S. and also a decline in expansion CapEx in hydro in Portugal, following the  stage of conclusion of the works in the four idle plant that we are finishing in 2016 and 2017. Maintenance  investments were mostly related with networks, but included also in 2016 a significant amount of pluri-annual  work in Iberian generation which were concentrated in 2016.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: In terms of financial results breakdown, we have already seen the very strong performance in terms of net interest  cost. We can see also that excluding one-offs, namely the €74 million in 2016 related with the anticipated  payment of more expensive debt, we can see that net financial results went down by 5% following the already  referred 14% decline of net interest cost with a strong positive contribution, which were then partially mitigated by  decline of €64 million on financial revenues related with regulatory receivables, mostly related with the 62%  decline of the amount in balance sheet and also the low returns of these receivables and also a 26% reduction in  terms of the amount of capitalized interest related with the commissioning of the hydro plants in Portugal.

texts.speaker: Miguel Viana
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Other financials include some negative in 2015 and 2016, in 2015 related with the forex and in 2016 relative  essentially with energy derivatives at EDPR level.

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA
texts.text: Moreover, let's get our net debt [indiscernible] (02:55), a 13% decline to €13.9 billion, which led to an adjusted net  debt to recurring EBITDA clear improvement to 3.7 times, even including the adverse impact from low hydro  production. Having said this, we saw once again the value of portfolio diversification with strong  performance of renewable, strong performance in Brazil and overall operating cost and [ph] dividend support  (05:13).

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.speaker: António Luís Guerra Nunes Mexia
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, EDP-Energias de Portugal SA

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The year was impacted by distinctive factors from regulation to prices and from electricity demand  to wind resource. During the year, EDPR has faced and managed the challenges, has shown its  capabilities and competitive advantages. And we ended the period with more visibility for the years  to come.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The second challenge that we faced was the impact of the U.S. economic downturn in our  business. This has affected the demand for new wind projects in U.S, clearly reducing the  opportunities for the next two years. Anticipating structural changes in the market where we  operate, we have built up a flexible business model starting on pipeline optionality and ending on  procurement flexibility. Clearly, we have focused our growth towards the European markets, which  has stable regulatory framework and we have limited our new investment in the U.S. project with  long-term contractual visibility.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Lastly, we also faced the challenge of the wind which is our resource and, consequently, our  [inaudible]. We have always followed a strategy base on the maximization and optimization of the  wind output and have gained a clear competitive advantage on this front. Despite the lower than  expected wind resources in 2010, our average load factor was once again one of the highest of the  wind factor reaching the 29% mark and ahead of our peers speaking on average terms for EBITDA  . This clearly proves the quality of our assets in the selective geographical investigation.  Throughout 2010 despite the challenges, we have shown our fundamental capabilities and I believe  we are better prepared for 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going to the load factor, we reach as Ana mentioned a 29% load factor in 2010, which was again  one of the highest in the wind sector and underlines the superior quality of EDPR’s assets. In  Europe, load factors increased from 26% in 2009 to 27% in 2010 with a strong contribution from  Portugal where we achieved good wind resource from Spain and Poland.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As you can see the realized load factor in Europe was 100% of the expected average or what we  were expecting for this year. In U.S., load factor was stable 32% in 2009 and 32% in 2010 and  through the nine months we are seeing very [inaudible] resource in the United States, we have a  strong recovery in the last quarter of the year in U.S. with strong load factors but, however, we end  up the year with a realized load factor below what were our expectation. All in all, in a year, with  wind resource got on the consolidated level was below the average, we managed through our  portfolio, balanced portfolio with the portfolio effect to reach a stable top-sector of 29%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And electricity output, electricity generated in 2009 increased 32%. This reflect the capacity  additions in 2010 and also the 12 months of operations of the capacity that was installed in 2009  and given the load factors the output increased from 10.9 kilowatt hour to 14.4 kilowatt hour, a 32%  increase.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The split of the production between the frameworks and the regions, 46% in 2010 was sold under  regulated frameworks in Europe – in European markets, 37% under long-term contract in U.S.,  around 16% was sold at spot prices in U.S. This have impact of lower contracts [inaudible] signed  in 2009 and then in the first half of 2010. The contracts that we have signed by the end of the year  didn’t have an impact on the production floor as we expect to have a more beneficial impact in the  future. Nevertheless, 84% of the 2010 electricity production continued to be sold under protective  frameworks as you can see in this slide.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Still I believe that it was as a result of the value of the existing team here – the origination team, our  commercial team in U.S. and the fact that we have comparative project that we were able to be  awarded with this contract by the utilities. So all in all, it’s 141 megawatts signed over the four  quarters or the full year of 2010. So where does this lead us.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As you know this agreement, this Royal Decree also foresee a temporary reduction of the premium  in 2012 with a 35% reduction from [inaudible] around €21 per megawatt hour. But still considering  what is the expected pool price for 2011 and ‘12 and the fact that we are that – these wind assets  are protected by either the pool or the tariff, EDPR does not consider that these premium will  adversely affect both the value of the project as well as the performance over these two years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, all in all, well where do we end up 2010, more than 1,100 megawatts under the Transitory  Regime. So the old regime where we benefit from a €38 per megawatt hour premium,  approximately 2 gigawatts hours of production from these assets are already covered by hedges for  2011, so we get also a visibility on what is going to realized pool price for these assets. And for the  other assets under the Royal Decree is one, 897 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: At this point as I mentioned we have 12% spot exposure and I prefer to have a conservative spend  that we do not consider or we don’t estimate any increase on the spot prices on the merchant  markets in U.S. So pretty much I would consider some power maintenance vis-à-vis 2010 spot  price, but if the portfolio, the existing portfolio that provides us with higher visibility for the full year of  2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In what concerns the new assets or the growth component of EDPR’s equity story, it’s still a growth  story. We are installing an additional 800 up to 900 megawatts, so by the end of the year 2011 we  should be at approximately 7.5 gigas of installed capacity worldwide. We do expect on a TCC basis  that our electricity output should be growing above 20% and not only as a result of the full capacity  in 2010 as well as the [inaudible] 2011 capacity new additions come online.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And finally 2011, we are now starting to benefit from the sourcing the new turbine that we have  contracted 2009 – sorry in 2010. That’s right now getting deployed on the ground and therefore this  is where we are starting to benefit from either lower CapEx per megawatt or even more importantly  the lower CapEx per megawatt hour, which as I mentioned in the beginning, it’s one of the key  issues that brings our project to a more competitive position and therefore it helps us to close this  long-term agreements in United States.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán

texts.text: Furthermore, the decrease of capacity payments is based on the very questionable assumption that Spanish  electricity system is characterized by overcapacity; might be characterized by over-energy, but not overcapacity. Also, this decision, we believe, goes in the opposite direction with respect to that  needed in order to comply with a reasonable return principle.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: In our opinion, measures to be taken should focus on: being non-discriminatory with respect to segments,  technologies and operators; applying the reasonable return criteria to all segments, in particular making sure that  activities with similar risk profiles afford similar returns; applying the reasonable return criteria, particularly, and  first of all, to thermal solar technology avoiding the presently expected rise in subsidies for this technology, which  are both unjustified and unbearable by the system; finance generation extra-cost on non-mainland territories  through the state budget, as prescribed by Royal Decree 6/2009; develop the present distribution remuneration  scheme in order to incentivize improvement of service quality levels and foster investments with special incentives  for smart grade technologies; implement a carbon tax for all sectors, as foreseen by the proposal of the directive  presented by the EU Commission. A number of countries, Ireland, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Sweden, and the  last one being Italy, have already approved the carbon tax in order to promote CO2 emission reduction in all  sectors of the economy, and also finance the deployment of renewable technologies.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: On February 18, the government released the national coal resolution for 2013, which did not recognize the  impacts arising from Law 15/2012, neither the 7% tax generation nor the green cent tax on fuels.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Additionally, on March 29, an amendment of the above mentioned resolution was released setting the obligation  for utilities to buy national coal on a monthly basis. It is worth to mention that the substantial reduction in  thermal gap, experienced during the first quarter, have not allowed these power plants to produce, and therefore  coal stocks are piling up in our power plants.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Presently, power plants burning national coal are obliged to buy coal even if they don't use it. And when  dispatched, they're obliged to operate at a loss. Finally, on March 15, the government approved to send to the  parliament for discussion a bill on non-mainland generation. We believe that the de facto exclusion of Endesa  from future investments in non-mainland generation – see point C in the chart, would be a discrimination, even  more so considering the retroactive remuneration cuts put in place in 2012.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: The transfer of pumped-storage plants to Red Eléctrica that is point D in the chart would remarkably increase the  present, already high, conflict of interest of Red Eléctrica, which exists both in the islands and in the mainland,  would eliminate competition, delay projects and increase costs. Furthermore, it is to be noted that according to  European law, system operators such as Red Eléctrica cannot be involved in any generation activity. Based on our  improved dialogue with the government, we're confident that the bill will be improved in the parliament.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: And let's now review the major regulation developments concerning our Latin American operations. In Argentina,  a new Cost Plus remuneration scheme has been published for generation. Under the scheme, while all fuels will be  purchased by CAMMESA, different compensation elements are envisaged for O&M, fixed cost depending on  actual levels of availability and one additional remuneration that will partially go to a trust that is a commission to  finance new projects. We preliminarily estimate an additional yearly margin improvement of approximately $80  million.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Brazil, distribution companies were involuntarily exposed to the wholesale electricity market, while prices were  increases – increasing as a consequence of the drought. The government has enacted Presidential Decree 7,945  aiming at partially compensate distribution companies for the above extra costs. The rest of the extra cost will be  recovered through additional government payments and/or specific tariff revisions. Regarding the annual tariff  adjustments in Ampla and Coelce, the process ended with the VAD – with VAD increases of 7.8% and 5.5%,  respectively.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Thank you, Andrea, and good morning, everyone. Now, let's turn to our results for Spain and Portugal. I would  like to start mentioning the main factors behind the first quarter 2013 results in Spain. First, Endesa's regulated  business margin, which includes our operations in non-mainland systems, were – was negatively affected by the  regulatory measures taken in 2012 and in the first months of 2013. On the other hand, Endesa's mainland  generation output significantly fell by 24% mainly explained by the 58% thermal output decrease, as a result of the  thermal gap drop during the quarter. On the contrary, Endesa's hydro production sharply increased to close to 3  terawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Finally, it is worth mentioning that despite the mounting competitive pressure, Endesa has maintained its  leadership in electricity supply with 37.5% share in the ordinary regime electricity generation in mainland Spain  with 36% market share. Endesa remains as the second gas supplier with a 15% market share.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: On the other hand, first quarter registered an exceptional contribution from hydro and wind output, which jointly  represented more than 40% of the total system output.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: The coexistence of the aforementioned factors translated into a negative thermal gap, the lowest in last five years,  and a sharp decrease of pool power prices, particularly in March, when a considerable number for our coal price  are zero. This scenario has somehow helped us to partially mitigate the effect of Law 15/2012, nevertheless, our  energy management budget always targeting the stability of our liberalized business results. In that sense, we  hedged in the forward markets a significant part of our electricity sales that are now backed with our own  production, therefore benefiting only limited terms of the very low pool prices. Finally, we think that this business  condition and the poor result cannot be extended through the rest of the year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Fixed cost decreased by 6%, helping in reaching €971 million EBITDA, 7% less than in 2012. Amortization and  depreciation charges grew by €84 million, mainly as a consequence of the write-off difference in CO2 and CDMs  in Q1 2013 versus Q1 2012. Therefore, EBIT decreased by 23% to €505 million.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: As mentioned before, gross margin in Spain decreased by 7% to €1.476 billion. Margin for the liberalized business  decreased by 10% affected by lower sales to final customers, the impact of Law 15/2012 on our generation output,  the lack of recognition of Law 15/2012 taxes on national coal and lower last resort tariff margin.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: These negative effects were partially compensated by a better energy mix. Regarding the regulated business,  margin decreased by 5%, mainly impacted by the regulatory measures in the non-mainland system.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving now to slide number 14. Generation output in mainland Spain amounted to 13.4 terawatt hour, a 24%  decrease, mainly due to a 58% and 7% drop in thermal and nuclear output, respectively, despite doubling the  hydro output during the period. Thermal output fell as a consequence of the already mentioned narrowing of the  thermal gap, while nuclear output decrease is explained by the closure of Garoña and planned outages in Almaraz  power plants.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: All in all, hydro and nuclear generation stood at 71% of Endesa mainland output versus 47% in 2012. Endesa's  mainland output – moving to gross margin sources in the period, Endesa's mainland output stood at 13 terawatt  hour with an average unit fuel cost of €27 megawatt hour, increasing from €26 megawatt hour in 2012, while  thermal output was significantly higher. This increase in unit fuel cost is explained by the effect of Law 15/2012.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Energy acquired in the pool amounted to 7 terawatt hour with an average unit cost of €50 megawatt hour, a slight  decrease compared to the €52 in 2012. As already commented, the unit purchase cost of energy in 2013 is affected  by the settlement of the four contracts. 7 terawatt hour were acquired through CESUR auctions to last – to supply  last resort customers.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Endesa was able to increase average unit – electricity unitary revenues to €64 megawatt hour from €62 megawatt  hour in 2012. Finally, Endesa sold 7 terawatt hour to clients under the last resort tariff. All in all, this resulted in a  2% decrease in the unitary electricity margin over 2012.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Brazil, EBITDA suffered a 24% drop, mainly explained by expensive energy purchases in the distribution  business. That could not be fully recovered through the current regulatory framework. Additionally, the drought is  affecting the country, increasing the thermal production and lowering generation margins.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Argentina and despite Endesa's regulatory announcement intended to improve the sustainability of the  electricity sector in the country, EBITDA has fallen especially in distribution business, reaching negative results  because of higher fixed costs following inflation in the country.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Chile, the group is experimenting a recovery in generation business. Despite the persistent drought that was  affected the country for the last years, Endesa has been able to improve margins supported by the entry to  operation in the second half of 2012 of the new coal-fired plant, Bocamina II, the reduction of the marginal cost in  the systems and lower fuel costs linked to gas purchases. All in all, EBITDA increased by 7%.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving to the results in Chile. During the first quarter and despite the lower hydro output linked to the persistent  drought affecting the country, generation output remained flat, thanks to the higher thermal output of the new  coal-fired plant Bocamina II, which started commercial operation in October 2012. Distribution sales rose 2% to  3.2 terawatt hour explained by the stable demand registered in Santiago, Chilectra's concessionaires supported by  the activities of residential and commercial customers.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Generation EBITDA increased 13% to €95 million, explained by both operational and one-off effects. Operating  effects during the period was mainly the lower fuel costs and better production mix due to the entrance of our  coal-fired plant in Bocamina II in the last quarter of 2012.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Additionally, lower cost of gas impacted in the margin of our CCGT's facilities. During the first quarter of 2012,  the positive effect of €46 million was recognized due to a favorable settlement with our client, CMPC. Stripping  out this effect, EBITDA would have increased by a remarkable 150%. Unit generation margin reached €27.7  megawatt hour, 11% higher when compared to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now move to Brazil. Generation volumes rose sharply by 28% to 1.2 terawatt hour, thanks to higher thermal  dispatch in Fortaleza, offsetting lower hydro generation due to the drought affecting the country. Distribution  sales grew by 6% to 4.8 terawatt hours, mainly due to the 10% increase in Coelce plant boosted by higher energy  consumption in the hydro sector for pumping storage due to the lack of rains. Additionally, in Ampla, sales  volume grew 2% associated with higher temperatures.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Generation EBITDA decreased 7% to €50 million due to the lower hydro output. Unit generation margin reached  €32.2 megawatt hour, 4% lower when compared to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: EBITDA for distribution business in the same quarter of 2013 reached €142 million, representing a decrease of  30% over the same period of 2012. This decrease is due to the extra cost incurred by the distributors resulting  from thermal generation dispatch and contractual exposure in the spot market, which could not immediately be  compensated by the mechanisms established by the Presidential Decree 7,945 of 2013.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Colombia, generation output was in line with the first quarter 2013, reaching 3 terawatt hour. During the  quarter, rainfalls decreased impacting hydro generation. This effect was partially compensated by higher thermal  dispatch. Distribution sales volume decreased 1% to 2 terawatt hour, explained by the slowdown in construction  sector and seasonality.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Generation EBITDA increased 10% to €150 million, thanks to higher price in spot market due to the lower  hydrology, partially offset by higher fuel compensation, energy purchases. Unit margin reached €42 megawatt  hour, 7% higher when compared to first quarter 2012.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving on to Peru. Energy output decreased 7% reaching 2.2 terawatt hour explained by lower thermal dispatch  from CCGTs and hydro output. Distribution sales grew 2% to 1.6 terawatt hour, thanks to the stable demand  registered in Lima. The lower performance compared to the last quarter when demand grew by 5% on average  responds to the lower energy consumption of the regulation customer – the regulated customers in the  construction area, differing from the rest of country, where energy demand stays strong over 5% due to the  industrial developments, especially in the mining sector.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Generation EBITDA decreased 5% to €63 million, mainly due to the higher fuel cost in thermal facilities.  Additionally, €3 million were booked last year regarding Urgency (sic) [Emergency] Decree 049 while in 2013,  this factor amounted to €0.4 million. Unit margin increased 1% to €31.1 MWh.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Finally, let's take a look at Argentina. Generation business experienced a 9% reduction in energy output, 3.9  terawatt hour, due to lower dispatch from thermal facilities in Spain by outages and lower hydrology. The  slowdown in the Argentinean economies was reflected in low energy demand growth. This represented a decrease  with sales of 3% to 3.6 terawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: General Manager-Economical Financial, Endesa SA
texts.text: Generation EBITDA does not include yet the positive impact of the new regulatory framework adopted for power  generation based on Cost Plus scheme that includes, among other things, a scheme to pay the fixed and variable  costs and ensuring a certain return on investments.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: The exceptional weather conditions, with hydro peaking at record levels, cannot be extrapolated to the rest of the  year. Although we expect that both prices and demand should increase throughout the year, outlook for 2013  remains challenging in Spain.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Latin America, unfavorable hydro conditions in Brazil and Chile have driven our results in the region, together  with the fact that no impact from recent positive regulatory development in Argentina were recorded in the  quarter. Finally, I would like to remark the successful closing of the Enersis capital increase consolidating the  group investment platform in Latin America.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Thank you, David. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining us today. I would like start, as  usual, by taking a look at market context in first quarter 2014. Demand in mainland Spain, adjusted for working  days and temperature effects, declined by 0.6%, while adjusted demand in Endesa's distribution area declined by  1% mostly due to a decrease in the Residential segment.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Regarding electricity prices in Spain, the exceptionally high hydro contribution into the system with a 40%  increase over the quarter and to a lower extent the high wind generation levels are the main reasons for the 40%  decrease in pool prices €24.3 per megawatt hour. Finally, in Chile, wholesale prices increased by 16% to $166 per  megawatt hour as a consequence of the lower thermal output from coal in our Bocamina II power plant and also  lower CCGT output as a result of maintenance works, which resulted in a higher contribution of diesel as marginal  price setting technology.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: During first quarter 2014, Endesa results were negatively affected by different non-recurring effects. In Spain, you  already know, regulatory measures impacted some €390 million and were partially compensated by the favorable  market conditions due to the exceptional hydro output and by a number of managerial actions including a further  reduction in costs. In LatAm, several factors, on top of the currency effect, have affected the quarter; further  analysis in the next chart.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Overall, EBITDA decreased by 10% to €1.5 billion. In Spain, EBITDA  remained basically flat, mainly thanks to the  peculiar weather conditions and the already mentioned managerial actions that substantially compensated the  negative impact from regulatory measures.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: EBITDA in Latin America was €546 million. That is 22% lower than in the first quarter 2013. The main reasons  behind this drop are the translation currency effect, the remarkable increase in wholesale electricity prices due to  the persistent drought in Chile that is affecting our supply commitment in that country considering the stoppage  of Bocamina II, also and costs related to the heat wave experienced in Argentina. Also, for this, further detail is  provided in the following slide.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: On slide number 5 now, let me explain in greater detail some of the exceptional effects of the first quart er in order  to get a better understanding of how would look more normalized operating margin levels. And starting with  Spain and Portugal, the most visible positive one-off contribution comes from the exceptional hydro conditions  registered in the quarter, where system hydro output increased by 40%. On second and third quarters usually –  the second and the third quarters usually present a lower rainfall, and therefore the first quarter hydro  contribution to the system should not be a sustainable benchmark for the full year.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: While the significant currency translation effect is not necessarily to be regarded as a recurring one, the outlook  concerning the drought in Chile is improving where substantial rainfall has already taken place and the El Niño  seems to be consolidating. And concerning Argentina, progress is being made towards a remuneration framework  affording a higher investment level and a suitable coverage of operating costs.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving now to slide number 7 , let's have a quick update of regulation in Latin Ame rica. In Chile, the new  government led by Mrs. Bachelet has established six energy policy pillars: that is, strengthening of the role of the  state; reorganization of land use; technological development, especially in renewable energy; energy efficiency;  increase of competition; and acceleration of interconnection projects.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Furthermore, in Chile, a tax bill is being discussed in the Congress. Major changes would include a gradual  increase until 2017 of the advance payment that companies make concerning the tax paid by shareholders from  20% to 35%; the disappearance of the so-called FUT, the Fondo de Utilidades Tributarias; the introduction of a  new emission tax with potential implications after 2017 .

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Brazil, non-voluntary exposure of distribution companies to high spot energy prices continued. To solve the  situation, the government approved Decree 8,221 on 1st of April which authorizes the Brazilian Chamber of  Commerce for Electricity, the CCEE, to refund the associated extra costs using proceeds obtained  from market  financing.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving to the next chart, number 9. On April 22, 2014, Endesa Chile and Southern Cross completed the purchase  agreement by which Endesa Chile acquired the remaining 50% stake in the GasAtacama Holding. Let  me remind  you that GasAtacama operates a 7 81 -megawatt CCGT in the SING, that is the Sistema Interconectado del Norte  Grande, and owns the gas pipelines of Mejillones-Taltal and of Atacama connecting Chile and Argentina.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: As a result of this transaction, Endesa Chile has taken total control of the company, starting full consolidation on  May 1, 2014. A number of synergies become now possible together with the possibility for GasAtacama to become  a competitive and environmentally sound base energy supplier, burning natural gas in a strong demand market.  The total price of the deal was $309 million or approximately €224 million. Based on full year 2013 results, the  enterprise value to EBITDA multiple achieves the very attractive level shown on the chart.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: And let me now, on chart number 10, summarize few other relevant events that took place during the period.  Endesa signed a new agreement with Cheniere for the supply of 2 bcm of LNG starting in 2018 for a 20 -year  period, which can be extended for an additional 10-year period. The competitive price will be linked to the Henry  Hub Reference Index which will improve our risk diversification.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: In addition, the contract provides high degrees of flexibility both in terms of destination and use of the gas. Last,  but not least, this transaction allows an improvement of the diversification also of the gas sourcing areas in our  portfolio.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Latin America, the final investment decision of the Los Condores hydro project was taken by Endesa's Board of  Directors for an estimated amount of $661 million. That is approximately €480 million. This project is expected to  come on stream by year-end 2018.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Finally, let me update you on the Bocamina II coal power plant in Chile. This facility was awarded a resolution of  environmental qualification back in August 2007 based on an output of 350 megawatts, while an update of such a  resolution is being sought mainly to adjust it to a 37 0 megawatt output. Nevertheless, the facility has been always  operated within the 350 megawatt limit and has always complied with the corresponding original emission  thresholds.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Nevertheless, on December 17, 2013, Bocamina II was temporarily shut down following a Concepción court order  and remains non-operative as of today. Needless to say, this facility is critical also to ensure security of supply and  to keep prices at reasonable levels in the Chilean SIC system. This has been highlighted by CDEC, the Chilean  system grid operator, in a recent report which warns of a very tight energy situation during the co ming months of  May, June and July that will bring about the dispatch of very high variable cost power plants to meet demand.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Thank you, Andrea, and good morning, everyone. I would like to start by mentioning the main factors behind the  first quarter 2014 results in Spain and Portugal. First of all, Endesa's regulated and liberalized business margin  were negatively affected by the regulatory impact of Royal Decree Law 9/2013. That had no effect in Q1 2013.  Nevertheless, the market condition that prevailed in Q1 2014 [ph] i.e.(26:19) exceptional hydro and wind output  resulting in extremely low pool prices helped us to mitigate part of the negative impact from the regulatory  measures.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Endesa's mainland generation output fell by 8%, mainly explained by the 33% thermal output decrease as a result  of previously indicated the thermal gap drop experienced during the period. Demand performance also  contributed to this thermal gap deterioration. All in all, Endesa's hydro production that already experienced high  increase in Q1 2013, increase of 169%, further increased this year by 5% or 2.8 terawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving now to the income statement for Spain and Portugal, revenues amounted to €5.4 billion, showing 5%  decrease, mainly driven by the regulatory measures from Royal Decree Law 9/2013 and the lower selling price to  liberalize customers. Variable costs also decreased by 5%, mainly explained by lower output and better energy mix  due to higher hydro and lower thermal output and significant lower energy purchase costs. As a consequence,  gross margin decreased by 4% to €1.4 billion.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: As previously commented, fixed cost declined by 9%, resulting in an almost flat EBITDA of €953 million. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Generation output in Spain amounted to 12 terawatt hours, an 8% decrease mainly due to the reduction of the  thermal gap, with hydro and nuclear output jointly increasing by 3% during the period. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Endesa's average unit fuel cost stood at €27/megawatt hour, decreasing from €28/megawatt hour in Q1 2013 due  to better generation mix. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Planned and unplanned outages in thermal plants, mainly in Chile and Argentina, could not be fully offset by the  increase in hydro output due to the slightly better hydro availability in Chile together with Generandes higher  dispatch resulting from improved condition in the Parnaiba river in Brazil. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Argentina, our distribution business carries over the negative effect of the heat wave suffered at the end of last  year. As a consequence, our subsidiary had to book indemnities as well as higher cost not recurrent by nature.  First quarter figures results had been substantially affected by depreciation of local currency against the euro with  a total impact of €7 9 million.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moreover, in Colombia, we have finished the first 111 megawatt tranche of the [ph] hydropower in Brazil, (33:28)  Salaco, which will have a total incremental capacity of 145 megawatts by the year -end. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving to the Latin America, income statement in the first quarter of 2014, revenues decreased by 12% to €2.1  billion due to some extraordinary effects such as the reduction in Chile, electricity generation result of the  persistent drought along with the lower thermal output due to the stoppage of Bocamina II power station, Latin  America currency weakness, and the one-off effects of Argentina heat wave that could not be offset by the good  performance of Brazil – of Colombia, and Brazil generation based on high output and better margins.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Gross margin, therefore, decreased 18% to €0.9 billion due to the higher variable cost, as a consequence of the  higher energy purchase costs booked mainly in Chile and Brazil. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving to the results in Chile, during first quarter, lower thermal output due to Bocamina II shutdown and some  CCGT's planned outages could not be compensated by marginally improved hydro conditions. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now move to Brazil. Generation output grew by 11% to 1.4 terawatt hours, driven by higher hydro volumes  from Cachoeira Dourada, as consequence of better conditions at Parnaíba river. These exceptional hydro  conditions at Cachoeira cannot be extended to the whole country since reservoir levels have reached historical  minimum levels as a consequence of the persistent drought.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Distribution sales grew by 8% to 5.1 terawatt hours, mainly due to higher volumes in Ampla concession area  where sales grew by 11% due to the record high in temperatures. Generation EBITDA increased 44% to €7 2  million due to higher selling prices and higher hydro output in Cachoeira that more than compensated the higher  cost of energy purchases.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: During this quarter, distribution companies have been continuing to incurring extra cost as a result of the drought  which provoked an involuntary exposure to the spot market. As Andrea mentioned before, the Brazilian  government has put in place new mechanisms to compensate this extra cost amounted to total €188 million. Out  of this amount, only €13 million will be cashed in next year according to regulation. Unit distribution margin  reached €29.8 megawatt hour, 30% lower when compared to the previous yea r. Foreign exchange impact  contributed negatively with €43 million to EBITDA. And finally, Brazil-Argentina interconnection line had an  EBITDA of €15 million.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Colombia, generation output has fallen 1%, reaching 2.9 terawatt hours. Better production did  not compensate  the lower thermal dispatch. Distribution sales increased 3% to 2 terawatt hours, below the country demand  increase of 4.9% due to lower prices of industrial and manufacturing activities in our concession area. Generation  EBITDA decreased 13% to €130 million. Better energy mix did not offset the foreign exchange impact amounting  to €21 million. Unit margin decreased to €38 megawatt hour, 9% lower compared to previous year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving on to Peru, energy output decreased 3%, reaching 2.2 terawatt hours, explained by lower hydro dispatch  due to an unplanned outage in our Chimay  power plant, partially compensated by higher output from our fuel gas  and energy plants. Distribution sales grew 4% to 1.7  terawatt hours due to seasonal effects and the good  performance of industrial and commercial segments present in our concession area .

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Finally, let's take a look at Argentina. Generation business experienced a 14% decrease in energy output to 3.4  terawatt hour, slight recovery of hydro and fuel gas generation could not offset lower dispatch from thermal  facilities, namely our Costanera CCGT as a result of a machine failure. Generation EBITDA includes a positive  impact of the new regulatory framework for power generation adopted in March 2013 based on Resolution 95, as  well as the higher revenues resulting from the availability contract of Costanera with [ph] Camex (43:46).

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: These effects resulted in an EBITDA increase of 46% over 2013, reaching €19 million with unit generation margin  reaching €9.2 megawatt hour, 33% higher when compared to last year. Distribution EBITDA was mainly driven by  the negative consequences of the heat wave suffered in the last month of 2013, which resulted in a number of one - off costs such as customer compensation and quality penalties for service interruption, as well as higher fixed cost  following the inflation that were not passed on into tariff.

file: ELE - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 7May2015 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Firstly, as we already anticipated in the last presentation, first quarter of 2015 brought about a change in demand  trends based initially on the recovery of industrial performance followed by a strong demand hike on the  residential segment, although this is mainly explained by the comparison with the milder weather condition of  previous year.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Additionally, this first quarter was marked by the normalization of the exceptional hydro contribution recorded  during the first semester of 2014. The swift recovery of wholesale electricity prices since June 2014 has had  continuity during 2015 when the average cumulative price stood at €47 .4 per megawatt hour, a 94% increase year- on-year.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It is also worth noting the strong price signal set by the balance 2015 forward price for the rest of the year, with a  price level of €50 per megawatt hour, higher than the current 2016 forward curve electricity price.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving now to the regulatory update; let me start by reviewing the latest news concerning the domes tic coal  regulatory framework. The new ministerial order draft foresees a capacity scheme consisting in a fix payment of  €7 2,000 per megawatt linked to the implementation of investments in order to comply with the European  Industrial Emissions Directive, which set October 2015 as the deadline when operators should decide to carry out  this investment.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We firmly believe that domestic coal is a competitive generation technology and crucial to guarantee security of  supply, and therefore, adequate capacity payment are essential. In our opinion, the initial amount proposed are  insufficient to carry out the required IED investments. Considering the current market and regulatory condition,  cash flow generation of this plan is close to zero.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Concerning non-mainland generation, let me inform you that the draft Royal Decree has been already submitted  for approval with no major changes to the state council. According to the pending administrative procedure, the  Royal Decree could be enforced in the near future.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In late March, a pending development of Law 15/2012 on hydro taxes was approved through Royal Decree  198/2015. According to this Royal Decree, the levy will not apply to inter-community river basins. Revenues will  be allocated to environmental usage, but the state budget will earmark an equivalent amount to the tariff deficit  reduction in accordance with the aforementioned Law 15/2012.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: All-in-all, no relevant impact is expected since estimated amounts are already being accrued according to previous  drafting. Concerning expected plant closures, the CNMC granted the authorization for the closure and dismantling  of our Foix fuel-gas plant in April. Similar authorizations have been requested for Compostilla 2 coal plant and  Colon CCGT and are currently awaiting approval.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Regarding the latter, should the closure request be approved, we will assess all potential options. Pending  regulatory chapters including distribution explicit RAB, mothballing and capacity payments, supply and  distributed generation Royal Decrees are still in progress.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This settlement includes among other things the application of a resolution that sets the final fuel cost reference  for 2014 in the non-mainland system. When it comes to 2015, the CNMC has released settlement number 2 of year  2015, which shows a temporary imbalance of €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Having said this, revenues amounted to €5.5 billion in line with the first quarter of 2014 while variable costs  decreased by 2%. All-in-all, gross margin grew 4% to €1.460 billion. This takes into account higher other  operating results amounting to approximately €130 million, mainly stemming from the swap of our CO2 rights  portfolio, which amounted to €173 million that will be explained in detail later on as well as the recognition of Law  15/2012 taxes in non-mainland systems.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As a result, EBITDA increased by 5% to €952 million. Amortization charges decreased by 18%, mainly due to the  useful life extension of our nuke and CCGTs facilities. EBIT amounted to €628 million, a remarkable 22% increase  quarter-on-quarter.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On slide 11, we summarized the main highlights describing our business performance during the period. Key  financial indicators performed remarkably. Reported EBITDA increased by 5%, while EBIT went up by 22%. Our  regulated business results have been positively impacted by the recognition of taxes from Law 15/2012 in non - mainland generation. On the other hand, and as a consequence of the normalization of the exceptional hydro  situation seen during last year's first half, coupled with the sustained demand increase, thermal gap doubled.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the liberalized business, the expected margin normalization was more than offset by the combined effect of the  demand recovery consolidation and higher other operating results that mainly relate to the CO2 swap transaction.  Finally, stripping out all non-recurring effects on personnel costs, fixed costs remained flat.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving now to the EBITDA split by business line, overall, EBITDA grew by 5% to €952 million, mainly due to the  CO2 transaction in the generation and supply business line that more than compensated the negative effects  coming from the normalized hydro condition in first quarter 2015, together with the positive performance in non - mainland generation due to the recognition of Law of 15/2012 taxes partially offset by previous year's  regularization and non-recurring items.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The CO2 transaction that was positively impacted by liberalized business results by €173 million is a consequence  of the value recognition arising from a swap transaction of CERs and ERUs that we had in our portfolio for new  EUAs. This figure is the difference of the fair value of ERUs and CERs at the date of the operation, and the EUAs  at March 31, 2015. This transaction is envisaged in the European legislation and the mentioned EUAs portfolio  will be sold during the next few months. Regarding distribution business, EBITDA is basically stable as foreseen  for the rest of 2015.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the other hand and partially mitigating this positive effects, I would like to highlight the negative impact  arising from the normalized hydro and wind conditions in first quarter 2015 compared with exceptionally good  condition in first quarter 2014 for these two technologies. This together with the demand increase has led to an  increase in thermal gap, which in our case resulted in higher fuel costs, higher energy purchase costs and higher  Law 15/2012 taxes.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving now to slide number 16, generation output in mainland Spain amounted to 15.1 terawatt hours, 22% more  than first quarter 2014. Let me underline again the improvement in the demand trend along with the sharp  increase of the thermal gap in the first quarter of 2015. Hydro and nuclear generation represented 63% of  Endesa's mainland output versus 79% in the same period of last year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Endesa's average unit fuel costs increased by – to €33 megawatt hour from €29 megawatt hour in first quarter  2014, while pool purchase volumes amounted to 5 terawatt hours with an average unit cost of €52 megawatt hour.  This energy purchase cost includes higher number of peak hours at a higher price compared to first quarter 2014.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We acquired 6 terawatt hour to supply those customers opting for the small customer voluntary price tariff.  Overall, the weighted average unit variable cost increased to €42 megawatt hour from €35 megawatt hour in first  quarter 2014. Gross electricity sales amounted to 26 terawatt hour. Endesa sold 20 terawatt hour to liberalized  customers maintaining its leadership position in supply.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Unitary revenues stood at €63 megawatt hour from €60 megawatt hour last year, mainly due to high underlying  selling price. All-in-all, the combined effect is an 18% decrease in the unitary electricity margin year-over-year.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Paolo. Now, let me sum up some final remarks on Endesa's performance in first quarter 2015.  Regulated business results have been positively affected by the third draft Royal Decree on non-mainland  generation that recognize Law 15/2012 taxes, while the distribution business has shown a stable result. On the  other hand, the liberalized business has delivered sound results despite the challenging weather and market  conditions compared to those in first quarter 2014.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This was possible, thanks to sound managerial actions we have deployed, of which the CO2 one -off transaction is  an important one. In addition, and stripping out non-recurring effects, the company has achieved flat fix ed cost  during first quarter 2015 compared with the same period of last year. Endesa will keep focusing on fixed cost  containment and reduction going forward.

texts.speaker: José Damián Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you, José and good evening, everyone. I would like to start by briefly commenting the main highlights of  our P&L. Thanks to the good  performance of the liberalized business and the efficiency plans.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Net financial expenses decreased by 39%, mainly explained by lower average debt and lower cost of debt. The  above mentioned CO2 adjustment accounts for €125 million, a net income level, which translates into a 10%  increase. As for CapEx is concerned, its growth is evenly split between generation and distribution, including  investments in the Litoral power plant in order to adapt it to European environmental directive, as well as  acceleration of CapEx related to deployment of smart meters.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the generation and supply business, out of €212 million EBITDA decreased quarter-on-quarter, there are  around €200 million non-recurring items, being the €173 million related with the CO2 swap transaction,  transaction the most important one. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Last, but not least, fixed costs in the generation and supply business are also impacted by around €20 million  increase in operation and maintenance costs, related to the business as usual activities, such as the program  refueling and the revision stoppage of Almaraz Nuclear Power Plant and higher cost in supply division related to  the business development, Galp integration added value services expansion, international activity expansion. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Also in relation to the gas business, let me underline the 9% increase in total volumes, mainly driven by  international sales in France and Portugal, the latter being a strategic line contained in the targets updated back in  November 2015. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition, margin from value-added services, one of our growing tools continue to grow at a good pace with  overall margin of €21 million, 11% above 2015. Focusing on this last topic, and moving to slide number 15. We show how our energy  management strategy has resulted in an 11% increase in the electricity unitary margin.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the left hand side of this slide, you can see the sources used to cover 21.2 terawatt hour of electricity sales in  first quarter 2016. Close to 60% of them were covered with our own generation versus almost 75% last year, while  the remaining 40% was produced versus 25% last year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the right hand side picture you can find the evolution and breakdown of unitary values, making up the  electricity margin. This good performance in the energy management proves once again the  resilience of our margins in the liberalized business.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And now, I will hand over to José Bogas for the final chapter of this presentation.  José Damián Bogas Gálvez  Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director  Thank you, Paolo. Before I summarize this presentation, allow me to briefly make three points, that I shared with  Endesa's shareholders at our Annual General Meeting two weeks ago. The first is that Endesa fully backs the  Spanish Government's commitment at the COP21 Summit in Paris to drastically reduce CO2 emissions and will be  at the forefront of the electrification of Spanish energy sector.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The second is that we believe that environmentally efficient and profitable energy plan should continue to operate  during the transition phase, in order to ease the consolidation of a carbon-free economy. The third point is that  Endesa has been extremely responsive to the challenges of energy poverty. We have subsidized families in  difficulties and we have presented a comprehensive plan to address this problem to the government.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Now, moving to slide 21. Allow me to go through some final remarks on Endesa's performance in the first quarter  of 2016. The regulated businesses performed as expected providing a stable result. Out of the total gross margin  and EBITDA figures, they contributed with 57% and 70% respectively. Secondly, net of the CO2 swap transaction  of last year, liberalized business show very good results, supported by our successful energy management strategy  we started to implement a long time ago. In terms of fixed costs, they remained flat underpinned by efficiency  plans. All-in-all, first quarter results show us that Endesa is well on track to meet the target communicated to the  market.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now move to chart number four, as I mentioned already these results were affected by a challenging  environment and a number of non-recurring issues. In fact based on the pretty sharp increases in prices recorded in the second half of 2010, we should  now consider that most of the reduction in margins has materialized and therefore in the second half of the year  we should be recording spreads in line with the first half of 2011.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: During the period there has also been an increase in generation cost due to a higher contribution from thermal  sources, due to a more normalized hydro production and lower contribution from our nuclear fleet as a  consequence of plant fuel recharges. texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Regarding the events affecting the Latin American business it is important to our client the severe drought in  Chile together with a delay in Bocamina II commercial operation date as a result of the earthquake that this  country faced last year. All in all the draught in Chile affected our Chilean operations in generation by €136 million at EBITDA level, as  Paolo will explain later on. We would also draw your attention to the dollar evolution against the euro over the last  18 months. The depreciation of the dollar in the first semester had a negative impact in our dollarized business for  the first time in several quarters. And lastly we would like recall the one-off effect in Colombia, already mentioned  recorded in the first quarter where we have fully recognized a net worth tax that amounts to €109 million that will  be paid in eight six-month installments between 2011 and 2014.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán

texts.text: The application of the reasonable return criteria for all electrical segments as clearly established by the Supreme  Court, starting with thermal solar technologies and making sure that activities with similar risk profile afford  similar returns. texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving to slide number 3, you can now find the main financial figures of the period. As just commented on,  EBITDA increase by 12% while net income by 15% compared with first half 2017. It has been positively driven by the favorable  hydrologic evolution in Spain and by the better conditions in the gas market. Also, the regulated business  benefited from the consolidation of the remuneration update in distribution. Finally, net debt increased by 19%  during first half to €5.9 billion mainly driven by the interim dividend paid last January that amounted to €741  million.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Before analyzing the operative and financial performance of the period, let me briefly touch upon the evolutional  growth, the key pillars of our 2018-2020 strategic plan. texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Last June, the European Union Council agreed to adopt a new set of ambitious energy target to increase  renewable contribution from the former 27% to 32% of total final energy consumption in 2030 to achieve energy  efficiencies of 32.5% versus former 27%, and finally to boost interconnection up to 15% of total capacity. Our  company is clearly committed to the above target.

texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: On the right-hand side of the slide, you can see that Endesa's strategic vision for Spain presented in our business  plan update is fully aligned or even [ph] assist (00:03:58) European Union target while enable us to comply  beyond 2030 milestone. To fulfill this decarbonization target, Spain will need to add more than 46 gigawatts of  new renewable capacity and boost demand of electrification. Moreover, nuclear, thermal, and hydro, together with  interconnection capacity will have to play a key role to ensure security of supply in this period.

texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Committed to energy transition and decarbonization target, we continue to pursue and deliver growth, both  organic and inorganic, in renewable capacity and network as I will detail in the coming slide. In line with the business plan guidance on efficiency, different  methods put in place over the last few years led to an absorption of inflation and growth effects in fixed costs.

texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: And last but not least, we are focused on creating value for our stakeholder not only with a more than sound total  shareholder return of 16% during 2018 after a dividend payment of €1.382 per share against 2017 result, but also  with several initiative aimed to contribute to United Nations Sustainable Development goals.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Regarding network, we continue our grid automation process with 97% of the smart meter deployed so far,  improving our loss reduction during the period by 3%.

texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: When it comes to asset, our extensive digital metering plan, grid automation boost through a smart remote  controlled devices in our network, and large scale batteries in generation [ph] operation (00:08:40) according to  plan. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Now, focusing on [indiscernible] (00:10:08) optimization, the efficiency programs are implemented across all  business lines.
