texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Now, moving on to slide 9, I would like to comment on the market context in Iberia for the period of this financial  report. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: The unitary integrated margin in the electricity business have shown positive evolution, increasing by 19% to  €25.4 per megawatt hour, benefiting mainly from a higher unitary revenue, plus 7.3% to €64.5 per megawatt hour  and a positive contribution of the [ph] strong (00:16:30) position following a different hedging strategy carried out  for 2018. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: As far as the year 2019 is concerned, we have hedged around 52% of our estimated output at an average all-in  price of around €74 per megawatt hour. texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Regarding the gas business in slide number 12, the recovery of market condition has resulted in an improvement  of the gas margins. Sales had decreased slightly by 2% mainly due to the milder temperatures of the second  quarter that affected residential demand in Spain. This was partially offset by higher sales to wholesale business  driven by international demand.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Endesa SA

texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Luca. Now, I would like to conclude with some final comments on Endesa's performance during  the first quarter semester. texts.speaker: José D. Bogas Gálvez
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Endesa SA
texts.text: The strong EBITDA evolution supported by the sound performance of the liberalized business based on the  proven flexibility and resilience of our integrated energy management strategy and the positive contribution of our  distribution business have been, once again, the main factor of the 12% increase in reported EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: On October 11th, Royal Decree 1307/2011 was published, which introduces the possibility of deficit private  placements among investors. After a 9.8% average increase of the last resort tariff in  January, followed by a 7.6% average increase of the excess tariff in April, on October 1, 2011, we saw a freeze in the  last resort tariff for the last quarter of 2011 with a 12% reduction in the TPA component merely in order to offset  the increase in the energy component. texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: As the National Energy Commission has stated in its official report on the fourth quarter tariff proposal, this  decision represents, "an improper use of the TPA component to compensate for the changes in the energy  component, which endangers the system's sustainability." As a consequence, the industry needs to appeal this  tariff resolution at the Supreme Court. In order to radically solve the tariff deficit issue, a number of measures are  to be implemented. Obviously, a gradual increase of the TPA tariffs, as well as the implementation of an  economically rational policy on renewable.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Whereby the focus must be on more mature technologies and not on less mature technologies such as the solar  ones, where the European targets need not to be exceeded on renewables and where the proceeds from the CO2  rights auctions are to be fully used to finance the deployment of renewables. texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Thank you, Andrea, and good morning, everyone. Now, let's turn to our operations in Spain and Portugal. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Revenues for Spain and Portugal total €17.74 billion, an 8% increase when compared to the first nine months of  2010. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Regarding the liberalized business, higher production, higher sales to final customers were offset by the increase  in variable costs. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: As I mentioned, these results were affected by normalization in liberalized margins. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now move on to Latin America. I will now review the main factors driving Latin America results in the first  nine months of 2011. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Chile, output declined by 6% to 14.5 terawatt hours due to the severe drought. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Additionally, dollarization of generation businesses resulted in a negative FX impact of €35 million. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Results in Peru were driven once again by higher activity and lower fixed costs. texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Argentina showed a strong increase in generation output of 5% to 12.5 terawatt hour. texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA

The third  placement was for an amount of €77 million of which Endesa will receive €34 million next November 12; while the  fourth one, for an amount of €112 million, of which Endesa will receive €44 million next November 19.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: The measures announced would have an annual direct negative economic impact on Endesa of approximately  €800 million prior to any potential recoveries through market prices. Overall, the measures announced do not  properly address the actual main cause of the tariff deficit. That is the level of subsidies to certain forms of the  renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Concerning conventional generation, overall, the announced measures would worsen the economic situation of  the ordinary regime, which is already critical due to weak demand, price distortion caused by the renewable  generation and low load factors. Furthermore, the announced measures would have, when added to the measures  put in place early this year and sustainable impact on the remuneration level of non-mainland generation, which  is regulated and, in principle, should not be affected by extra regulatory costs.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: The same principle should hold for domestic coal generation. Concerning coal generation in general, the  announced measures would also make the situation even more critical in view of the very sizable investments that  ought to be necessary to keep them operating according to the new European Industrial Emission Directive. The  announced measures would worsen the situation of hydro and nuclear power plants which today do not recover  on the market their full costs. The measure decided and announced will seriously hit the utility sector, one of the  few vital ones in Spain, and would generate risks for investments, employment and service quality level.  Let's now move to the next chart. We fully share the commitment of the government to solve the tariff deficit  issue, as we already said. However, we're technically in disagreement with a number of measures. On this chart,  you can see a number of possible improvements to the announced measures according to our opinion. First of all,  as I said, non-mainland and domestic coal generation have their returns for income established by regulatory  schemes. Therefore, it should be made clear that the new taxes ought to be considered as allowable variable  generation costs and as such ought to be, among other things, included in the costs taken into account when  calculating regulatory income or return.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Announced tax measures not being of a structural nature should be considered as temporary, that is not  permanent as temporary measures in order to help under the present critical circumstances restore the proper  financial balance between regulated costs and revenues. It should be clarified that amounts collected through the  announced measures, although fiscal in nature, will be 100% used to offset tariff deficit. In order not to cause  unjustified distortions to international electricity exchanges, new taxes should be applied also to electricity  imports and not applied to electricity exports. In order to address the fundamental causes of the tariff deficit taxes  on hydro and nuclear generation should be reduced while increasing the impact on solar technology.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now move to the regulation update in Latin America starting with Brazil. texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: And moving now to Chile, the President of Chile has sent to the parliament two bills regarding the electricity – the  Electrical Highway, so-called, and the interconnection of the SIC and the SING grids. texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: And finally regarding Argentina, in August, the government announced the intention to develop and implement a  new regulatory model. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now review the results in Latin America during the last nine months of the year. The main factors driving  results in Latin America were the resilience in the region to the current global economic crisis. In this context,  electricity sales and distribution grew by 4.6% on average. It's important to mention that all of our subsidiaries in  Latin America showed an increase in sales. Generation output increased by 5% when compared to the same period  of 2011, basically explained by the better hydro conditions registered in Brazil and Colombia.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Chile, despite its light recovery in hydro levels in cumulative terms, the country has suffered its third  consecutive year of drought. During the third quarter, the Brazilian government announced a new regulatory  scheme that is not expected to impact significantly on Endesa's assets in this country. Finally, Argentina results  are getting worse from both distribution and generation businesses as a consequence of the unsustainable  conditions in the country.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving to the results in Chile, during the first nine months generation output increased by 5%. Despite the  drought still affected the country, hydro output increased by 0.9 terawatt hour or an increase of 12%. The higher  hydro production more than offset lower thermal generation output many due to less dispatch from combined  cycle gas turbines. Distribution sales rose 5% to 10.8 terawatt hours, supported by the strong demand registered  in the Chile concession area. Generation EBITDA decreased by 35% to €307 million, explained by both  operational and one-off effects.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: During the first nine months, the low hydro combined with higher fuel and energy purchase cost had a negative  impact of roughly €80 million. Operating effects during the period were mainly the lower selling prices partially  explained by the expiration of risk clauses in the contracts that allowed a pass-through of higher marginal costs.  These represent a negative impact of €36 million.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Let's now move to Brazil. Generation volumes rose sharply by 48% to 3.5 terawatt hours, thanks to higher rainfall,  which boosted Cachoeira's production, higher thermal dispatch in Fortaleza. Distribution sales grew by 7% to 15.2  terawatt hour mainly due to an 11% increase in Coelce boosted by strong demand, weather condition and  increased client base.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Moving on to Peru, energy output decreased by 4% reaching 6.9 terawatt hours, explained by the scheduled  maintenance outage of the thermal plants in Edegel and Piura. Distribution sales went up by 5% to 5.1 terawatt  hours. Thanks to strong economic growth. Generation EBITDA increased by 1% to €187 million mainly due to  higher energy sales prices and capacity payments, which was partially offset by lower gas sales in Piura.  Generation unitary margin increased by 12% to €29.4 per megawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Paolo Bondi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Endesa SA
texts.text: Finally, let's take a look at Argentina. Generation business experienced a 6% reduction energy output due to the  lower dispatch from thermal facilities, as well as planned outage in combined cycles. The slowdown in the  Argentinean economy is reflected in a lower energy demand growth. These translated into sales increase of only  2% to 13.3 terawatt hours, the lowest growth in the region.

texts.speaker: Andrea Brentán
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Endesa SA
texts.text: In Latin America, we have obtained solid operating results improving with respect to 2011 and despite the  unfavorable hydro conditions in Chile and the still pending new regulation in Argentina. Finally, I would like to  remark the progress in the proposed transaction to consolidate the Group investment platform in South America  and its capability to capture the growth potential opportunities there. And this concludes our third quarter results  presentation. Thank you very much for listening.  Unverified Participant
